                                 Books by the Author
1. 3D Unconditional Security—graphical overview of principle perspectives regarding unconditional security.
2. 4D Forgiveness—examines four levels of biblical forgiveness and explains how it is possible for God to
    forgive and forget our sin in one stratum while not forgiving or forgetting our sin in another stratum.
3. Breaking the Rocking Horse—introductory book regarding the distinction between having eternal life as a
    gift versus obtaining it as a reward in relation to the outer darkness and the parable of the soils.
4. Carnal Corinth—an affirmation of the categorical existence of carnal Corinthian Christians.
5. Destined for Salvation—evaluates five major models for interpreting 1Thess 5:9-10 and takes the passage
    as promising an unconditional rapture (and thus unconditional security) to all believers in Christ, even to
    those who are morally asleep. However, an incentive for being morally awake is provided by making
    salvation (in the form of millennial and eternal rulership) contingent upon being morally alert.
6. Fallen from Grace but Not from Perfection—an advanced defense of unconditional security which affirms
    that believers can fall from grace but not fall from perfection.
7. Is God a Communist?—by comparing Paul’s teaching of the workmen with Jesus’ parable of the laborers,
    this book refutes communistic views of Heaven which think that Jesus is building heavenly mansions in
    New Jerusalem for all believers regardless of the way they live.
8. John in Living Color—a color-coded translation and reference manual of the Gospel of John that focuses
    on the grammatical and aspectual indications of unconditional security.
9. Like a Tree Planted by the Water—expounds upon the OT background for the outer darkness by examining
    the precursor texts in Psalms, especially Ps 1-2.
10. Logic Tables and Diagrams—illustrations of logic with scriptural implications pertaining primarily to the
    soteriological and misthological arenas.
11. Mere Christianity and Moral Christianity—a more comprehensive discussion regarding perseverance (and
    other performance-related themes) as being needed for rewards in Heaven rather than for entrance into
    Heaven. This book provides both introductory material and advanced treatments.
12. Monogamous Sex in Heaven!—at the same time in which the present author was reading books by Marrow
    and Kreeft posing that sexual intimacy continues in Heaven, he discovered that his wife had stage-3 breast
    cancer. As a therapy to help him deal with this news, he poured himself into research to see if Marrow and
    Kreeft might be correct, thereby enabling him to believe that no matter what happened, the best was yet to
    come. This is the conclusion and comfort of this book.
13. New Birth by the Sovereign Wind—refutes the Calvinistic interpretation of Jn 3:16 that limits God’s love
    to the elect. An excursus deals with the Calvinistic claim from Jn 3:3 that one must be born again before
    one can see (i.e., believe) the gospel. An additional excursus entertains a possible duality to what it means
    to see the kingdom.
14. Predestination and the Open View—a discussion of predestination that focuses on free will and the book
    of life from an open view.
15. Rewards are Eternal—is a defense of the eternal nature of biblical rewards against the proposition that
    Rev 22:5 indicates that all believers will rule in the eternal state and against the premise that Rev 21:4
    proves that misthological death will no longer exist in the eternal state.
16. Sealed and Secure—a thorough defense of a popular argument for unconditional security that also defends
    the premise of unconditional promises.
17. The Race of Grace—introductory book in which performance-related themes (such as perseverance) are
    considered essential for rewards in Heaven. Entrance into Heaven, in contrast, is regarded as free. A strong
    defense of unconditional security derived from believers being given to Jesus is a strength of this book.
18. The Outer Darkness—a magnum opus that ties together the author’s arguments for unconditional security
    and conditional rewards.
19. Trichotomy—an advanced holistic dichotomous discussion of trichotomy with an integration of nikology.
20. Woolly Wolves and Woolless Sheep—a rejection of the notion that profession of salvation is proven genuine
    by the way a person lives. This book focuses on the parable of the sheep and the goats and shows the
    inadequacy of conditional security in interpreting this parable.
                      For books by the author, see http://misthology.org/?page_id=35.
                        For additional material, see www.UnconditionalSecurity.org.

                                 Chapter 1.
                    Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven
                                                   Introduction
       My propensity is to be very skeptical as to the reliability of extrabiblical experiences of Heaven, such as
NDEs (near death experiences), visions, and dreams. Nevertheless, since this series has entertained some highly
conjectural possibilities regarding Heaven and has provided limited interaction with some experiences of
Heaven or Hell claimed by various people, further interaction may be advisable to balance some of the
discussion and theoretical possibilities. Plus, during my writing of this series, I continued to experience various
synchronicity events. This topic is no exception. As I began writing this section, I had just finished reading a
book by Buck Stephens, in which he relates some information based on his NDE and dreams of Heaven. I was
reading his book with my usual, highly skeptical vantage point regarding NDE and dreams. In fact, before
reading his book, I purposefully read several books recommending a very cautious approach toward embracing
NDE as a creditable source of information. So, after first having reinforced my negative outlook, or shall we
say my cautious approach, I finally turned to books purporting such experiences of Heaven and read Stephens’s
book. He claims to have had a NDE and uses that NDE and dreams of Heaven to justify some of the conclusions
in his book. As it turns out, at the same time, I had just received my copy of Bill Salus’ new book, Nuclear
Showdown in Iran, dealing with prophecies regarding Elam. There was no way I was going to wait and read
Salus’ book until after I had finished suffering through a NDE-dream-vision book. Thus, I was reading both
books concurrently, during the same two-week period. I have enjoyed the scholarship and exegesis of Salus’
earlier books. I was certain that his new book would be an equal treat.
                                                   Bema Book
Dream
       On the very first page of his introduction, Salus relates, “Have you heard that miracles, visions and
dreams are occurring with regularity, causing throngs of Iranians to convert to Christianity? From
approximately 500 believers in 1979, to several million today, Iran is the fastest growing evangelical population
in the world.”1 Okay, I had heard about that phenomenon and was willing to grant the credibility of those
dreams. I will take it at face value that Muslims are encountering Christ in their dreams and converting to
Christianity in large numbers. At the time, it did not occur to me that I might not be entirely consistent in readily
dismissing other dreams. As a case in point, that very week, about half way through Salus’ book, I had a dream
in which I went to Heaven. My having a dream in which I meet Jesus or go to Heaven is extremely rare. But I
have dreams practically every night; almost none of them are worth mentioning. So, when I have positive
dreams about Jesus or Heaven, I just take them in stride with my normal dreams, giving them no further thought.
Plus, I take melatonin to help me sleep, and it seems to increase the frequency of strange dreams. Because I
tend to dismiss the relevance of dreams, I thought nothing of having a dream of going to Heaven, even though
as part of my research I was going to read several books describing the experiences of others going to Heaven.
       But I had never had a dream like this one. In this dream, when I got to Heaven, I sought out and found
what was known in my dream as the Bema Book.2 In my dream, I was more interested in that Bema Book than
in Heaven itself. Given my interest in the Bema, that aspect of my dream was not entirely surprising. If I actually
were to go to Heaven, the Bema Book, if there were such a thing, would be among my chief interests. I would
want to know how I was going to do at the Bema. From my perspective, getting into Heaven is a done deal. I
have believed in Jesus Christ for eternal life as a free gift, so I know I am going to Heaven. Case closed. What
I now want to know is, “How well will I do at the Bema?” Thus, I am much more interested in how I am going

1
  Bill Salus, Nuclear Showdown in Iran: Revealing the Ancient Prophecy of Elam (La Quinta, CA: Prophecy
Depot Ministries, 2014), vii.
2
  Bema is the transliteration of the Greek word for judgment and is used to refer to the Judgment Seat of Christ.
All believers will appear before Christ to be judged for their works, that is, the way they have lived. The outcome
of the judgment determines whether they qualify for positions of rulership in Heaven. Entrance into Heaven is
not in view since that is a free gift given to those who simply believe exclusively in Christ for eternal life as a
free gift.
Page 2                                                                                Misthological Models Part 4
to do at the Bema than in Heaven itself. Therefore, upon awakening, I rationalized the dream as merely the
product of my subconscious interests. Nevertheless, something in my dream surprised me, as it did not seem to
make any sense. During the dream, when I opened the book and found my name, I could clearly read the entire
entry under my name. The entry simply read: Marty, stop reading, now.
        The Bema Book knew that I was reading it, and it told me to stop reading it! In my dream, I was so
shocked by that admonition that I felt like a child caught with his hand in the cookie jar, who did not know that
there was anything wrong with putting his hand in the cookie jar to get the cookie until he was caught in the act
and told to stop it. Why did the book not want me to read it? Despite my bewilderment, I immediately closed
the book and woke up. “Strange dream,” I thought. Additionally, when I awoke, I remembered having the
distinct recollection from my dream that I intended to look up Scott Crawford’s name in the Bema Book next.
After I first found out what the Bema Book had to say under my name, I unmistakably had planned on seeing
what it would have under Scott’s name also. That plan was cut short, shockingly, by the book telling me to stop
reading immediately.
        This was the first time that I had dreamed about Scott. However, I pray for him and his family each
morning, praying that they will do well at the Bema. Plus, he and I focus our studies and discussions on the
Bema. Hence, when I woke up, I rationalized that such a dream was certainly not out of place, albeit very
strange. I simply disregarded the dream as highly irregular, yet not totally unexplainable. Then Sunday came.
        Scott is our Sunday School teacher, and our Sunday School lesson that Sunday focused on the following
passage: “An argument arose among them as to which of them was the greatest. But Jesus, knowing the
reasoning of their hearts, took a child and put him by his side and said to them, ‘Whoever receives this child in
my name receives me, and whoever receives me receives him who sent me. For he who is least among you all
is the one who is great’ (Lk 9:46-48). This is the very passage I first thought of when I had awoken from my
dream! Nevertheless, although Scott was teaching the lesson on that very passage, I did not even think of my
dream when we were studying this passage, even though it was just a few days earlier, since I completely had
dismissed any possible connection between this passage and my dream when I initially had the dream. A desire
to be greater than Scott was not my objective. Accordingly, as soon as I woke from my dream, my rationale
was, “Why presume any association between the passage and the dream since it does not genuinely reflect my
desire?” With such thoughts over the course of a few days, I had been successful in dismissing the dream from
any further consideration. Notwithstanding, during that same Sunday School lesson, we also discussed the
related passage in Mk 10:35-45, where James and John, two of Jesus’ top disciples, asked Him to allow them
to sit on His right and on His left in His coming kingdom, which would be the highest places of honor. Jesus
responded, “To sit on My right or on My left, this is not Mine to give; but it is for those for whom it has been
prepared.” That passage also crossed my mind after my dream, but I did not see the connection and had managed
to disregard it as being irrelevant, so that this passage did not cause me to think of the dream either. Thus,
despite the facts that (1) the only other person in my dream was (2) teaching about the very subject matter of
my dream and was (3) using the very passages that I immediately thought of when I awoke from my dream, I
did not perceive any connection with the dream that Sunday morning and did not recall the dream.
        Then, two days later I reached the last chapter of Salus’ book. Therein, he stated his conviction that the
dreams and visions promised in the latter days by the Lord in Joel 2:28-29 are finding fulfillment in what is
currently happening: “This is exactly what’s happening throughout various parts of the world presently. It is a
burgeoning phenomenon in persecuted areas such as Iran. Both male and female believers are receiving an
outpouring of the Holy Spirit. These Christian men and women are also experiencing dreams and visions.”3 I
was open to that as being a valid possibility. After all, I would grant a 70% probability that we are living in the
very last of the last days, so there was no need for me to be skeptical about the legitimacy of the Muslim
conversions occurring through dreams and visions. At the same time, with my typical skepticism, I was reading
Stephens’ book, and Stephens was using this text to justify he and his wife having prophetic dreams:

                These experiences are happening more and more throughout the Body of Christ and are of
         the type prophesied in the Book of Joel. In that prophecy, we are told that in the “last days” dreams
         and visions would become part of the activity of the Holy Spirit within the Church. I was very
         skeptical of this type of thing until I encountered the glory of the Lord in that “near-death
         experience” and that glory began to manifest in dreams and visions in my own life. I was the most
3
    Ibid., 183.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                              Page 3
      surprised person of all when the Lord began to reveal things to me I could not know any other way
      and then watched them manifest so accurately.4

      Even though I was reading this claim by Stephens in the same time frame that I was reading the statement
by Salus, I was only open to the probability of the type of dreams being shared by Salus as being prophetic
dreams. I did not spot any disconnect in my attitude towards to the two sets of dreams. Then I reached the
following statement by Salus:

             Everybody dreams an occasional dream, but not everyone seems very adept at deciphering
      its potential spiritual significance. In December, 2012, I dreamt that I was being Raptured into the
      clouds above my house. Does that mean my generation will be raptured? I hope so, but I am still
      taking daily walks in an attempt to live as long as possible. However, dreams are leading many
      Iranians to Christ. Converting to Christ through a dream is a big commitment, considering most
      Iranians have been brought up under the strong influence of Islam. Yet testimonies like this are
      continually coming out of Iran.5

       Salus relates his own dream and draws a possible connection! Poor enough water on a duck’s back and
perhaps even a duck will take notice. I was the duck. At this point, I now spotted my inconsistency. If Salus
was willing to allow the possibility that his own dream had eschatological significance, then I should not limit
theologically significant dreams to the soteriological dreams being experienced by Muslims.6 Duh! It took a
while, but I finally got the point. At least the Lord did not have to give me a NDE, like He did Stephens, to get
the point across: just two independent books on theological dreams being read at the same time, a theological
dream, two passages of Scripture related to the dream, a friend in the dream (about whom I had never dreamed
before) teaching the same subject matter as the dream, the very next Sunday, using the same Scriptures that I
was trying to process after the dream. At this point, even I could see a plausible connection.
       Salus’ whole section in this regard is a worthy read. He attributes part of the Iranian openness to dreams
to their being a “very emotional people” (emphasis his).7 Interestingly enough, Stephens takes pains to explain
the role of emotions in a related capacity. Is it just a coincidence that I was reading both books at the same time?
I would have assumed it was just coincidental, and therefore incidental, if the Lord had not hit me with a number
of confirming events at the same time. Ironically, my preference for logic over emotion might explain, to some
degree, why I was being so illogical in my rejection of Stephen’s appeal to emotion. I prefer to have a biblical
text where I can pull out my Hebrew or Greek lexicons and apply logical rules of interpretation to perform my
exegesis. Never mind that some of that biblical texts provide dreams, visions, and emotions! However, once I
spotted my inconsistency, in that I was allowing the plausibility of theological dreams on the part of unbelievers
but disallowing them on the part of believers, I perceived that it would be more consistent to follow Salus’
example and at least be open to the possibility of prophetic dreams on the part of believers.
       The biblical text anticipates such theologically significant dreams, and the Iranians are experiencing
them. At this point, the pieces immediately came together. The Lord had used my concurrently reading two
books about two different subject matters that approached the issue of theological dreams from two different
directions, in conjunction with my own dream and collaborating Scriptures from a Sunday School class during
the midst of that same period of time, being taught by the only other person who was the subject of my dream,

  The reader is already familiar with the word theology, which is based on a combination of two biblical Greek
words: theos (God) and logos (teaching). Thus, theology refers to biblical teaching about God. In similar
fashion, soteriology is based on two biblical Greek words, soteria (salvation) and logos (teaching), and
correspondingly refers to biblical teaching about salvation. Although the biblical concept of salvation includes
many dimensions other than deliverance from Hell, it is this aspect of salvation to which writers refer frequently
when they use the word soteriology. Thus, salvation from Hell (or more specifically, from eternal damnation in
the Lake of Fire) will be referred to as soteriological salvation. A soteriological interpretation of a passage thus
would treat the passage as dealing with eternal salvation from the Lake of Fire (Rev 20:14-15).

  Ibid., 187.

to open my eyes to the intersection. The opening of my eyes was not a blinding vision, to be sure, but to someone
who is mathematically oriented, the probability that all these convergences was nothing more than mere
coincidence was completely unreasonable. As an added bonus, as soon as I was open to the possibility that I
might have had a prophetic dream, I was easily able to exegete my dream.
        As believers, if we are being faithful, then we certainly can anticipate a favorable outcome at the Bema.8
Like Paul, we can know, for example, that we will receive the crown of righteousness (2Tim 4:7-8). On the
other hand, we cannot know how well we will do compared to other believers who apparently are being equally
faithful. As a case in point, before the Bema occurred, Andrew and John could not know the specifics of what
positions they would receive relative to other faithful believers because such positions will be given, at the time
of the Bema, to those believers for whom such positions have been prepared, in accordance with their
preparation for the Bema. In other words, like Andrew and John, I cannot know now, before the Bema, how
Scott and I will do at the Bema in comparison to other faithful believers. Scott and I cannot derive that degree
of specificity regarding the Bema outcome until the Bema takes place. The best we can do for now, in order to
maximize a positive Bema outcome, is to overcome and serve. Just as believers cannot know the day or hour
of the rapture, overcomers cannot know how they will stack up against one another at the Bema. For now, the
only thing overcomers prudently can do is to serve one another, not to compare themselves to one another.
        Amazingly, I could not put my finger on the meaning of the dream, even though that theological
conclusion is what I already believed, until I was first open to the possibility that the dream was intended to
have theological meaning. Sometimes faith precedes sight. On those occasions, you have to believe in order to
understand. I first had to believe that my dream might have theological significance before I could understand
the theological significance of my dream. At last I was able to exegete my dream. I could now vividly see, on
the pages of that Bema Book via my dream, what the extrapolation of my theological beliefs looked like in that
regard.
        The next day, during lunch on 7-24-2014, my mind wandered back to my previous theological dreams
that I had ignored over the years. I could not remember any details, just that a few times I had met Jesus or been
to Heaven and once that I visited Hell as an observer and witnessed the sufferings of unbelievers. But I had not
dwelt on the details of any such dreams at the time, inasmuch as they were just dreams, and I did not attribute
any significance to them as such. So I could not remember any details. Then, as I mused over my disappointing
lack of recall during lunch, I faintly recalled that sometime within the past couple of years or so, I had dreamed
that Jesus came to my bed and touched my left knee and healed it. Unfortunately, I do not recall the time frame
well enough to know if it was before or after I hurt my knee the second time.
        Many years ago I tore my ACL playing basketball and had surgery. Then, about a year and a half ago, I
had hurt my knee again playing church basketball. The doctor told me that my ACL was still intact this time,
so no surgery would be necessary. But I was unable to jog for months. Eventually, my knee got better, and the
pain gradually went away altogether as I resumed jogging. However, after having returned to jogging five miles
a day, and sometimes even doing an occasional eight miles, I read that high intensity interval training was better
than extended jogging. So I gave up long distance jogging. The strength in my legs increased steadily. I had
been lifting weights all along, but to my surprise, the jogging had not substantially increased my leg strength.
Initially, I only press 180 pounds on the leg press machine. But about nine months later, after transitioning away
from long distant jogging, when someone asked me how my workout went that morning, I said that it went
great because I finally had maxed out the leg press machine, pressing all of its 495 pounds for the first time!
So, as it just so happened, on the very morning that I maxed out the leg press machine, I recalled during lunch,
a few hours later, that I had dreamed sometime previously that Jesus had touched my knee and healed it. Now
perhaps my remembering that dream about my knee on the very day that I maxed out the leg press was merely
coincidental. But when I factor in that the only reason I remembered that dream about Jesus healing my knee
was because of another unusual series of events that had just led me to be open to the possibility that such
dreams might have significance, I had to conclude that the dream about my leg might have had some
significance.
        At the same time, during that lunch the thought also occurred to me that I might prematurely have
dismissed the possibility of some type of Bema Book. Even after coming to conclude that the dream about a
Bema Book might have theological meaning, I had dismissed the probability of such a book actually existing. I

assumed that the book was a nonliteral image that the Lord may have used to trigger my thinking. However, if
the Lord is preparing places for us in the Father’s house, as He has promised in Scripture, then logically He
would need to know where to make that place and what kind of place to make. In other words, the preparation
of such places for us would have to anticipate how well we are going to do at the Bema. Subcomers would not
have a place prepared for them in New Jerusalem. Overcomers would have to have their places prepared for
them in the Heavenly City, in accordance with how well they will do at the Bema. In other words, not only must
there be Books of Works, as described in the Scripture, but there must be something akin to a Bema Book. Those
heavenly agents currently preparing our mansions under the Lord’s direction must know the kind, size, and
location of our particular mansion. If some mansions are bigger, better, and closer to the Lord than others, and
surely they are, then the necessary information must be provided to those doing the construction as to what and
where they need to construct each individual mansion. Per Jesus, we know that our mansions are not being built
willy-nilly. Not even Jesus could give positions on His left and right without consideration of the preplanned
preparation. I postulate, therefore, that some type of Bema Book actually must exist, which already accurately
records the results of the Bema in advance so that those working on the mansions may be supplied directions
as to what to build and where. Further, I would theorize that not everyone has access to that book. Access to
the Bema Book is on a need-to-know basis. In my dream, I did not have access to the book in that I could not
read the misthological information that would be recorded under my own name, much less someone else’s
name.9 I do not believe that Satan and his fallen forces have access to the Bema Book either. Nor do I see any
reason to think that every angel has access to it, much less all of it. Limited access to the Bema Book still makes
it somewhat of a guessing game, even for those doing the building, as to when the Lord will return for His Bride
via the rapture. For example, if the Father is the only one who has unlimited access to the entire Bema Book,
then only He will know when sufficient building has been done for the Son to come fetch His Bride. Perhaps,
the Father gives Jesus the directions as to what needs to be built where for whom, and Jesus, in turn, passes
along this information to those actually doing the building. At least, as a practical necessity, something along
this line seems to be feasible as a working theory.
        At the very least, the Lord apparently used that dream to stimulate my thinking (so that I came to
conclusions that I should have reached anyway from my study of Scripture) and to open me up to the possibility
that He may be using dreams, even today, in capacities beyond the humble scope of my dream of the Bema
Book. The next day, when I did a Google search on Muslim Christian dreams, I got 7,790,000 hits.10 To be sure,
the phenomenon has its critics. For example, one such on-line critic charges that the gospel-by-dream approach
wrongly presents a minimalistic gospel as sufficient for salvation, leaving out repentance, for instance. Yet, for
theological reasons, many of us in FG theology have concluded years ago that a minimalistic gospel, while not
the most desirable form of gospel presentation, is sufficient for regeneration, as long as one believes in Christ
alone for eternal life as a free gift. Repentance, though important for other things, such as rewards within
Heaven, is not a theological requirement for entrance into Heaven.
Phone Call
       On the morning of 8-23-2014, another amazing example of synchronicity occurred in the form of a
telephone call from Scott Crawford. This call was after I already had added the above material about the Bema
Book in the present series. Not until later that morning, after I went back and read this Bema Book material, did
I realize that the occurrence of this telephone call was exactly one month after my Bema Book dream, which
had occurred on 7-23-2014.
       As I was having my prayer time on the morning of 8-23-2014, Scott called and asked if I thought there
was any possibility that our names literally were recorded in some book in Heaven in relation to how well we
will do at the Bema! I had not told him about my Bema Book dream, which occurred exactly one month before.
Nor had I told him about my Bema Book theory. Plus, I had just emailed him the rough draft of this series the

                                               Reading Journal
       Notwithstanding my own interesting turn of events that led me to at least have an open mind regarding
this type of material, I wanted to proceed with caution and start off with some cautionary reading material.
Since I basically had ignored this extrabiblical genre regarding dreams and visions of Heaven for years, I
decided to research this area. So I procured some classics in this area, read some recommendations by friends,
and consulted www.christianbooks.com to get some of the current literature being published in this arena. A
reading journal with brief interaction with each book is the format I will use for the summation herein.
Brain Tubbs
      I had seen the movie, Heaven is for Real, in which a young boy by the name of Colton purportedly went
11
   During the call, I told Scott to read my second chapter in Part 2 of this series regarding eternal rewards
because I already had created illustrations of this very possibility therein. In that discussion, I had argued that

I certainly would list this verse in both capacities in the present series. However, not until his phone call did it

stand firm in the Lord in Phil 4:1. An exclusively soteric citizenship makes little sense as grounds for appealing
for moral performance in a context of misthological destruction. The telic (telos) destruction of these particular
heavenly citizens gives grounds for concluding that their names will be erased from the heavenly registry. They
will reap misthological destruction (lose misthological life) rather than gain misthological life. Citizenship

many other commentators, believes that Paul is describing the Lord as coming from this city. (Govett, Romans,
472.) In Phil 1:27 and 3:20 respectively, Paul exhorts us to act as members of this heavenly city (politeuo) in
view of our membership in that city (politeuma). This city is the literal city of New Jerusalem. In terms of
contingency and unrealized potentiality, their names can be erased from the heavenly registry, thereby
excluding them from residency in the Heavenly City. The names of those whose names will remain in the
heavenly registry are the “church of the firstborn who are registered in heaven” (Heb 12:23; NKJ).
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                             Page 7
to Heaven. Given my skeptical nature of NDE as being a reliable source of information regarding Heaven, one
of the first books I purchased was a critical analysis by Brian Tubbs of the book, Heaven is for Real. Like
Tubbs, I was open minded enough already to have a positive outlook as to the plausibility of OBEs (out of body
experiences):

         Many of the OBEs contain verifiable sightings - things the person “saw” (which were later verified
         by third parties). In young Colton's case, for instance, he says he saw his Mom on the phone in the
         waiting room and his Dad in another room, praying to God. And he saw this - while sedated and
         in surgery! There are many OBEs characterized by similar verifiable observations. These types of
         OBEs are what some experts on the topic refer to as “evidential out-of-body experiences.” When
         we’re talking about evidential OBEs, we're not talking about mere claims. We’re talking about
         proven claims - at least in terms of what the person saw. An intelligent person, with at least the
         semblance of an open mind, cannot ignore such evidence.12

       True, but being out of body and looking around one’s body in a hospital room is one thing. Taking a trip
all the way to Heaven is quite another. A legitimate OBE is insufficient grounds for a trustworthy NDE of
Heaven. Tubbs evidences reasonable caution regarding NDE claims. For example, Tubbs finds Colton’s
recognition of what Jesus looks like from the painting Akiane Prince of Peace. A quick Google will bring up
that image.

       Is that really what Jesus looks like? Tubbs finds the possibility intriguing but cautions: “Given the Second
Commandment's prohibition against ‘graven images,’ I don’t know that trying to figure out what Jesus actually
looks like is where we’re supposed to be focusing our time and energy.”13 Fair enough. And Tubbs is able to
be cautionary without questioning Colton’s integrity. One scenario that Tubbs poses is

Colton had visions of the future while in Heaven. He may have seen his father, as an overcomer, coming with
Jesus in the clouds to fight in that battle, which is a plausible scenario (Rev 19:14). Or Colton may have had a
dream of the future after his NDE. Some of those who have had NDEs seem to have a greater propensity to
prophetic dreams subsequently. So I would not discount the possibility that Colton saw a prophetic dream or
vision. All in all, Tubb’s assessment is positive, yet reasonably cautious.
John Ankerberg
       Although Ankerberg and Weldon’s book had a negative rating on Amazon because of its cautious
approach toward NDEs, this is the very reason I ordered the book.16 I wanted a book that would explore the
cons of the phenomena. I already was aware of some of the drawbacks in giving credibility to NDEs, so this
type of book is precisely where I wanted to begin my research. These authors rightly criticize the common NDE
claim that a baby’s soul does not enter its body until the time of birth and that the baby’s soul is not present
during abortion and that the baby does not experience pain during abortion. NDErs also tend to dismiss the
importance of sound doctrine in the name of a nebulous love. However, the Bible says, “Let love be without
hypocrisy. Hate what is evil; cling to what is good” (Rom 12:9; TM). Biblical love is not incompatible with
biblical hatred. We are supposed to hate evil doctrine. Biblical love “does not rejoice in unrighteousness, but
rejoices with the truth” (1Cor 13:6). Jesus commends a church for their love and works but criticizes them
because of their tolerance of evil doctrine (Rev 2:19-20). A believer’s misthological salvation is conditioned on
perseverance in sound doctrine: “Pay close attention to yourself and to your doctrine; persevere in these things;
for as you do this you will insure salvation both for yourself and for those who hear you” (1Tim 4:16; TM).
Therefore, Ankerberg and Weldon appropriately caution against giving credibility to the typical NDErs’
dismissal of sound doctrine. Additionally, NDErs frequently abandon Christianity for some form of New Age
Gnosticism. Reincarnation replaces the need for regeneration. Hell is replaced with universalism. The loving
God of the Bible, who lovingly provides atonement for sin to escape judgment, is replaced by a divine light
denying such biblical realities so that morality is no longer of eternal consequence. On the other hand, biblical
near-death experiences (BNDEs) can bring unbelievers to Christ and believers closer to Christ. Consequently,
one must be discerning in distinguishing New Age NDEs from BNDEs, so a book such as this by Ankerberg
and Weldon is well-advised. Unfortunately, one will also need to be discerning in reading this particular book,
though, because it concludes by conditioning salvation from Hell upon one’s repentance and commitment, a
common Lordship fallacy.
Douglas Groothuis
       During their discussion, Ankerberg and Weldon cite Groothuis’ book, Deceived by the Light. He also has
an article available online by that title.17 Groothuis’ material exposes Betty Eadie’s best seller, Embraced by
the Light, as a blend of Mormon and New Age theology posing as a Christian NDE. Many falsehoods are
embraced in her deception, such as: All roads lead to God, so Jesus is not the only way to God. The human soul
is preexisting, so all humans are incarnated, not just Jesus. Repentance is just learning to forgive ourselves.

Obviously, submitting Edie’s NDE claim to biblical analysis would disqualify it from being considered
a reliable source of information as to what happens after one dies. Uncritically accepting such NDE
claims is dangerous and potentially deadly. We will revisit Groothuis’ analysis shortly.18
Raymond Moody
      Raymond Moody’s book, Life after Life, sold millions of copies and was heralded as a scientific
breakthrough in the analysis of NDEs. Except for the suicides, the NDEs tended to be very positive, devoid of
judgment:

             Even those who previously had some traditional conviction about the nature of the afterlife
      world seem to have moved away from it to some degree following their own brushes with death.
      In fact, in all the reports I have gathered, not one person has painted the mythological picture of
      what lies hereafter. No one has described the cartoonist’s heaven of pearly gates, golden streets,
      and winged, harp-playing angels, nor a hell of flames and demons with pitchforks.
             So, in most cases, the reward-punishment model of the afterlife is abandoned and
      disavowed, even by many who had been accustomed to thinking in those terms. They found, much
      to their amazement, that even when their most apparently awful and sinful deeds were made
      manifest before the being of light, the being responded not with anger and rage, but rather
      only with understanding, and even with humor.19

       Could such experiences with a Being of Light (BOL) who finds the most awful sins a person commits to
be humorous be an encounter with a genuinely holy being? Or would they be better explained as encounters
with an angel of light pretending to be a holy angel? After all, Scripture warns us that “even Satan disguises
himself as an angel of light” (2Cor 11:14-15) but instructs us to regard such angels as accursed when they teach
a false gospel: “Even though we, or an angel from heaven, should preach to you a gospel contrary to that which
we have preached to you, let him be accursed” (Gal 1:8). Moody attempts to dismiss the latter possibility with
the following rationale:

      It seems to me that the best way of distinguishing between God-directed and Satan-directed
      experiences would be to see what the person involved does and says after his experience. God, I
      suppose, would try to get those to whom he appears to be loving and forgiving. Satan would
      presumably tell his servants to follow a course of hate and destruction. Manifestly, my subjects
      have come back with a renewed commitment to follow the former course and to disavow the latter.
      In the light of all the machinations which a hypothetical demon would have to have carried out in
      order to delude his hapless victim (and to what purpose?), he certainly has failed miserably—as
      far as I can tell—to make persuasive emissaries for his program! (KL 1901-1906)

      Moody’s response is poorly reasoned. If the goal of satanic emissaries is to impersonate holy angels of

God by appearing as angels of light, then they are not going to promote a blatant gospel of darkness. They
would cloak their false gospel in light as well. A gospel of love and acceptance would do very nicely. Contrary
to Moody, such demonic entities are not failing miserably when they lead people away from the Christian gospel
to another gospel. Rather, they have succeeded brilliantly—so much so as to fool Moody completely. If the
promotion of good behavior leads to false belief, then the deception has been very effective.
Bill Myers & Dave Wimbish
      In their chapter, “Near-Death Experiences,” Myers and Wimbish offset the positive NDEs documented
by Raymond Moody’s book, Life After Life, with the more balanced Christian perspective by Maurice
Rawlings’ book, Beyond Death’s Door. From the documentation provided in the latter book, they point out:

            The doctor worked feverishly to save the man’s life— and succeeded. As a cardiologist he’s
      accustomed to life-or-death situations. But he couldn’t get this frightening experience out of his
      mind. That’s why, a few days later, when the patient was stabilized, the doctor asked him why he
      had been so frightened. Had he seen flames or monsters? Perhaps even the devil himself?
            But surprisingly enough the man didn’t know what his doctor was talking about. He didn’t
      remember a thing.20

       Accordingly, from this and other examples, Myers and Wimbish posit the possibility that “people who
are given a glimpse of hell are so shocked and stunned by the sight of something they never believed in—nor
thought would ever happen to them—that their minds simply can’t retain it.”21 Typically, suicide victims have
hellish experiences. Nevertheless, Myers appropriately caution: “Do I mean to suggest that all suicide victims
go to hell? Of course not. God alone is the judge of that. But these experiences seem to back up the truth that
suicide is always the worst way out of any problem.”22 And his conclusion is: “There’s no way to know for
sure, this side of heaven, exactly what near-death experiences are.”23
Randy Alcorn
      I was not familiar with the NDE genre back when I read Randy Alcorn’s fictional book, Dominion, so I
was surprised when he fictionally portrayed this NDE scene recounted by Reg Norcoast to Clarence:

             “Clarence, something wonderful happened last night.” Norcoast suddenly sounded
      euphoric. “I was just about to die—in fact I think I may have died, really. I was walking down this
      shinning corridor and there was this magnificent angel of light. It was so beautiful. The angel
      assured me there’s a special place in heaven for me. He said I just needed to get in touch with
      myself, live a good life, and do the best I could to love others. It was so real. I was on the verge
      of heaven, and I didn’t want to come back. But I realize I was sent back for a reason. To tell people
      of God’s love and acceptance.
             Clarence looked at him, slack-jawed. “Reg, I was here last night. I heard you crying out to
      God and screaming and talking about demons attacking you. You felt like you were on fire, then
      you talked about being all alone. You weren’t on the verge of heaven. You were on the verge of
      hell!”
             “What are you talking about?” Norcoast said, “No, you’ve got it all wrong. I remember it
      clearly. A bright angel, a beautiful home, peaceful feelings....I’ve made contact with my angel
      now. Esther says eventually I’ll learn to talk to him and get his guidance.”
             Clarence stared at him, at a complete loss for words. (Italics his.)24

      Given the evidence cited by Rawlings, Myers, and Wimbish, this explanation by Alcorn, as to how some
unbelievers could have positive NDEs, seems highly plausible. I am particularly pleased that Alcorn attributed

Satan. Surely, Satan can counterfeit NDEs.
John Bunyan
       John Bunyan (1628-1688) is the famed author of The Pilgrim’s Progress, who endured twelve years of
imprisonment for his preaching. In Visions of Heaven and Hell, he relates an alleged account of his guardian
angel taking him on a tour of both. Under the influence of an atheistic friend, Bunyan began to doubt the reality
of God, Heaven, and Hell. He went to the woods to kill himself and thus find out the truth about the matter via
suicide. However, his guardian angel intervened by taking him on a trip to Heaven and Hell so that he would
never doubt such realities again. First, the angel takes him to Heaven where Bunyan talks with Elijah. While in
Heaven he observes that some saints shine brighter than others, and he is given this explanation: “Those who
have the most enlarged capacity do love God most, and are thereby changed most into His likeness. This is the
highest glory heaven can give. Nor let this seem strange to you, for even among God’s flaming angels there are
diversities of order and different degrees of glory.”25 The thought that they would express such differences
before the Bema occurred was not something that I previously had considered to any great depth. Yet this
proposition of a pre-Bema misthological distinction in degrees of glory among faithful believers is reasonable.
       Not being a fan of the filled-cup misthology, I demurred when this type of explanation was also given:
“And though the vessels are of several sizes, while each is filled there is none that can complain.”26 On the other
hand, if Bunyan was seeing matters in Heaven as they currently exist, which is pre-Bema perspective, then I
would concur. I would not expect those who are to be cast into the outer darkness after the Bema to be upset
about it beforehand. They will think that the current state of affairs in Heaven will approximate the eternal state
of affairs until they find out differently at the Bema. Then they will weep—after the Bema takes place, not
before. After the Bema, their post-Bema little cup will no longer be full of happiness as it was in their pre-Bema
state. One is left to wonder how many of those who hold to the full-cup misthology may be holding to a
theological perspective that goes back to Bunyan and thus may have failed to consider the possibility that this
alleged full cup, on the part of unfaithful believers, is limited to their contentment before the Bema rather than
afterwards.
       On the other hand, one is justified in questioning the legitimacy of Bunyan’s supposed heavenly vision
altogether. For he claims to have been informed by one of the redeemed in Heaven: “Nor is there male and
female here, but all are like the angels. For souls cannot be distinguished into sexes.”27 That sexless proposition
is questionable in the extreme. Not engaging in sexual relations is one thing; being neutered and losing gender
is quite another.28 Moreover, Bunyan is internally inconsistent. In the very next paragraph Bunyan is informed
that his female guardian will come shortly! He describes her: “I hardly could behold her for the exceeding
brightness of her face.”29 He then continues to relegate what “she said.”30 Immediately, after saying that there

       Allegedly, this sexless-female guardian angel then conducts Bunyan on a tour of Hell. While there,

         them of their foolishness in serving us.”31

       How can Bunyan be so gullible so as to believe a demon who has just told him that it is his business, as
a demon, to deceive those trying to teach others the right road to Heaven, so that they will be led astray in their
doctrine and thereby wind up in Hell instead!?! Yet Bunyan is going to take this demon’s word on what is the
right road to Heaven, even after this demon has just informed him that it is his business, as a demon, to deceive
those seeking the right road to Heaven! Let me give you a hint, Bunyan, if you are going to ask someone for
directions to Heaven, don’t ask a demon! Now, if we are to believe Bunyan and this demon, we are to reject
deathbed conversions as being a possibility, since Bunyan and this demon report:

                Going farther on, I heard a wretch complaining in a heartbreaking strain against those men
         that had betrayed him and brought him here.
                “I was told,” said he, ‘by those that I depended on, and that I thought could inform me
         correctly, that if I said ‘Lord, have mercy on me,’ when I came to die, it would be enough to
         save me. But oh, now I find myself mistaken, to my eternal sorrow! Alas, I called for mercy on
         my deathbed, but found it was too late. Before that time, this cursed devil here told me that I
         was safe. Then on my deathbed, he told me it was too late. Hell must forever be my portion.”
                “You see, I did tell you the truth at last,” said the devil, “and then you would not believe
         me. A very fitting end, don't you think? You spend your days enjoying sin, and wallow in your
         filthiness, and you want to go to heaven when you die! Would anyone but a madman think
         that would be just? No; he that sincerely wants to go to heaven when he dies, must walk in
         the ways of holiness and virtue while he is alive. You say some of your lewd companions told
         you that saying, ‘Lord, have mercy on me’ when you came to die would be enough. A very fine
         excuse! If you had read the Bible you would have known that ‘Without holiness, no one shall
         see the Lord.” Therefore, if you were willing to live in your sins as long as you could, you did
         not finally leave them because you did not like them, but because you could follow them no longer.
         And this you know to be true. How could you be so stupid to think you could go to heaven with
         the love of sin in your heart? No, no, no. You were warned often enough that you should take
         heed of being deceived, for God is not mocked, but what you sow you reap. You have no
         reason to complain of anything but your own folly, which you now see too late.”32

        Bunyan accepts this demon’s explanation as the gospel truth and, in so doing, swallows a false gospel—

that the thief on the cross was saved by calling on the Lord for mercy in his hour of death! In Bunyan’s demonic
soteriology, salvation from Hell is not by grace through faith apart from works but by living a virtuous way of
life. Heaven becomes a reward for being virtuous, a reaping rather than a gift. How can Bunyan and his readers
be so stupid, to use the demon’s term, to think that they could get to Heaven this way? The demon has done his
job well. If Bunyan actually had this vision, as he claims, then he has chosen most unwisely to believe a demon
rather than the Bible.
        Is Bunyan corrected by his guardian angel who is giving him the tour of Hell? Not at all! To the contrary,
this alleged guardian angel seems to be complicit with the demon’s perception:

             “This lecture of the devil was a very cutting one to the poor tormented wretch,” I said to my

      what a far different judgment do they make in this sad place from what they did on earth.” “The
      reason for this,” replied my guardian angel, “is that they will not allow themselves to think what

       Assuming that Bunyan actually had this life-changing vision that he purports to have had, I must conclude
that the whole vision is a fraud because the gospel presented by this vision is fraudulent. The guardian angel is
nothing more than a fallen angel masquerading as an angel of light who gives Bunyan a fake vision so that
Bunyan will become one of the very teachers that he depicts as being tortured for having led many on a false
road to Heaven. Bunyan is a false teacher trying to teach others the right road to Heaven and who yet ends up
giving them a false gospel instead. Such soteriology is not fitting for a pilgrim’s progress to Heaven. It leads to
Hell instead. As a forgery has truth within in it, so this vision might contain elements of truth regarding some
possibilities pertaining to the afterlife. But turning to a forgery to find the truth is a precarious proposition.
Completely discarding this vision as providing any reliable information is the best recourse.
Sadhu Sundar
        Like Bunyan, Sundar (1889-1929) was planning on committing suicide when he received his heavenly
visitation. Surprising to him at the time, the face he said that he saw was that of Christ, not the faces of his
traditional Indian gods. Thus, he became a Christian, who is noted for carrying a NT as his sole possession. He
claims to have frequent, detailed heavenly visions that provide him instruction that he shares in his books.
Reputedly, the loved ones of those who have died previously are sometimes “permitted to attend his deathbed,
and to conduct his soul to the spiritual world.”34 This proposition is problematic because, although Scripture
indicates that we will be like angels in some ways, the time frame is stated to be after the resurrection
(Mt 22:30). Previously, it seems that the dead did not have ready access to the living (Lk 16:24-31). Plus,
adopting such a perspective may encourage grieving ones to long for such a ministry performed by the departed,
opening those in grief up to demonic deception. While these problems might not be considered completely
detrimental to Sundar’s claims, his theology of a second chance nullifies his claims to biblical legitimacy.
        Supposedly, if a man dies, who is not too bad, “he will wander blindly round in the dim light of the lower
parts of the intermediate state, and keep on bumping his philosophical head, until tired of his foolishness, he
repents. Then he will be ready to receive the necessary instruction from the angels appointed for that purpose,
and, when instructed, will he be fit to enter into the fuller light of God in the higher sphere.”35 The impression
conveyed by one of the angels is that the man had not become converted during his lifetime, thus missing the
requirement of Mt 18:3 to enter into the kingdom, so he will have to fumble along in the intermediate state until
he is converted and ready to enter the kingdom. Such soteriology is wholly unsatisfactory. Even so, this accursed
soteriology is repeated:

       Either believe Sundar or the Bible. Don’t pretend that you can believe both! He even holds out hope for
those “far down in the world of spirits in a place of darkness”38 that God might have mercy on them so that they
“understand how to become members of the Kingdom.”39 The bad theology of this book is not limited to
accursed soteriology. Sundar claims: “God neither casts any one into hell, nor will He ever do so, but man
himself, by being entangled in sin, creates hell for himself. God never created any hell.”40 Sundar should have
spent more time with the NT he carried and less time with demons impersonating angels. For the NT affirms
that people are cast into Hell (Mt 5:29; 18:9; Lk 12:5; Rev 20:15), a place “prepared for the devil and his angels”
(Mt 25:41), not created by man. The Bible says that God will separate the sheep from the goats (Mt 25:32-33).
Sundar claims otherwise: “God’s arrangement here is such that goats and sheep, that is, sinners and righteous,
separate of their own accord.”41
       At least Sundar does not give a second chance to everybody. Those actually in Hell do not have hope:
“In the dark part of the world of spirits, which is called Hell, there are many grades and planes, and the particular
one in which any spirit lives in suffering is dependent on the quantity and character of his sins....if they are not
restored by true repentance, and the grace of God, (while on earth), then in this fearful form they must remain
in torment forever.42 Salvation from Hell is conditioned on repentance, not on faith apart from works, in this
accursed soteriology. Evidently, repentance will save unbelievers from Hell so that they wind up in some “lower
parts of the intermediate state” where they eventually can get tired of their foolishness and thus repent, thereby
moving up the scale closer to qualifying for Heaven. But if those saved from Hell are those who repented, then
how can those in the lower parts of the intermediate state be there because they have failed to repent? Sundar
is oblivious to his internal inconsistency. Because of this internal inconsistency and his repeated assault against
sound biblical soteriology, Sundar should be soundly dismissed as a bogus source of information on the afterlife.

Marietta Davis
       As a young woman, Marietta Davis (1823-1848?), at the age of twenty-five, fell into a trance for nine
days from which no one could awake her. During this time she purportedly was in Heaven. This popular book,
first published in 1859, relates her experience that she recounted upon awakening. She died seven months
thereafter, at the time she had predicted. A number of Christians express their sentiments that they believe this
book to be a genuine experience of Heaven. After floating in midair, unguided for a brief time, a female angel
met her and became her guide.43

                                         Separation of Good and Bad
       The explanation for the separation between good and bad is “according to the moral nature of the dying”
so that:

      And all classes as they emerge from the physical form are attracted to and mingle with kindred
      associations, beings to whose character they assimilate. Those of discordant and unhallowed
      natures are attracted by like elements, and enter into regions overhung with clouds of night; while
      those, who for the love of good, desire pure associations, are by heavenly messengers conducted
      to the orb of glories appearing above the intermediate scene.44

While this might teach a separation according to performance, and thus disqualify this vision as being
legitimate, it might just as easily be taken as a separation according to degenerate versus regenerate nature, thus
simply a separation between the lost (i.e., those who do not have a regenerate nature) and the saved (i.e., those
who have a regenerate nature). Thus, this separation might be reasonable. I was willing to suspend judgment
and continued to read.

                                                  Multiverse
      The question she asks the conducting angel is exactly what I wish to investigate: “Canst thou tell me in
what portion of the universe these beings find a resting place when their spirits depart?”45 Davis was thinking
too small to suppose that they inhabit some portion of our universe. As she and the angel approached a bright
“orb of glories appearing above the intermediate scene,”46 they passed through a vast, intermediate expanse
composed of multiple universes!

      “Behold,” said she [the angel], “the countless, planetary hosts. Mark the rolling orbs, suns,
      and systems of suns, moving in silence and harmony. The vast expanse is occupied and
      peopled with universes, constructed in infinite wisdom. These are inhabited by holy beings,
      happy and immortal, though varied in degree of development and refined spirituality.”47

       If this experience is genuine, then it confirms the multiverse models that I already had developed through
a biblical analysis in which the outer sphere of Heaven holds a vast inner hyperspace that is populated with
multiple universes! One would pass through this vast expanse if one is to reach the bright, outer orb of Heaven.
How would someone living in her time period have anticipated this advanced cosmology unless through
supernatural influence? Additionally, I theorized that these other universes might be inhabited by animals living
in an unfallen state. On the other hand, these planetary hosts and galaxies populated by immortal beings might
not be limited to other universes. If these planets and galaxies inhabited by immortal holy beings are found in
the outer realm of Heaven itself, then the stage is set for the Caulian-Crawfordian model. Surely, the Heavenly
City is not the only inhabitable location within the Heavenly realm! Could not some of the less refined immortal
holy beings live inside the Heavenly realm but outside of the Heavenly City?

                                             Outer Orb of Heaven
        I proceeded to read Davis’ book with the hope that this book might not disqualify itself as a forgery. She
and the female angel proceed on their way to the bright orb in a cloud of light. When they reach the cloud of
light, they soon entered a plain with groves of fruit trees, the paradise of peace and relates the following Q&A:

      Supposing that I was on some terrestrial orb I inquired its name.
             My guide answered, “These trees, these flowers, these birds occupy the outer expanse of
      the spiritual paradise....
             “Here the redeemed are first conducted by their guardian protectors, as they leave the
      valley and shadow of death, and here they are taught the rudiments of immortal life. Here they
      receive instructive lessons relative to their heavenly abode, and learn the nature of pure love,
      unmarred by sin. Here friends who have advanced in spiritual attainments return from higher
      employment to welcome the spirit on its entrance upon this plane of the spirit world. Here kindred
      are permitted to meet and hold converse; and ‘tis in these immortal groves where spirits first
      attempt in unity the song of redeeming grace, and reposing in soft and heavenly sweetness, breathe
      the pure air of paradise.”48

       The impression conveyed is that she approaches a bright orb. Upon landing, she perceives of it as a
terrestrial orb where she finds a plain with groves of fruit trees. Apparently, she has landed upon a planet in
Heaven, one of the countless planetary orbs in this dimension inhabited with holy, immortal beings. The angel
further explains: “When thy course on earth is ended, here thou shalt mingle in the infancy of thy immortal
state, with thy kindred and receive lessons, preparatory to an advance to more exalted mansions, the more
glorified home of the blessed.”49 This proposition is entirely reasonable, especially for a young woman who is
about to die in seven months. At her death she will entry the lower, outer expanse on this heavenly planet
where believers are first conducted until she is ready to advance to the more exalted mansions in high levels.
But this preparatory stage in Paradise is not limited to young believers but encompasses all newly arriving
believers. The infants are conveyed “to the sphere of infancy in the paradise of peace.”50
       Next, her “guide moved on, and upward through forests becoming more pure and fair as we
ascended.”51 “Chalk one up for Crawford’s model,” I thought, “When believers die, they go to a garden
Paradise in the shape of a planet according to this explanation, not to the Heavenly City.” But wait! Turning the
page, I came to the next chapter, entitled, City of Peace, which begins by her recounting her experience of this
city: “At a distance, I saw a dome of light. ‘That,’ said my guide, ‘is the gateway leading to the City of Peace.
There the manifestation of thy Redeemer is made visible.’”52 What is more, this city apparently has the literal
amphitheater I had anticipated: “Around us, and in this spacious room, appeared seats in the form of an
amphitheater, yet glorious beyond description.”53 She meets children and loved ones whom she had known on
Earth within the city. So Davis pictures Paradise as being preliminary to be taken to the Heavenly City,
somewhat of a combination of Crawford’s model and mine. Jumping to the conclusion that this vision is genuine
must be met with caution when one encounters this statement in the next chapter, however: “‘Be faithful, then,’
said the spirit, ‘to the light given, and at last thou shalt enjoy the bliss of heaven.”54 If this statement is an
expression of soteriology, then it is false. Alternatively, if it is an expression of misthology, then it is splendid!
Unfortunately, the context does not differentiate, so let us proceed with caution.

                                                Human Angels
       Chapters 6-9 are devoted to Infant Paradise, which, according to Davis, is a circular city built in the
middle of a floral plain covered by a vast, dome-like canopy. Infants are conducted to this city, where they grow
until they are ready to enter more advanced sections of Paradise. As to mothers who lose their infants, the

angelic instructress giving Davis the tour is apparently the one who makes this revealing statement: “Those

established in the Christian’s heart. I was once a mother in the world of sorrow and loss. There I learned to
weep; and there I also learned the priceless value of faith in God’s mercy through our Lord Jesus Christ.”55 The
stress on faith and the distinction between believing in Christ and submitting to Christ give evidence of sound
soteriology. My concern with this paragraph, however, is that, according to this account, this angel was once a
human mother. This one statement may be sufficient grounds for dismissing this whole book as an unreliable
source of information about Heaven. For according to the Bible, when believers rise from the dead, they will
be like angels (Mt 22:30; Mk 12:25; Lk 20:36); they will not be angels. The proposition that believing mothers
who lose their children on Earth will be able to raise children in Heaven and function like angels is eminently
reasonable, though. Functionally, such believers may be like angels. My objection is to Davis identifying this
mother as an angel, per se. Technically, that would seem to be inaccurate.

                                           Levels in New Jerusalem
       Chapter 10 is entitled, “The City Viewed from a Superior Plain.” The city in question is the city of Infant
Paradise. “Soon we emerged from the ascending gallery of rainbows and stood upon an aerial plain, resting in
the transparent air above that magnificent and lofty dome which crowns the center temple of instruction in the
paradisical [sic] abode” (KL 535-536). This city seems to be the lower level of the “City, John, the Revelator,
saw” (KL 988).

                         Illustration 2. Marietta Davis’ Vision of Heavenly Paradise




       The illustration pieces together the details provided by Davis. In her NDE, she leaves Planet Earth and
travels through Heaven, seeing various inhabited planetary orbs therein. Upon arriving through the clouds, she
lands upon one of these planetary orbs, called Paradise. Initially she arrives at a flowery plain on this Planet
Paradise and is informed that this is the place where the redeemed first arrive when they die, where they are
given instructions pertaining to their heavenly abode, and where they meet with their kindred.56 Her guide then

                                                      Hell
       After touring Infant Paradise, which is the first and simplest form of Paradise according to the angel,
Davis then takes an extended trip into the subterranean realms of darkness and beholds the sufferings of those
in Hell. Those who have committed suicide are there, naturally. But since Davis does not explicitly say that all
those who commit suicide are there, the book cannot be dismissed as being soteriological defective simply on
the basis of what Davis says about suicide. One also gets close to having grounds for dismissing the book when
Davis describes a false cleric suffering in Hell:

      His whole appearance bespoke agonies equal to the worst conceptions of the relentless sinner’s
      hell, and reminded me of the language of Jesus, who said, “And they shall, go into outer
      darkness, where there shall be weeping and wailing and gnashing of teeth; where the worm dieth
      not and the fire is not quenched.” While he lay enveloped in the fires of his own unhallowed
      passions, one of his audience arose and thus addressed. (KL 814-816)

If Davis actually had equated Hell with the outer darkness, I would have insisted on her being mistaken. If she
had attributed such an equation to the angel, I would have dismissed her entire vision as being fraudulent. But
as it is, Davis merely asserts that Hell reminds her of the way Jesus described the outer darkness. Correlatively,
I have no objection to that association. Yet the astute reader should remember the differences as well as the
similarities between the outer darkness and the darkness of Hell. In particular, Jesus never associated the outer
darkness with flames.

                                            Questionable Soteriology
      In ch. 13, Jn 3:16 is quoted and affirmed, giving one the impression that Davis might believe that one
receives eternal life by simply believing in Jesus for eternal life. But such quote is followed immediately by the
expressed need to forsake sin. She is given this reminder:

      Learn from this, that he whose heart is not established in truth, whose nature is not controlled by
      the law of holy love, is exposed to the attracting influence of evil; for there is no safety for the soul
      not born of Divine Good. He who hath not this principle, is in moral condition exposed to those
      influences which tend to outer darkness, and the abode of those existing in the sphere of deadly
      magnetism. Remember that he who would be the disciple of Truth and enter into rest, must deny
      himself the gratification of the unholy inclinations of the perverted heart, which cleave to that
      which does not inspire reverence for God or a desire to be found doing His will; and he must
      convert the attributes of his being to the exercise of well doing, for thus and thus only can be
      secured through grace divine, everlasting good.57

If this is a soteriological rest, or if the statement about the outer darkness is soteriological, or if this grace is
salvific, then the vision should most likely be dismissed as forgery, since, in that case, it would seemingly be
teaching a false soteric gospel that conditions securing this grace on one’s performance. On the other hand, if
the rest, outer darkness, and grace are being used misthologically, the statement is fine. The rest is earned
(Heb 3:11, 18; 4:3,5,11); the outer darkness is mistholic in the NT, and grace sometimes is used misthologically
in the Bible. My impression of Davis’ context is that these items are intended to be taken soteriologically,
however.58 Thus, my inclination is to question the legitimacy of her vision. Granted the angel might be speaking

valley just after a Spring-time shower.” Phillip J. Swihart, The Edge of Death (Inter-Varsity Press, 1978), 69.

       Similarly, the following statement is true if taken misthologically but potentially false if taken
soteriologically: “What thou hast witnessed and what angels have taught thee, consider, when these scenes are
past, and make thou a wise improvement thereof, lest a greater evil, than to realize an entire unfitness for an
everlasting inheritance with the Sanctified, befall thee.”59 This statement seems to express conditional security
and apparently is followed by a conditional assessment of heavenly rapture: “And when thou art restored to
external sense and action, look unto Jesus, who alone can prepare thee to return and enjoy the rapture, and
engage with the worshipers in this abode of the blessed.”60 But since Davis died shortly after returning, this
rapture is apparently not the Thessalonian rapture but the rapturous experience of being taken to Heaven when
one dies. If so, it would be an expression of conditional security, unless this greater evil is a misthological outer
darkness. Therefore, I am left once again with an inclination to question her vision. Reading a misthological
vantage point into Davis’ vision seems to give her more credit than she is due.
         In a dialogue between Mercy and Justice, soteric Grace seems to die within her book:

      Mercy said, “Shall the sinner, even he who lieth in his fallen condition, be rescued? Shall he find
      favor?” Justice replied, “God in Christ reconcileth the world to himself, and through his mediation,
      Heaven shall be just in the justification of all who come to God through Him. If the sinner forsake
      the evil of his way, and the unrighteous man his thoughts, and return unto the Lord, he shall obtain
      favor. He who seeketh life, shall in Jesus enjoy the blessings of everlasting righteousness unto
      peace.61

Favor (grace?) is conditioned on performance. Little room seems left for salvation by grace apart from works
by this alleged Mercy-Justice duo, even though the book ends by affirming such grace: “I offered myself in
thanksgiving to God for the blessings of immortality, and, above all, for the gift of grace in Jesus.”62 That sounds
like an affirmation of salvation by grace apart from works, unless you contemplate the paragraph that
immediately precedes it:

      “Child, for a wise purpose thou art to return. Be faithful to thy charge. Relate, as thou art able,
      what thou hast seen and heard. Fulfill thy mission, and, at the time appointed, angels shall meet
      thee at the gate of death, and bear thee to mansions in the kingdom of peace. Be not sad; my
      grace shall sustain thee. In thy sufferings thou shalt be supported.” Then an angel gave him a
      golden goblet, and he placed it to my lips. As I drank I was filled with new life and fortitude to
      endure the separation, and I bowed and worshiped him; and he with his right hand raised me up,
      saying, “Child of sorrow from a world of gloom, thou art redeemed, thou art blessed
      forevermore. Be faithful, and when thy course on earth is ended, thou shalt enter into the
      joy of thy Lord.”63

Affirmations of the freeness of salvation are enjoined with performance themes.64 Now, if this being blessed

forevermore is an unconditional and soteriological benefit (since it is conditioned solely on being redeemed)
and if this entrance into mansions and into the joy of the Lord are misthological benefits to be distinguished
from the unconditional soteriological benefit associated with being redeemed (since the mansion and joy are
conditioned on fulfilling one’s mission and being faithful), then, yes, one can harmonize this vision easily with
the Bible. And, admittedly, one should make similar such allowances when interpreting the biblical vision in
Rev 21:6-8, so as to realize that free elements and costly elements are used back to back without being fused or
confused. Still, I am inclined to be cautious in accepting Davis’ vision as a reliable source of information.
       If Martha Davis was a legalist, for example, then a fallen angel could have come and given her a false
vision of Heaven that was geared to mix the gospel of grace with works and thereby lead unsuspecting readers
to Hell. For that matter, although her mother and sisters were believers, Martha was an unbeliever at the time
she received this vision. One certainly is justified in having misgivings about a vision of Heaven by an
unbeliever!65 Yet, because her vision does not clearly condition the soteriological outcome on performance, one
might suppose that both soteric and mistholic themes are being intertwined without necessarily being equated
in the book. If this charitable explanation is adopted, then Davis’ book provides useful consolation for those
mothers who have lost infants, and it might be recommended reading in that capacity. Reconciling the free and
costly perspectives is not impossible in her book. I am just not convinced that Davis or her angel necessarily
intended such reconciliation. Therefore, I am hesitant to accept the testimony of her book as reliable.
Nevertheless, if the book is allowed as a creditable witness as to what the afterlife is like, then it provides very
interesting collaboration for both Crawford’s model and my model as to the location of believers during the
intermediate state, affirming both Paradise and the City of Peace.
       Notwithstanding my cautions, my research into this genre finds her model a very attractive working
model for harmonizing the biblical data with the NDE data.66 If the unfaithful believers who fail to meet the
misthological ideal are disqualified from entering the Holy City, then they could live outside the city in
the lower planes of Planet Paradise or on one of the other heavenly planets inhabited by holy, immortal
beings. After all, even her own book acknowledges that there are degrees of glory linked with ascending planes
and that believers must give account of their stewardship. This NDE data seems to favor this Caulian-
Crawfordian model.

             We bring to this life the same tastes, the same desires, the same knowledge, we had before

      may not enter. What would be the use of our ofttimes long lives, given to the pursuit of certain
      worthy and legitimate knowledge, if at death it all counts as nothing, and we begin this life on a
