Certainly, some of the books we write on Earth will be available in Heaven, and additional books will be written
in Heaven. The thrust of this explanation is quite acceptable. However, the explanation may be poisoned by a
statement at the beginning that limits our entrance on our earthly purity. If this sentiment is that entrance into
Heaven is conditioned on present purity, then it teaches a false gospel, and the dream may be discounted
immediately. But since the entrance is undefined, one may proceed cautiously. If entrance into the Reward City
is posed, then such an entrance would be rightly conditioned on moral purity. She is informed that some in
Heaven have the duties to prepare new, poorly informed arrivals. For example, her father

         is called usually to those who enter life with little preparation—that which on earth we call death-
         bed repentance. You know what wonderful success he always had in winning souls to Christ; and
         these poor spirits need to be taught from the very beginning. They enter the spirit-life in its lowest
         phase, and it is your father’s pleasant duty to lead them upward step by step.70

       Unlike some who claim visions of Heaven and yet deny the possibility of deathbed conversion, Springer
affirms the reality of deathbed conversion and provides a reasonable expectation that those who fall into that
category will need very basic instruction. A dominant motif in her dreams is that husbands and wives still
live together in Heaven. When I originally read this book, I thought that this proposition strains the credibility
of this vision to the logistical and biblical breaking point. Biblically, Jesus clearly said, “When they rise from
the dead, they neither marry, nor are given in marriage, but are like angels in heaven” (Mk 12:25). However, in
the two-year lapse of my writing the initial rough draft of the present book, I have focused my research on
investigating the question as to whether overcoming husbands and wives will still live together in Heaven. My
conclusion is a resounding, Yes! I have defended that thesis in the book I wrote during that time (MSIH):
Monogamous Sex in Heaven! Therefore, I would now conclude that her affirmation of husbands and wives
living together in Heaven could be taken as a mark of her vision’s authenticity.
       Nevertheless, I still approach her book cautiously. She is looking forward to her children coming to live
with her. Logical consistency is sacrificed in that Springer does not live with her parents, so why think that her
children will live with her. Logistically, the proposal falls apart. Would children live with the groom’s parents
or with the bride’s parents? What about those who have been married more than once? What if one’s spouse
does not make it to Heaven or one’s spouse or child is thrown into the outer darkness? Indeed, Springer seems
to envision some such possibility, as her father explains his predicament to her:

               “I have the most difficult problem to deal with I have ever yet met in this work. It is how to

      enlighten and help a man who suddenly plunged from an apparently honorable life into the very

So here is a son who murdered his mother and now resides in the lowest sections of Heaven!:

      To one just freed from earth it seemed a paradise indeed; but to those of us who had tasted heaven’s
      rarer joys, something was wanting. We missed the lovely individual homes, the little children
      playing on the lawns, the music of the angel choir; it was tame indeed beside the pleasures we had
      tasted. We found the young man seated beneath one of the flower-laden trees, intently perusing a
      book that my father had left with him. There was a peaceful look on his pale face, but it was rather
      the look of patient resignation than of ardent joy. His mother approached him alone; my father and
      I remaining in the background. After a little time he glanced up and saw his mother standing near
      him. A startled look came into his face, and he rose to his feet. She extended her arms toward him,
      and cried out pathetically, “John, my dear boy, come home to me—I need you!” That was all.
      With a low cry he knelt at her feet and clasped her knees, sobbing: “Mother! mother!”72

So the son leaves the lowest sections of Heaven to live with his mother in her mansion. Not much of a
consequence for killing ones’ mother! Such a perspective would make a mockery of the Judgment Seat of
Christ. One might object that the book does not deal with the Bema, for the Bema would be in the future.
Perhaps, but this story does not give one the impression that the Bema would undo what has been done, which
gives mitigation to the Bema.
       In a supplement, Springer gives this defense and explanation of her vision: “Let me in the beginning
reassert what I have heretofore stated: that I have never claimed that this strange experience is either a revelation
or an inspiration. It came to me during a period of great physical suffering and prostration, and I have always
considered it as sent in compensation for that suffering.”73 She acknowledges that “the subject of dual marriages
has been introduced,” but her response is woefully inadequate: “In heaven are no conflicting ties; no questions
that vex; no conditions that annoy.”74 Not much of an answer to those of us trying to understand Heaven while

still on Earth is it? Perhaps her best response is the generalization she provides:

              There are some seeming inconsistencies in the book, of which I myself am aware. Looking

       From that point of view, I can read this book as a heartwarming devotional of the subjective nature of
Heaven. Throughout the expanse of Heaven, there will be no ill will among those who have been previously
wronged by those living in Heaven, and living in New Jerusalem will be like living in a great big house (the
Father’s house) with your spouse(s), children, and friends close by, in their adjoining rooms (mansions). With
this thought in mind, I can say with Springer:

             This thought, to me, answers in a measure the questions asked in regard to dual marriages.
      My own belief, of this mortal life, is, that no two friends can occupy the same place in our hearts.
      Each heart is filled with chambers stately and old, and to each beloved guest is assigned a chamber
      exclusively for himself. That room is always his. If death, or distance, or even disgrace, separates
      him from us, still the room is his and his only forever. No other person can ever occupy it. Others
      may have rooms equally choice, but when a guest has once departed from the room he has held in
      another heart, the door of that room is barred forever; it is held inviolate—sacred to the departed
      guest. And so, in heaven, each guest has his separate room or home. “In my Father’s house are
      many mansions. I go to prepare a place (room) for you.”
             I am no advocate of second marriages. The thought of two lives alone as one, is beautiful to
      me; but I do not, all the same, believe that a man sins against the memory of a wife beloved and
      lost, when he places by her side (not in her place) a good woman to cheer and brighten his home.
      She cannot, if she would, take the place left vacant in his home and heart; it is inviolate. I speak,
      of course, of true marriages, where not only hands are joined, but hearts and souls are knit together
      as one forever.76
H.A. Baker

                                             Not Demonic Visions
      H. A. Baker and his wife were missionaries in China running an orphanage by the name of Adullam
Home, which housed mostly boys, from age six to eighteen. During a supernatural outpouring of the Holy Spirit
upon these children, they, not the Bakers, had numerous collective and individual visions of Heaven and angels.
These experiences surely were supernatural, exhibiting insights and abilities far beyond what the children were
capable and holding up under cross examination. For such reasons, discounting this experience as a
supernatural event is impossible. Hacker recounts these experiences and gives his understanding of these
amazing phenomena in his book, Visions Beyond the Veil.77 I ordered a printed copy from Amazon, but the
book can be found online as a free download and in oral format.78 But is it a biblical accurate experience, thus
imparting reliable information, or might it be a satanic deception? Baker addresses this concern, saying

      We took refuge behind the promise that those who sought the Father for bread would not get a

        Baker and his wife were of a Charismatic persuasion and were encouraging these children to seek a
similar experience as they had received it would seem—the baptism of the Holy Spirit, inclusive of speaking
in tongues. Not being of a Charismatic persuasion myself, I am approaching this data with a measure of guarded
skepticism for that reason. For reasons of their own, Baker and his wife were initially skeptical as well. After
all, they were the professional missionaries, and they had never had experiences like what these children were
experiencing, and they could only observe the results of the visions, such as the children interacting with the
angels in New Jerusalem. Although the children could see the City and move through it and talk with the angels
therein, the missionaries were only able to observe the children moving and talking in the Adullam Home, as if
they were moving elsewhere and talking with someone the missionaries could not see. For various reasons, the
missionaries, upon cross examination of the children and observing these and other phenomena, soon regarded
the ongoing visions to be genuine. Since even I am willing to concede that God might still implement the gift
of tongues on unique occasions and am mindful that Joel 2:28-29 might give some justification for some
experiences of this ability in the later days, I will not use the tongue phenomena as sufficient grounds to dismiss
the visions. Additionally, only a little over half of the children spoke in tongues (p. 47), although they were all
experiencing the visions.

                        Baker Mistakenly Equates New Jerusalem with Heaven
     The children were given multiple and prolonged visions of both New Jerusalem and Hell. Baker equates
Heaven with New Jerusalem and asserts:

             The Bible tells us the heaven of the redeemed is “the third heaven.” The future home of the
      people of the Lord is a place in the third heaven. This place is a city. The name of this city is “The
      New Jerusalem.” This New Jerusalem is not “a figure of speech.” It is not a combination of ideas
      skillfully clothed in earthly words of the Lord to give man a false conception of something it is
      not. The Bible says this New Jerusalem is a real city with a real foundation which God himself
      laid. (Bold his.)80

       If Baker is correct, then my model is proven: All departed believers currently live in New Jerusalem.
This is the model I held in my book, The Outer Darkness (TOD). However, I have reason to question the
precision of Baker’s interpretation:

      As they passed through the first heaven they felt air on their faces. Having passed the second
      heaven, they looked back upon the stars in their wonderful beauty, much as from a mountain height
      a person might gaze down upon a beautiful, light-studded city below. From this starry heaven
      they passed on into the third heaven until they came to the Heavenly Jerusalem. As they
      approached this heavenly city they saw its light in the distance.81

This block quote is from the PDF version. It provides a critical piece of information that has been glossed over
in the printed version. The key sentence in the printed version says, “Finally they reached the third heaven
and came within sight of the New Jerusalem” (p. 67). The publisher’s note for the printed edition says, “This
79
   Idem, Printed, 30.
80
   Baker, Veil, PDF version, 29. The visions by the children repeatedly confirm the literal nature of the city: “In
the Spirit Adullam children were caught up to this city time after time, not as in a dream but as a living reality”
(p. 28). “Walking on the streets of the New Jerusalem was to them as real as walking on the streets of a Chinese
city” (p. 29).
81
   Ibid., 29.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                            Page 25
new edition has been updated for the modern reader. Words, expressions, and sentence structure have been
revised for clarity and readability.” Perhaps that was the intent, but the accuracy of the original, as represented
in the PDF, has been mangled by the printed version. The impression given by the printed edition is that they
traveled some distance in hyperspace after they left our universe before they came to the third heaven and New
Jerusalem. The more detailed information of the PDF makes it clear, in contrast, that they traveled for some
time in third heaven before they came into the Heavenly Jerusalem. This clarification is critical for the
present study. My model of Heaven and New Jerusalem, as presented in my book, The Outer Darkness, is in
complete harmony with the printed edition. My revised model, as I am posing it in the present series, is in
harmony with the PDF version. I developed both of these models before reading either edition of Baker’s
Visions. If the PDF version is correct, then Baker was wrong in equating Heaven (i.e., the third heaven) with
New Jerusalem. Rather, New Jerusalem would be a part of Heaven. The Heavenly City is merely a part of the
third heaven.
        Now, perhaps Baker is correct that believers live within New Jerusalem during the intermediate state.
Indeed, this is what I posed in my original model, and he has the data from the visions to backup that proposition.
But Crawford poses that we live outside of New Jerusalem during the intermediate state. If Heaven is bigger
than New Jerusalem, as the more accurate PDF version indicates (and as I now believe to be the case), then, at
least in theory, believers could live in this part of Heaven outside of New Jerusalem during the intermediate
state. In other words, given the perspective of the PDF, Crawford’s model is at least a theoretical possibility. In
that case, my model would need further proof. The further details of the visions provide collaboration for my
model but also allow the possibility that unfaithful believers live outside of the city. We will examine that
possibility momentarily. First, let use note a little more detail about the city.

                                   New Jerusalem is a Three-Sectioned Pyramid
The city is laid out as three cities composing a pyramid:

                This city in the sky the children saw as three cities in one: one city suspended above
         another, the largest city below, the smallest city on top, making a pyramid. Since this city
         John saw is surrounded by a wall, and since the city is one thousand five hundred miles high, Bible
         students have supposed the heavenly city is not a cube but a pyramid. Our children, however, knew
         nothing of this, neither had I ever thought of the New Jerusalem as three cities, one suspended
         above another. God who suspends the worlds in space can suspend these cities in space. The Bible
         does not tell us the internal order of the city.
                One of our small boys spoke in prophecy when in vision at the feet of the Lord the Lord
         was talking to him. In this prophecy the Lord said that he had made heaven big enough for
         everybody, that he had made it in three cities one above another, and that at present his throne is
         in the upper city. 82

In Darkness, I used a three-sectioned pyramid for New Jerusalem. As to some of the internal details of what
the children saw, they pose no difficulty.

                On either side of the beautiful golden streets were buildings side by side, a room for each
         person, every room opening onto the street. Upon the door and about the front were precious jewels
         so resplendently brilliant that the building shone with light and glory. The name of each occupant
         was above the door. Angels led the children into the rooms. Within all the rooms were the same
         kinds of furnishings: a beautiful golden table upon which was a Bible, a flower vase, a pen, and a
         book; by the table was a golden chair; there was also a wonderful golden chest and a golden bed.
         In each room was a jeweled crown, a golden harp, and a trumpet. The walls were gold. From the
         Bible, made of such paper as had never been seen on earth and bound with gold, light and such
         brilliant glory shone forth that the whole room needed no other light. The visitors were told that
         when they came to stay after death they could go out into Paradise and pick any flowers of their
         choice to place in the beautiful vase on the golden table.83

82
     Ibid., 29-30.
83
     Ibid., 33.
Page 26                                                                                 Misthological Models Part 4

       When I first read this paragraph I thought, “What? No computer on their desk!” Upon further reflection,
I realized that a Bible in the form of a book is a more advanced form of writing than a scroll. Perhaps first
century believers had scrolls in their rooms, and maybe technology in Heaven subsequently advanced to having
bound books. Then I realized that a printed page that lights up a whole room would be the equivalent of a
computer screen! The technology, as these boys saw it even back then, was already more advanced than what I
had given it credit upon my initial impression. Possibly, it is more advanced than what I currently am looking
at on my computer screen!
       As an aside, while Crawford and I were trout fishing, he speculated that those residing in Heaven will be
using the H-Pad (Heaven-Pad) rather than I-Pad. Cool. I think he probably is right. He further believes that the
H-Pad will not need upgrades. I suggested, however, that the creativity and ingenuity, which continues to take
place in Heaven, will mean upgrades for the H-Pad. In my job, I do tech support for a software company. We
constantly are improving our software and adding new features. Surely, they will be doing the same in Heaven.
I wonder, though, if the H-Pad will need tech support? If so, I must admit that I do not want to be the one
providing tech support in Heaven. I’ve done enough tech support on Earth!
       In any event, the details of the vision continue, not only describing current events in New Jerusalem. The
children were also shown visions of literal events in the future, including the Marriage Supper of the Lamb:

                Great tables were spread in Paradise in the midst of its magnificent trees, its wonderful
         flowers with enchanting fragrance, its glorious birds of every plumage that sang their carols of
         praise, where all redeemed animal and vegetable creation was one harmonious, spirit-filled, God-
         praising whole. Here, then, in this indescribable Paradise of God in open spaces were spread the
         tables for the great Marriage Supper. Angels and the glorified saints skipped about everywhere
         playing harps, blowing trumpets, singing, and praising the Lord. Some of the children acted out
         these scenes before us. They hurried to their jewel bedecked home to get their harp or trumpet and
         joined the spirit inspired music of the greatest of all festival scenes, the climax of all the hopes of
         the ages. Great companies sang, and danced, and praised the King. Others hurried about preparing
         the tables or the seats and carrying the golden dishes of food.84

As already demonstrated in “Computation” in MMP1, ample room is easily available for everyone to be
seated at these literal tables. Even a 7x7 mile park would seat one hundred million people at dining tables,
with about a square mile left free in the center for a platform, and a 24x24 mile park similarly would seat
1.5 billion people. Such logistical considerations are no excuse for denying the literality of the dining
capacity. Surely the seating capacity of the central city park in New Jerusalem would easily accommodate
the actual number of attendees, whatever that number may turn out to be.

                                       These Things are Conditional
       This next statement in the book about conditionality is critical, of course. Believing is not enough to
qualify for these promises:

                 In these visits to heaven the children could go to their rooms at pleasure to read their Bibles
         or to play their harps and trumpets. Sometimes they took their trumpets or harps out into the streets
         or out into Paradise to play and sing with the angels and the redeemed who are now in heaven.
                In these excursions through heaven the children, though lost to their real surroundings on
         earth, were always conscious that their visit to heaven was temporary. They knew they were there
         only to see what was prepared for them after death, so they might go back to earth again to tell
         others. Angels and the Lord told these heavenly visitors that, if they believed and obeyed, all
         these things would be theirs. They not only knew they must come back to earth again, but they
         sometimes knew when they were coming.85

These rooms, among other items in New Jerusalem, are conditioned on the performance of these

84
     Ibid., 68.
85
     Ibid., 34.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                                Page 27
believers. These rooms in the city are a reward! Either the visions are teaching salvation from eternal
damnation by works (and should be dismissed entirely), or the visions are teaching some degree of
misthopology.86 As misthopologists, Crawford and I insist that New Jerusalem is a Reward City. On the
other hand, although Dillow unfortunately does not believe that the city is a literal city, at least he has
entertained the notion that the outer darkness is within the city, so that parts of the city are a reward. At
least when he entertains the possibility that the city is literal, he poses that parts of it, at least at times,
are reserved for overcomers. Baker adds a note that would seem to allow this theoretical possibility:
“Adullam children have had visions of other parts of the New Jerusalem with its spacious parks and
elaborate mansions. Tribes people have also seen this part of the city.”87 Even though I disagree with
Dillow that unfaithful believers live within the city or even have access to the city after the Bema, one
might postulate that the conditional aspect is limited to parts of the city.

                                        Current Privileges within the City

       City Residency
That at least some believers who have died are living currently in the city is affirmed by additional details:

                One boy, after enjoying the glories of heaven, hung his crown and trumpet up in his room
         so he could have them again after he died and went to heaven to remain. He then came back to
         earth. The power of the Holy Spirit left him. When he opened his eyes he was in our Adullam
         room telling the wonders of his trip to heaven.
                Can we suppose the Lord saved these boys, baptized them with the Holy Spirit, and then
         fooled them by showing them a figurative and mythical heaven? Impossible!!! An earthly father
         may deceive his children with false hopes and false promises. Our Heavenly Father shows his
         children what he has for them (I Cor. 2:10), promises he will give these things (Rev. 3:21), and
         then gives the very things which He has promised (Lu. 11:9, 13).
                When these children saw the heavenly rooms of their Adullam friends they clapped their
         hands, laughed, and shouted with great joy, calling each one by name to come and see his room.
         The one in the Spirit was passing along the streets of the New Jerusalem, reading the names above
         each door.
                The first day when the Holy Spirit fell upon the children, and one of the boys was caught
         up to heaven, with angels who came to welcome him came also the two Adullam boys who were
         undoubtedly saved and who died the year before. These two, “Hsi Dien Fu” and “Djang Hsing,”
         had with them in heaven a little girl who died in Kotchiu four years previous, whom our children
         had forgotten. These who had died and gone on before led those who were caught up in the joys
         and wonders of heaven. They led them to see Jesus, first of all, and to worship and thank Him.
         After this they were shown their dwellings and escorted around the city or led out into Paradise to
         play.

      White Garments and Wings
      The Paradise in question is a large park in the city, not an area outside of the city. This detail would
correspond to my model of the city. If we are to believe this vision, then their rooms and crowns are waiting
already. However, they were also informed that their retaining these things would be contingent upon their
obedience. They could forfeit the rooms and crowns that were already theirs. Naturally, Jesus’ warning in
Rev 3:11 comes to mind: “Hold fast what you have, in order that no one take your crown.” If these visions are
correct, then we already have crowns waiting for us in our rooms with our names above the doors. The question
then becomes, “When do we lose these crowns and rooms if we are not faithful, at death or at the Bema?” In
my model, I pose that the unfaithful do not lose them until the Bema. Perhaps at that time such rooms and
crowns are taken away from the unfaithful and given to the most faithful (Mt 25:28). But what about the white
garments? How can the present reception of white garments be explained?

86
     Misthopology is the doctrine of the reward city.
87
     Baker, 33, n. 22.
Page 28                                                                               Misthological Models Part 4
       According to the children, “all who went to heaven were given white garments. The angels, also dressed
in seamless garments of spotless white, had wings, but the redeemed did not have wings. There was a clear
distinction between the two.”88 Baker was quite thorough in his investigation of this matter:

                 I have already told how our children had visions of some of our Adullam people already
         dead and now in heaven, clothed in white and enjoying Paradise and of their seeing the saints of
         old clothed in white. The Scripture teaches that between death and the resurrection the saints have
         spiritual bodies and that the saints are clothed in white before the time of the resurrection. When
         I cross-questioned the children as to how they knew whether the saints they saw in heaven had
         been resurrected or not, they said they did not know until the angels told them that they saw only
         the souls of the saints and that their bodies had not been resurrected. I questioned and cross-
         questioned in some of these matters and always got a uniform testimony: the children always saw
         the saints in white; the saints never had wings; all of the angels had wings; there was no difficulty
         in distinguishing between saints and angels.89

       In deference to Rev 6:11, as mentioned in Darkness, I am willing to allow the possibility that faithful
believers can be given white garments in the intermediate state. Some would disagree and insist that those
believers clothed in white garments in Rev 6:11 had to be resurrected saints. However, if we are to believe what
these children have reported, then we would have to allow the bestowal of some type of white garment in the
intermediate state. If my proposition is correct that such garments are given only to faithful believers and if the
children are correct that everyone they encountered in Heaven was wearing white garments, then the most
reasonable solution would be to pose that only faithful believers are in the part of Heaven where the children
were. Unfaithful believers would be outside the city (per Crawford’s model) or in a lower part of the city (per
my original model). Or one would have to presume that unfaithful believers are stripped of these white garments
at the Bema, at which time they are cast out of the Heavenly City into the outer darkness. Given the parabolic
detail in Mt 22:12, however, the most reasonable inference is that unfaithful believers do not have white
garments before the Bema and therefore are cast out of the city as a result of the Bema. In fact, Rev 6:11 seems
to indicate that the white garments are not given immediately to the faithful. These robes are given to them after
they have been in Heaven long enough to start crying out “how long”? If new arrivals have to go through lower
grades before being given robes and allowed into the city or into higher planes in the city, then one might
theorize that unfaithful believers remain in the lower grades during the intermediate state. Thus, they never
receive white robes. If white robes are given during the intermediate state, I would pose this as the most
plausible scenario. Faithful believers may standout even before the Bema and be given white robes and taken
to their rooms in the city that have their names above those rooms. Unfaithful believers may even be left in dark
about their inevitable fate as they wait in the lower grades, until such time when they are brought to the Bema
within the city and are then cast out of the city into the outer darkness. Ironically, if that is the case, they will
find the outer darkness very enlightening, as they discover by being cast into it that they will never receive the
white garments or set foot back in the city again.
       As to the distinction regarding wings, some NDErs say that believers have wings; many say that they do
not. I would think that the do-not position is the superior. However, these children were seeing believers in their
pre-Bema state. If crowns are dispensed at the Bema, then might the ability to wear wings be given to faithful
believers as well at that time? Could overcomers who occasionally wish to wear wings be able to do so after
the Bema? Will the Lord make overcomers higher than angels but not allow them to have wings like angels
when overcomers, on occasion, wish to appear like angels? Would overcomers have to dress up like angels in
costume fashion in order to have such fashionable wings? Will Jesus give overcomers crowns to wear as they
desire but not give them wings to wear if they desire? For now, I retain my belief in the theoretical possibility
of Bema wings.

         Animals and Pets in Paradise
         The Paradise Park within the city, as described by the children, presents a possibility that I previously

had not considered:

             Similar and surpassing beautiful scenes in Paradise were seen, repeatedly seen, by a large
      number of Adullam children. In Paradise they saw trees bearing the most delicious fruit, and vistas
      of most beautiful flowers of every color and hue, sending forth an aroma of surpassing fragrance.
      There were birds of glorious plumage singing their carols of joy and praise. In this park were also
      animals of every size and description: large deer, small deer, large lions, great elephants, lovely
      rabbits, and all sorts of little friendly pets such as they had never seen before.
             The children held the little pets in their arms and passed them from one to another. Or
      perhaps they found the lion peacefully lying beneath a tree. In that case they climbed on his back,
      ran their fingers through his shaggy mane, brushed his face, and put their hands in his mouth....
             Little children rode the small deer, while older children rode the larger deer or the friendly
      elephant.90

        The presence of tame animals in Heaven is certainly not startling. That they are already there may be a
little surprising. But the mention of the rabbits made me think about the rabbit problem already discussed earlier
in this series (See MMP2). If the rabbits reproduce and there is no food chain, as obviously there is not in this
city, then would they not overrun the city? This problem is not insurmountable, of course. Rather, I would
expand the suggestion already made earlier in this series: Animals in certain parts of the millennial kingdom
will be susceptible to death, while others are not susceptible to death. In this case, I would pose that just as some
human beings in the millennial kingdom will be in mortal bodies and able to reproduce while others are in
immortal bodies that do not reproduce, so some animals will be in mortal bodies that can reproduce while other
animals are in immortal bodies that do not reproduce. Those animals living in Heaven are in the latter category.
        For an extended biblical defense, I would recommend a chapter by Thomas Horn.91 He cites other authors
who hold this perspective: (1) Randy Alcorn believes “our pets will be in Heaven simply because we love them
and God promises to give us the desires of our hearts (Psalms 37:4)” (KL 173). (2) Billy Graham “replied, ‘If
it would make you any happier, then yes [your pet will be in Heaven” (KL 181). (3) Peter Kreeft asks, “Why
not? How irrational is the prejudice that would allow plants (green fields and flowers but not animals in
heaven?” (KL 1881)92
        On a personal note, I am particularly pleased that Horn is quoting from Kreeft’s book, Ever Thing You
Ever Wanted to Know about Heaven but Never Dreamed of Asking, and thereby endorsing that book to some
degree. In MSIH, I build upon Kreeft’s thesis that sexual relations continue in the hereafter. However, I amend
such arguments and pose that the intimate love of former pets and spouses is a reward limited to those believers
who qualify to live in the Heavenly City. See my MSIH for that argument as it applies to sexual intimacy with
one’s soulmate. As to pets, Horn notes

             The question of whether pets go to Heaven may depend, some believe, on their “covenant”
      relationship with man! In other words, just as we are made a part of the family of God as a result
      of accepting the grace extended to us through Jesus Christ, pet animals may be brought back into
      a pre-Fall covenant by coming under and accepting human dominion as it was first intended. No
      longer “wild” and outside man’s control, they become part of a Christian family, and are saved as
      a result. In this way, some animals as “pets” may be in Heaven while most other animals will not,
      similar to how some humans will be in Heaven while others will not, all depending on restored
      covenant. (KL 229-233)

       As noted in MMP2, I amend this line of reasoning by suggesting that such conditional immortality on
the part of animals would be limited to the pets of those humans who qualify to reside in the Heavenly City.
So, if an overcomer wants to have his or her pet back in heaven, why should such a request not be granted? If
having pets is a reward, which I contend to be the case, then it provides confirmation of preliminary rewards:

       Skipping ahead, I will interject a comment from John Burke’s book, Imagine Heaven. Although I will
interact with that book subsequently, since I read it latter during the course of this reading dairy, his analysis
regarding pets is applicable to the present discussion. He concludes that animals are in the Heavenly City, and
pets are also allowed:

        All sort of animals were with the children. It was an awesome sight to see a magnificent lion
        frolicking with the children, as if it were a kitten....
               ....If God uses animals to teach children (and even adults) how to love, don’t you think
        renewing all things [Is 11:6] would include pets we’ve loved as well? I imagine so. Van Lommel
        noticed that NDE “children do encounter favorite pets that have died more frequently than adults.”
        The ten-year-old who “died” in the judo accident said, “My pet dog Skippy was there. Skippy had
        died some years earlier and was the only ‘person’ that I had any real family connection with that
        was dead. I was overwhelmed with Joy and Love and embraced my dog.” I imagine dearly loved

       If Burke is correct and such NDErs are valid, which certainly seems to be the case, then the special love
of one’s favorite pets is already being experienced in the intermediate state by those who reside in the Heavenly
City. Further, if I am correct, then similar arguments should lead one to conclude that the special love of one’s
former spouse is likewise being experienced by those living in the city (see MSIH).

                             Baker Mistakenly Thinks Repentance is Soteric
      Reconciling the visions becomes more challenging when one reaches the chapter regarding, “The
Kingdom of the Devil.” Because the eyes of the children are opened to spiritual realities, they can see not only
angels but demons and have to engage in spiritual warfare. I have no problem believing that to be the case.
Indeed, it would have been surprising if it were not the case. The first problem is that Baker makes salvation
from Hell conditioned on repentance rather than faith:

               When one man who did not know the Gospel died, his soul, after being liberated from the
        body, wandered about unhindered from place to place on earth, until one of the devil’s angels,
        descending from the sky with chains, bound him and forced him down to hell. The death of a
        professing Christian who had known the Lord, but had not truly repented, was still more
        terrible. When this man was dying, demons by his deathbed waited in fiendish delight for the
        liberation of the soul of this hypocritical, one-time professing Christian. The demons began to bind
        him before he was entirely out of the body and completed the binding of their captive the minute
        he drew his last ungodly breath. The hypocrite did not enjoy one moment of freedom to wander
        about the earth. An object of ridicule to his demon captors, in terror he was at once dragged and
        pushed into hell.94

       If Baker had said that the reason this professing Christian was dragged off to Hell was because he had
not truly believed, then all would be fine and well. But Baker attributed the problem to the man’s lack of true
repentance. Now, granted, I have added the emphasis to the word repented in the above quote, perhaps in
Baker’s mind believe and repent are virtuously synonymous. For many years I held to the old FG view that
soteric repentance is a merely turn from unbelief to belief. If that is what Baker intends, then I have no
theological objection to his statement. And given his splendid soteriology elsewhere in the book, such as the
closing chapter, “The Way,” one might be willing to allow that possibility. Nevertheless, I am skeptical. For
exegetical reasons, I still maintain that Baker should have attributed this professing Christians lack of
conversion to a failure to believe. I already have demonstrated that Baker is not an infallible interpreter of these
visions which the children had in that he mistakenly equated New Jerusalem with Heaven, when in fact, per the
details of their own visions, New Jerusalem is only a part of Heaven. I would further suggest that, per his own
soteriological analysis, he should have attributed this man’s lack of conversion to a lack of belief, not to a lack
of repentance. But Baker immediately proceeds to describe one of the children as only a professing Christian

93
     Burke, Heaven, 311.
94
     Baker, 50.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                               Page 31
because of his lack of repentance:

                After seeing him begging on the street for several days we took him into the Adullam Rescue
         Home. He promised to reform, made an outward showing of decency, heard the Gospel for a
         considerable time, and professed repentance.
                Different articles disappeared from the Home, but the thief was not found until this boy was
         caught on his way to sell the stolen plunder. We then put him out of the Home.
                After several months of beggar life, during which time this boy repeatedly promised to
         reform if only we would allow him to return, we gave him another chance. The Lord also gave
         him another chance, for there were manifestations of the Holy Spirit and supernatural revelations
         sufficient to make the way of life clear to the most simple. This boy himself had anointings of
         the Holy Spirit, when the Lord dealt directly with him about his sins and showed him the
         better way. In spite of all this the boy ran away and joined a street gang of beggar-thieves. A few
         months later he fell and broke his arm, infection set in, and he was about to die when he was picked
         up by a hospital worker. In the hospital he was so hopelessly disobedient that he was thrown out
         and was soon in a dying condition on the street. Coming to us with promises of repentance, we
         pitied him and took him in once more.
                Day by day he neared the end of the way. The night before he died I was awakened by
         unearthly shrieks that sounded like uncanny howls of some wild animal or of some fiend. The next
         day when the boy died I was away from home. As he lay in death throes, delighted, awful hellish
         demons gathered about him. When his soul was leaving his body the boy seeing his captors, wept,
         yelled, shrieked, and cried at the top of his voice in wildest terror; "Mr. Baker, help! help! help!
         O, Mr. Baker, come quickly! Mr. Baker, Mr. Baker, Mr. Baker! Help, they are all about me with
         chains! They have come for me. Help, help, Mr. Baker, help! Oh, oh, oh, help! help! help! They
         are binding me with chains. Help! help! Oh, oh, oh, help! Oh—h—e—l—”95

       Again, I would insist that the reason this boy went to Hell was not because of his lack of genuine moral
reform (aka repentance) but because of his lack of belief. Note that Baker equates repentance with reform, not
with merely turning from a state of disbelief to belief. By conditioning the boy’s salvation from Hell on moral
reform, Baker fails to present a genuine gospel. Contrary to Baker’s expectations, perhaps the reason that this
boy went to Hell was because Baker had garbled the gospel presentation so that this boy thought that he had to
reform in order to escape Hell. This detail also gives grounds to derail much of the credibility of visions in
general. Baker explicitly says, “This boy himself had anointings of the Holy Spirit, when the Lord dealt
directly with him about his sins and showed him the better way.” How did the Lord show him? Through visions?
After all, since the anointings of these other children universally involved these visions, should we not conclude
that this boy also was taken to Heaven and saw the Lord? If so, was his vision false? And if that is the case,
what is to prevent us from considering the other visions as potentially false? Or was his vision genuine, and
was he given the opportunity to believe but failed to do so, perhaps thinking that his salvation was in part
conditioned on his performance?
       At the very beginning of the book, Baker informed us: “All who received the Holy Spirit knew enough
to believe in one God and to trust in the blood of Christ for salvation.”96 What happened to this pristine
soteriology? Why is it abandoned in the case of this boy who obviously did not reform? Why not simply
acknowledge that he did not trust in the blood for salvation? Using Occam’s Razor as my guide, I will choose
the easier explanation, which is that Baker is mistaken in his explanation as to why the boy went to Hell. Even
if he was allowed into Heaven provisionally as a child, he failed to believe that his salvation from Hell was not
conditioned on his performance. In being presented a full gospel, that included an explanation as to how to earn
a room and crown in the Heavenly City, he failed to believe that his salvation from eternal damnation was
unearned. I can see how someone reading Baker’s book could fail to make the distinction. Why not think that
this boy, sitting under his ministry, failed to make the distinction and went to Hell as a result?

                  Over and over again children had visions of hell and the lake of fire. The first time any one

     Ibid., 51.

     Ibid., 4.

         was under the anointing of the Spirit he usually had a vision of hell. He was bound in chains by
         demons and taken through a region of darkness. Some children could hear demons all about them

        Not obeying the demons is linked with believing in Jesus to save them, but one suspects that the former
encompasses more than the latter and includes moral performance. Many times the stress is on the adequacy of
belief:

               There was no vision of any one in heaven or the name of any one on the mansions by the
         golden streets who did not trust in Jesus. Those in hell were all unbelievers. One night when the
         Lord spoke through a small boy in wonderful prophecy, among the things he said was, “There will
         be no one in heaven except those who believe the gospel.”98

It is difficult to discredit the visions offhand when such clarity is manifested on more than one occasion.
Yet on other occasions it is garbled, or at least mingled:

                 In this vision, repeated until it seemed the impression could never be forgotten, the one in
         vision seemed to be standing by the cross at the parting of the two great roads. The one was the
         narrow way of life that leads to heaven and glory; the other was the broad way to hell and
         destruction.
                 Great, busy, hurrying multitudes—multitudes hustling with business, carrying great loads
         of sin and rushing along with the affairs of life—were passing by in endless streams and countless
         numbers. The child was the preacher at the cross roads. Again we heard one side of the
         conversation: “Hello! my friend! Please wait a minute; I want to speak to you. Say, do not go down
         that broad road; it leads to hell and ruin. I have been down that way and have seen hell for myself.
         Stop here by the cross and let Jesus wash all your sins away. From the Cross of Christ here you
         can start up this other road that will lead you to heaven and everlasting life and joy. Oh! that
         fellow does not believe it. There he goes on down the broad road. What a pity! I will stop this
         other man and see if he will believe. Hey there! Just a minute! Say, do not follow that crowd. They
         do not know where they are going. That road leads to destruction; that is the road to the lake of
         fire. Please don’t go on. I came out here to stop as many of you as possible and give you fair
         warning. Better turn aside here, let Jesus wash your sins away, and go with us up the road to heaven
         where God is. Oh, there he goes, too!
                 Here is another. Wait a moment! Say, come out of that crowd. Cannot you see there is no
         one traveling back this way? They all go down that road; no one ever comes back. That is the
         broad road to hell. Stop here by the cross, believe the gospel of salvation through Jesus’ blood,
         and you will be safe. There is no other road further on. This is the only road to heaven. Turn in
         here or you will be lost too.
                 “Oh, what a pity he does not believe me. There he goes with the others.”
                 Sometimes the youthful preacher would decide that if no one believed him he would follow
         the willful crowd to see what happened. When he arrived with the crowd at the brink of the lake
         of fire in hell, we heard him say, “Look at that crowd falling into hell! Not one escapes. Everyone
         goes in.” Slowly drawing near the edge of the pit and leaning over and looking down into the lake
         with its suffering multitudes, the preacher said: “I cannot help you now. I told you all about this
         back there at ‘the gospel cross roads,’ but you would not believe. No, you would not believe, even
         if I could help you out. No, I am helpless now. If you had listened when I warned, the Lord would
97
     Ibid., 51.
98
     Ibid., 54.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                               Page 33
         have saved you; you came on and fell in because you would not take advice. No, I can’t. I am
         going back to the cross roads to see if I can find someone who will listen, and stop a few at any
         cost.”
                He was occasionally successful in persuading one to listen. Then he would say, “Now, you
         get down there at the foot of the cross of Jesus and pray. Oh, you don't know how to pray? Well,
         you say what I tell you. 'Jesus, I am a sinner! I was on my road to hell. I am only fit for hell. The
         big load I carry is only sin. Forgive my sins and teach me to live only for your glory. Amen’.”
         There was rejoicing then as the sinner was saved and started up the narrow road, while the
         preacher went out to try to rescue another deluded traveler.
                These visions, with some variations, were repeated many times, making it clear that
         salvation was only by repentance and belief in the blood of Christ, through the preaching of the
         gospel.99

       Note that the stress is on believe. In fact, in the actual vision, the word repentance is not used. Baker adds
it. Yet I would say rightly so, as a description of what it means to travel the narrow road in this vision. At this
juncture, I’m sorely tempted to right this vision off as a confused mess and point out how it contradicts itself
by conditioning salvation simply on faith in some parts and on faith plus performance in other parts. Two things
keep me from doing so, however. First, Occam’s Razor suggests that I take the simpler explanation. And despite
appearances, attributing this whole thing up to a satanic scam is not easy. Discrediting seemly valid real-time
interactions with those in Heaven and Hell from multiple sources is difficult. Read the book in its entirety to
see what I mean. I am willing to engage the problematic portions of this book at this length because the book
seems to merit the effort. Second, I suspect that Baker did not resolve these tensions within the book because
he was unable to do so, but this does not mean that doing so is impossible. Indeed, until very recently I would
not have been able to resolve them either. However, the Lord has brought me far enough in my spiritual
pilgrimage that, by the time I finally was willing to read this book, I had developed the hermeneutical tools
necessary to reconcile the tensions, if I thought it worth the effort.

                                         Reconciliation Through Duality
        In Darkness, I would have dismissed this vision as presenting a false gospel because I insisted on a
soteriological view of the narrow road. I still believe that is a valid interpretation. But, as argued in this series,
I also allow a misthological view of the narrow road. This duality, among other things, allows me to see a
reasonable solution to the dilemma that would have been facing Baker at the time in trying to provide an
explanation. Salvation from the Lake of Fire in this vision, though I might not have called it the Lake of Fire
during the intermediate state, is received as a free gift simply on the condition of faith in the shed blood of Jesus
for forgiveness. Therefore, eternal life with Jesus in Heaven is a free gift by faith apart from works. However,
the part of Heaven that the children are urging these unbelievers to join them in is New Jerusalem. This part of
Heaven requires that these unbelievers not only believe in Jesus’ shed blood for soteric forgiveness but also
repent and obey by morally walking the narrow road in terms of the misthological performance necessary to
qualify for rooms and crowns in the Heavenly City. These children are presenting the ideal gospel message in
that, ideally, we would want those traveling on the road to Hell not only to believe the gospel of grace, and thus
be saved from Hell, but also to obey the fuller gospel of the kingdom, and thus take the road that leads to
rewards within New Jerusalem. I wish Baker had provided such an explanation. If he had, then his book would
have been much more persuasive. As it is, he has left the hard part up to others, that is, to resolve the problems
in his explanations. But then again, at that earlier point in time, I would not have been able to resolve the
tensions either. The hermeneutical tools were not in place to do so. Therefore, I cannot fault him for his inability
to resolve the experiences with satisfactory explanations.

                                                   Tightrope
      Nevertheless, the visions of witnessing to those on their way to Hell were not merely visions of theoretical
possibilities. They included real-time interactions. Now we come to the most difficult part of the book to
reconcile:


99
     Ibid., 54-55.
Page 34                                                                              Misthological Models Part 4
            Opposite our front gate lived a university student who was to have graduated from the
     university that year. After moving here I talked with him, asking him to come over and discuss the
     Bible and Christianity in a friendly way. He came a few days, and I felt certain he was convinced
     of the truth of what I said. The questions he raised seemed to be answered to his full satisfaction.
            Through him I managed to get a chance to talk with some of the other university students
     during their vacation. I had been going to their rooms ten days, when there came the mighty
     outpouring of the Holy Spirit upon Adullam. The students were friendly, and I felt that the student
     I have mentioned saw clearly the truth of the gospel. I could see that, although he was polite, he
     was not disposed to accept the truth and did not seem to like the friendly way the other students
     responded to the Bible discussions.
            One morning when one of our girls was out at our front gate it happened that this young
     university student was out there too. The girl began telling him he ought to be a Christian, in a
     simple way urging him to believe in Jesus to save him from his sins, make him a good man,
     save him from hell, and lead him to heaven. [Note the duality, reconcilable as above.]
            “What’s the use of my being a Christian ? I do not need to be saved.”
            “You might die suddenly in your sins, and you would go to hell.”
            “Who are you?” scoffed the student. “You are a little snip of an ignorant girl, just a sort of
     useless beggar. What do you suppose you are trying to do? You are trying to teach me something
     when you are not worthy to even talk to me. I am a university student. I am wise. I have read many
     books. I have been many years in Peking. I can speak and read English as well as Chinese.” He
     then spat in her face and told her to mind her own business.
            Two weeks later hearing a funeral commotion in the front alley, I was surprised to learn that
     they were carrying this university student to his burial; I had seen him on the street a few days
     before. One of the boys said that as we were going out to preach, a few days previous, he had
     offered this young man a tract, but he would not take it.
            I knew nothing of this conversation with the girl. About a month later this girl was in a
     trance under the power of the Spirit. After seeing visions of heaven and the glories of the redeemed
     she stood still and bent over as though looking into hell. This is what I heard: “Ah! There is hell.
     No, I cannot; I have no power to help you now. You certainly are in an awful plight. It is you who
     are worse than a beggar now, all dirty, all filthy, and suffering in the lake of fire. In fact, you look
     worse now than any beggar I ever saw. I thought you told me you were rich and that you had a
     great education. Where is your education now? Well, I cannot help you now even if you do
     apologize. That may be, but I have no power. No, only Jesus can save you, but when I told you
     about Him you made fun of Him and cursed me.
            “Look what we beggars who believe in Jesus have received in heaven: all is joy, all is
     happiness; all is love in the city of golden streets with its wonderful Paradise of God.”
            Then the girl seemed to be crossing the lake of fire over a narrow bridge. We saw her
     walking as though she were walking a rope, placing one foot carefully in front of the other
     while extending her arm on either side until she recovered her balance. With a sigh of relief
     she said, “My! this is dangerous! But the Lord will help me. I will get across to the other
     side.” Then she carefully brought the other foot forward and nearly lost her balance again.
     She praised the Lord until she recovered her balance and proceeded as before. In this way
     having crossed the room, she seemed to be safely in heaven, past every danger of ever falling
     into the lake of fire.
            Whatever the effect of relating these visions may have on others, these things have taught
     us in Adullam to believe more assuredly than ever in the reality of heaven and the Kingdom of
     God and the reality of hell and the Kingdom of the devil. More positively than ever do we assert
     that the way through this life that leads over the dangers of the lake of fire, the way that
     “overcomers” must travel, is like walking a rope which must be traveled step by step with
     fear and trembling. Only the Lord Jesus can sustain us in the balance so that we may not
     topple in to the right, or escaping that, fall to the left. We are surer than ever that God means
     for us to stand by the cross at the cross roads to point sinners to the narrow, little-traveled
     road that starts at the cross and leads by it on up to heaven and the life the Lord has prepared
     for them who love Him. How can any be saved without this salvation; how can any escape who
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                              Page 35
      neglect this salvation? “For if the word spoken through angels proved steadfast, and every
      transgression and disobedience received a just recompense of reward; how shall we escape, if
      we neglect so great a salvation” (Heb. 2:2,3)?100

       Baker rightly ends on a note regarding reward! A salvation that is conditioned on any performance, much
less a performance pictured by walking a tight rope and being good, is most certainly a reward, not a gift!
Earning this reward requires that one not only be a believer but also that the believer be an overcomer in the
sense intended by Revelation. Ironically, it is my ability to interpret a similar tension in Revelation that prevents
me from completely discarding this vision as an affront to the Gospel of John (GJ). As John makes repeatedly
clear in GJ, the only thing necessary to receive eternal life as a free gift is that one simply believe in Jesus for
this free gift. On the other hand, rewards within Heaven are very costly, as John makes abundantly clear in
Revelation, where he describes one such reward in these terms: “He who has an ear, let him hear what the Spirit
says to the churches. He who overcomes shall not be hurt by the second death” (Rev 2:11). But John defines
the second death as being thrown into the Lake of Fire (Rev 20:14). Because believers have eternal life, they
cannot be thrown into the Lake of Fire, a deduction provable not only from Scripture but also from the reputed
utterance of the Lord as recorded by Baker in his book. So how can we resolve the tension?
       To be sure, Rev 2:11 is a litotes, promising abundant life (as the opposite of the second death) as a reward
for overcoming. Still, through the principle of correlativity as discussed in Darkness and the LLR-SML theory
as posed in Part 2 of this series, one reasonably may postulate that believers can be hurt by the second death in
a nonliteral but misthological manner. If this girl’s tightrope act must be interpreted soteriologically, then the
vision is a scam. But if this tightrope walk pictures the truth presented in Rev 2:11, then it is a biblically viable
picture of misthology. In other words, if tightrope walk is actually accentuating a reward aspect, as Baker
intuitively perceives, then the vision can be reconciled easily with the Bible and with Baker’s book if one is
willing to use advanced misthology.
       Moreover, one may even posit that believers are hurt by the second death in terms of temporarily
experiencing these fires misthologically at the Bema (or a preliminary Bema), which leaves lasting results of
not being able to live in the Reward City. Indeed, Hollandsworth has posed this very solution and spends an
entire chapter fleshing it out. “Apparently, Jesus will baptize (immerse) believers in fire at the Judgment Seat”
(Mt 3:11; Jn 15:6; 1Cor 3:13-15; Heb 6:8). Some believers will not be hurt by the fire (cp. Rev 4:6; 15:2).
Consider the possible typological parallel in Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. “Despite their baptism in fire,
they were not harmed, not even singed...For their faithfulness, God rewarded them with positions of
rulership.”101
100
    Ibid., 55-57.
101
    James S. Hollandsworth, The End of the Pilgrimage: Your Judgment Seat Verdict and How It Determines

suggested a similar possibility: “Some expositors suggest that the book of Revelation teaches that a believer
could be harmed, though not destroyed, by the second death (2:11).” Joe L. Wall, Going for the Gold: Reward
and Loss at the Judgment of Believers (Chicago: Moody Bible Institute, 1991), 141. Of course, ultraistic writers
have insisted that believers are hurt literally by the second death, being cast into the Lake of Fire for a thousand
years, throughout the course of the millennium. Faust, for example, spends multiple chapters defending this
thesis. J.D. Faust, The Rod: Will God Spare It? An Exhaustive Study of Temporary Punishment for Unfaithful
Christians at the Judgment Seat and During the Millennial Kingdom (Hayesville: Schoettle Publishing Co.,
2002). In Faust’s model, unfaithful believers temporarily experience soul-death at the Bema by being killed
physically and then being hurt by the second death in the Lake of Fire (pp. 121-162). Faithful believers,
however, according to Rev 2:11, will “not painfully fall into the midst of the preliminary Lake of Fire when he
walks across it before the judgment throne of God” (p. 162). They will be able to stand before that throne
(Lk 21:36) by standing on the Lake of Fire as a sea of glass (Rev 15:2). Faust’s full-blown model has
theological, exegetical, and logistical problems that led to my rejection of much of his thesis in my antithesis
within Darkness. Nevertheless, even I acknowledged therein that not all believers will have the misthological
strength to stand before the Lord at the Bema.
     Hollandsworth’s model is not subject to the same shortcomings as Faust’s model in that Hollandsworth
does not equate soul death with physical loss of life in Rev 2:11 but with the misthological loss of life, which
is eternal (pp. 63-64, 69). Hollandsworth has proposed a noteworthy mediation, therefore, between my model
Page 36                                                                              Misthological Models Part 4
        Given that Revelation provides impetus for using these advanced hermeneutical tools for interpreting
biblical visions from the Lord in this manner, applying this same advanced explanation for this tightrope vision
might be prudent as well. If so, then believers walk this tightrope not to be saved from eternal damnation in the
Lake of Fire but to be saved from being hurt by the Lake of Fire in a way that would correlate to losing
misthological life in New Jerusalem. Put bluntly, walking the tightrope saves believers from being cast
misthologically into the outer darkness, which for them would be the counterpart to unbelievers being cast
literally into the Lake of Fire. Whereas unbelievers are cast soteriologically into the Lake of Fire, unfaithful
believers are hurt misthologically (through correlativity) by the Lake of Fire.

                                         Reputed Message from Christ
       The primary reason I am willing to entertain the possibility that these visions might not be a satanic scam
and that the tightrope vision might be reconcilable with the other visions and with the biblical data is because
of the following account relayed in the book, pertaining to a boy who reputedly gave a prophetic message from
the Lord:

             Prostrated in vision at the feet of the Lord, the boy said, “Lord Jesus, I am not worthy to be
      here or to be saved at all. I am only a little street beggar.” Then Jesus addressed the boy. The boy
      did not know it at the time, but the Lord actually spoke through the boy as a mouth piece, using
      the first person and addressing us and the children sitting about him. Here is the “Thus saith the
      Lord” that we wish might grip your hearts as it still grips our own.
                    “I weep tonight. I am heart-broken. I am in deep sorrow because those who
            believe in me are so very few. I planned and prepared heaven for everyone, having
            made room for all the people in all the world. I made the New Jerusalem in three
            great cities, one above the other, with plenty of space for all men. But men will not
            believe me. Those who believe are so very few. I am sad, so very sad. (This message
            was given between heart-rending sobs and floods of tears from the boy.) Since men
            will not believe me, I must destroy the wicked earth. I planned to visit it with three
            great calamities, but it is so wicked that I have added a fourth.
                    “If you have any friends, tell them to repent quickly; persuade all men as
            rapidly as possible to believe the gospel; but if people will not listen and will not
            accept your message the responsibility will not be upon you.

and Faust’s model. I would suggest Faust’s discussion be consulted but reinterpreted in harmony with
Hollandsworth’s model. In any case, Hollandsworth has made an attractive synthesis that serves as a useful,
competing model to my theory of correlativity pertaining to the second death and Lake of Fire. Whereas, due
to the eternal nature of rewards, I disallowed literal applicability of the Lake of Fire in Darkness, Hollandsworth
allows temporary applicability of this literal fire merely at the Bema, but he affirms that the results are eternal,
in harmony with my more fundamental concern. His proposal is plausible and may even be helpful for the
present NDE discussion.
     Consequently, herein I am entertaining a possible synthesis between Faust’s preliminary take on the Lake
of Fire, Hollandsworth’s quick-dip hypothesis, and Baker’s NDE tightrope so as to suggest that perhaps
believers who die before the rapture have a preliminary judgment to determine whether they will be clothed in
white and thus enter the city. If they have been faithful, they can stand on this sea of glass mixed with fire
before the throne (Rev 4:6; 15:2); otherwise, they are not able to stand the heat and shrink away in shame to the
relative darkness outside of the city (cp. 1Jn 2:28). In Darkness, my thesis was that the outer darkness was not
applicable until the millennial kingdom started. In Destiny, Dillow’s antithesis was that the outer darkness is
applicable immediately after the Bema, thus during the tribulation. In Part 4, my synthesis is that the outer
darkness is applicable immediately after the pre-Bema in the case of those who die before the rapture.
Hollandsworth’s own analysis would lead to this conclusion since he concurs with my misthopological model
regarding the Reward City and even takes Heb 12:22-23 in that vein (pp. 87-88), a conclusion I did not reach
until Part 4 of this series. I find this immediate-reward synthesis (pertaining to the intermediate state) to be
superior to Hamblin’s immediate-resurrection hypothesis (pertaining to tribulational martyrs). David A.
Hamblin, Unveiling the Mysteries of the Last Days: Systematic Prophecy from Genesis to Revelation (Mustang,
OK: Tate Publishing & Enterprises, 2010), 158, 181.

                      “Get the baptism of the Holy Spirit. If you will tarry and believe, I will baptize

         already written, and then again repeated from the little prophet's memory item by item, made it
         easy to see how in days of old the prophets spoke as moved by God, how a scribe might record
         every word as it came from the lips of the prophet, or how the prophet himself could record his
         own messages, truly saying, “thus saith the Lord.102 (Bold his; italics mine.)

       The soteric emphasis and sufficiency within the utterance is focused clearly on the necessity to believe.
The singular call to repent does not detract from the sufficiency of belief. Ideally, unbelievers should repent,
not merely believe. The gist of the soteric content seems to be that only those and all those who believe become
His children and are promised that they will be caught up (i.e., raptured) and saved. Particularly impressive is
the statement: “I will not destroy my own children; I will protect and save every one; not one of mine will
perish.” The Johannine flavor of this soteriology is unmistakable (e.g., Jn 1:12; 3:16; 5:24; 6:47; 10:28-29). If
I am granted Johannine soteriology as the safety net by which to put the misthological tightrope in perspective,
then I would conclude that a fall from that tightrope could not result in eternal damnation but only in loss of
reward. Loss of eternal life at the soteriological level would be impossible since Jesus, per the reputed utterance
and the Gospel of John, will not allow any of those who believe in Him to perish. The only other option to
explain the perspective of the visions would be Calvinism, thus posing that the Lord saves all believers by
causing them to walk the tightrope successfully. If the visions are fake, their fakery is exposed by their
Calvinistic perspective. But given that the invitation appears to be universal and that whosoever will may come
if they will simply believe, Marrowism is the better option for explaining the phenomena.103 Therefore, with
102
      Ibid., 72-73.
103
      Marrowism is the present author’s coined term for describing his mediating non-Calvinistic Free Grace
Page 38                                                                               Misthological Models Part 4
some reluctance, I will be willing to count this book in favor of Marrowism. Consequently, it would support
my classic Caulian model of New Jerusalem with unfaithful believers currently living in the lower portions of
New Jerusalem or it might support a joint Caulian-Crawfordian model in which unfaithful believers currently
live outside of New Jerusalem while faithful believers are allowed to live in portions of New Jerusalem.

                                                     The Way
      In his last chapter, “The Way,” Baker begins by quoting Jn 14:6 and then proceeds to explain how,
according to his understanding, one reaches Heaven. His soteriology in this section is excellent, stressing time
and again that our only hope is faith in Christ for eternal life as a free gift:

              I simply believed that Jesus did it all. He that believeth hath eternal life.” “He that believeth
      hath passed out of death into life.” To them that believe he gives “the right to become sons of
      God.” Having believed that Jesus did what He said He did and having accepted Him as my
      substitute and as my sin-bearer, He accepted me as His child. He sent His Holy Spirit into my
      heart, so that I was born from above. The Holy Spirit in my heart bore witness, crying, “Abba,
      Father.”...
              Christ finished salvation. He died for the sins of the whole world. Eternal life is a “gift.”
      “The free gift of God is eternal life.” This gift is free. All we have to do is accept it or reject it,
      take it or ignore it. We must be like one or the other of the thieves on the cross: either believe that
      Jesus is God and can save a sinner who acknowledges his condition, and spend eternity with Christ
      in Paradise, or be like the other thief and disbelieve that Jesus is God, and die in our unrepented
      and unforgiven sins away from God.
              Christ saves any and all who are saved because of their belief. “Whosoever believeth in
      Him shall not perish but have eternal life.” Those who believe and are thus saved, Christ keeps.
      They hold not the Rock, but the Rock holds them. They do not hold Christ; Christ holds them.
      They are saved by grace through faith apart from works. They will be kept by grace through faith
      apart from works. “This is the victory that overcometh the world even our faith. Who is he that
      overcometh the world but he that believeth that Jesus is the son of God.”104 (Emphasis his.)

        The problem with this excellent soteriology is that it does not completely match the visions he has
reported. What happened to the necessity of walking the tightrope in order to escape the Lake of Fire? A
salvation conditioned on successfully walking a tightrope is certainly not a salvation by grace apart from works!
Unless the salvation being pictured by that tightrope scene is something other than the salvation bestowed freely
by grace, a hopeless contradiction exists between what he has just said and what he previously described. What
happened to the statement discussed above where he himself reported: “Angels and the Lord told these heavenly
visitors that, if they believed and obeyed, all these things would be theirs”? Unless these things are something
other than the free gift of eternal life, a contraction is apparent.
        From his biblical analysis, Baker knows that the visions are supposed to point people to faith in Jesus as
the only way to Heaven. However, he seems to be at loss as to how to reach that conclusion with the data he
has in hand. Nevertheless, since I can reach that conclusion even with the difficulties in the data as it stands, I
am not necessarily inclined to dismiss either his data or his conclusion offhand.
        Believers cannot be cast into the Lake of Fire, but they can be hurt misthologically by the Lake of Fire.
These things, conditioned on ongoing obedience, are indeed more than not being cast into the Lake of Fire
soteriologically. More is afoot than Baker simplistically suspects. An earlier paragraph in his closing chapter
illustrates Baker’s failure in making the necessary clarifications:

             Man on the merits of his character will never walk the golden streets. What a man is, what

theology, which is positioned between Arminianism (PEARS) and Calvinism (TULIP) and summarized herein
by the author’s acronym GRAPE. Historically, this movement was expressed in seminal form by the Marrow
Controversy. In a number of key areas, the present author may be considered a modern day Marrowist. As used
by the author, Marrowism refers to a defense of unconditional security consisting of soteriological and
misthological consistency.

    Ibid., 84-85.

      a man does, or how a man lives has nothing to do with his salvation. On the basis of how “good”
      he is, the best man on earth has no more hope of heaven than the worst man on earth. Man who
      trusts in his own character, his own moral goodness, is only a modern Pharisee with eyes blinded
      to the truth. The publican, the drunkard, the harlot will enter the city of God, while that “good”
