       Because, via the visions, Baker has conditioned walking on the golden streets on the believer’s ongoing
moral obedience, more is necessary to walk these golden streets than simply being a believer. Merit is necessary
to walk these streets: not soteriological merit, but misthological merit. The logical deduction is that only
repentant, obedient, believers will enter the city. Disobedient believers will be brought into the city long enough
to be judged and then cast out of the Heavenly City into the outer darkness during the intermediate state (so
Crawford’s model). Or they will reside in the lower parts of the city and then be cast out of the city at the Bema
(so my original model). As Crawford and I both agree, this outer darkness is not soteriological exclusion but
misthological exclusion.
Anne Sandberg
       After having read the above so-called classics, and found most of them disappointing in terms of general
reliability, I then read Seeing the Invisible by Anne Sandberg. This book is research oriented. Sandberg spent
several years researching this area, so I was hopeful that the accuracy of this book would be better, and in a
way it was. In general, the biblical analysis is very good. Particularly impressive is her motive for writing the
book:

            The most important reason for writing this book is to show that our rewards, types of service
      and capacities for fellowship with God in the “world to come” will be in proportion to the degree
      of growth and spiritual maturity we have achieved while on earth. The greatest mistake a Christian
      can make is to arrive in heaven not having attained his fullest potential for spiritual growth.106

       Given my wholehearted agreement with this perspective, I was highly optimistic that the book would
shed useful light on my own research. Also, I appreciate her insistency on the literality of the city: “It is neither
a symbolic word nor figure of speech. It is a definite place, a city which hath foundations. Hardly anyone would
dispute that this is what the biblical authors themselves believed.”107 Wonderful! Fully in accord with the
biblical data! The problem is that some kingdom teachers, like Dillow, do not believe the city is literal, which
is one of my reasons for researching this type of genre. Does the extrabiblical data confirm a literal or nonliteral
city?
       Sandberg begins by citing sources such as John Bunyan, Marietta Davis, H.A. Baker (the Adullam
Orphanage), and Sadhu Sundar Singh as positive sources. However, as seen in my own review of these writings
above, I have misgivings about the reliability of some of their statements. These reservations caused me to
proceed with considerable caution in wholly endorsing Sandberg’s conclusions, even when I agreed with her
conclusions. Nevertheless, I was pleased with her analysis of the biblical data.
       As she explains in her chapter 2, for example, we live in a three-tiered universe encasing universes
(so Davis) into which the human population was intended to expand through procreation and will expand
in eternity future. Splendid! She allows the legitimacy of people having NDEs because they encounter other
people who had died even though some of these NDErs had no way of knowing that the people they encountered
on the other side had died.108 Her biblical analysis regarding rewards is also highly commendable. Only

        My theory in 4D Forgiveness (4DF), which allows preconversion sins to be a misthological factor in
deathbed conversions, was formulated in response to such data as what Sandberg records here, along with my
analysis of Acts 22:16 in 4DF. Accordingly, I am open to the possibility that the misthological distinction
between being clothed in white or not being clothed in white might indeed be apparent before the Bema
judgment takes place at the rapture. I only wish that Sandberg had reported whether Hooley’s uncle was inside
or outside the city in that misthologically unclothed, intermediate state. Eventually, I was able to track down a
copy of the booklet, but that detail about whether he was inside or outside the city was missing. Nevertheless,
I will interact more thoroughly with her testimony at the conclusion of this chapter.
        In any event, Sandberg’s chapter on a biblical analysis of rewards is right on target: Some believers will
be hippies in Heaven while others compose the Bride; overcomers will be closer to Jesus than subcomers; in
the parable of the talents the outer darkness is a misthological theme (pp. 137-143). She follows this up with an
excellent discussion of the need for Christian growth and suggests that subcomers will be spiritually retarded

in Heaven because they did not reach maturity during their time on Earth (p. 148). God wants His children to

then concludes this chapter on growth with the fitting quote from Julia Ruopp’s The Window of Heaven, who
surmised, as a result of her NDE experience, that “not to grow spiritually seemed to me then and still does the

bottles of milk for crowns” (p. 166). No crown of life would be a form of misthological death. Therefore, a
bottle of milk would be a picture of such death.
       Her chapter 8, “The City of God,” was of particular interest since my primary interest in the present book
is to determine if the extrabiblical data suggests that believers currently reside inside or outside of the city. She
surmises scholarly opinion: “A number of Bible teachers say believers will remain in that part of heaven
called paradise until the time of the resurrection, after which time they will be transferred to the New
Jerusalem. Others say paradise and the New Jerusalem are simply different sections of heaven” (p. 60).
My friend, Scott Crawford, would combine these two perspectives to say that believers live in the Paradise
section of Heaven outside of New Jerusalem until the resurrection at the rapture. So he is by no means alone in
such an assessment. Sandberg devotes this chapter to the urban section (New Jerusalem) rather than the rural
section (Paradise). Yet, as she notes, even the city had parks. So here is the problem. If someone reports only a
rural experience, can we be certain that they were not in the city? Sandberg only hints at the possibility that
even supposed rural experiences might actually have occurred inside the city.
       In any case, the city can be viewed from outside: “When Ivan Moiseyev was taken by the angel to the
other world, the angel said that because the youth was still in this body, he would have to view the New
Jerusalem from another planet” (p. 63). Other NDEs report actually going to the city and walking inside of
it. Sandberg appropriately concludes, “Some Christians will learn at this time [the Judgment Seat of Christ]
that they will remain forever in a lower plane in heaven than God had planned and desired for them”
(p. 184). The question of present interest, however, that Sandberg did not address is, “Will these lower planes
be inside the city or outside of the city?” Might unfaithful believers have to live outside of New Jerusalem on
another planet, for example? Her analysis leaves this question unanswered; nevertheless, it leaves room for this
hypothesis. After all, she had said, “All Christians will go to heaven, but they will be assigned to different
locations or planes’ (p. 180), and she reports that some had to view the city from another planet within the
third heaven. Locating all those planes within the city is quite unnecessary. In any event, her book is
commendable as a biblical analysis of NDEs.110
Marvin Ford

                                             Being of Light (BOL)
       Marvin Ford describes the experience of the Being of Light (BOL) encountered by NDEs but urges:
“Extreme caution must be exercised here against deception” (pp. 40-41).111 Part of the concern is that this BOL
seems to be an “impartial observer” who has little interest in the way one had lived. Ford also believes that the
silver cord (cp. Ecc 12:6) connecting the “spiritual entity to the physical body” can be severed resulting in death
(pp. 45-46), providing one reason to caution against soul-hopping (aka astral projection or soul travel).112 Other

    There are some soteriological and misthological deficiencies in Sandberg’s book, however. She apparently

acknowledgment that not all believers live a life consistent with such alleged additional soteriological

                                                    Betty Baxter
       If this account is accepted as genuine, then my model is proven: Believers are currently living in the
Heavenly City. Likewise, Ford relates an account by Betty Baxter. When she stepped inside the dark Valley of
Death, it lit up. She walked through it with Jesus. When they came out of the valley, they came to a wide river
separating her from a beautiful land where she could see the “river of life wending its way through the city of
God. Standing on the banks was a company of those who had been redeemed” (p. 109). She was not permitted
to cross the river but sent back to Earth. The impression from this description is that Paradise is not limited to
the city, and a company of the redeemed are currently living within the city within Paradise. This raises the
question, “Might some of the redeemed be living currently outside the city?” This account is sufficient as to
allow this possibility but insufficient so as to confirm or deny the reality.

                                          Anna Hewlett Ward
      The account related by Anna Hewlett Ward adds the details of all three heavens:

             “When I left my body, I ascended through the air,” she related to friends. “As I passed
      through the first heaven, I could feel the air gently blowing upon my face. Having passed the first
      heaven, I ascended up through and beyond the stars [the second heaven]. I looked down upon the
      starry realm. What a wonderful sight! I might compare the stars with the lights of a great city as
      seen from a distance [possibly how our universe would appear from a distance in hyperspace].
             Suddenly, she saw the enchanting gold and jasper light of the heavenly city in the distance.
      Rapidly approaching the radiant, gem-studded metropolis, she was met by an angel who pointed
      downward, saying, “You must return to Earth again” (p. 110).114

       Ward’s description is in accord with my multiverse hypothesis. Ford poses that for Christians “no
illusionary planes are encountered, the flight is direct to Heaven” (p. 112). If Ford is correct, then the data
related by believers would seemingly be trustworthy.

                                                  Dick Mills
       The account that Ford relates regarding an evangelist, Dick Mills, gives me cause for caution, however,
even when evaluating the accounts of believers who may not be subject to illusionary planes. Mills relates that
in his NDE he was “getting close to the city of Heaven.” Nothing unusual there; however, he continues:

                Jesus met me, and we talked. He pointed to the city and said, “Do you know that if you go
         in there it’s forever?” I said, “Yes. I know that one of Heaven’s names is the Eternal City.
                “Did you know that everything in there is based on the laws of harmony?” He probed. I
         replied, “Yes.” “Did you know that you are out of harmony? He continued, “Yes,” I admitted.115

        This claim runs counter to the experiences of those who claim to have been inside the city. How is it to
reconcile with such claims? One might theorize that those who merely have visions of the city may be allowed
into the city. NDErs are not allowed into the city because they are on the verge of death, however, and their
spirits have actually left their bodies. For them to enter the city would be permanent and cut the silver cord
connecting their spirits to their bodies. Therefore, they are not allowed into the city because they are to return
to Earth. Even if Mills’ claim can be harmonized by this or by some other hypothesis with the counterclaims of
those who say that they have been inside the Heavenly City and who lived to tell about it, the problem still
remains of evaluating his explanation: “Reflecting on his near-death experience, Mills says: ‘I found out that
between this world and the next, it wasn’t worth it to have all that resentment in my heart. In fact, it kept me
from getting into Heaven’” (p. 116). Taken at face value this explanation, although in harmony with common
interpretations of the unforgiving servant (Mt 18:21-35), is actually counter to the Bible and teaches a false
soteriological of salvation from eternal damnation based on performance. That passage in Matthew is actually
a misthological text.
        Mills is relating either (1) a false experience, (2) a misunderstanding, or (3) a miscommunication. Using
Occam’s Razor, I will adopt one or both of the latter two possibilities. My hypothesis is that believers are not
infallible in their understanding or communication of the events which have happened. If this is the situation in
this case, then Mills is a genuine believer who probably misunderstands the meaning of the encounter. Mills
was not kept out of Heaven; rather, he was only kept out of the Heavenly City. He failed to consider that Heaven
is not limited to the Heavenly City. This account would allow the possibility that unforgiving believers will not
be allowed into the Heavenly City, even during the intermediate state, but have to live outside the city. The
Caulian-Crawfordian model poses that very possibility. Hopefully, something like this is what Mills meant
when he said that he was kept out of Heaven, and he simply misstated the situation. Or he simply may have
meant that his unforgiving spirit kept him from being ready to enter Heaven at that time. In either case, the
explanation by Jesus in this account is in harmony with the Caulian-Crawfordian model. Despite the
attractiveness of this hypothesis, the data is too inclusive to embrace it wholeheartedly. Conflicting data lies
ahead. (See Case 5 Revisited, 50.)

                                                     Mrs. Jang
       In the very next page, Ford relates the NDE of Mrs. Jang in China. She went with Jesus and came “before
a gate of pearl. It was the gate of Heaven” (p. 117). This explanation on her part might be considered, like that
of Mills, as being imprecise in failing to distinguish the difference between Heaven and the Heavenly City. But
then she walked with Jesus in the city: “I walked beside the Lord on the golden streets” (p. 118). This claim is
inconsistent with Jesus’ alleged explanation, per Mills, that “if you go in there its forever.” So I must call into
question either the experience, the understanding, or the communication of these NDEs. I cannot ignore this
inconsistency. Nevertheless, even if Mills accurately has conveyed a genuine explanation by Jesus,
harmonization is not impossible. The you might be understood as not applying universally to all NDEs without
exception. In Mills’ particular case, “if you go in there its forever,” but this should not be taken as a law that
necessarily applies to all NDEs, only to some NDEs. Many NDErs experience a gate, a river, a fence or some
other point of no return over which they are not allowed to pass because they are to return to Earth. Jesus’
words, “if you go in there its forever,” is presumably that line for Mills. If this NDE experience is valid, then
Mills evidently misunderstood the full significance of Jesus’ explanation. The explanation that Mills offers for
not being allowed to leave the city is because it is called “the Eternal City.” That explanation is insufficient if

                                                  Marietta Davis
      Ford also relates the experiences recorded by others, such as city being composed of innumerable plains
and that “paradise plains exist on all levels of the city, each arranged in ascending degrees of grandeur....The
various plains [on the various planes] of the city are similar, though differing in beauty and detail. Marietta
Davis identifies one as an infant paradise” (p. 162).

      Varying according to the spiritual attainment of the person, the aura gives one the appearance of
      being dressed in flawless white, while at the same time clothed in beautiful colors of varied hues.
             Those living on the higher planes of the city radiate the brightest light, being so resplendent
      that their glory must be cloaked so others of lower degree can look upon them. Visiting the higher
      levels is possible, but the spirits of the lower realms must be prepared or covered so they can stand
      in the presence of greater glory. Perhaps this partially explains the degree of rewards awaiting
      those who make the ultimate journey beyond.118

       If such testimonies are taken at face value, then believers who have died already have been awarded
places in the city according to the degree of glory appropriate to their service while on Earth. If the Bema
already has taken place for them on an individual scale, then the mass Bema after the rapture will only need to
deal with those believers still living at the time of the rapture. Or perhaps those believers currently living in the
higher planes and in a more splendid state of glory have only been given a preliminary evaluation, with the full
evaluation to await the mass Bema. In either case, these present misthological distinctions seen by NDErs
certainly allow the possibility that those believers who have not been faithful are currently either at the lowest
part of the Heavenly City (so my original theory) or in Heaven but outside the city (so the Caulian-Crawfordian
model).
       The typology presented by Davis allows either possibility. Although Ford focuses on the planes of the
city, Davis did not limit her treatment to the city. Ford’s description of Davis is accurate insofar as it goes.
Davis had said, “These infants, having been prepared, will ascend to a more exalted plane—a realm where,
blessed with superior advantages, and surrounded with still brighter glories, they shall arise from one degree of
attainment to another.”119 And one may deduce that more advanced levels within New Jerusalem are being
affirmed. However, at the very beginning she noted that inhabitation in the heavenly realm was not limited to
the city.120 Ford’s book is thus recommended for its surveys and analyses.

a bad experience might be recalled as a positive experience, which might explain in part why some researchers
in this area report only positive experiences. “I have found that most of the bad experiences are soon suppressed
deeply into the patient’s subliminal or subconscious mind. These bad experiences seem to be so painful and
disturbing that they are removed from conscious recall so that only the pleasant experiences—or no experiences
at all—are recollected” (p. 65). Other supplemental possibilities are also suggested:

      Some of the “good” experiences could have been false impressions, perhaps created by Satan
      appearing as an “angel of light” (see 2 Cor. 11:14). Or perhaps the meeting place is a pleasant
      environment representing a “sorting ground” or a pre-judgment area, since most cases report a

      can be transversed. However, a few unusual cases report that they were allowed to break through
      the “barrier” into what appeared to be heaven or hell. (Pp. 64-65)

                                                        Case 2
       Those reporting a positive experience, sometimes relate details that I personally found doubtful, such as
the NDEr who claimed, “I also saw a cross that was on the side of the mountain and a figure was hanging on
that cross, still alive. I know it was Jesus” (p. 82). However, biblically we know that “Christ, having been raised
from the dead, is never to die again; death no longer is master over Him” (Rom 6:9). Therefore, I would be
inclined to reject this NDE experience as a false impression by a satanic impersonation, unless it was a vision
of what had happened in the past at Calvary.122 In any event, this being on the cross did not identify himself.
After all Rawlings observes: “It is interesting that whatever ‘being’ they encounter has not, as a rule, identified
himself. Usually, the person having the experience makes the identification. Thus, the Hindus, Muslims, or
Buddhists may say that they see their deities while the Christians identify him as Christ” (p. 86).

                                                     Case 3
       One-sided, plausible exceptions are noted, however: “Those strong in their faith have no doubt that the
light represents Jesus Christ. Some say that He identified Himself precisely” (p. 89). I am inclined to think that
for such a being to identify Himself as Jesus Christ would be tantamount to a confession that Jesus is the Christ
and that Jesus is Lord. Thus, my inclination would be to accept such testimonies as biblically trustworthy. On
the other hand, Rawlings makes a solid case for considering the BOL preaching universal love with no judgment
to be a satanic counterfeit (pp. 88-89). This BOL is lying. The NDE evidence itself proves this to be the case
since some NDErs have hellish experiences. Plus, some NDErs meet a biblical Christ who is very much
interested in the way they live.
       For the present study, his section, “Encounters Beyond the Barrier,” is of particular interest. This section
describes those who break through the barrier into Heaven: “Persons may report a direct entrance into heaven

                                                      Case 4

      For example, consider this account of another case:

             I was flying through space at a rapid rate.
             There was a river below me, and it was becoming dawn. Everything was getting brighter. I
      noticed that I was crossing over a beautiful city below, as I followed the river like a soaring bird.
      The streets seemed to be made of shining gold and were wonderfully beautiful. I can’t describe it.
      I descended onto one of the streets and people were all around me—happy people who were glad
      to see me! They seemed to be in shinning clothes with a sort of glow. (Pp. 94-95)

If the river was outside the city and he followed it to the city, then it stands to reason that there is land outside
the city.

                                                   Case 5
This impression is confirmed by another case related by Rawlings:

              Next thing I remember was going through this dark passage. I didn’t touch any of the walls.
      I emerged out into an open field and was walking toward a big white wall which was very long. It
      had three steps leading up to a doorway in the wall. On a landing above the stairs sat a man
      clothed in a robe that was dazzling white and glowing. His face had a glowing radiance also.
      He was looking down into a big book, studying.
              As I approached him I felt great reverence and I asked him, “Are you Jesus?”
              He said, “No, you will find Jesus and your loved ones beyond that door.” After he looked
      in his book he said, “You may go through.”
              And then I walked through the door, and saw on the other side this beautiful, brilliantly lit
      city....There were many people all dressed in glowing white robes with radiant faces....
              As we walked along together to find Jesus, I noticed there was one building larger than all
      of the others. It looked like a football stadium with an open end to the building where a blinding
      light radiated from it....
              They said, “In there is God.” (Pp. 98-99)

       Unfortunately, we do not know if the book consulted by the angel was for soteriological or misthological
purposes. If soteriological consultation is in effect, then my model would be correct. All believers are allowed
into the city simply because their names are soteriologically in the Book of Life. On the other hand, obviously
some heavenly land exists outside of the Heavenly City. This land is described as an “open field” and has a “big
white wall” in it. If the book is being consulted misthologically, then the person in question might not have
been allowed to enter the city but left to explore the open field if his name was not found in the book. In this
case, the Caulian-Crawfordian model would be correct. Rawlings follows up with this tantalizing statement:
“Borderline cases of near-entry into what could be initial judgment are not uncommon” (p. 100). If
misthological judgment is indicated, which would be the only reasonable deduction in that case, then the
evidence would favor the latter model. Regrettably, this is not the focus of Rawlings’ book.123

  Another NDE describes being carried to and from the city by a female angel with wings (p. 97). He met his

                                                      Case 6
       Instead, he moves on to his chapter to provide NDErs who, in his opinion, went to Hell. One NDEr “was
standing near a shoreline of a great ocean of fire...There was no one in it” (pp. 103-104). This account is better
than some I have read which have people already in the Lake of Fire, in that being cast into the Lake of Fire is
biblically a future event.

                                                     Case 7
       One NDEr who went to Hell described it as “the Outer Darkness” (p. 110). Biblically, however, the outer
darkness is not a soteriological reference to Hell but a misthological reference to exclusion from the Heavenly
City (but not from the heavenly land surrounding the city). My reading of this type of literature persuades me
that a NDE does not make one an infallible interpreter of the event. Those trying to interpret their experiences,
whether they be positive or negative, do not necessarily interpret them accurately. Hence, one must do due
diligence in performing an analysis.

                                                        Case 8
       Rawlings shares an account of someone who “attended church every Sunday and considered herself an
average Christian” who went to a hellish darkness (p. 106). Frankly, a Christian going to Hell should not be
surprising. Most likely, most Christians will go to Hell—when Christian is defined simply as a public follower
of Christ. Even during Jesus’ ministry not all of His followers were believers (Jn 6:64), and given the legalistic
mindset prevalent in Christianity today, it stands to reason that most of His followers today are not believers.
Instead of trusting in Christ alone for eternal life as a free gift, most Christians have trusted in Christ plus their
performance for the gift of eternal life. One cannot be saved, however, by trusting any degree in one’s
performance for this free gift. Many followers, therefore, do not qualify as genuine believers. Some of these
unbelieving Christians have determined, as a result of their NDE of Hell, that the problem is that they did not
perform well enough to escape Hell (p. 110). They tragically have misinterpreted their experience and are
working even harder to earn a free gift.

                                                      Case 9
       Not having this framework with which to work, Rawlings finds it difficult to understand some of the
cases he reports. For example, he tells of “a staunch Christian, the founder of a Sunday school, and a lifelong
supporter of the church” who had a hellish NDE the first time, “passing out into blackness and then I saw these
red snakes crawling all over me” (p. 118). Neither Rawlings nor the patient could “volunteer an explanation for
its occurrence to a professing Christian” (p. 120). But two heavenly NDEs occur thereafter: “Without any
apparent reason, unless some secret transformation or dedication occurred of which I am unaware, this
patient’s subsequent two experiences during other deaths were beautiful” (p. 119). In lieu of their inability to
provide an explanation, I would offer the hypothesis that after having a hellish NDE despite living a good
Christian life, this staunch Christian determined that living a good Christian life would not save him from Hell
and consequently stopped trusting in his good Christian life to save him from Hell and trusted exclusively in
Christ instead. In other words, he was saved by grace as a result of giving up on being saved by works. He
experienced NT salvation.
       Incidentally, in his second NDE, he experienced “a rolling green meadow that was slightly uphill....then
we came to a white fence that looked like a split rail, but I could not get over it” (p. 120). This detail again
confirms that the heavenly land is not limited to the Heavenly City. On his third NDE, he “was floating over
this beautiful city” (p. 120). He was about to enter this city when he awoke and was returned back to his body.
One could pose that unfaithful believers are cast into the outer darkness somewhere outside of the city, even if
it simply means to live in the rolling meadow outside the city.

                                                      Case 10
       With that realization in mind, it is tempting to speculate that Rawlings unknowingly reports a case where
that very thing happens. A Christian shares his testimony: “I was very young when I took Christ as my Savior.”
He then shares a surprising NDE:

             I was drawn into total darkness. Then I stopped. It felt like a big hallow room. It seemed to
      be a very large space, and totally dark. I could see nothing, but felt the presence of this power.
Page 48                                                                              Misthological Models Part 4
             I asked the power who I and who he or it was....He answered that he was the Angel of Death.
      I believed him. The Angel went on to say that my life was not as it should be, that he could take
      me on but that I would be given a second chance, and that I was going back. He promised me that
      I would not die in 1967. (P. 116).

       Though I realize that unfaithful believers will be cast into the outer darkness and am very open to the
possibility that they could be cast into the outer darkness even now during the intermediate state, I am very
skeptical that this account describes that event. Granted, no flames are mentioned, just darkness, which would
be plausible for a misthological scenario. Nevertheless, I do not anticipate that literal, pitch black darkness is
entailed for the misthological level. A literal darkness would be anticipated for a soteriological darkness, not
misthological darkness. Further, the proposition that the outer darkness would be administered by the Angel of
Death is highly problematic. Admittedly, the parable of the unforgiving servant in Mt 18:23-35 does allow the
possibility of picturing the outer darkness misthologically as being placed in a dungeon and handed over to
torturers therein, particularly during the intermediate state. Thereafter, the misthological location and nature of
the outer darkness might undergo a transition. While such speculations may not be entirely impossible, they are
highly improbable.
       For one thing, the Angel of Death might be Abaddon, a fallen Cherub, the ruler of the abyss. If this
popular assessment is correct, then the darkness in question in this case study would be under Abaddon’s fallen
jurisdiction, not likely part of the Messiah’s kingdom. One might counter that Abaddon is allowed to rule over
the kingdom dungeon presently, however. Thus, dogmatism on this particular point may be imprudent.124
Notwithstanding, the NDE data surveyed thus far confirms my suspicion that the darkness experienced in this
case is not the misthological darkness described by Matthew. In the experience of Dick Mills, documented by
Ford and discussed above, Jesus met Mills outside the city and told him that he was not yet ready to enter the
city because of his unforgiving spirit. (See Dick Mills, 43.) Jesus, not the Angel of Death, is the one who gave
the second chance. Additionally, the second chance was offered from within Paradise, not from inside a dark
room.
       Rawlings might be correct, therefore, to place this experience with the Angel of Death in the hellish
category.125 If so, this so-called Christian never really took Christ as his Savior at an early age, contrary to his
mistaken claim otherwise. This assessment certainly should occasion no surprise, as many children erroneously
think that they have been saved when in fact they have not. For example, many (perhaps most) children are
mistakenly informed by would-be evangelists that they can be saved by asking Jesus into their hearts or by
giving their hearts to Christ. Such faulty evangelistic invitations are recognized to be fraudulent by more
prudent evangelists (such as Bunge), who favor the biblical invitation to believe in Jesus for eternal life as a
free gift, not conditioned in any way upon works.126

       Thankfully, Rawlings realizes that “a believer in Jesus can’t lose on either side of death. As a Christian,

been there and returned to tell about it” (p. 32). One murderer asked, “God, does God ever make mistakes?”
because the BOL was not interested in judgment, only unconditional love (p. 62).

                                                Case 5 Revisited
       In the newer edition, Rawlings also supplies a critical piece of information that was missing in the older
edition regarding the accountant recounted in case 5. (See Case 5, 46.) We now learn that the Christian who
was allowed into the Heavenly City after the “big book” was examined was “a Christian-turned-cold
following the death of his mother several years previously when her leg was amputated. In spite of his
most fervent prayers, she died, and he concluded, ‘God is as deaf as a stone idol. He has no use for me,
nor I for him’” (p. 95). This testimony refutes the claims of those who insist that if believers commit a willful
sin, they will go to Hell. This believer turned his back on God and was still allowed not only into Heaven but
into New Jerusalem! This means that the book must have been consulted exclusively for soteriological purposes,
not misthological purposes, providing strong confirmation for my classical Caulian model over and above the
composite Caulian-Crawfordian model. Even unfaithful believers can be allowed into New Jerusalem during
the intermediate state—at least in their NDE.

       Conflicting Details
       On the other hand, this NDE to which I could appeal for my classical Caulian model is in conflict with
that of Dick Mills (p. 43.), who was not allowed to enter the city because the city is one of harmony and he was
out of harmony due to his unforgiving spirit. Also, Mills had been informed that entrance would be forever.
This case regarding the accountant reported by Rawlings, though, poses that a believer who had not forgiven
God (!) was allowed to enter the city and walk in it and return to Earth. Harmonization of these two accounts is
challenging.

        Possible Harmonization
        Sometimes unfaithful believers are allowed into the city; sometimes they are not. Sometimes a point of
no return is encountered; sometimes it is not. Perhaps harmony might be obtained by suggesting that Jesus
meant that misthological entrance is forever, but Mills was not qualified to enter misthologically. Thus, he was
sent back to Earth to rectify his misthological deficiency and forgive the person on Earth. This particular
believer, Mills, reconciled with that person on Earth as a result of not being allowed to enter the city. Perhaps
the “retired and well-to-do accountant” (p. 95), recounted in case 5 by Rawlings, was allowed to enter the city
because this is exactly what he needed in order to forgive (in the sense of change his mind and consequently
his feelings about) God. For in the city, he met his mother, “but now she had two legs and was walking!” (p. 56)
In contrast to Mills, this particular believer got right with God as a result of entering the city. Entrance into the
city is supposed to be for eternity. My model poses that those believers who die permanently in a misthologically
unqualified state will not be allowed to dwell in the city for eternity. Perhaps this is what Jesus meant if Mills
has reported his NDE accurately.
        Even if this is the case, though, the Caulian-Crawfordian model cannot be completely discounted at this
juncture because one might amend it to allow the possibility that some believers who do not qualify to live in
the city might be allowed to enter the city initially during a NDE but not allowed to remain there. After all, if
they have no mansion/dwelling prepared for them in the city, they would not reside within the city. If the silver
cord is severed while they are in the city in a misthologically unfit state, they would be cast misthologically
outside of the city into the outer darkness. My working theory at this juncture, then, is that those believers who
encounter a point of no return outside the city are not allowed into the city because this would be the best thing
that could happen to them to maximize their misthological potential. Contrastively, some believers are allowed
into the city because this is the best thing that could happen to them to maximize their misthological potential.
The experiences are tailor-made for individual believers according to what would be best for them to maximize
their own misthological potential and that of others.
        My proposal bears some similarity to that offered by Swihart: “Dying is a process, much as birth. One
assumption that might follow from such a hypothesis would be that God may help individuals through that
process in special and unique ways. Again, it would also follow, that whatever methods he might use during
such a process would in no way violate his own Word, the Bible.”130 God does not have to use a rubber stamp
in giving everyone the same NDE.


130
      Swihart, Edge, 56.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                           Page 51
                                                    Case 9 Revisited
       Evidently, Rawlings revisits the case 9 discussed earlier. (See Case 9, 47.) This time he suggests that the
reason the Baptist Sunday school teacher initially had a hellish NDE was because “he said he knew he was not
the Christian he should have been” (p. 76). Yet, in the earlier edition, Rawlings had described this patient as “a
staunch Christian, the founder of a Sunday school, and a lifelong supporter of the church.” Rawlings still
concludes that “some sort of conversion resulted,” leading to the subsequent heavenly NDEs (p. 76). Agreed.
However, Rawlings is mistaken to imply that a moral transformation, such as this Sunday School teacher
becoming the Christian he should have been, was the antidote to Hell. This would be refuted by Rawlings’
revisited case 5, an observation that evidently escapes Rawlings. To his credit, Rawlings is merely reporting
the facts at this juncture. He does not attempt to reconcile the discrepancies. Evidently, he was not able to
formulate a working hypothesis to do so. Therefore, I will maintain my hypothesis that this Baptist came to
trust in Christ alone for entrance into Heaven, for the first time in his life, after the hellish NDE. The
transformation that took place, and which resulted in this Baptist having positive NDEs after his initial hellish
NDE, was not a moral transformation but an internal transformation, namely, regeneration. One would
anticipate that, in such a context, experiencing regeneration would have a positive impact on his Christian walk,
of course. Yet a better Christian walk was not the key that saved this Baptist from Hell. The key is to believe
in Christ for the free gift of eternal life, not to believe in one’s Christian walk.

                                               James E. Johnson
       Reconciling soteriology and misthology are not the only challenges confronting one trying to harmonize
the NDE examples Rawlings provides. Johnson describes his experience of going to “a celestial city, like a
castle in the sky” (p. 57). The typology presents the interesting problem of harmonizing this account with those
who describe the city as being in an open plain with a river. Where are the river and plain if the city is a sky
castle? Does the city move within the heavenly realm during the intermediate state? I am speculating here,
admittedly, but we know that the city will move later, when it comes to Earth. Thus, my migratory projection
is not without biblical precedent. For believers, the light at the end of the tunnel seems to be one of two
possibilities: “Some patients have seen a city of golden streets and some had seen something like the Garden of
Eden with beautiful surroundings. Some had seen both” (p. 243). Another possibility is that the city is
surrounded by a large meadows and gardens, but this land is suspended in the sky.

                       Paradise                                            Paradise and City




      Probably multiple factors are involved in whether a believer will be taken simply to (1) Paradise or to

for the NDEr and those to whom the NDEr will return to tell about the experience. For these reason, some
unfaithful and faithful believers alike are allowed into the city, while other unfaithful and faithful believers are
not allowed into the city. Because unfaithful believers are not robed in white and are not seen within the city
by those reporting seeing many robed believers within the city, the data suggests that unfaithful believers will
reside outside the city during the intermediate state once their silver cord has been cut. If this deduction is
correct, then the NDE evidence to this point seems to favor the Caulian-Crawfordian model. Thus, the picture
on the left would be the picture of the outer darkness. All in all, Rawlings’ later edition, To Hell and Back
(1993), is a classic on the subject and a worthy read.
Doug Groothuis Revisited
       As stated earlier, to a large extent, Groothuis’ Deceived by the Light (1995) is a critical evaluation of
Betty Eadie’s Embraced by the Light (1992).131 As noted by other writers surveyed thus far, this Being of Light
(BOL), encountered by so many in their NDE, shows no interest in rewards, punishment, sinful deeds, or
judgment (p. 48). The claim of this BOL is countered by other NDEs, showing this BOL to be deceptive.
Groothuis cites other research that support’s Rawlings’ findings in this regard, including the repression of
negative NDEs. Such writers are performing a very commendable service to the Christian community in
unmasking the deceptive nature of the BOL. Groothuis notes (pp. 113-114), among others, that a NDE is not a
total release from one’s body because the silver cord has not yet been broken (Ecc 12:6-7).
       Perhaps, clinical death is the separation of the spirit from the body (Jam 2:26), but the biological death
which only occurs once, and after which comes judgment, is the severance of the silver cord (Heb 9:27). The
present inquiry includes considering the possible judgment of unfaithful believers during the intermediate state.
Groothuis relates a NDE account that may have some bearing on this question:

             Dan was an active homosexual....He then traveled through a dark tunnel to a beautiful
      garden, hedged by a fence that stopped him from going further. A brilliant light appeared, radiating
      love and peace, and Dan knew that it was Jesus Christ. Yet this being of light was not all-accepting.
      Sin was indeed a problem, for Dan heard the words, “It is not time to come into my Father’s
      kingdom. You have not lived as I intended. Go back and glorify me.” Dan returned to his body
      and awoke as a follower of Jesus Christ. He stopped his homosexual ways and became a part of a
      devoted community.132

       Unfortunately, Groothuis does not tell us whether Dan was a believer in Jesus Christ before he “awoke
a follower of Jesus Christ.” Thinking that Groothuis’ failure to provide this critical piece of information might
be because Groothuis is unaware that one can be one without the other (p. 128), I obtained the original source
from which Groothuis quoted. Klamecki was the Christian physician who relayed Dan’s testimony.
       Klamecki calls it Dan’s “conversion.” However, it does not sound like a conversion to Christianity but
to the Christian way of life—to becoming sexually straight because he already is a Christian. The counsel that
Klamecki gives would be in error if given to a nonbeliever: “Your body, emotions, and talents are some of
God’s greatest gifts to you and to others....And the Giver of gifts desires you to use those gifts in the way they
were intended. Especially our bodies. They must not be misused or abused, as they are the holy temple in
which he chooses to reside.”133 Naturally, one recalls the parable of the talents but even more so 1Cor 6:15-20
while reading this counsel. This passage from 1Cor 6 teaches that believers should honor God with how they
conduct themselves sexually because their bodies are holy temples in which God resides in the person of the
Holy Spirit. Thus, Klamecki’s counsel is excellent for a believer, but only for a believer. The point of the
passage is that believers’ bodies are temples of the Holy Spirit, so believers should honor God with their bodies
for this special reason. This particular reason would not be true of unbelievers. God does not reside in
unbelievers. Nor are unbelievers holy temples. The counsel that Klamecki gives Dan is only applicable to
believers. Unless, Klamecki is giving false counsel, one would conclude that he considered Dan a believer.
       Second, the place of contact between Dan and Christ is of considerable interest: “Finally, I came out of

piece of information, misquoting it as: “You have not lived as I intended.” He should not have put his paraphrase
in quotes, nor should he have made the issue simply the way one lives. At the very least, one would think of the
parable of the talents where Christ gives spiritual gifts to believers for them to use in order to gain rewards
within Heaven, not entrance into Heaven (Mt 25:14-30). The Holy Spirit and eternal life are also gifts given
only to believers. Believers are allowed into Heaven because they have received the soteric gift of eternal life
(and the Holy Spirit). Dan’s being allowed into Heaven supports the proposition that he had received these
soteric gifts. After all, Christ affirms that Dan had, in fact, received the gifts which Christ had offered him.
Dan’s not being allowed into the innermost part of Paradise, in contrast, would be an issue related to rewards
and how he uses his talents.
       Fourth, Dan is not excluded from the kingdom altogether. Apparently, he is walking in the outskirts of
the kingdom. Rather, “it is not time” for him to come into the kingdom because of the way he was living.
Evidently, the way he was living would prevent him from accessing the innermost part of the kingdom, not the
outer part of the kingdom, and this is the reason it is not time for him to enter the part of the kingdom beyond
the fence.
       Fifth, Christ does not say that Dan needs to believe in Him for the free gift of eternal life. But this gift is
what is required to enter the kingdom soteriologically. Christ’s concern, therefore, appears to be limited to
misthological entrance, an entrance that this unfaithful believer was not qualified for at that point in time
because of the way he was living.
       Sixth, after his so-called “conversion,” to use Klamecki’s term, Dan simply says, “I have been cured of
my homosexuality. I am in a strong, supportive Christian community.”135 He does not say, “I have become a
Christian.” All evidence would suggest that Dan was a carnal Christian, living in a homosexual lifestyle until
his NDE. Afterward, he was converted from his homosexuality, to living in a manner consistent with his
Christianity. This believer in Christ apparently met Jesus in the outskirts of Paradise but needed to go back to
Earth and become a follower of Christ so that he would be ready to enter New Jerusalem, not merely the
outskirts of the kingdom, when the time came. The probability of this interpretation being correct is increased
when one observes that, according to following NDE account, for example, when Christ appears to unbelievers
in NDEs, He does not do so from within Paradise.
B. W. Melvin
       Melvin relates his NDE descent into Hell.136 The light at the end of his darkness was Christ. When he
encountered Christ in his NDE, he could “not blot out the shame and guilt of rejecting this person standing
before me” (p. 66). Christ told Melvin, “It is appointed once for man to die. When it is not that time, returning
is an option” (p. 67, emphasis his; cp. Heb 9:27). From this we may deduce that Melvin was an unbeliever.
Where did Christ meet Melvin? In Paradise? No. When Melvin emerged from the darkness to meet Christ (who
was the source of the light to which he was traveling through the darkness), he met Christ standing “upon a
round hewn rock jutting out from this black void” (p. 66). I would theorize that this meeting took place in
hyperspace between our universe and the heavenly outer realm. In other words, I speculate that it occurred in
the hyper dimensional void between our universe and Paradise. In any case, it was not in some beautiful garden;
it was not in Paradise. Next, Melvin was told to repeat His Name and Title, thus Jesus Christ, in the trial that
lay ahead. With that, Christ then opened up a tunneled vortex, into which Melvin entered and thus began his
journey in Hell.
       When Melvin initially arrived in Hell, he thought that he “had arrived in paradise.” People started coming

out of a “solid brick house on a hill” on a plain covered with “moldy-looking grass” to welcome him “as some
type of long lost friend.” They were laughing happily. “At first their enthusiastic welcome almost convinced
me that I was among friends in paradise,” Melvin recounts, “but a dank darkness behind their eyes betrayed
them; there was no love or compassion there.” “I thought I saw people I knew in this crowd” (p. 70). He quickly
discerned that “these were not people at all, but some type of creatures, masters of illusion and lies” (p. 71). A
demon takes Melvin on a tour of Hell because it has been granted to Melvin to see Hell. Melvin describes seeing
people being brought into Hell, who, like him, sometimes think that it is Paradise initially. Unbeknown to them,
upon arriving in Hell, each individual is placed in a 10x10x10 cube with some demons who create an illusion
and act out this illusion. The human souls trapped inside the cubes have no idea that they are in a cube. They
might think that they are in a room, grassy plain, or flower-covered fields, etc. Many, when they initially arrive,
think that they are in Paradise, but it is a counterfeit Paradise.
       Melvin’s description reminded me of the holodecks on Star Trek used for simulated reality. No matter
where you moved, even if through a door appearing to be to another room, you remained in the cube, though
you would have no idea that this was the case if you were inside the cube. Because Melvin was looking from
outside the cube, he could see what was actually happening, as well as the illusion that was being experienced
inside the cube. “Every person was imprisoned in his or her own private prison. All were in varying degrees of
anguish, according to the deeds and actions done in life” (p. 80).
       The individualization of punishment based on degrees of performance is a reasonable biblical
expectation. The timing is surprising perhaps, in that this personalized punishment is being experienced in the
intermediate state and, therefore, presupposes that some form of preliminary judgment already has occurred.
However, it is judgment without a judge, an impersonal judgment, in that the individuals evidently have not yet
appeared before God to be sentenced to some personalized punishment in Hell; otherwise, they would have
known that they were in Hell. This proposition is plausible, nonetheless, because unbelievers do not stand before
God for the individualized judgment until the Great White Throne judgment, which is yet in the future. Still,
my initial reaction was to be skeptical because, from the biblical account of the rich man and Lazarus, I would
have expected those in Hell currently to be in flames (Lk 16:24). Melvin had the same expectation. However,
Melvin sees some people in these hellish cubes currently “in darkness or flames” (p. 162). Therefore, partial
harmonization with the biblical account is possible. Although the rich man in Lk 16:24 was in flames, this does
not mean that every person in Hades is currently in flames. That aspect of his account is easily harmonized.
What is not readily harmonized, though, is hellish NDErs who do not describe cubes. Were they placed in cubes
without realizing it? Perhaps. But if so, Melvin’s claim that those inside the cubes could not see outside the
cubes poses a problem with the biblical record. If the rich man was inside such a cube, then how would he have
been able to see outside the cube? On the other hand, if Melvin was only shown a portion of Hell, which seems
to be the vague impression given by Melvin’s NDE, then perhaps the rich man was in a different portion of Hell
where punishment was handled differently. Or perhaps the nature of punishment was changed when Christ led
captivity captive at the time of His crucifixion and resurrection. He removed Paradise, the abode of OT
believers, from Hades to Heaven at that time. Perhaps other changes were invoked as well.
       Regardless, if unbelievers are undergoing a preliminary sorting and punishment according to their degree
of works, being slowly conveyed to the Lake of Fire of the final judgment which can be seen in the distance as
Melvin describes (p. 180), then misthological symmetry would suggest that believers also are undergoing some
sort of impersonal preliminary judgment as they await the Bema. For example, if some believers are clothed in
white and some believers in Heaven are not clothed in white, then preliminary distinctions are possible. Further,
if some believers already are living in their heavenly mansions, as the NDE data repeatedly attests, then they
must have been assigned their mansion according to their works, even before the cooperate Bema occurs.
       One intriguing part of Melvin’s observations regarding the initial misimpression is that his experience
would explain, to some extent, the discrepancies being reported by NDErs: “I saw many souls arrive in this
place thinking that they had arrived in paradise only to discover a hellish reception. Others immediately awoke
to anguish” (p. 88). This discrepancy reminds me of some of the research going on regarding UFOs. Some UFO
phenomena appear to be attributable to demonic forces. Part of their deception is to discredit UFO research by
introducing discrepancies. Because of seeming inconsistencies, the legitimacy of UFO research is discredited
in the minds of many. Some ufologists (researchers into UFOs), however, have discerned that demonic forces,
trying to throw the proverbial monkey wrench into the research, would purposefully introduce apparent
contradictions. Consequently, trying to sort through intentional disinformation, both by natural and supernatural
sources, is part of the research.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                              Page 55
        It stands to reason that masters of illusion seeking to hide their tracks in the related field regarding NDE
research would seek to throw investigators off track by introducing intentional discrepancies as well. Of course,
this would not be the only reason for the discrepancies. Thanatologists (researchers into death) also have other
hypotheses to explain some of the discrepancies. For example, deception seems to be less likely and less
frequent in cases of terminal illness. A return with an Omega Message may be less probable in that case, so
fallen resources may be devoted to areas where a return from the beyond is more likely so that a false message
can be propagated. The fallen forces, although numerous, are not infinite. Plus, their cloak of deception might
be perforated at times by forces of Christ who give genuine revelations. Melvin’s experience might be such a
perforation. Christ may have allowed this unbeliever to travel to Hell and back and see behind the scenes so
that he could report what he saw and thus unmask, to some degree, the deception that is occurring. Could those
experiencing the alleged BOL during a NDE actually be placed unknowingly in a cube where they are taken
for a ride? Even if they are not placed in a cube, they could easily be subjected to deception in the astral plane
by forces who are very adept at such deception. If fallen forces can pull off this level of deception with only a
10 x 10 x 10 box, imagine what level of deception they would be able to produce with an entire astral plane at
their disposal.
        Consider, for example, the frequent claim among NDErs that they meet their loved ones as proof that
their NDE experience is free of deception. Melvin describes a man who, when placed “inside his box like a
cell,” thought that his experience was genuine because he was supposedly greeted by his loved ones: “Upon his
arrival several creatures entered into his cube. These spectators gave the appearance of friends and loved ones”
(pp. 90-91). If these masters of deception can appear as friends and loved ones inside these cubes, then certainly
they can in the astral plane as well.
        As to the frequent claim among NDErs that the Being of Light that they encounter is also a Being of Love
(so that BOL could stand for either or both), Melvin describes a purple creature that kept following him in Hell
that used deceptive love as its ploy:

            It was beautiful and could give illusions of being something else with great ease when
      welcoming some new arrival to this hellish domain....
            This creature was crafty and beguilingly beautiful, and often emitted illusions of itself as
      a great loving being. The love that this creature used to deceive with also had a certain kind of
      benevolent malice mixed in as well. It was a love that was all puffed up and did not pierce one’s
      soul.
            This entity’s favorite ploy was to expound that all roads lead to God in baited half-truths.137

Love is a lure, the bait on the hook. Many unsuspecting souls will swallow this lie and be lured to their eternal
death by this BOL.
       Once Melvin emerged from Hell, he was back “upon that great hewn rock from whence the journey had
begun.” Evidently, this rock was in hyperspace. To its left were the pit of Hell with cubes being conveyed to a
lake of fire outside it. To its right was “a beautiful city....a new city and lands” (pp. 180-182, italics his). Once
again, as is typical, we find confirmation of a literal city and that Heaven is not limited to this city but includes
the lands were the city resides. This unbeliever encountered Christ outside those lands, again confirming the
impression that those who encounter Christ within those lands are believers. Melvin’s book is an excellent read
for those who want a plausible expose concerning the intermediate state of the deceived and dammed.
Gary Stearman
       Stearman poses five migratory locations for Paradise: (1) Emerald Eden, (2) Earthly Eden, (3) Hadean
Eden, (4) Heavenly Eden, and (5) Heavenly City.138 The fourth location is of significance for the current study.
Paul was caught up to “the third heaven...into Paradise” (2Cor 12:2-4). If this Paradise is currently outside of
the Heavenly City and believers go to Paradise when they die currently, then they are outside of the Heavenly
City. Crawford’s model would be correct in that case. Alternatively, in my classical model I posed that when
Paradise was moved from its hadean compartment, it was moved to the Heavenly City. To be sure, it will

experience a fifth and final move, but it will do so because it is in the city and the city will move to Earth. My
proposal seems to be in better accord with Stearman’s own assessment: “At some point, the New Jerusalem
was sufficiently complete to receive the tree [of life]. From our perspective, this probably happened after
Christ’s Resurrection, as He rose to heaven” (p. 118). Since the Tree of Life was in the Earthly Eden and moved
with Paradise to the subterranean location at the time of the flood, it stands to reason that when the Tree of Life
was moved from that hadean location to New Jerusalem that Paradise was moved to the same location. Posing
that Paradise was transferred to outside New Jerusalem while the Tree of Life was transferred inside of New
Jerusalem only to be transferred back inside New Jerusalem later adds needless complexity. More likely,
Paradise and the Tree of Life (which was in Paradise) were both transferred to New Jerusalem at Jesus’
ascension into Heaven, making New Jerusalem the more probable location of the current inhabitants of
Paradise. Nevertheless, I am open to the possibility that Paradise might be inclusive of the area in Heaven
outside the Heavenly City, while the Tree of Life is confined to the Heavenly City. Thus, the Caulian-
Crawfordian model is plausible.
Gordon Lindsay

                                                 Forerunner
      Writing in 1973, Gordon Lindsay in his book, Abode of the Righteous Dead, has beaten Crawford and
me to the punch line and is, therefore, the forerunner of the model being adopted and adapted herein. After
spending years developing various models, I came across this little booklet by Lindsay, which well anticipates
the Caulian-Crawfordian model that I already had developed independently of Lindsay’s discussion,
demonstrating once again that there is nothing new under the sun.

                                                    Marietta Davis
       Lindsay gives an overview of Marietta Davis’ classic work, drawing his conclusions from Scripture and
her NDE, as collaborated by the NDEs of others. He correctly notes that “the floral plains were only outer
regions of the habitation of the sanctified. They [Marietta and her escorting angel] continued their journey until
they reached the central city of the infant paradise.”139 Lindsay and I have a slightly different take on Marietta’s
location of Infant Paradise, however. In Lindsay’s understanding of Marietta’s book, “Paradise is not in the
throne of heaven, but it is in the vicinity” (p. 14). One can see from my reconstruction that I perceive Marietta’s
NDE differently.140 While it is true that Infant Paradise is not the throne of Heaven but near it, the throne of
Heaven is a part of the more comprehensive Paradise in my reconstruction of Marietta’s model. Lindsay also
relates: “Those who have been favored with a vision of paradise often speak of a central city. Marietta tells
about seeing the city of the infant paradise. This is probably different from the city or cities of the saints” (p. 15).
True, they are different, but, as I perceive it, Infant Paradise is located in the lowest level of the Heavenly City.
Just as Paradise is composed of many paradises, so the Heavenly City is composed of many cities. Marietta,
being an unbeliever, could only see this one city at the lowest level of the greater City. Many other cities
probably populated this lower level as well, not to mention the upper levels of the Heavenly City. Like
Stearman, Lindsay observes that before Christ’s resurrection, Paradise was always down. Afterwards, it was
always up (p. 21), correctly deducing that it had been moved.
       Lindsay makes an interesting proposal about those made perfect in Heaven: “As regarding a subject we
have considered earlier, the saints who have been in heaven or paradise for a considerable time, [sic]
have now reached a state of perfection. Hebrews 12:22-23 indicates that they live in their heavenly
Jerusalem and that their spirits have been made perfect” (p. 23). According to such NDEs, believers start
out on the lower level when they first arrive and only move up to the upper levels after maturation. Earlier,
Lindsay correctly had observed: “Her [Marietta’s] description relates almost entirely to the infant paradise and
not the paradise of men and women who have reached maturity” (p. 17).
       First, note the minor inconsistency. Lindsay acknowledges that those who have reached maturity live in

after being in Paradise for a period of time. This proposition is plausible. Additionally, it accords with other

                                    Misthopology in the Eternal State
      The major point, however, is Lindsay’s third assessment:

             The great City, the New Jerusalem, the overcomers eternal home, some 1500 miles in
      extent....is that to which Jesus referred when He said, “I go to prepare a place for you.”...It appears
      that the abode of each saint will be prepared in some relation to the reward he has earned by his
      work on earth.
             Certainly there will be a place for each one who wins the prize. Those who loiter should
      remember the warning of Jesus, “Hold that fast which thou hast, that no man take thy crown”
      (Rev. 3:11)....
             We close with this thought that we have written elsewhere:
             “In the new heaven and new earth there will be two main orders of human beings: those
      who have been found worthy to dwell in the New Jerusalem—those who reign with Christ
      throughout the ages of eternity. Distinct from this order will be the nations of the earth that will
      walk in the light of the New Jerusalem. (Pp. 31-32)

       Splendid! Lindsay correctly understands that “some will have a great reward; others will have a meager
one. Some, alas will have no reward....Such persons will be saved as by fire [1Cor 3:15]. They are saved and
share a place with the redeemed, but...will not share the joy that others have” (p. 26). But even “the lowest
member of the church would never go to sheol or hades” (p. 20). If I may take Lindsay at face value, and every
indication is that I may, this would mean that Lindsay correctly anticipates that in the eternal state unfaithful
believers will not share the joy of dwelling in New Jerusalem but neither will they be sent to Hades; moreover,
following the Bema they will “never” (thus not even during the intermediate state) be sent to Hades. His book
excels in excellent misthopology!

                                              Bridal Misthology
        He continues, “The most important reward will be the position of nearness to Christ....There will be those
who are reckoned as the attendants of the Bride (Matt. 25:1-13). There will be those who make up the bridal
company itself” (emphasis his, 28). “Paul sees that there is a supreme prize ahead for those who win the
race....To win brideship with Christ is the highest and greatest prize that heaven can offer” (p. 29). In this
context overcomers are the saints who are found worthy to “rule under Christ” (p. 30). They will be the ones
who are “found worthy to dwell in the New Jerusalem” (p. 32). Dwelling in New Jerusalem is a reward limited
to bridal saints, that is, to overcomers. Brideship is equatable with rulership, and regency with residency.
Unfaithful believers, accordingly, must live outside the bridal city in Lindsay’s assessment. His bridology
(doctrine of the bride) is right on target!

                                     Misthopology in the Intermediate State
      Lindsay’s delightful little book even goes on to deduce, correctly, that we will inhabit galaxies throughout
the universe (pp. 24, 30, 32). About the only thing missing from Lindsay’s treatment is an explicit
acknowledgment that unfaithful believers are not living now in the Heavenly City in Paradise during the
intermediate state. However, Lindsay has given us the raw materials by which to derive that conclusion for
ourselves from the Scripture itself:
      22
        But you have come to Mount Zion and to the city of the living God, the heavenly Jerusalem,
      and to myriads of angels, 23 to the general assembly and church of the firstborn who are enrolled
Page 58                                                                           Misthological Models Part 4
      in Heaven, and to God, the Judge of all, and to the spirits of righteous men having been made
      perfect. (Heb 12:22-23; TM)

       The spirits currently dwelling in Heavenly Jerusalem are the spirits of those who belong to the church of
the first-born, which is a misthological theme limited in its realization to overcomers. Those believers who
dwell in this city are those who have been made perfect (perfect participle) during their time in Heavenly
Jerusalem during the intermediate state. Lindsay took us this far and then jumped ahead to the eternal state
to indicate that only overcomers will inhabit New Jerusalem during the eternal state; others living in the
kingdom during that time will live outside the capital city.141
       The only thing left to be deduced is that only overcomers dwell in the Heavenly City during the present
intermediate state. Lindsay already has reached this conclusion explicitly during the eternal state. Moreover,
he has given grounds to anticipate this will be the case during what we might call the future intermediate state
following the Bema before the Lord returns in the Second Coming to set up His millennial kingdom on Earth.
Because dwelling in this city presently is implicitly associated with a clear misthological theme and with a
misthological maturation during the current intermediate state in this passage of Scripture, the most reasonable
conclusion is that dwelling in the city is limited to bridal overcomers during the intermediate state, which
certainly will be the state of affairs during the eternal state (and all the time in-between).

upon the misthological nature of the city, even during the intermediate state in Heb 12:23, I have come to

John Burke
       The next book documenting NDE that I read months later was by John Burke, Imagine Heaven. I had
not planned on doing any further reading along this line for the present book, but one of my readers had seen
an interview on T.V. pertaining to Burke’s book and recommended that I compare his findings with mine. I am
glad I did. By this time, I had finished the rough draft of my next two chapters in the present book and added
an excursus, after reading books on Heaven by Marrow and Kreeft.142 Unlike those two books, Burke’s book
was basically an analysis of the NDE phenomena. Just like my present chapter. Burke notes that some people
in Heaven wear white robes and some do not. Some just wear the clothes that “they felt most comfortable in on
earth” (p. 63). He posed a theory:

             After reading so many of these accounts, I have a theory. It’s just a theory but follow me. I
      think we will find we can clothe ourselves in what feels natural, so people from different times
      and cultures will wear what felt comfortable to that time. However, many NDErs report people
      dressed in robes of white. Reading this I thought, I don’t won’t to wear a white robe forever! Then
      I contemplated what this “white robe” might signify to make it so special....
             So here’s my theory. Maybe people want to wear the white, translucent “robes” you’ll hear
      so many describe because it shows off how much they share in God’s glory.” We dress on earth
      to show off our physical “glory” or the physical attributes we want noticed. What if in Heaven,
      what we want noticed is how much the light/glory of God shines through us? NDErs note this
      translucent body seems to be able to “shine” or radiate a light that comes from within, and different
      people radiate different degrees of brilliance. Maybe the “white” robe isn’t white at all, or even a
      “robe” as we know it, but what it means to be clothed in God’s glory. (Emphasis his, 64-65).

       I would amend Burke’s theory by suggesting that those inside the city wear white robes or at least are
capable of wearing white robes when they so desire. One NDEr is given a tour of the city and reports, “I was
taken to a grand auditorium. Everyone was clothed in glowing robes, and as I entered into the arena, I found I
was clothed in a robe also” (p. 307). But those who live outside the city are only capable of wearing bright
clothes, not white robes. Another NDEr describes those in the countryside wearing “simple yet beautiful clothes,
and it seemed to me that the colors of these clothes had the same kind of living warmth as the trees and the
flowers that bloomed and blossomed in the countryside around them” (p. 270). Living quarters are found inside
and outside the city, as Burke relates: “From the composite picture I get from many NDErs, there are homes in
the country, homes in the mountains, homes in quaint villages, and homes in the City of God” (pp. 271-272).
Burke makes a reasonable suggestion that “maybe we will have multiple homes to enjoy” (p. 273), though I
would be inclined to pose this option for only overcomers, not for subcomers. Overcomers could have homes
both inside the City and outside the City, for example, but subcomers could not. In short, my theory is that
overcomers wear white robes, at least when they so desire. Perhaps they only do so on special occasions.
Whether they do so at all times while they are inside the City is open to conjecture. If so, perhaps their wearing
white robes is optional outside the city. On the other hand, subcomers are unable to wear white robes at any
time because their bodies do not generate enough light to create white robes. Indeed, Burke comes to the
threshold of making this same deduction:

            Everyone in Heaven will see the Lord and experience the joyful bliss so many NDErs have
      described, but I’m not sure that everyone will be equally close in the same way. One person
      surmised that our love and faithfulness to God on earth determines our capacity to experience him
      in Heaven. People who love God deeply are deeply moved in his presence, while the ones who

             But I’ve also noticed how some NDErs knew they could not yet go to the City of God.

        My hypothesis is that these outer environs of Heaven are the outer darkness of Matthew. Could people
weep there? Yes. After being rescued from Hell, Howard Storm could not get closer than these outer environs
either. “So we stopped where we were, still countless light years away from the great supreme being in heaven,
I cried from shame, and he [Jesus] comforted me” (p. 281). The radiant beings could come out to Storm, but he

        When Gary Wood approached the city, the angels had to check the Books of Works to see if he would
be permitted to enter the city, which confirmed my conclusions (pp. 254-255). Going beyond my anticipation,
however, Burke reports that all of our works are recorded, even our future works, but the latter needed special
permission to be seen (pp. 255-257). My own research had led me to conclude that our preconversion sins could
be taken into account misthologically, so I was not surprised by this finding. Also, I had come to conclude that
the names of those who would inherit heavenly mansions already had to be recorded in advance in a Bema
Book or the Lamb’s Book of Life, but any such book was not readily accessible to everyone. Thus, this NDE
conclusion, that the future works are recorded and were only accessible with special permission, is pretty much
a confirmation of my own exegetical and logical deductions.
        Later, Burke records a vision of Heaven by Ed Gaulden. The surprising thing about this vision is not that
it posed that the city was surrounded by the land called Paradise, which is a frequent NDE affirmation, but that
both the land and the city were in a large golden sphere with a diameter about twenty times the size of the city.
At other places in my writings, I already had concluded that New Jerusalem would be enclosed in a temporal
displacing, cloaking, biosphere. Thus, the only thing really new from this NDE was that the city was already in
the sphere. However, this makes sense if the city already has localized temporal displacement in place, that is,
if it is in a time bubble that can accelerate or slow down time within the sphere. Moreover, I already had
projected that the outer darkness would be in the outlying planets, not on Planet Paradise. My model, therefore,
reconciles the remote outer environs with the land of Paradise. Indeed, I would speculate that Planet Paradise
serves the function of what I called the Twilight Zone in TOD.143 Burke appropriately remarks that the city was
created as a place where God can dwell with those who love Him (p. 290). Not all believers love the Lord, so
it is reasonable to conclude that not all believers will live in the city.144 Overall, Burke’s book has many useful
