Ian McCormack
       As a result of reading Burke’s analysis, I bought about eight more books on NDEs, choosing some of the
more interesting ones that he had cited. I find it a healthy practice to go back and double check the findings of
others whom I am citing on critical matters, and Burke’s claims were worth the double check. Several interesting
testimonies of Heaven were recorded by Doucette, whom Burke had cited, so I started there. The first testimony
was by Ian McCormack. When he reached Paradise, he described it as a new planet, a new Earth:

      I could see looking out from this entrance, incredible green fields, meadows, fields opening up
      from this entrance, incredible green fields, meadows, fields opening up before my very eyes. As I
      looked out, it looked like a new planet, I could see a crystal clear stream working its way through,
      it was like earth but untouched, you know what I mean, like a totally new Earth.145

       This testimony confirms the Planet Paradise hypothesis. One might suspect that since the things on Earth
are a shadow of what is in Heaven, perhaps Earth itself is a 3D shadow of Planet Paradise. After his NDE, he
read the entire Bible in six weeks in order to try to gain a better understanding of the experience. McCormack
expresses his new found understanding in a conversational way, as him speaking to God and God speaking
back to him:

            I said God, then what’s this thing, I seemed to leave my body or something. He said
      Ecclesiastes 12 verse 7 when a man dies, his spirit leaves his body and returns to God. His physical
      body, God says, is mere ash and dust. I said I seemed to go through darkness, where is that
      mentioned in the Bible. He said, Acts 26 verse 18, Jude chapter 1, Second Peter chapter 2, there is

(p. 125). The Being of Light (BOL) seems to be Jesus in the majority of the cases (p. 141-144, 162ff, 211-212).
The only thing necessary to be saved is to believe in Jesus, per Jesus (p. 146), though Burke unfortunately
would seem to add more (p. 169). Jesus has blue eyes (pp. 185-186). Jesus in not limited to one location (p.
147). Guardian angels (p. 195). Despite the claim of one NDEr that there is no negative emotion or regret in
Heaven (pp. 195,197), others say that they experience shame (p. 281). Personally, I do not think that there is
any lasting profound regret or profound shame in the intermediate state. That level of regret would be reserved
for the Bema. I disagree with Burke’s opinion that we could still theoretically sin in Heaven (p. 215). Salvation
by grace apart from works appears apparent in the testimony of one NDEr (p. 228). His hypothesis that
unbelievers could still choose to be saved during the NDE sounds reasonable since they are not yet actually
dead (p. 231-233). Even believers can be shown a tour of both Heaven and Hell (p. 233). Being shown Hell
might be more misthologically effective than showing them the outer darkness is my hypothesis. Though Hell
is not soteriologically possible for believers, the outer darkness is misthologically correlative to Hell. Believers
can more readily grasp eternal misthological implications of the outer darkness if they are shown its correlative
counterpart. The same Gehenna that applies soteriologically to unbelievers applies misthologically to unfaithful
believers. As Burke surmises, “The life review NDErs experience seems to be a preview. It’s not the judgment”
(p. 243). Similarly, I would hypothesize that a preview of Hell does not mean that a believer will be sentenced
to Hell at the judgment. But being shown a preview of Hell communicates the seriousness of the judgment to
those believers who are misthologically obtuse. Such a hypothesis would be out of Burke’s reach since he
wrongly, or at least inconsistently, limits the discussion to the unconditional nature of God’s love in relation to
judgment and assumes that the Bema has no judicial element but is merely an “awards ceremony” (pp. 252-
253) and that “we will all be equally loved and valued” and like “cups with different capacities” all “overflowing
with God’s love, joy, and excitement” (p. 271). Nonsense. His own findings and conclusions show the
shallowness of such conclusions. He should have remembered his own advice, that NDErs are not necessarily
the best interpreters of their own experiences. Moreover, even he acknowledges that all believers do not
experience the same degree of intimacy with God or depth of love (pp. 278-280). (In any event, see my books
TOD and RAE and MMP1 for refutation of equal-love and full-cup misthology.) The Spirit is the River of Life
(pp. 308-310). “The Throne Building was huge...several hundred miles wide and at least fifty miles tall, and it
had a doomed roof” (p. 316).

        Associating Ecc 12:7 with OBE is certainly nothing new, but it was new for McCormack. He was clueless
as to this association before this event. Associating the postmortem darkness that McCormack experienced with
Acts 26:18; Jude 1:6; and 2Pet 2:4,17 is certainly reasonable. I am certainly not going to object to assigning
postmortem value to the valley of the shadow of death in Ps 23:4. Indeed, I have argued that it has misthological
applicability. In fact, what I garner from McCormack’s experience is that he was saved both soteriologically
and misthologically during his reciting the Lord’s Prayer. He was saved soteriologically by asking God to
forgive his sins. He was saved misthologically by forgiving others subsequently. Nevertheless, I am hesitant to
associate the misthological darkness with literal darkness such as what McCormack experienced. Thus, I was
impressed when he did not cite the outer darkness in either Mt 8:12; 22:13; or 25:30. My interpretation of these
passages is that the outer darkness is misthological and only secondarily soteriological via the principle of
correlativity. But the outer darkness at the misthological level would not be pitch black or shared with the
dammed in Hell. My arguments are highly detailed and complex, far beyond the range of a novice like
McCormack. Therefore, I was open to the possibility that the Holy Spirit was directing McCormack through
the hermeneutical minefield with a considerable degree of success as he tried to understand his experience.
        Still, I was reading cautiously, looking for discrepancies. And on the next page, he did refer to the outer
darkness: “I said God, a tunnel, where is that mentioned? He said, Matthew 7, 13 and 14 narrow and small is
the way that leads unto the presence of God, you found it; most find the broad way that leads to destruction
and outer darkness. He said, son, I took you along the highway of holiness.”147 According to McCormack, the
tunnel he went through in his NDE is described in Mt 7:13-14. It was a circular tunnel that took him from the
hellish pit of darkness in which he initially found himself up to light “in what appeared to be the center of the
universe.”148 Once again, I was having difficulty discounting this description because I have described the
narrow gate and path in TOD in much the same way, using the imagery of a tunnel and conveyer belt. So we
are independently using similar soteriological imagery. Moreover, his reference to “destruction and outer
darkness” is most peculiar. The biblical references to the outer darkness occur in Mt 8:12; 22:13; and 25:30.
There is no reference to the outer darkness in Mt 7:13-14. However, I would grant correlative applicability
between the passages. Not only does he not wrongly cite these three misthological passages as being directly
associated with this soteriological tunnel, even though the tunnel can have misthological applicability, he also
leaves out the definite article. He does not refer to “destruction and the outer darkness,” but only to
“destruction and outer darkness.” The lack of the definite article seems to be giving correlative applicability,
not exegetical equality. In short, McCormack, despite being a biblical illiterate surfer, has surfed his way
through razor sharp hermeneutical reefs so as to give a description of the outer darkness that meets the technical
specks in nontechnical language. What has taken me hundreds of pages to explain at the scholastic level, he has
accomplished in very simplistic language at a rudimentary level.
        Nonetheless, I retain a high degree of skepticism regarding the accuracy of his recounting his experience
on all counts. He espouses pseudo Lordship Salvation:

       My Son clearly taught He was the door of life; the door of life, the door to the sheep; John 10 verse
       7 to 9 and He said, those who came into Him shall be saved and go in and out and find green
       pasture.

love.150 And he immediately goes on to add: “I said, I saw a river, He said a river of life; I saw a totally new

away in an all consuming fire, it will melt, the elements will melt, but your spirit will pass through the fire and

They will qualify for misthological new birth. But soteriological new birth is conditioned simply on believing
in Jesus for eternal life. On the next page, McCormack gets this right: “He said, I am the resurrection and the
life, those who believe in Me, though they die yet shall they live” (Jn 11:25).152 Ideally, one should surrender
to Jesus as Lord in terms of performance and affection when one believes in Jesus for eternal life. Yet to make
the misthological ideal a soteriological necessity is a poisoned soteriology. Therefore, McCormack presents a
poisoned gospel. He unwittingly acknowledges that very possibility:

             I said, hundreds of people see that light, move along that tunnel, but don’t believe it’s you;

      people into believing there is something else. He said, even if an angel or another spirit would
      come and preach anything but Christ, let him be accursed because there are many spirits but there
      is only one Spirit that is holy, the same Spirit that rose my Son Jesus from the dead.153

       McCormack did not navigate that part of the coral reef successfully. Consequently, my confidence in his
ability to interpret all the details of his experience accurately is very low. Nevertheless, I will allow the
probability that his account is genuine overall. He has some growing to do in his understanding of his
experience, however.
Oden Hetrick
       The next testimony Doucette documents is by Oden Hetrick, a minister who sought for the Lord to take
him to Heaven for many years. Reputedly, the Lord then sent His angels to give him multiple trips to Heaven,
eighty in fact! Because I think such requests are unwise and may open one up to Satanic counterfeits, I am not
inclined to give his comments any credibility if they strain biblical plausibility to any degree whatsoever. That
said, here are some of the more pertinent statements:

             Interviewer: What does Heaven look like?

      you on the Mount.” Well that pattern was the city of Heaven, see? And so when Moses made this
      Tabernacle it had [1] a large outer court and inside of that it had [2] the holy place and inside of
      that [3] the most holy place. That’s the general layout of the whole thing.

        Naturally, some learning goes on in the outer environs, but the growth accomplished there does not
qualify them to pass beyond the barrier separating them from the holy place. Counter wise, those who live in
the holy place learn and grow so that they can reside in the most holy place. Such statements are consistent with
biblical expectations and other NDEs. He says that everyone has a golden crown representing eternal life. To
be sure, the Bible talks about the crown of life, but it is a reward conditioned on faithfulness: “Blessed is a man
who perseveres under trial; for once he has been approved, he will receive the crown of life, which the Lord
has promised to those who love Him” (Jam 1:12). “Be faithful until death, and I will give you the crown of life”
(Rev 2:10). On the other hand, one can harmonize Hetrick’s claim with the biblical warning: “I am coming
quickly; hold fast what you have, in order that no one take your crown” (Rev 3:11). Having a crown is one
thing; being able to keep it is another. Perhaps unfaithful believers will be stripped of their crowns at the Bema.
After all, regarding the unfaithful servant at the Bema, Jesus says, “Take away the talent from him, and give it
to the one who has the ten talents” (Mt 25:28). If this is the case, the crown of life represents reward potential
of eternal life, the potential to rule; however, the realization of this potential is conditional on one successfully
passing the Bema.
        Hetrick’s daughter, Lois, who also claims to have visited Heaven, immediately adds a comment to Oden’s
statement regarding Rev 21:12 above: “And no matter what each person gets, each person is completely happy
and there’s a lot of laughter and happy fellowship in heaven. Everyone is happy with what they received.”158 I
already had postulated both possibilities. In addition to all believers initially have a crown in the intermediate
state, they might also be happy with having this crown and being in Heaven. What Oden and Lois fail to realize,
however, is that the Bema will overturn both. Unfaithful believers will lose their crowns and weep as a result—
at the Bema, after the marriage feast already has started—(Mt 25:30).
        Oden may be speaking more accurately than he knows when he goes on to add: “He built a beautiful city
for us to go to. And we should by all means press on as the Apostle Paul did; press toward the mark for the
prize of the upward calling of God, that beautiful place [Phil 3:14].”159 Exactly! The Heavenly City is a reward,
a prize which we should strive to obtain, which is in fact what Paul was indicating. Not all believers will live
in the City. Unfaithful believers will live in the “outer environs,” as Oden calls them, or the “outer darkness,”
as Jesus describes it. They will not be in Hell, but in the suburbs which are outside of the city, as Oden correctly
surmises. Oden is standing on the very cusp of making this stupendous observation. Indeed, he has made it, but
not clearly or consistently. For he goes on to add in his concluding remark an ambiguous statement: “Friends,
I‘ve done my best to tell you the joys of heaven and I’m going there myself, I’m planning on it. And I know
that the only way to go there is to accept Jesus as savior and Lord and follow Him and with all my heart seek
after Jesus.”160 This statement smacks of pseudo Lordship Salvation, the hallmark of which is to confuse the
gift and reward aspects of Heaven. My perception is that Hetrick has given an accurate portrayal of Heaven,
but has not been able to interpret his experiences of Heaven with the precision that his own observations would
demand. His own statements would lead to the following conclusion:

             Following Jesus with all of your heart is necessary to live in the Reward City. Unfaithful
      believers do not follow Jesus wholeheartedly and thus do not have the works necessary to pass
      beyond the barrier to enter the Reward City. Therefore, they cannot enter the Reward City, much

         less live in it. Instead, they must live in the suburbs outside the Reward City. These results are
         eternal because, whatever growth they may experience while in Heaven, unfaithful believers will
         not be able to make up for their deficiencies in Heaven so as to be able to cross the barrier and

        This is my summation of Hetrick’s testimony in a nutshell. He is correctly affirming misthopology (the
reward nature of the City), though he does not communicate it clearly in his concluding invitation. The ideal
response is that believers not only believe in Jesus for eternal life but follow Him as Lord in the way they live
their earthly lives so that they can enjoy the full richness of Heaven and not be confined to the suburbs of
Heaven. Clearly, Hetrick attempts to derive this ideal response from what he thinks is the ideal invitation, but
in doing so he sacrificed clarity—a clarity readily derivable from his own testimony, however. Thus all is not
lost, if you read his invitation in the full context of his explanation.
Gary L. Wood

                                     Inconsistent Arminian Interpretation
       One of the next books I read, which had been cited by Burke, was A Place Called Heaven by Gary Wood.
The book has some soteriological deficiencies. Citing Mt 6:14-15, Wood states: “There are Christians who are
in danger of losing their forgiveness from God because of their inability to forgive others. This is serious! You
must realize that there is no place in heaven for those who are unforgiving, unloving, mean, rude, or unkind.
Never gossip.”161 This is a true statement if taken misthologically or misthopologically but false if taken
soteriologically. He seems to mean for it to be taken soteriologically. Thus, he teaches a false gospel. Once
again, those claiming experiences of Heaven are not necessarily the best interpreters of their experiences. Burke
was certainly correct in that regard. Wood also inserts a testimony by Terance Hopkins, which pictures Jesus
as teaching a false gospel:

                 I grew up in church, cut my first tooth on the back of a pew. I called Jesus, Lord, and
         believed that he died for my sins. I was baptized in water and with the Holy Spirit. I was saved at
         an early age. As I grew older, the temptations of the world drew me away from Jesus. I left Him
         for life on the wild side. Wine, women, and song; that was the path for me. Jesus newer leaves us,
         but we sure can leave Him. I never saw the train....
         ....The next thing I knew, I was standing in the very presence of Jesus. His power and glory more
         than I could stand, so I fell to the ground like a dead man. He lifted me up and said, “My son, I
         have work for you to do. If you do not wish to do the work that I have for you, then let me show
         you where you will be going with the way you have been living in the past.” As far as I could
         see, were pits of fire. It was so big, like a canyon with high, rocky walls. I saw thousands of people
         in hell.162

        So the book is using NDEs to promote Arminian soteriology by denying unconditional security, thus
conditioning salvation from Hell on works and the way you live. This book is teaching an accursed gospel. As
to the testimony by Hopkins that he believed that Jesus died for his sins, doing so would not constitute saving
faith, contrary to the opinions of many. Believing that Jesus died for your sins is not saving faith unless it is
coupled with the realization that by believing in Jesus for this forgiveness you realize that you are freely
forgiven eternally and thus unconditionally secure as a result. Therefore, one must trust in Jesus for the free gift
of unconditional security. This gift cannot be conditioned on performance. One must understand that this gift
is received by simple faith in Jesus as the giver, not by faith in oneself as the worker. Many Arminians are going
to wind up in Hell because they trust in Christ for performance-based probation rather than trust in Him for
eternal life as a free gift. Accordingly, one could deduce that Hopkins never believed and certainly
misunderstands what Jesus is telling him is necessary to be saved from Hell, or if he understands this so-called
Jesus correctly, then it is a fallen angel impersonating Jesus and giving misdirection.


161
      Gary L. Wood, A Place Called Heaven (Kingwood, TX: RevMedia Publishing, 2014), 41.
162
      Ibid., 49-50.

                                            BOL or LBOL or BOTG
       Nevertheless, we need not brush aside Wood’s experience as a forgery too hastily. A NDE does not make
one an infallible interpreter, either of the experience or the Scripture. Wood still might have had a valid
experience and related it reasonably accurately. Burke has done a commendable job of filtering out much of
the bad soteriology from these NDEs. In fact, Wood’s own observations would refute his works-based
soteriological interpretations:

      I saw hundreds and hundreds of volumes of books. Each book had a cover of beautifully carved
      gold with a single letter of the alphabet engraved on the outside. Many angels were there reading
      the contents of the books. John explained to me that these books contain a record of every
      person’s life that has ever been born, throughout all history. Everything we do here on earth
      is recorded in these books—good or bad—everything. I watched as an angel opened one of the
      books, and with a cloth, wiped the pages. As he did this, the page turned red and the writing
      vanished from the pages, leaving only a name. I asked what that meant and was told the red
      represents the cleansing from the blood of Jesus, your Savior. Names were transferred from
      these books to the Lamb’s Book of Life and sins were erased and remembered against you no
      more. The Lamb’s Book of Life is for those who have received everlasting life by asking Jesus
      to save them. Have you? Other books were shown to me that contained prayer requests, spiritual
      growth in the Lord, and a record of the number of souls that one had led to Christ. The books were
      all very detailed, as everything we do is known to God.
             John pulled a book from one of the shelves with my initials on the outside. It was the Lamb’s
      Book of Life. He laid it open on a table and found my name recorded in the book. Next to my name
      were the words, “Paid in full by the precious red blood of Jesus.” I praise God for what He did
      for me on Calvary. Because of His precious blood, I had a right to be in Heaven!163 (Italics his.)

       If all such works are removed soteriologically simply because you trust in Jesus to save you, then no
works are left to condemn. If all sins are paid in full by the blood of Christ, then their payment cannot be
conditioned on your performance. Your works and the way you live might be recorded in other books to be
evaluated misthologically, but all works are wiped out soteriologically. His Arminian theology is refuted by his
Arminian testimony. The only thing left to quibble about is that he says that the Lamb’s Book of Life is the
soteriological record. I have models that allow that possibility. But one model proposes that the Book of Life is
used soteriologically (and perhaps dualistically in a misthological capacity also) while the Lamb’s Book of Life
(LBOL) is used misthologically. One might speculate that Wood has not been entirely accurate in his
assessment if one prefers the latter model. Questioning Wood’s labeling is particularly reasonable since he
merely asserts that the book is the LBOL. Is this merely an inference that he drew from his own assessment, an
educated guess in other words? Other NDErs have made similar educated guesses and called these books the
Books of Life.164 Or one might speculate that the LBOL can also be used in a dualistic capacity. Wood states
that the angel had to check the books to ensure that he was qualified to enter the City:

      A giant angel was holding a sword while standing guard at the gate. He was at least forty feet
      tall. His hair was spun gold. Rays of dazzling, soft lights flowed from this magnificent being.
      Another angel came through the gate, and he was checking the pages of a book that he was
      carrying. He then nodded to the giant angel, confirming that I may enter into the city.165

       So a book outside of the gate of the City had to be checked to allow Wood to enter into the city. We
might generically refer to this book as the Book of the Gate (BOTG). But inside the city he finds the LBOL
where all his works are wiped away because his sins have been paid in full. He affirms that this soteriological
LBOL gave him “a right to be in Heaven.” In contrast, this BOTG gave him the right to be in the city. I postulate
that this BOTG factored his works into consideration.166 Consequently, a more precise designation would be

BOTG-W (BOTG-Works). Your works and the way you live determine whether you will be allowed to enter
the city. Your works and the way you live do not determine whether you have a right to be in Heaven. Being
allowed into Heaven is conditioned simply on believing in Jesus for salvation from eternal damnation. This
proposal harmonizes Wood’s testimony with that of Hetrick, who said that those in the outer environs in Heaven
were not allowed into the city because they did not have the works necessary to qualify them for entrance. Per
Wood’s own statements, I will accept his testimony as being soteriologically and misthologically reasonable
and harmonizable with Hetrick and reject the Arminian testimony that Wood offers by Hopkins.

                                              Spherical Satellite
      Unfortunately, Wood did not describe the “giant golden satellite” in this book. Burke has astutely
associated this with the golden sphere described by Gaulden. To get the context of this reference, I had to
consult the source actually cited by Burke, which was Wood’s testimony in another book:

             Then the swirling mass of a funnel-shaped cloud opened up wide and I saw a giant golden
      satellite suspended in Heaven. All earthly things are built upon something, but God has this city
      suspended in Heaven because there’s nothing on earth that could hold it. When I approached
      Heaven, there was an angel with a sword who granted me access into Heaven. Then I was
      actually standing on the outside of the city, on a lush green carpet of grass on a hill. I started
      walking up the hill.167

       Burke did very well to pick up on the association of Wood’s satellite with Gaulden’s sphere. You have
to piece together the details of Wood’s description to discern that this is indeed what he is describing. Yet
having to play detective to derive this conclusion increases the probability of its legitimacy.

Ed Gaulden
        Reading Gaulden’s book was a special treat because he drew pictures! After my trying to draw
composites of the major components that others were describing who had been to Heaven, I finally came across
someone who had made the visit and done that very thing! On the one hand, I wish I had read this book earlier.
It would have been a whole lot easier for me to come to this conclusion if I had had his picture in the beginning!
On the other hand, I am glad I did not have his picture to go by because my deriving a roughly analogous
composite through piecing together details from others gave me a greater openness to the possible credibility
of Gaulden’s account. Specifically, I had already designed Illustration 10. Subterranean Paradise moved to
Planet Paradise (p. 120) and related illustrations picturing the city on a green planet surrounded by other planets
before I read Gaulden’s book. Gaulden’s model is different from mine, but not too different.
        He was writing a book about Heaven and prayed a brief, ten-second prayer asking that God allow him to
see it firsthand. Reputedly, his prayer was answered when the Lord sent an angel to give him an OBE escort to
Heaven. Because I tend to be very suspicious of people who initiate a request to see Heaven, I would have been
inclined to discredit his experience if I had not already pieced together something similar as a result of my own
independent research. He was shown Heaven, then Paradise, then the Heavenly City. According to his testimony
Heaven is a golden, transparent sphere. Paradise is green land inside the sphere. The city is the cube-shaped
New Jerusalem, and it sits in the middle of the land. From a distance the land seems flat, but up close you can
see the hills and valleys. Being a former math major, I loved his mathematical estimates:

              From my perspective and distance upon the Mountain of Stars, Paradise appeared flat.
      However, when the angel and I flew up close, Paradise revealed ‘wrinkles’ that proved later in my
      visit to be hills and valleys. Paradise is a disk of thick land fitted inside the sphere. Its disk-like

             Beneath the disk of land, the angel indicated that the bottom half contained water, but not

      that you do not know about.” Then he offered this explanation of the water. “It is water that is not
      under God’s curse. God’s Word calls it the Water of Life. It is Living Water.”172

One of the most interesting details was his description of orbiting outer environs in the form of islands:

             On the outside of the golden sphere, there are bands of islands circling the sphere, such
      as like our Earth’s moon. The islands are different sizes and shapes and are irregular. Their
      general shapes were curved and oblong. Their orbits followed the roundness of the outside of the
      golden sphere. Some islands seemed smaller than New Jerusalem, while others could hold
      many cubical cities. Like the rings of Saturn, the floating islands orbit at the sphere’s equator.
      They extend outward, about half the diameter of the sphere....
             I could see that the general color of the islands were a dark and lush green.... The verdant
      lush color was because of the thick forests and grasslands.173

       Gaulden then provided a picture of the Sphere of Heaven that he had created using Photoshop. I have
adapted his illustration and drawn it to scale using his estimations provided in his comments. However, I added
water to the bottom half of the sphere, per his own comments.

George G. Ritchie
       Next on my reading list was the NDE book by George G. Ritchie. Burke had described Ritchie as having
to see the City from “the outer environs of Heaven.” I wanted to double check the context to make sure Burke
had dealt with it accurately. So I read Ritchie’s book. Burke had done a good job. Although Ritchie did not use
the term outer environs, this was an apt description and a way to alert the reader to Hetrick’s account, who did
use the term, and which shared some similarities in that regard.

             Now however, we seemed to have left the earth behind. I could no longer see it. Instead
      we appeared to be in an immense void, except that I had always thought of that a frightening word,
      and this was not. Some unnamable promise seemed to vibrate through that vast emptiness.
             And then I saw, infinitely far off, far too distant to be visible with any kind of sight I
      knew of...[ellipses his] a city. A glowing, seemingly endless city, bright enough to be seen over
      all the unimaginable distance between. The brightness seemed to shine from the very walls and
      streets of this place, and from beings which I could now discern moving about within it. In fact,
      the city and everything in it seemed to be made of light, even as the Figure [Jesus] at my side was
      made of light.
             At this time I had not yet read the Book Revelation. I could only gape in awe at this faraway
      spectacle, wondering how bright each building, each inhabitant, must be to be seen over so many
      light-years of distance. Could these radiant beings, I wondered, amazed, be those who had
      indeed kept Jesus the focus of their lives? Was I seeing at last ones who had looked for Him in
      everything? Looked so well and so closely that they had been changed into His very
      likeness?...[Ellipses his.] Even as I asked the question, two of the bright figures seemed to detach
      themselves from the city and start toward us, hurling themselves across that infinity with the speed
      of light.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                             Page 73
             But as fast as they came toward us, we drew away still faster. The distance increased,
      the vision faded. Even as I cried out with loss, I knew that my imperfect sight could not now
      sustain more than an instant's glimpse of this real, this ultimate heaven. He had shown me all
      He could; now we were speeding far away.174

        They left Earth and went into a void from which they could see the city at an immense distance. But
Ritchie was not allowed to go closer to the city. He had become a believer at age eleven, but by the time he had
reached twenty, the things of the Lord had become unimportant to him, which was the time he had this
experience as a result of an illness (pp. 22, 53, 62). Therefore, he rightly attributes his salvation from Hell to
his new-birth experience at age eleven, not to his post-conversion performance. Accordingly, this book exhibits
a sound soteriology and very good misthology. His leaving our present reality and arriving in a void sounds a
lot like the experience described by Marietta Davis. My conjecture is that this void is the hyperspace separating
our universe from the heavenly realm. This might be the outer limits of the outer environs of Heaven described
by Hetrick. NDErs describe the heavenly realm as having galaxies and planets. If Ritchie had just entered the
edge of this heavenly realm on the other side of the hyperspace void separating our universe from Heaven, then
the two accounts harmonize.
Dale Black
       Dale Black’s book is one of those NDE books that contains his whole testimony, not just his trip to
Heaven and to the gate of the City. The book is a good read. He describes a huge gathering place inside the city:
“There was a huge gathering of angels and people, millions, countless millions. They were gathered in a central
area that seemed over ten miles in diameter. The expanse of people was closer to an ocean than a concert
hall.”175 If you can have a concert hall that big, then it should not be any problem to have a dining hall that big,
which would be large enough for everyone in the city.
Richard E. Eby
      Eby’s book is another NDE book that presents his life’s testimony, not just his trip to Heaven. For the
purposes of the present book, I just skipped to the short chapter describing his trip to Heaven, rather than read
the whole book. As a physician, his comments about the nature of his body are understandably detailed, but
what may be just as helpful is his insightful perception that God may customize the experiences. If so, we need
not expect the testimonies to be carbon copies:

             Being a physician, my first instinct was to inspect my new body, and I instantly admired it!
      It was mine alright. After 60 years in the old one it was easy to see that the new body was me. (I
      am sure that God included in this entire heavenly experience only those things which would
      be specifically meaningful to me, for proof and edification. He would give a different set of
      revelations to someone with a different background.) I was the same size, the same shape, as
      the person I had seen in the mirror for years. I was clothed in a translucent flowing gown, pure
      white, but transparent to my gaze. In amazement I could see through my body.176

Some variation among the testimonies might reasonably be allowed. Nevertheless, some variations require
critical examination and even refutation. He makes what might be considered a counterclaim to my thesis:

             My feet were easy to see. No bifocals needed. I had instantly noted that my eyes were
      unlimited in range of vision; ten inches or ten miles-the focus was sharp and clear. (“We shall
      mount up as eagles,” said King David—he was alluding to their pinpoint eyesight perhaps!) There
      were no bones or vessels or organs. No blood. I noted the absence of genitals. (How unneeded
      when in Heaven there is no marriage nor childbearing-His Body of believers being already
      completed!) The abdomen and chest were organless and transparent to my gaze, though
      translucent to my peripheral vision. Again my mind which worked here in heaven with electric-
      like speed answered my unspoken query: they are not needed; Jesus is the Life here. His is the

His description of this body and environment is not entirely persuasive, nonetheless, not even on the premises
that NDErs might have different experiences from one another. For one thing, he immediately proceeds to

      one on earth, minister or Bible teacher, had mentioned to me this heady perfume! Like the sight

       On the one hand, he claims that “there was no air,” while on the other hand, he acknowledges that “the
air was just the same.” Obviously, there was air, and he is breathing it in order to smell the aroma.179 But would
breathing air in not suggest internal organs, like lungs. Moreover, he affirms that his telescopic eyesight was
experienced through the means of his eyes. He had eyes in his head in order to see, why not lungs in his chest
in order to breathe? Plus, would his electrified mind not indicate an internal brain? Despite his claims to have
a quickened mind and intuitive knowledge, he is not thinking very clearly in making his deductions. There is
food to eat. Other NDErs eat from the various fruits. However, I would agree that, in that intermediate state,
they have no bones or blood. Jesus said, “A spirit does not have flesh and bones as you see that I have”
(Lk 24:39). But if Jesus has bones in the resurrected state, and those believers who have not yet been resurrected
do not have bones while in their unresurrected state, then we may safely deduce that they will have bones when
they receive their resurrected bodies. Yet, if they receive bones at that time, why not other organs as well, such
as genitals? Just because NDErs claim supernatural knowledge and mental ability does not mean that we should
take their interpretations of their experiences at face value. We must critically examine their claims against
Scripture and logic. Eby may have described his experiences accurately, but he certainly did not interpret them
accurately. A more precise assessment might be to pose that any internal organs are not observable.
Nevertheless, there seems to be at least some limited internal functions that would normally be associated with
internal organs. Therefore, I will postulate that any internal organs were transparent, which lead Eby to make
the mistaken impression that they were absent. But if the internal organs are invisible, one might speculate that
external sexual organs were also invisible.
       The postulation of invisible external sexual organs is implausible. For one thing, NDErs report seeing
both beautiful female angels in Heaven? Are they breastless? How about the beautiful female women reported
to be seen in Heaven? Are they breastless? Or would Eby’s statement about the absence of genitals only apply
to male genitalia? If so, why do angels in Heaven use their wings to cover their genital region if they have no
genitals? The postulation of an invisible penis seems preposterous. So how might Eby’s statement regarding
his absence of genitals in Heaven be harmonized with other NDE data that seems to refute such a claim, such
as reports of beautiful female women in Heaven and rape of humans in Hell during the intermediate state?
Proposed hypotheses about the intermediate state must be able to accommodate these various sets of data. If
intermediate bodies do not have sex organs, then how does one explain the occurrence of sexual rape in Hell?
       MSIH evaluates various possibilities in some detail, discussing not only sex in Heaven but also sex in
Hell. Sexual interaction in the intermediate state does not require sex organs. Since intermediate bodies have
not yet experienced the transformation associated with the resurrection, these spiritual bodies might function
like the spiritual bodies of those who project into the astral plane to engage in astral sex. Spiritual intercourse
between purely spiritual entities can exchange spiritual energies without the need of genitalia. Astral rape does
not require genitals. Yet spiritual bodies engaging in sex in the astral plane can form sexual genitalia, if they so
desire, as optional means of performing astral sex. (1) Since present-day testimonies confirm that this is the

       Sex may be broken down into three basic levels: (1) Physical intercourse is level-one sex and requires

Richard Sigmund

                                               Married Couples
      Sigmund’s testimony is included in Roth’s book of NDEs. One item that caught my eye from that
abbreviated account is Sigmund testifying: “I saw a three-level mansion of maybe thirty rooms. There I saw my
grandfather and grandmother sitting on the porch together talking to other people walking by. I wasn’t
allowed to talk to my grandfather, but he saw me and he waved and smiled a great big smile. That meant
everything to me.”180 His grandparents were living together as a couple in this mansion. His testimony is
collaborated by others that couples who have been married on Earth can live together as couples in Heaven.

                                               Air and Breeze
       Turning now to Sigmund’s own book, which has a very detailed account of his trip to Heaven, I will start
off by noticing something as mundane as the air and breeze: “And as I walked, the flowers faced me. The air
was filled with their aroma” (p. 22). “And there was a continual sound of chimes coming from the leaves as
they brushed against one another in the gentle breeze” (p. 24). Not only is there air to breathe, but it even
generates a breeze. His comments about eating are also detailed:

             When I touched the fruit to my lips, it evaporated and melted into the most delicious thing
      I had ever tasted. It was like honey, peach juice, and pear juice. It was sweet but not sugary. My
      face was filled with the juice from the fruit....Immediately, the juice from the beautiful, sweet
      tree’s fruit ran down my throat like honey. My face was just covered all with this beautiful,
      wonderful liquid that the fruit had turned into.181

There is food to eat, but evidently not to digest nor eliminate (pp. 75, 94). On this latter matter, Eby and Sigmund
appear to agree.

                                                      Books
       More pertinent to the present study are his comments about the books when he approaches the wall of
the city and other books that he finds inside the city. First, in natural order, he describes the books he finds at
the entrance to the city:

             The angel walking with me gestured and said, “Behold the wall.” The wall was tall, and it

       Sigmund introduces this discussion with a quote from Rev 3:5, which is a promise of reward to
overcomers in relation to the Book of Life. And he follows this discussion with a quote from Rev 21:27,
according to which only the pure will enter the city, which is certainly compatible with a misthological
understanding. Nevertheless, he does not seem to be fully aware of the misthological nature of what is occurring.
When the time comes for him to enter the city, two books were consulted. Surely, the mile-high book represents
the believers’ works, therefore the Book of Works (cp. Rev 20:12). When the LBOL is consulted, it not only
has his conversion experience but specifically designates him as being a “servant of God.” In other words, it
recognizes his service. But service would be meritorious and determined by his works. God apparently
customized this experience in such a way for Sigmund that he would not fail to report it, even though he does
not seem to fully understand it. His works had to be consulted to determine if he was a servant of God. The
bottom line is that he was a servant, as recorded in the LBOL consulted outside the gate, so he was allowed into
the city. Entrance into the city was a reward. At least while observing some of the more interesting mansions
in Heaven, he explicitly notes the misthological nature of one such mansion:

                I was taken to one house on the street on which I was walking. It was a single mansion
         carved out of a single, giant pearl. The house seemed to be two hundred fifty to three hundred feet
         across and one hundred feet tall.
                 The furniture inside had been formed by angels who had molded and carved the pearl into
         shape. Even the chandelier had been carved out of the pearl, and it was lit. It glowed from within.
                The house made of pearl belonged to a woman named Pearl, and the angels told me her
         story. She had been a missionary known for giving to the poor. Eventually, she had died of
         starvation. The house of pearl was a reward for a pure heart.183

       Her mansion was a reward. Of course, it was a reward. It is certainly not a gift! But the same would be
true of other mansions given to those in the city because of their service to God. That her mansion “was a
reward” almost goes without saying. The self-evident fact that the mansion is a reward is only mentioned in
passing by the angels, in connection with their explanation as to why the house is made out of a pearl. For the
rest of the mansions, it goes without saying that they are rewards. In order to be allowed into the Reward City
and be given a mansion within the city as one’s reward, some degree of pre-Bema judgment has to be performed.
Other books inside the city seem to be related to Bema judgement yet to come:

                I was taken into a very large building that had a huge archway. Inside were rows upon rows
         of shelves with books. The shelves seemed to be miles long and miles high, and the books looked
         about fifteen feet tall. There were hundreds of angels servicing the books. They were going in and
         out—there was a lot of activity....
                God keeps records, and this large building was the Archives of Heaven.

                   And I saw the dead, great and small, standing before the throne, and books were
                   opened. Another book was opened, which is the book of life. The dead were judged

      Ibid., 26.
183

Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                            Page 77
              according to what they had done as recorded in the books. (Revelation 20:12)

              The Archives of Heaven contain the different books about our lives, and these are the books
       that are taken to God when judgment time comes. The books are the records of our works here on
       earth. If a person sins, it is recorded in the book.
              I was given the understanding that when we repent, anything that we have done that was

       books. These angels appeared to be eight to nine feet tall, and they wrote in the books using a

       a book in his right hand and make the record with his left. I saw angels pull out books with their
       left hands and open the thick pages. In each page was something like a video screen, except the
       images were three-dimensional. The images contained the history of life. And the books were
       written—the pictures were created—before time.

              Your eyes saw my unformed body. All the days ordained for me were written in your
              book before one of them came to be. (Psalm 139:16)184 (Emphasis his.)

        The presence of multiple books and various types of books for each person is certainly reasonable. That
the sins of overcomers are wiped out, at least from the books pertaining to the result of the Bema, is a logical
deduction. After all, faithful believers will be misthologically blameless, composing a pure, virgin Bride. That
their lives might be recorded in their entirety in another set of books is possible.
        As a writer, I found Sigmund’s detail that the books we are currently writing on Earth are accessible in
Heaven to be an encouraging detail:

              The main libraries in these houses were lined with books that were embossed with gold.
       They were heaven’s pre-copies of books that have been written and that will be written in the time
       to come.
              Of the library at the Hegstrom home, Jesus said to me, “These books were written by My
       Spirit at the beginning of time. They were given to Paul Hegstrom to write on earth when he was
       there. You will meet him later. When you do, tell him that there is much to do and not to slacken
       the pace.185

                                               Clothing
      Sigmund sees clothing being produced in Heaven for the people who will soon be arriving and makes a
misthological connection:

               I believe that the garments were rewards that were being heaped up in heaven. In heaven,
       God rewards us for what we give on earth that is known only to Him. He-knows what we give in
       secret.
               Dress in heaven varied. Some people were dressed in some sort of pants and pullover shirts
       that were pure white. One outfit I saw was bright yellow, but I saw others of different colors. I saw
       people dressed in suits similar to what we wear here on earth but much more expensive looking. I
       also saw people dressed as one would think angels would dress—in long, flowing robes.186

       If he is correct, then all the clothing we wear in Heaven, or at least in the Reward City made in the manner

he describes, is a reward. If you have no rewards, would you be naked, as Jesus seemed to indicate in Rev 3:17-

on all occasions. Perhaps they would only be required to wear them on certain occasions, such as at the marriage
feast (Mt 22:11-12).

                                              Marriage Supper
       Sigmund’s description of the marriage feast seems entirely realistic, and by my calculations the pavilion
would be sufficient to accommodate all overcomers. What is new is the idea that the food and drink are already
ready. Since neither would spoil in Heaven, this proposal is logical:

                Then, Jesus turned to me and said to the angels, “Take Richard to My marriage supper feast,
         and let him see it. It is almost ready.” I was there before I could even think.
                I saw a building that was very tall. It had arched supports and columns that were about fifty
         feet apart. The tables where the supper feast was to be held were made of gold and inlaid with
         jewels. These tables were lined with chairs that looked like kings’ thrones. That is how they
         appeared to me, and I have no other words to explain the beautiful way they were constructed.
         The pavilion was about twenty miles long, in my best estimation! There were three rows of
         tables in a racking semicircle, with a throne in the background.
                Each chair had a name engraved on the inside of the back. I asked when they had been
         engraved, and the Lord said, “When their names were recorded in the Lamb’s Book of Life.”
                I grew silent and bowed my head with complete gratitude. Then, I raised my head and
         looked ahead of me. In that same instance, I saw my name engraved on one of the chairs. I wanted
         so much to sit in that chair, but Jesus said, “Not yet. It shall be sat in for the first time when My
         Father says, ‘Sit at the marriage feast of My Son.’ A virgin shall be given, and a virgin feast shall
         be given to a virgin Groom.” And again, I wept with great joy.
                There were goblets filled with sweet nectar from heaven. A golden dish was filled with
         heaven’s best. Everything was prepared to perfection. The marriage supper was ready for the
         Groom to make His entrance. There was room enough for multiplied millions of people.187

                                                 City and Cities
      The capital city is not the only city, naturally. So other people must live in these cities and countryside
outside of the capital city:

                From up in the air, I could see the City of God. I had seen other cites in heaven. For
         example, I had been shown an oasis that is a city on a peninsula extending out into the ocean. Yet
         the City of God appeared to be heaven’s capital city. It was built around the Throne and contained
         what looked like beautiful apartment buildings. I saw a waterfall coming off of one building. There
         were villages in the countryside surrounding the City of God. They appeared to be hundreds
         of miles from the outskirts of the city. These villages were of many different styles, just as there
         are around the world today. But all were clean and beautiful, with flowing fountains everywhere.188

       Would living inside of Heaven but outside the Heavenly City in the outskirts be what is described by the
Bible as the outer darkness, or might it be the twilight zone, so that those living outside the golden sphere
(described by others) will be the only ones actually in the outer darkness? When the Heavenly Jerusalem comes
down out of Heaven, will everything inside the golden sphere come with it, or will the city leave the sphere and
come in its own sphere? We have several valid possibilities for the outer darkness.

                                           Far Away in Two Ways
       Sigmund’s perception leaves plenty of room for the outer darkness in Heaven: “Supernaturally, I knew
that there were other continents, islands, freshwater oceans, and seas far away. The seas are large bodies
of water surrounded by land but open to the oceans. I was not allowed to know anything about them, but I knew

187
      Ibid., 48-49.
188
      Ibid., 83.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                              Page 79
they existed. To me, heaven seemed like a very large planet—millions of times the size of Earth” (p. 67). To
harmonize his intuition with the visual observation of others, I would propose that in actuality Heaven is
composed of millions of other planets. My deduction is that the outer darkness would be on these other planets.
My hypothesis is that those living outside the city but inside of Paradise may have a variety of housing options,
on mountains or by oceans, for example:

         I was then taken to an area near the crystal clear seashore. It was a city of homes that actually
         floated above the treetops. The buildings were smaller than some of the others I had seen but were
         magnificent to look at. I was told that some of heaven’s citizens desired homes on the seashore,
         and other places, as well. Then, there were those who wanted to have their homes anywhere that
         they happened to be. I marveled at the love of God. How He loves to provide our hearts’ desires
         when our ways please Him!189

       What about those believers whose ways do not please Him? Sigmund does not consider this possibility.
My hypothesis is that the believers he observers in his NDE do not fall into this category. Personally, I believe
that these unfaithful believers reside far away—outside of the city and, even more remotely, outside of Planet
Paradise—in the outer darkness described by Matthew. They are not in Sigmund’s preview. Instead, unfaithful
believers would be at the fringe locations that Sigmund supernaturally perceives. Inadvertently, Sigmund opens
up the door to this very possibility when he later quotes Jesus as saying, “My Father cast the evil one, and all
those who followed him, into outer darkness. They were cast far away from this perfect abode that I have
prepared for My bride of faithful believers” (p. 126). The perfect abode in Paradise, which Sigmund describes
in detail, is for faithful believers, that is, the Bride. But there are two types of places described by Sigmund that
are far away from this perfect paradisiac abode for faithful believers. A reasonable postulation is that the first
faraway place, which comprises the outer dimensions of Paradise, is for unfaithful believers. The second
faraway place, which is much further away and exists in a different dimension, is for unbelievers.

                                                  Howard Storm
        As an interlude, I note that Howard Storm, on the other hand, repeatedly describes the hellish place to
which he was taken as “the outer darkness.”190 I would allow that term as being an apt description of the place
to which he was taken. Nevertheless, I would insist that biblically the outer darkness, as Matthew uses the term¸
would only have a correlative association to the literal outer darkness described by Storm.
        Storm appears to teach a false soteriology conditioned on loving performance (p. 36). He refutes himself,
therefore, when he says, “We do not earn our love of God by the things we do. God’s love is given without cost
or strings (p. 37). He teaches a false eschatology when he asserts, via the information allegedly given by Jesus
and some angels, “There will be no more world wars” and “God will not allow a nuclear war” (p. 44). Nonsense.
Read Revelation. Supposedly, within the next two hundred years there will be no technology nor space travel
because people will be satisfied to communicate telepathically with intelligent beings on other worlds in other
galaxies and universes (pp. 45-46, 68-69). This postulation is preposterous. Mankind will rule the stars in the
multiverse because we will travel there, not just send telegraphs! Some unbelievers allegedly will experience
annihilation rather than eternal damnation (p. 53).
        Evidently, the Jesus portrayed by Storm does not believe Jn 3:16. For this so-called Jesus, salvation from
eternal damnation is accomplished by loving God and one another—not by believing in Jesus (p. 64, 67). Even
here, however, Storm cannot resist the temptation to contradict himself because at the same time he allows, in
passing, “When we trust him, he will raise us up to heaven” (p. 67, cp. 72). So, which is it, are we saved from
Hell by loving or by trusting? They are not the same. One religion is as good as another since, per Storm, all
religions are evidently pretty much the same (pp. 73, 128).
        Storm contradicts himself yet again, when in the midst of this long blander on God’s unconditional love,
he says, “God loves an honest agnostic more than a religious hypocrite” (p. 74). But if God loves one group
more than another because they are more honest than the other group, then being loved at this higher level is
conditioned on being honest. Therefore, God’s love is not unconditional. When explaining why Jesus had to
die, no need of the atonement is mentioned (p. 75). This so-called Christ and these so-called angels, according

189
      Ibid., 123.
190
      Howard Storm, My Descent into Death: A Second Chance at Life (New York: Doubleday, 2005), 21-23.
Page 80                                                                           Misthological Models Part 4
to Storm, assert: “Have no expectation of reward for loving” (p. 79). However, the biblical Christ taught the
opposite (Mt 5:46-6:18; Lk 6:35). Storm says that he received a new life because he called upon Jesus for
salvation and forgiveness—not because he was loving (pp. 108, 136). This contradicts his assertion that we are
saved by being loving. Yet he denies that we are saved by “trusting in Jesus” because he did this in his youth
and yet still wound up in Hell (pp. 131-132). He enjoins his readers to “ask the angels to teach us God’s will”
and to “invite the angels to show themselves to you” (pp. 140-141). I would caution my readers to do the exact
opposite. Storm’s experience was apparently hosted by fallen angels masquerading as angels of light
(2Cor 11:4). Those who pray to angels for direction and appearances can expect delusion. Given the repeated
contradictions within Storm’s discussion, we need not give any weight to his potential simplistic
misidentification of the outer darkness with Hell.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                           Page 81
                                  Illustration 8. (The) Outer Darkness
Page 82                                                                               Misthological Models Part 4
       Returning now to Sigmund, what is critical to note is that Sigmund, unwittingly perhaps, has used the
descriptive phrase far away in two different capacities. These other continents, islands, freshwater oceans, and
seas that make Heaven seem like a very large planet—millions of times the size of Earth—are the first items
perceived to be far away. I will refer to these as FA1. My hypothesis is that they comprise the outer darkness
as described by Matthew (8:12; 22:13; 25:30). This outer darkness is part of the heavenly realm.
       When Jesus takes Sigmund to “the other place,” “the place of separation,” Sigmund describes this second
place as far away also. This secondary far away place, which is outside of the heavenly realm, is distinguished
herein as FA2. According to Sigmund, Jesus does not refer to FA2 as “the outer darkness” but simply as “outer
darkness,” without the definite article, an anarthrous outer darkness (pp. 116, 119, 126). The definite article—
the—is missing. FA2 is not the articular outer darkness, not the outer darkness. Rather, FA2 is merely outer
darkness, a generic outer darkness, a correlative outer darkness, not the outer darkness specified by Matthew.

                                           Quasi-Omnipresence
        As to Jesus being everywhere, Sigmund attempts to explain what seems to be a quasi-omnipresence:

               In heaven, everybody has a turn to see Jesus directly, and, therefore, nobody is anxious
        about it. They are excited about the thought of seeing Him, but they are respectful of other people's
        turns to meet with Him; nobody tries to crowd ahead of anyone else....
               Yet this was the remarkable thing: though I could see Jesus ahead of me, I could not say
        that He was not also right behind me. He moved at what seemed to be the speed of light. There
        was only one of Him, but Jesus seemed to be everywhere at the same time. And I just wanted to
        be with Him.191

                                              Correct Soteriology
       Sigmund also attributes a correct soteriological perspective to Jesus, when the Lord took him on a tour
of Hell: “Jesus urged me to tell people what I saw. ‘I want you to tell others of this place and warn them that
unless they are washed in My blood, unless they are born again, this is where they will spend eternity’” (p. 117).
I am appreciative that Sigmund does not condition salvation from Hell on performance related issues, such as
loving the Lord and others.

                                               Limited Knowledge
       At this juncture, I might as well pull over to respond to objections regarding NDEs by John MacArthur.
Frankly, I find MacArthur’s blanket protests to NDEs to be very shortsighted. For example, he surmises, “There
is simply no reason to believe anyone who claims to have gone to heaven and returned. John 3:13 says, ‘No one
has ascended into heaven except he who descended from heaven, the Son of Man.’ And John 1:18 says, ‘No
one has seen God at any time.’”192 Such reasoning is very nearsighted, however. Did Paul not ascend to Heaven?
How about John? Certainly. Shall we use these comments from the Gospel of John to dismiss the book of
Revelation, both written by John? Of course, not! Better to reject MacArthur’s objections!
       MacArthur goes on to say, “Paul gave no actual description of heaven but simply said what he saw would
be unlawful to utter. In short, the biblical descriptions of Heaven could hardly be any more different from
today’s fanciful stories about Heaven.” In response, we may note that MacArthur’s pretending that it is unlawful
to describe one’s experience of Heaven is nonsensical. John described his experience of Heaven in the Book of
Revelation. Harmonizing Paul’s statement with John’s account is not that difficult. What Paul actually says is
that he “was caught up into Paradise, and heard inexpressible words, which a man is not permitted to speak”
(2Cor 12:4). Paul does not say that everything everyone hears in Heaven is inexpressible or impermissible to
share. Rather, only some heavenly things fall into this inexpressible category. A number of NDErs share that
they had limitations on what they could learn or recall. Sigmund excels in this detail:

•     “I saw that, as the children grew older, they began to attend school, just as they do on earth. But the schools

        Despite all the detailed information conveyed by Sigmund, my thoughts were, “Why should I desire a
trip to Heaven in the present to confirm my research so that I could write about it when it appears that the
information I would want to confirm by means on any such OBE or NDE would evidently be off-limits?” Many
of those who have been to Heaven and then returned to Earth have to struggle with depression afterwards
because they so strongly want to be in Heaven instead here on Earth. Frankly, given all the disclaimers that
Sigmund gave about the limitations placed on his knowledge, I am not sure that an intermediate trip to Heaven
would be worth it. Even Paul had to struggle with a thorn in the flesh and depression afterwards. As the bottom
line, the only real reason I could perceive for wanting to go to Heaven would be to see Jesus. Despite all my
research and the resulting hypotheses that I would like to have confirmed, the singular desire to see Jesus would
make all my other research-related desires pale in comparison. I want to see Jesus. And when I see Him I am
not going to have some compelling desire to leave Him in order to return to Earth in order to write a book telling
about the experience. To the contrary, I am going to want to stay with Him.
        So, at present, to the extent I am able, I console myself with the realization that writing about Heaven by
analyzing Scripture and the testimonies of others might actually be better, from an overarching analytical point
of view, than going to Heaven myself and returning to write about it. After all, those who have had the NDEs
and OBEs seem to have problems synthesizing the information provided by their experiences with Scripture
and the testimonies of others. Objective analyses by those who put the pieces together without actually having
a NDE or OBE is certainly needed. Being an analysist is a rewarding experience in its own right, kind of like
the satisfaction one gets from putting together a giant jigsaw puzzle. In this case, Scripture and each creditable
testimony contribute pieces to the overall puzzle. Some of those who have been through the OBE and NDE
maze seem to have problems stepping far enough out of the maze of the puzzle to see the entire maze and how
to navigate the maze successfully to an integrated solution. They cannot see the forest for the trees, so to speak.
Their perception is too weighted to their own subjective experience. Still, I would recommend Sigmund’s book.

193
    Children are not the only ones learning. “There are great universities in heaven—I mean great—and there
are many of them. Our education is not complete when we leave earth. We have only just begun....One hundred
percent of your mind is used—and it is increasing in capability....And I was told that anything you learn in
heaven, you never forget” (p. 56). I find this prospect exciting. However, I would anticipate that those believers
in the outer darkness will miss out significantly on these abilities and opportunities.

Marvin J. Besteman

                                           Permissible Discrepancies
       Moving on to another book, when Marvin Besteman was taken to the Heavenly City, he met Peter at a
large wooden gate. He relates his attempt to explain how this piece of the puzzle fits with other pieces described
by others:

             As I tell you my story; there will be a few times where I just can’t explain what I saw.
      This is one of those times. Other heavenly travelers have seen pieces of the gate that they have
      described as pearly; I believe them. I also believe I was given a different vision, an image of heaven
      that included a gate made of heavy, dark wood and covered in twinkling lights. I’m at peace with
      that, and I hope you will be too. Rather than try to be as smart as God, we should just quit while
      we’re ahead.
             A final note on this matter: my trusted spiritual advisors have prayed with me and for me as
      I’ve come to terms with my time in heaven, and they have suggested that perhaps the gates will
      indeed be enormous pearls when the New Heaven and the New Earth come to be, in God’s timing
      and plan. After all, I was given a hint of the Intermediate Heaven, the place believers go now when
      they die. It’s a different place from the New Heaven and New Earth we will inhabit after Christ’s
      return. That’s a very important distinction to make, so please take note. My spiritual advisors could
      be right, or maybe it’s another answer altogether. Pearly or not, I’m so grateful I had the chance
      to stand in the shadow of that marvelous gate!194

        I appreciate Besteman’s attempt to reconcile the discrepancies and his sticking to his story despite the
apparent discrepancies. Some discrepancies increase the probability that the stories are being related truthfully.
This discrepancy is one such case in point. Some NDErs describe meeting angels at pearly gates. Besteman, in
contrast, meets Peter at a wooden gate. Although it is true that the Intermediate Heaven is not the same as the
New Heaven, and this fact should certainly be kept in mind in resolving certain discrepancies, I believe this
observation is a faulty explanation as to how to reconcile the present discrepancy. My hypothesis is that the
Heavenly Jerusalem, to which Besteman was taken, will indeed be the New Jerusalem, of the eternal state.
Therefore, the harmonization suggested by his earthly advisors will not work in the present case. “Another
answer although,” a possibility that Besteman allowed, is readily available and one that I, among others, have
already suggested: Entrance into the Heavenly City is not limited to the twelve pearly gates. This city is far too
massive, and the people and angels coming and going far too numerous, for the entrance limited to these twelve
gates. Besteman is simply taken to another gate. A subsequent detail provided by Besteman supplies unintended
collaboration, when he sees the throne where the Father and Son are seated: “The throne was about three
quarters of a mile away, and dazzlingly bright, lit with brilliant, white lights. It’s hard to imagine as I sit here
in this dark earth, remembering, but in heaven my eyes could see much clearer and much farther away than they
ever could down here” (p. 185). Telescopic vision is a commonly reported OBE and NDE phenomenon. But
the throne was only about ¾ of a mile away. You do not need telescopic vision to see something that big and
bright such a short distance away. This short distance proves that the gate to which Besteman was taken was
not on the outer perimeter of the City wall. Otherwise, the throne would have been much further away, hundreds
of miles away.

                                            Argument with Peter
        The thing I liked most about Besteman’s book was the argument he got into with Peter at the gate to the
city. I have postulated in my books that we will not necessarily agree with one another on everything when we
reach Heaven. This detail confirms that hypothesis.

            We talked a bit, and even argued (guess who won?), and when I play that conversation over
      and over in my head, I am thrilled to have had such an encounter with one of the bravest and best
      men who ever walked this earth.

194
  Marvin J. Besteman with Lorilee Craker, My Journey to Heaven: What I Saw and How It Changed My Life
(Grand Rapids: Revell, 2012), 82-83.
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                               Page 85
                I’ll tell you more about that incredible meeting later on, but for now, you should know that
         Peter leafed through the Book of life, which was actually multiple books, looking for my name.
         But of course he couldn’t find it; otherwise I would be in heaven now, possibly having another
         lively debate with Peter. He left his post at heaven’s gate briefly to consult with God about what
         to do with me—keep me or send me home. My vote was definitely to keep me there. Surely it was
         on purpose, but Peter left the door to heaven open, revealing a translucent gate through which I
         could see inside.195

                                            Books of Life and BOTG
        His testimony that the Book of Life is actually multiple books, with multiple purposes, has been
anticipated already for exegetical reasons in the present series and thus finds confirmation in his testimony.
Overall, Besteman does an excellent good job of grappling with the impactions of the Books of Life, as he
calls them: “It never clicked that these books were the Book of Life, or as I discovered, really, the Books of
Life, until Peter turned away from me and looked in a specific volume, searching for my name. Then I
realized what these books must be, and what their glorious contents were all about” (italics his, 105). If
Besteman had not supplied this little aside, then we might have inferred that he was informed that these books
were the Books of Life. However, he only deduces that they are the Books of Life. Perhaps, he is correct. Then
again, perhaps these books are the Lamb’s Books of Life. Yet again, perhaps these books have another title
altogether since other NDErs are allowed into the city because their names were in books but his name was
not.
        How is this discrepancy to be resolved? Besteman does not offer a suggestion as to how to reconcile the
fact that some NDErs are allowed into the city because their names are in the books while others are not allowed
in because their names are not in the books. Yet his discussion is well worth reading. I thoroughly appreciate
that Besteman strongly affirms unconditional security in the midst of this discussion (p. 108). He thinks that the
“book of remembrance” (Mal 3:16) is part of the Book of Life and is a record of the good works we have done
(p. 111). Maybe. An alternate possibility would be to see these works as part of the Books of Works in
contradistinction to the Books of Life. Besteman does make careful note, however, that Peter told him that his
name was not in the books for today:

                I was in for quite a shock when Peter returned and broke my reverie.
                “Marv,” he said, looking slightly puzzled. “I can’t find your name for today.”
                “For today.? ... What in the world did that mean? I’m sure my mouth dropped open.
                I was instantly disappointed. What’s happening? I thought that once you made it this far,
         you were in, no turning back? I was confused, but yet I never once thought that maybe I wasn’t
         really saved.
                I knew I was saved. There wasn’t the tiniest doubt in my mind.
                And Peter had emphasized the words “for today,” which meant that I wasn’t supposed to
         go all the way into heaven that day. There is, I know, another date God has in mind, known only

                The bulldog in me came out as I began to argue with the founder of the worldwide church

         And I had nothing to lose.
                “It’s taken me all these years, a long time, to get this far, to heaven, and I’m not going back
         now,” I said. “I’m a hardheaded Hollander. It takes me awhile to figure things out. I’m not
         going back. What can we do?”
                Peter didn’t say much, but he seemed to know I wasn’t going to go back voluntarily—

      Argue with Peter? Burke relates an NDE from “Jeffery Long’s website” of “a thirteen-year-old girl

       Barbara did not want to come back and argued with the angel at the gate when the angel, apparently,
could not find her name in the big book—yet. The angel’s answer would certainly lead one to believe that she
will be allowed in later, just not on that particular day. Jake’s statement that he would see her soon—back in
Heaven—confirms this impression. Barbara was too early. She thinks that the book that the angel is checking
is the LBOL. But that is just an inference that she draws on her own. Perhaps it is a volume from the Books of
Life instead. Or perhaps it is another book altogether. In any case, it is a book checked outside the gate. This
Book of the Gate (BOTG)that only has one’s name if it is their time to die might be called BOTG-T. In order
to harmonize various accounts, I will postulate that in some cases BOTG-W is consulted allowing temporary
entrance for those whose names are not yet in BOTG-T. Just as there are multiple Books of Life so there are
multiple Books of the Gate.198
