                                                    Carol Hooley
        As mentioned previously, after about three years I was eventually able to obtain a copy of Carol Hooley’s
booklet, Caught Up to Heaven, with the assistance of her daughter, Cindy Morrison, who supplied further
clarification. Because this chapter is written in the form of a reading diary and since I received this copy of this
booklet after I had finished the initial rough draft of the current book, I will supplement my previous interaction
with Hooley earlier in this chapter, which was through the writing of Anne Sandberg, with a fuller
documentation here.200 Hooley was the daughter of a Presbyterian pastor. She drifted away from the Lord. But
after coming back to intimacy with the Lord, following a bout with her health in which the Lord healed her, she
often prayed that she could see the Lord (p. 2). One day her prayer was finally answered, and two “rather large
and masculine looking” angles appeared and escorted her to Heaven (p. 3).
Sequence
       Note the spatial sequence in Hooley’s testimony: “I remember the joy of entering into [1] the realm of
the third heaven, that portion of the universe where God’s will is continuously being done....The angels took
me to [2] a definite location in the third heaven, where we entered into a city through a beautiful
gate....They took me to [3] a beautiful mansion, an ivory palace....I saw many of these mansions” (pp. 4-5).
This sequence has been observed in other NDEs surveyed herein as well. Nothing new there. After being taken
through our universe, Hooley comes (1) to the third heaven, then (2) to the Heavenly City located in a portion
of the third heaven, then (3) to a mansion located in a portion of the Heavenly City. Although this is a common
NDE sequence, it will bear repeating yet once more because of an addition component of her testimony that
will be the focus of our analysis. Again, the sequences of places she visited, from the outermost rim of the
heavenly realm to its innermost were:

                                                   1. Third Heaven
                                                   2. Heavenly City
                                                   3. Mansion
Testimony Concerning Black Sheep Uncle
       Hooley asked Jesus many questions about Heaven but not all questions were answered: “Some of my
questions He answered, but others He didn’t” (p. 8). She is by no means unique in this experience either.
Likewise, all our questions may not be answered—at least not explicitly. Nevertheless, a careful analysis can
make logical inferences from the clues given. In a section entitled, “A Shocking Experience,” Hooley relates
the following very useful details:

                 The Lord revealed a scene to me which I shall never forget. I saw a large host of saints, and
         I began to recognize some of the faces as I was taken near. I knew these people to be believers in
         the Lord Jesus. Then, suddenly, I spotted the familiar face of an uncle who had died only a short
         time prior. I was shocked, because as far as I knew, he hadn’t served God. My Lord brought me
         to even a closer view, and I asked, “Did he make it?” My Lord answered in the affirmative, but
         He also said, “Carol, don’t ever forget what you are seeing.”
                 For some reason I wanted to turn my face, for my uncle was not robed like the others
         about him. It wasn’t the feeling of embarrassment from looking on one who is naked, but my
         Lord was impressing a great and important truth in my heart. He talked to me very sincerely and
         in a way which I could understand, and I was made to know that my uncle had just barely made
         it into heaven. When I returned, I learned from my aunt, who lived in another state, that my uncle
         had accepted Jesus Christ as his personal Saviour just prior to his death.
                 This experience has taught me the importance of living daily a victorious life in Christ.

199
      Ibid., 88.
200
      See Anne Sandberg, 39.
Page 88                                                                             Misthological Models Part 4
      My uncle received the gift of eternal life the same as any other believer, because salvation is
      by grace, not works. Yet, he did not live a victorious life in Christ here on earth; he did not build
      upon the foundation of faith in Christ. He waited until the very end of his life to commit himself
      to Jesus Christ. I saw a definite distinction between my uncle and those who had lived a
      consecrated Christian life. (Underline hers, pp. 11-12.)

Excellent Soteriology and Misthology
       This testimony contains both excellent soteriology and misthology; the two are appropriately
distinguished. Hooley appropriately proceeds to quote 2Cor 5:10 and 1Cor 3:11-15 to explain the implications
of her testimony. Her biblical interpretation of her heavenly experience is 100% accurate at this point. Hooley’s
biblical discernment is superb in all aspects of this part of her experience! Repeatedly, she expresses pristine
FG soteriology: “There is only one way to receive everlasting life, and that is to receive Jesus Christ as your
personal Savior” (p. 13). “I pray that many who read this testimony will accept Jesus Christ as their personal
Savior” (ibid.). “If you have accepted Him as your Savior, there is a day coming when the angels of God will
carry you into His presence” (p. 14). Commitment to the Lordship of Christ as a worker is not necessary to be
saved as a believer. Excellent soteriology! And her misthology, in regard to 2Cor 5:10 and 1Cor 3:11-15, excels
just as well.
Preconversion Sins
        Nevertheless, some would reject her testimony prematurely because her uncle’s preconversion sins are a
negative factor in his preliminary judgment. As she surmises, he purposefully waited “until the very end of his
life to commit himself to Jesus Christ.” Even then, he was not saved because of his commitment but because
he “accepted Jesus Christ as his personal Saviour just prior to his death,” thus receiving eternal life as a gift—
as a believer, not as a worker.
        To be sure, this testimony is at odds with simplistic notions of soteriology and misthology, which assume
that preconversion sins can never be factored in misthologically since they are forgiven soteriologically, but I
have refuted that simplistic assumption in 4DF and thus have no qualms accepting the plausibility of her
testimony in this regard. (Consider the implications of Acts 22:16 in relation to Gal 6:7). Those who
purposefully wait until the end of their lives to become believers, so that they can avoid being workers, can rest
assured that the Lord will save them from Hell if they simply believe in Him for eternal life at that time. No
doubt about it. However, God will not be mocked. Presuming upon His grace so as to delay committing to Him
as Lord can be expected to have very negative misthological consequences at the Bema.
Embarrassment
       Because of his waiting until the end of his life to believe, so that he could be saved by grace and delay
any commitment to the Lordship of Christ until then, her dead uncle’s just-barely-saved clothing caused her to
be embarrassed to look at him. I wonder if he felt embarrassed by his just-barely-saved clothing. Could his just-
barely-saved clothing indicate that he was just barely clothed? In any event, I do not anticipate that he feels any
profound regret or profound shame in his intermediate state for his lack of suitable clothing. He is probably just
grateful to have made it into Heaven. Most likely, he will not experience any profound regret for his lack of
suitable clothing until the Bema. After all, the man who entered the wedding feast without being properly
clothed did not weep until he was excluded from the feast at the time of the Bema (Mt 22:12-13). He did not
weep over his improper clothing until it resulted in his exclusion from the feast. At that time, such believers
will shamefully depart from the Lord (1Jn 2:28), having to find accommodations elsewhere in the heavenly
realm. Since the Lord will live in the Heavenly City, they will have to live elsewhere in the kingdom. But that
exclusion from the city at the time of the wedding feast is future. Where is he located now, presently, in the
intermediate state?
City Exclusion
      Hooley’s testimony leads me to suspect that her uncle is having to live outside the city even now.
Carefully observe what she testifies as a result of her conversation with Jesus: “I was made to know [by Jesus]
that my uncle had just barely made it into heaven.” Per the understanding imparted to her by Jesus and
per the details of her own testimony, his just barely making it into Heaven would have to mean that her
uncle only made it into the outskirts of Heaven. Recall the sequence. She first entered the “realm of the
third heaven.” Then, subsequently, the angels took her to the Heavenly City. If her uncle just barely
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                           Page 89
made it into the third heaven, he could not have made it into the Heavenly City, which, according to her
own testimony, was a particular location further inside the heavenly realm.
        The logical conclusion is that the angels who brought him to the heavenly realm must have left him
at the outer rim of that realm. If there are planets in this outer rim, this would have to be his habitation.
Jesus did not make it that hard to figure out. Jesus caused her to understand that her black-sheep uncle
had just barely made it into heaven—not into the city! Jesus did not want her to think that her uncle had
just barely made it into the city. Rather, the Lord wanted her to perceive that her uncle merely made it
into heaven. This is the distinct impression that the Lord gave her.
        Nevertheless, the Lord may have left it up to her—and through her, us—to figure out that her uncle was
left outside the city. Her uncle was not in the city because he had just barely made it into Heaven, and the city
was located further inside of Heaven. I do not know if Hooley figured out the logical implications of what Jesus
revealed to her in this regard. Nevertheless, this conclusion was staring her right in the face. When I inquired
from her daughter, Cindy Morrison, if her mother was ever explicit about whether her uncle was inside or
outside the city, Carol responded that her mother was not explicit about whether he was inside or outside the
city.201 Notwithstanding, because logical consistency dictates that her uncle was in the outer rim of the heavenly
realm, I will adopt that conclusion as my working hypothesis as to what Jesus was impressing upon her mind
while she was with Him in Heaven.
Unrobed Versus Unclothed
       As to her uncle’s clothing or lack thereof, she states: “My uncle was not robed like the others about
him. It wasn’t the feeling of embarrassment from looking on one who is naked.” For sake of expediency,
I will presume this to mean that her uncle was skimpily clothed rather than royally robed—and in this sense,
unrobed. Such deductions and my own analyses elsewhere cause me to challenge a subsequent assessment
made by Hooley. We basically agree conceptually regarding the distinction pertaining to the clothing, but we
differ in the exegetical explanation. When it comes to heavenly clothing, she interprets her experience as
follows:

             While still in the mansion, I was taken into a second room, very quiet and beautiful, where
      another angel suddenly appeared. I was given a white garment to put on—a beautiful, long,
      pure white linen garment. In Revelation 19:7-8, John was shown a future scene in heaven when
      the bride of Christ will be at the marriage supper of the Lamb. John saw the bride (consisting of
      God's saints) all arrayed in fine linen, clean and white.
             The Bible teaches that there is only one way to heaven. We need to be forgiven of our sins
      and be cleansed by the blood of Jesus Christ. Then the righteousness of Jesus Christ is imputed to
      us. I was permitted to see and wear that garment of righteousness which is reserved for all those
      who have accepted Jesus Christ as their personal Saviour. I am glad that Almighty God has
      extended His hand of grace to all mankind. In John 3:16 we read, “For God so loved the world,
      that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish, but have
      everlasting life."
             After I was clothed in the fine white linen, another angel brought other pieces of glorious
      apparel containing the colors blue, purple, scarlet, and gold. This was prior to and in
      preparation for my personal visit with our Lord. I was told to put them on, although I did not
      understand their significance at that time. I know now that the Lord wanted to clearly
      distinguish between the two kinds of garments. Since that day, God has enlightened my
      understanding about these garments through the study of His Word. The fine linen clearly relates

       to the gift of salvation when Christ’s righteousness is imputed to the believer, but the subsequent

       I disagree with her identifying the first white garment given to her as the soteriologically imputed
righteousness given to every believer, supposedly affirmed by Rev 19:7-8. First, contrary to popular opinion,
Rev 19:7-8 is misthological text, not a soteriological test. Only faithful believers will compose the Bride. Only
they will be clothed in these white garments. Even a simple reading of the passage confirms this to be the case:
       7
        “Let us rejoice and be glad and give the glory to Him, for the marriage of the Lamb has come
       and His bride has prepared herself.” 8 Indeed, it was granted her to clothe herself in fine linen,
       bright and clean; for the fine linen is the righteous works of the saints. (Rev 19:7-8; TM)

        First, the Bride prepares herself by clothing herself in righteous works as her fine linen. The passage is
dripping wet with misthological implications. I have belabored this point at length in my books (TOD, MMP3,
LTPW) and need not do so here. Her uncle was lacking these righteous works; therefore, he could not possibly
have been clothed in such a garment, which nullifies Hooley’s interpretation of the event, in thinking that the
garment is given to all believers. Second, the white garments in Revelation promised to humans are rewards for
overcomers (see TOD). Third, it makes no sense to suppose that Hooley would have been embarrassed to look
at her uncle if he was clothed in such “a beautiful, long, pure white linen garment.” Fourth, she testifies very
clearly that her uncle was just barely saved and embarrassingly clothed. Being barely saved and embarrassingly
clothed does not compute with being beautifully clothed. Fifth, she admits that she was not given any
understanding of her garments at the time but was given understanding of her uncle’s embarrassing clothing by
the Lord at the time of the experience as indicating her uncle had just barely been saved. She had to do what
she could to figure out the implications of her own clothing later. Sixth, we have seen numerous examples
where those taken to Heaven are not the best interpreters of their own experiences. Nothing about the experience
makes her an infallible interpreter of her experience when she is having to draw her own inferences. Seventh,
per her own testimony, better explanations are readily available for the white garments she describes.
        The white garment is given to her inside the mansion. We have every reason to believe that her uncle
was not allowed into the city, much less into a mansion inside the city, even less into an inner room inside the
mansion. This white attire is associated with innermost access. Hooley is correct to think that a white garment
suggests bridal attire. However, bridal attire is a reward, not a gift. Yet bridal attire is not the only misthological
attire. Priestly garments are misthological as well. Hooley does well to pick up this fact. What she failed to
perceive was that two different types of misthological garments were given to her. I have no reason to doubt
her experience, but I have considerable reason to reject this particular aspect of her explanation. Scriptural
confirmation for what she experienced is readily available. She was wearing these bridal garments because of
her closeness to the Lord, a closeness that she already had achieved when she was praying to see the Lord: “My
relationship with the Lord became so precious and full of love. I wanted so much to please Him and to see our
family find His perfect will for our lives” (p. 2). This was the state she was in as she prayed and when her
prayers were answered to be taken to Heaven. Her intimacy with the Lord was the reason her prayer was
Chapter 1. Extrabiblical Experiences of Heaven                                                              Page 91
answered, and she was taken to a mansion inside the city and clothed with a bridal garment. The bridal garments
show intimacy; the colored garments show royalty. Both are rewards, not gifts. She qualified for both rewards.
Her uncle qualified for neither. Therefore, we may safely deduce that he has neither type of clothing. His
clothing causes embarrassment, not enchantment. Hooley’s experience appears to be completely genuine, but
her explanation as to the significance of the clothing given to her needs tweaking. The white garment given to
her because of her intimacy with the Lord indicates bridal intimacy reserved for the faithful. Conversely, her
uncle’s embarrassing clothing implies a lack of bridal intimacy with the Lord.
       She described herself as just “a babe in Christ” at the time she had the vision. Comparatively, in terms
of the maturity she would later achieve in her Christian life in Christ, this was a reasonable statement.
Nevertheless, in terms of the bridal gown she was given at the time, this was a false assessment. Toddlers wear
diapers and bibs, not bridal gowns. She was given a bridal gown, not a bib. I can picture her uncle as being
clothed in the misthological equivalent of a diaper and bib, but not her. Instead, her clothing suggests that of a
young virgin being readied to meet her groom, the king. As concluded in my book, Like a Tree Planted by the
Water (LTPW), faithful believers will stand at the Messiah’s right hand as His queen, adorned in gold, with
beauty He desires (Ps 45:9-14). Hooley’s restoration to intimacy with the Lord qualified her for misthological
beauty. Her uncles’ procrastination until a deathbed conversion did not. The moral to this story, in my
assessment, is you need to believe in the Lord as your Savior and learn how to experience daily victory in Christ
through Free Grace, kingdom, exchanged-life trichotomy (FGKELT) without a moment of delay.
                                                    Conclusion
       During my research of dreams, visions, and NDEs in this section, I have become more open to these
phenomena as being useful resources to flesh out the details for the exegetical framework concerning the
heavenly dimension. Nevertheless, caution must be exercised. Not only does the Bible call for us to practice
discernment, but the conflicts within the data itself necessitate that the data be examined critically. This critical
interaction with such extrabiblical data through a biblically informed filter proved mutually beneficial, not only
for formulating hypotheses to filter out inconsistencies and to harmonize the extrabiblical data with itself and
with the biblical data, but also for encouraging enhanced vantage points within the biblical analysis itself.
       Keener analyses regarding several biblical texts have been suggested by this study. Additionally,
plausible conceptual projections have been garnered along the way. For example, the probability of an actual
Bema Book has been reasonably proposed.
       As to some of the inconsistencies reported by those having these extrabiblical experiences, the present
study has noted that some have testified that angels are wingless and sexless, whereas others have affirmed that
angels have wings and gender. Contrary to the opinion of some, harmonization with Scripture encourages that
we affirm the latter. At the very least, Scripture certainly leaves that possibility open in the field of angelology.
In conjunction with my thesis in Monogamous Sex in Heaven, I simply note that the NDE confirmations of
sexual distinctions and sexual attraction, as documented therein and herein, confirm my findings.202
       On the other hand, in the area of soteriology, the discrepancies between Scripture and some alleged
accounts are completely irreconcilable. Yet Scripture wins easily. When one is getting one’s soteriology from
demons whose self-admitted goal is to deceive, one should not be surprised that the soteriology does not match
Scripture! Likewise, when some NDErs are only reporting happy experiences and relating a BOL who leads
them to believe that there is no judgment, while other NDErs are reporting hellish experiences associated with
judgment, it does not take a rocket scientist to spot a major inconsistency. For those given to a biblical
viewpoint, posing a model to filter out the erroneous data in such cases is very easy.
       Some of the testimonies have confirmed the multiverse model that I have adopted during the course of
these studies. Even more astonishingly, some of these testimonies have confirmed that the heavenly Paradise

202
    If Adam and Eve were created as male and female in the image of the divine council to express the masculine

guise but a part of their function as God’s image bearers. To pose that they are male and female in gender and
function necessarily implies that they are sexually functional in their interactions with one another. My thesis
is that angels engage in monogamous sex in Heaven with their singular angelic soulmate and that we may safely
infer that the same is true of faithful believers in the Heavenly City. For details, see my book, Monogamous Sex
in Heaven!
Page 92                                                                               Misthological Models Part 4
has an outer expanse in the form of a terrestrial orb on another planet where the redeemed are first brought by
their guardian angels before being allowed to the Heavenly City. As for the Heavenly City itself, various levels
are reported, with the lower levels being on the bottom, accessed according to one’s degree of maturity and
reward. The reward nature of this Reward City is confirmed in various ways. Even entrance is conditioned upon
finding one’s name in a book, presumably the Bema Book, though the testimonies are not uniform in that regard.
In short, some testimonies were very conducive in deriving a preferred model herein. Nevertheless, some of the
testimonies presented challenges that were difficult, albeit not impossible, to harmonize with the biblical data.
More advanced soteriological and misthological models appear to be rather capable of reconciling these
accounts within reasonable parameters with plausible harmonization hypotheses. The most attractive model, at
this juncture, is to pose that unfaithful believers live outside of New Jerusalem in cities and villages surrounding
the capital city during the intermediate state, while faithful believers live inside New Jerusalem at a level fitting
their level of maturity and faithfulness. Some other analysts of the NDE data have apparently come to this same
conclusion, even to the point of recognizing that the city is a reward for the bride. Rulership is equatable with
brideship.
                                       Chapter 2.
                              Biblical Analysis of Heaven
                                                  Introduction
       Preliminarily integration of the testimonies of NDErs with biblical analyses in the previous chapter has
tended to favor the Caulian-Crawfordian model, which is one of the primary models for the outer darkness
being considered in the present series. Apparently, during the intermediate state, unfaithful believers live
outside of New Jerusalem in cities and villages surrounding the capital city, perhaps on other planets in the
heavenly realm, while faithful believers live inside New Jerusalem at a level fitting their level of maturity and
faithfulness. In the present chapter, the biblical framework will be pursued more thoroughly, primarily
regarding the present state of perfection affirmed by Heb 12:23 and secondarily regarding the delay of
perfection until the present in Heb 11:40.
                                               Popular Writers
       Since in reference to the Heavenly Jerusalem Heb 11:16 says that God has prepared the city, rather than
will prepare or is preparing it, Randy Alcorn proposes that New Jerusalem is already “complete or nearly
complete” and “that those in the intermediate Heaven are already living in it [so the Caulian model]. Or it may
be set aside, awaiting simultaneous habitation by all its occupants when transferred to the New Earth [so the
Crawfordian model]” (emphasis his).203 Like Crawford and myself, Alcorn failed to consider that a mediating
position might be possible. Further consideration of the contest in Hebrews leads to a mediating Crawfordian-
Caulian position.
                                                      Grammars
       Before delving into various commentators about the spirits of righteousness having been made perfect
in Heb 12:23, let us hear a brief word from our grammarians. What does this perfect participle about having
been made perfect mean? Wallace (GGBB) notes that “the perfect participle is almost always antecedent with
reference to the main verb. When it is contemporaneous, such is due to ether an intensive use of the perfect or
to a present force of the perfect in its lexical nuance.” Robertson (GGNT) likewise says that the perfect participle
“either represents a state (intensive) or a completed act (extensive)” and “may be represented as completed
before that of the principle verb and so antecedent action.” Fanning (VANT) similarly states, “The perfect
participle preserves the basic sense of the other prefect forms in denoting a state or condition resulting from an
anterior occurrence...it often emphasizes the resulting state and only implies the anterior occurrence” (p. 416).
The “temporal meaning,” that is, the anterior occurrence, is “in relation to some reference-point, usually the
action of the main verb” (p. 408). “The perfect participle’s normal temporal relation to the main verb is that the
resulting state is contemporaneous with the main verbal occurrence, and the action which produced it is thus
antecedent to the main verb” (p. 416, n. 23).204 They are each saying the same thing; namely, the perfect
participle acts perfectly normal, just the way you would expect a perfect aspect to act in Greek. So there is no
excuse for commentators or biblical expositors to miss its significance in Heb 12:23.205

      are enrolled in Heaven, and to God, the Judge of all, and to the spirits of the righteous men having
      been made perfect (teleioo). (Heb 12:2-23; TM)

     The main verb in Heb 12:22-23 is proserchomai (you have come), used in the perfect tense in v. 22.

        The perfect participle of teleioo (having been made perfect) in v. 23 indicates that this teleological

Reward City in this context, we safely may deduce that their realized misthology in the spiritual dimension

       Just to make sure this crucial point does not pass over the heads of those not versed in Greek, let me draw
a picture that answers the riddle: How is it that (A) the OT faithful could not be perfected apart from (B) NT
believers (so Heb 11:40), yet (A) the OT faithful reached their state of perfection before (B) the NT believers
came on the scene (so Heb 12:43)? In other words, how is that A must come after B, yet A came before B? Are
we not violating the law of non-contradiction? No, the answer is very simple. The reference for B is not the
same in both parts of the statement. Note in the illustration that the perfection in v. 23 comes before (i.e.,
antecedent to) the action described by v. 23.

perspective, thinking in terms of the entire NT era. (The writer of Hebrews stresses the dispensational transition

the epistle. These NT believers are part of the new inaugurated era. But in Heb 12:22, the writer is talking
specifically about the Hebrew believers whom he is warning about the danger of not finishing the race they
have begun. He is not talking about the whole NT era but that part of the NT era comprised by believers who
had come to faith after that era had started. These NT believers, as part of the new dispensation, had come to
potential realization of misthological perfection in the intermediate state when they first believed. But the new

beginning of the NT dispensation marked the beginning of such metaphysical perfection. Put simply, NT
believers now have come to the place in time, dispensationally speaking, where the spirits of the righteous
already have been made prefect in association with their having entered the Heavenly City; something
that did not occur until the start of the new dispensation. So what exactly happened? These righteous spirits
were translated to the Heavenly City at the transition to the new dispensation. Now, will the commentators and
interpreters reach this proper conclusion? Lindsay did.
                                                Commentators
Greene
       The transition above, denoted by the grammar, would have been accomplished metaphysically by the
relocation of Paradise. Though Greene does not mention the perfect aspect used for made perfect, he uses the
popular descent-into-Hades model to explain the passage and thus correctly explains the general sense of the
passage, though he lacks the misthopological understanding implied by the biblical writer:

             We are come “to the spirits of just men made perfect.” Of whom does the Holy Spirit speak
      here? He is speaking of the Old Testament saints....The spirits of all the Old Testament saints are
      resting in Paradise, together with the spirits of New Testament saints who have departed this life....
             Through the death, burial, and resurrection of Jesus the Old Testament saints were made
      perfect, and when Jesus rose from the dead He “led captivity captive.” He brought the spirits of
      the Old Testament saints out of the Paradise which was in the heart of the earth and carried them
      with Him to the Paradise far above all heavens; and since the resurrection of Jesus, every believer
      who has departed this life has gone immediately to be with the Lord (Phil. 1:23; II Cor. 5:6-8).207

       Although Greene’s explanation is a failure in terms of misthology, since he assumes that the passage is
describing mere soteriological perfection; nevertheless, he is right on target in denoting the relocation of the
inhabitants of sub-terrestrial Paradise to heavenly Paradise. Soteriologically, the relocation would apply to all
believers. However, the writer of Hebrews is emphatic that unfaithful believers will never enter the
misthological rest. Never includes now. Therefore, for Greene to pose that all deceased believers are “resting
in Paradise” lacks the precision intended by the biblical writer. In making this observation, I am amending my
own classical position in TOD regarding the outer darkness as well.
       A more technically correct distinction, in accordance with the present series of studies, would be to say
that the spirits of all OT and NT believers are now inhabiting Heaven, but only faithful believers are
resting in the Heavenly City. Yet, because Paradise encompasses more than just the Reward City, some
unfaithful believers might be currently residing on Planet Paradise (and thus in that part of Paradise) but not
allowed into the Reward City in the northern part of the planet in the higher regions of Paradise. In any event,
whether the unfaithful believers are located exclusively on other heavenly planets or partially on lower parts of
Planet Paradise, the unfaithful are not allowed into the Reward City. The spirits of the righteous have been
perfected in the sense of inhabiting the Reward City now that the transition from the subterranean
Paradise has occurred. The standard descent-into-Hades model needs to be modified to accommodate this
more accurate biblical understanding, which incidentally is supported by the better NDE data. Accordingly, at
the conclusion of this biblical analysis, we will return to the standard descent model, and I will tweak my own
classical descent model that I originally offered in Darkness by incorporating the additional insights gleaned
from the current study. In any event, for now it suffices to say that Greene’s analysis fails because he poses a

Lang
        Concerning Heb 11:40 and 12:23, Lang is at the opposite end of the spectrum from Greene. Whereas
Greene advocates a realized soteriology, Lang insists upon an unrealized misthology. Lang is correct in that the
passages are misthological; Greene is correct in that the promise has been realized. Lang points out the perfect
tense in Heb 12:22 but completely fails to note the perfect participle in 12:23, resulting in a highly imperfect
argument. As to Heb 11:40, he makes strong assertions:

               Perfection consists in the rejoining of soul and spirit in a heavenly house, a body of
       resurrection glory....
               It is thus, and only thus, that the people of Christ can be perfected.” “Without that body of
       glory man could not endure that Divine light, nor could a naked soul be permitted in that perfect
       realm and glory. Either resurrection or rapture is imperative.
               If the notion were fact that Christ at His resurrection and ascension removed from Hades
       the godly dead and took them to heaven, then one of two things must have happened: either they
       were perfected, by the gift of the body of glory, in which case for them, “resurrection is past
       already,” which Paul regarded as serious error, overthrowing faith (II Tim. 2:18); or else these
       were taken to heaven imperfect, which is impossible.
               Now our passage denies explicitly that they had been perfected at the ascension of Christ,
       for it asserts that “apart from us” they cannot be made perfect, and we shall not be so until the day
       of Christ. This is confirmed by the fact that one of the men of faith named by the Writer, David,
       had not ascended to heaven by the day of Pentecost, though Christ had already done so
       (Acts 2:34).208

         Although Lang is an astute scholar, whom I hold in very high regard and with whom I am in substantial
agreement regarding much of my overall bridal and misthopological models (as attested in my Rewards are
Eternal), still, on this intermediate matter, I must respectfully and completely disagree with his statements. A
distinction between the already-not-yet aspects of misthological perfection is necessitated by the data. The
prefect participle in Heb 12:23 destroys his argument above. Contrary to Lang, apart from us in Heb 11:40
cannot mean that these OT believers must wait until we NT believers are perfected at the day of Christ, for the
simple reason that Heb 12:23 affirms that these select OT believers already have been perfected spiritually in
the manner anticipated in Heb 11:40, namely misthopologically. Misthopological perfection, insofar as it
pertains to the departed spirits of the righteous, is already a reality. To be sure, at present it is only realized
partially since it is only realized spiritually. Two different stages of misthopological perfection must therefore
be hypothesized.
         Intermediate misthological perfection allows an inaugurated realized metaphysical misthology
regarding the spirits of righteous believers in certain aspects: being clothed in white garments, eating the Tree
of Life, and inhabiting the Heavenly City. Ultimate misthological perfection requires the joining of
metaphysical spirit-soul body with the physical body in order to rule over physical creation in a glorified
resurrected body.
         Lang insisted that the ultimate form of misthological perfection was the only type possible, to which I
say, “Impossible!” The perfect participle in Heb 12:23 demonstrates that an intermediate form of misthological
perfection must be allowed regarding righteous spirits, as is explicitly confirmed by the biblical text. Lang
missed this crucial observation in Heb 12:23, though, thus erroneously asserting counter wise:

               Ye have come “unto the spirits of just men made perfect.” As explained above at ch. 11: 40
       [see block quote above]...we understand this to mean that we have come unto a point of privilege
       entitling us to anticipate a [misthological] share in the first resurrection of the just, for the just are

       I am quite confident that Lang currently is residing in the Heavenly City, much to his initial surprise,

Govett
       Like Lang, Govett insists that the perfection in question in Heb 11:40 and 12:23 requires a physical
resurrection. Commenting on 11:40 he postulates that those raised from the dead in Mt 27:52-53 at Christ’s
resurrection have entered the Heavenly City:

             Moreover, we have, at the close of our Lord’s life, a notice of “the spirits of just men made
      perfect,” and of entry into the eternal city, in those words of Matthew: ‘And the tombs were
      opened and many bodies of the saints which slept arose, and came out of the tombs after His
      resurrection, and went into the Holy City, and appeared unto many.211 (Italics his.)

       In this theory, Jesus only led some of the captives captive into the eternal city—those whom were raised
from the tombs. The major problem with this proposal is, of course, that the perfection in Heb 12:23 is applied
to disembodied spirits. When he gets to Heb 12:23, Govett attempts to dispute this common understanding,
saying that in this verse “‘perfected’ belongs grammatically not to ‘spirits;’ they are not perfected as ‘spirits,’
but as righteous men’” (p. 453). His argument, then, is that having been made righteous modifies just the word
righteous, not the entire phrase the spirits of the righteous. This novel grammatical appeal fails on multiple
accounts, however.
       First, in the sentence immediately preceding, he claimed, “They are ‘perfected,’ inasmuch as they are
accepted by God, and have run through their mortal course” (p. 453). No, this would describe why these OT
believers are righteous, not what it means to be perfected in this verse. Perfection in both this verse and in the
preceding reference has, as he himself admitted in regard to the previous reference, a view to “entry into the
eternal city.” This perfection pertains to entrance into the Reward City.
       Second, the biblical writer already has said that they could not obtain this type of perfection—entry into
the Heavenly City—apart from us NT believers, that is, apart from Jesus’ resurrection and the NT covenant it
inaugurated. These OT believers were, however, able to run their mortal course and become misthologically
acceptable to God apart from us and Christ’s resurrection. Therefore, contrary to Govett, the writer of Hebrews
is not posing a non-dispensational righteousness in 12:23. Govett is correct that we have drawn near
dispensationally, but he is wrong to say that “the word ‘just,’ or ‘righteous,’ describes them dispensationally”
(p. 452). To the contrary, dispensationally describes their perfection. A dispensational shift has occurred, and
these OT believers are now, in the time period of the new dispensation, something they were not before—
misthologically perfect in spirit. They were righteous before the NT dispensation, of course, but not perfect in
spirit in the manner being described in this context, that is, misthologically, or more specifically,
misthopologically.
       Third, Govett contradicts himself. On the same page, talking about the same verse no less, he refutes

       The dispensational transition that took place in Heb 10:14, took the spirits of all these subterranean
believers and made them soteriologically perfect. This dispensational transaction paid their redemption, taking
them off layaway as it were. Nonetheless, the writer’s words in Heb 12:23 cannot refer to that soteriological
perfection, as the writer has placed the perfection within the latter verse in a misthological setting replete with
misthological warnings, applying only to the misthological righteous. Soteriological perfection is not an option
for Govett in this passage. Indeed, he acknowledges that moral righteousness is in view. He also recognizes that
they are disembodied spirits. Misthopological perfection of morally righteous disembodied spirits is the natural
conclusion to which his own analysis leads.
Tanner
       Although soteriological perfection was affirmed earlier in Heb 10:14, the writer of Hebrews moved on
to misthological perfection in Heb 11:40: “God had provided something better for us, so that apart from us they
should not be made perfect.” Tanner (GNTC) correctly suggests that the church of the firstborn in Heb 12:22
is misthological in nature and that the corresponding perfection in Heb 11:40 is misthological as well, in
contradistinction to the soteriological perfection found in Heb 10:14.212 However, Tanner’s rationale probably
needs refinement. He assumes that because the perfection in Heb 10:14 already has been accomplished, the
perfection in 11:40 is more encompassing, anticipating the future realization of the full Messianic scope of
salvation. He is on the right track, noting the misthological nature of the context in chapter 11 of Hebrews, but
in his discussion of 11:40 he has failed to observe that the perfect participle in Heb 12:23 indicates that they
already have obtained the perfection in question insofar as it pertains to their spirits. This aspect of their
misthological perfection is not future.
       The reward for which God was preparing Abraham was the Heavenly City (Heb 11:8-19). After
establishing this fact in ch. 11, the writer of Hebrews then proceeds in ch. 12 to say that spirits of these ethically
righteous believers have now been perfected. The deduction is simple. These OT heroes of the faith now have
joined the faithful believers of church age in the church of the firstborn in Heavenly Jerusalem. They
already have been granted this part of their reward via inaugurated misthopology. The OT faithful
obtained the misthological promises (Heb 11:33), but those promises remained unfilled in the OT era
(Heb 11:13,39). Not until the NT era were these promises fulfilled and the spirits of the faithful perfected (Heb
11:40; 12:23).
       Not all believers qualify for this misthological perfection, of course. Only the faithful believers within
either the OT or NT dispensations qualify. The spirits of the faithful OT and NT believers, even now, during
the church age, while awaiting their physical resurrection, already have experienced the misthological
spiritual perfection by qualifying misthologically to dwell in the Heavenly City. The full realization,
complete with their physical resurrection and rulership, awaits the future, of course, as pointed out by the writer
of Hebrews. Nonetheless, the writer of Hebrews is urging believers to be faithful, not only because
eschatological misthological concerns are at stake, but because inaugurated misthological benefits are at stake
as well, already being experienced presently by a cloud of witnesses in the Heavenly City.
       FG commentators such as Constable, Hodges, and Tanner perceive the rest being entered within Hebrews
to be a futuristic inheritance of the kingdom as reward. In Fallen from Grace, I adopted this perspective also,

212
      J. Paul Tanner, Hebrews, GNTC.
Chapter 2. Biblical Analysis of Heaven                                                                      Page 99
and still do. Misthological rest is in view. However, neither I nor they had entertained the possibility of a
partially realized misthology being combined with a futuristic culmination. To be sure, the writer of Hebrews
is calling upon believers to live by faith, to exercise a faith that qualifies for the future fulfillment of
misthological promises. Nevertheless, he uses a present tense verb to assert that those believers who have that
kind of faith “are entering” (GWN, NJB) this place of rest, evidently right now. The use of the present tense
in the verse has caused many exchanged-life trichotomists (ELTs) to assume that a present temporal experience
of peace and victory is entailed, espoused by the let-go-let-God mentality. Tanner rightly shows the
shortcomings of such a present-rather-than-future perspective. For one thing, believers must exercise due
diligence (Heb 4:11) to enter this rest, which would necessarily entail works. Yet the context asserts, “For the
one who has entered His rest has himself also rested from his works, as God did from His” (Heb 4:10). Living
believers cannot rest from their works because they must work in order to enter this rest. Also, the passage is
concerned with the possibility of failing to enter this promised rest rather than losing a temporal rest that is
being experienced already. A postmortem rest or an eschatological rest—or both—must be entailed.
       Aspectually, a punctiliar entrance () is suggested amidst a linear entrance: An aorist infinitive,
suggesting punctiliar entrance, is used to state, “A [futuristic] promise remains of entering () His rest” (Heb
4:1), while a present indicative is used to suggest linear entrance. “For we who believed are [currently] entering
[ ] that rest” (Heb 4:3; TM). Yet the present entrance would not be experienced in the present, on Earth, by
those believers striving to live for the Lord.
       Both the tension of the punctiliar-linear action and the present-future time are resolvable by enjoining
realized and eschatological misthology. The two verses (Heb 4:1,3) combine to indicate that the liner action
may be pictured as the outer shell and the aoristic action as the inner with a distributive aspectual symbol: “For
we who have believed  are entering  that rest” (TM). At the point of death, those soteriological
believers who qualify as misthological believers are considered those who have believed. Their misthological
faith  at the end of their lives qualifies  them for this misthological rest. Their perseverance in faith
throughout the course of their lives qualifies them to be considered misthological believers at the end of their
lives. At that point, they enter into their misthological rest, the City of Rest, as their heavenly reward. They join
the company of the “the spirits of righteous having been made perfect” (Heb 12:23; TM). Spiritually, they
already are experiencing this aspect of their misthological inheritance. Physically, though, their inheritance
(Heb 1:14) of “the world to come” (Heb 2:5), associated with “the city which is to come” (Heb 13:14), has not
yet been realized. Obviously, this city already exists. The writer is not saying that the city is to become, that is,
come into existence. Rather, this city, which already exists in the heavenly dimension and which is currently
housing the spirits of the righteous, is to come into our physical dimension at a future time. We do not have a
“lasting city” here, that is, on Earth. But we do have such a city there, and it will come here, to Earth, when we
inherit the Earth.
       In short, those righteous spirits, who already have entered this City of Rest, are already enjoying the fruit
of their labors. Their works have followed with them (Rev 14:13), and they are eating the fruit of the Tree of
Life, evidently even now, within the city (Rev 2:7). They already are (not merely will be) a part of Christ’s
misthological household (Heb 3:6). They are living with Christ in His misthological city. Such NT believers
who endure until the end of their lives are, even now at the end of their lives, becoming partakers with Christ
in His city, during the current dispensation. They already “have become partakers” with Christ in this City of
Rest (Heb 3:14). This city is their residency. They already are Christ’s partners in this city. What is ours
provisionally and principally, as NT believers, is becoming ours experientially, even now at the point of death,
if we qualify misthologically.
       As a result of Christ’s sufferings, He became perfect in the sense of reaching His goal of winning an
eternal misthological resting-place, as a man, in the City of Rest, which He can share with the believing remnant
of humanity who live obediently just as He did:

 •   “For it was fitting for Him, for whom are all things, and through whom are all things, in bringing many
     sons to glory, to perfect the author of their salvation through sufferings” (Heb 2:10).
 •   “Although He was a Son, He learned obedience from the things which He suffered. And having been made
     perfect, He became the author of eternal salvation to all those who obey Him” (Heb 5:8-9; TM).

      Jesus was perfected through His sufferings in the sense that He became (ginomai) something He was not
Page 100                                                                             Misthological Models Part 4
before: “the author of their salvation.” He became an author. When I wrote my first book, I became something
I was not before—an author. Likewise, when Jesus took captivity captive and led the faithful believers to their
heavenly rest inside the City of Rest, He became something He was not before—the author of their
misthopological salvation. At that point, He brought many sons to glory, that is, to the heavenly home in glory.
As a result of His ascension, “He became the author of eternal salvation to all those who obey Him.” The aorist
tense is used, not the future tense. He became—not will become—the author of this experience at that point in
time. He already has written His book, so to speak. He already has become the author of the firstborn enrolled
in Heaven (Heb 12:23) in that firstborn saints (i.e., the spirits of righteous believers) are living already in the
Heavenly City as citizens of that city. Christ already has become the author of misthopological salvation,
providing this misthopological experience, ever since His ascension, to faithful believers during the
intermediate state.
        Jesus reached His goal of becoming such an author by learning obedience. In the same manner, believers
must learn to “obey Him” if they are to win this eternal salvation. This eternal salvation in Heb 5:9 is not merely
a millennial salvation that awaits future realization but a salvation that the spirits of the righteous made perfect
already have been enjoying for two millennia. Those misthologists who claim that rewards only last a thousand
years are refuted by the realization that the faithful are being rewarded already in the intermediate state and will
continue to be rewarded in the millennial kingdom and beyond. Rewards cannot possibly be limited to a future
thousand years when the spirits of the faithful have been enjoying their heavenly rewards for two thousand
years!
        At the point of their physical death, those believers who have obeyed Him, during the course of their
earthly lives, are being taken to the Heavenly City and literally seated with Christ in the heavenly places
(cp. Eph 2:6). Being seated with Him is not merely a positional truth but a literal experience on the part of those
faithful believers who have crossed over to the other side. The Lord won the right to be exalted as a faithful
human being and to share this exaltation with other faithful human beings who would believe in Him and then
follow His example. The right He won was to sit down “at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the
heavens” (Heb 8:1) as a victorious man and share this right with victorious human believers. He already has
taken His seat in the Heavenly City. He became the author/source of this same experience to believers who
obey Him. Those believers who follow Him obediently are taking their seats with Him as they pass over to the
other side.
        What happened when Enoch was taken to the other side, that is, was translated (KJV) or taken up (NAS)?
“By faith Enoch was taken up so that he should not see death; and he was not found because God took him up;
for he obtained the witness that before his being taken up he was pleasing to God” (Heb 11:5). The OT
background for this text is Gen 5:24, of course: “And Enoch walked with God; and he was not, for God took
him.” The popular theory adopted herein is that God took Enoch to Heaven. A popular counter argument is that
Enoch could not have been taken to Heaven because, many years later, Jesus said that no one but Him had
ascended to Heaven (Jn 3:13). This objection is not entirely persuasive, however, because Scripture also says,
“It is appointed for men to die once and after this comes judgment” (Heb 9:27), yet we know that there are
exceptions, like Lazarus, to this general rule. Exceptionality apparently applies to Enoch on both accounts: He
did not die, and he did ascend to Heaven. Notwithstanding, he did not ascend to the Holy Hill, to New
Jerusalem.213 The same chapter of Hebrews, which presumably affirms Enoch’s heavenly ascension, also

         Another popular explanation notes that Elijah and Enoch were ascended passively; whereas, Christ
ascended actively. They were taken, in other words, while He ascended by His own power. Yet another
explanation adds that Christ was the first (and only one) to ascend as the firstborn from the dead (Col 1:18;
Rev 1:5), which goes back to Ps 89:27, an enthronement Psalm. Christ became the firstborn at this time (Heb
1:6-7), preeminent in terms of misthological rights. He is the only one to ascend as the firstborn, that is, with
this type of authority. Thus, only He speaks these heavenly things with the type of authority Jesus is claiming.
Various commentaries come to similar conclusions: Barnes, Jamieson-Fausset-Brown, Matthew Poole, Gill.
See http://biblehub.com/commentaries/john/3-13.htm. Some would also add that Jesus’ using the question
posed in Prov 30:4, “Who has ascended into heaven and descended?” to frame His answer. Elijah did not go up
to Heaven and return to tell about it. The same might not be said about Enoch, admittedly, in that he seemly
made heavenly trips before his translation, if we believe the book of Enoch. Nevertheless, Enoch did not return
after his translation to tell us about it, and he only traversed the lower realm of Heaven, the basement of Heaven,
so to speak.
         Such explanations are not mutually exclusive, of course. Indeed, Nicodemus should have been able to
acknowledge the plausibility of each of these explanations. He would have been aware that Elijah and Enoch
were taken into Heaven, per the OT. Equally obviously, according to the OT, they did not ascend by their own
power or with the authority anticipated by Psalms. Nicodemus presumably would be aware of the tradition that
Enoch was taken to the lower part of Heaven, and thus one logically could deduce that Enoch could not speak
with authority regarding the higher heavenly truths concerning where God lives.
         This explanation also allows the possibility that Moses was raised from the dead before Christ, but
Moses was not raised as the firstborn, and thus not as the first fruit, in that Moses was not even allowed into the
Heavenly City until Christ ascended and took righteous believers, including Moses, to the city. Any supposed
conflict with Acts 26:23 must take into account that Christ was not the first person physically raised from the
dead; nevertheless, He was the first raised preeminently from the dead. He was first in preeminence rather than
sequence.

Ellingworth
        Ellingworth (NIGTC) correctly translates the perfect participle in Heb 12:23 as having been made perfect
but superficially sees a contradiction in 11:40: “The reference to these human spirits ‘having been made perfect’
is in apparent contradiction to 11:40.” Posing a scriptural contradiction regarding this perfection is ridiculous.
Ellingworth is correct that perfection is being used in the same sense in both verses, but he wrongly thinks that
it is contradictory or merely “anticipated rather than fully realized.” He had the correct answer staring him right
in the face and rejected it: “It is probably misleading to suggest that the righteous are thought of here as having
been made perfect in spirit, but not yet in body: this dichotomy does not appear significant in Hebrews.”216 Not
significant?!? Hebrews is affirming this very thing! These victorious believers had not yet experienced the
better resurrection (Heb 11:35) of their physical bodies, but they have come to experience the postmortem
perfection of their departed spirits.217

disembodied spirits on the doorsteps of an unrealized eschatological misthology. What we really have, via the
writer of Hebrews, is an affirmation that the disembodied spirits of misthologically righteous believers already
have stepped through the doors of the Heavenly City and obtained a corresponding degree of misthological
perfection.

Bruce
        Bruce (NIC) affirms the perfection in terms of spirit-body dichotomy and city residency. “The new
Jerusalem has not yet come down to men, but in the spiritual realm they already have access to it....they have
already arrived there in spirit.”220 “No distinction in meaning can be pressed between ‘spirits’ and ‘souls’

already in the sense that they are with God in the heavenly Jerusalem.”221 Exactly! Although physical
perfection has not yet been attained, spiritual perfection has been attained, on the part of the faithful, in terms
of their heavenly residency in the Heavenly City.
        When greater specificity is necessitated, in a passage such as Heb 4:12, I hold to a trichotomous
perspective.222 In a passage such as Heb 12:23, though, the separation between soul and spirit is not stated since
stating it is unnecessary. The misthological perfection of the postmortem spirit includes the perfection of the
postmortem soul. The word spirit, in such a case, is a synecdoche for the spirit-soul metaphysical part of the
person. Surprisingly, the distinction between the soul and spirit can be perceived in the NDE, as Robinson
testifies:

               Then suddenly, like a butterfly breaking out of a cocoon, my inner being, my spirit, and soul
        separated from my physical body. I felt my lower torso and legs to through the mattress and bed
        frame. Then my spiritual being was poised perpendicular to my broken body. Immediately I was
        transported into another dimension: a spiritual world!....
               Multiple things were simultaneously revealed to me. Amazingly, I knew I was a spirit, I had
        a soul, and I lived in a physical body in the natural world.223

       The timing of my reading this particular NDE was rather amazingly to me. I was finishing my rough
draft of the current book and had switched over from reading NDE books to reading a stack of books on
trichotomy to resume my ELT writing project when I came across this NDE testimony affirming trichotomy!
Knowing that we have a soul is discernable experientially. But knowing that we have a distinct spirit is
necessarily a matter of revelation and fundamental to ELT. It had not occurred to me that even in the spiritual
world such knowledge would be foundational and necessarily one of revelation. Upon returning to his body, he
retained this perception: “To my surprise I now had the ability to perceive and detect the soul and spirit of these
human beings.”224

Lane
      Although not grasping the full misthological-versus-soteriological implications of what he is saying,
Lane (WBC) rightly acknowledges the basic dichotomy:

       “The spirits of righteous persons,” refers to those who have died (BAGD 810) but who now
       inhabit the heavenly city that is the goal of the pilgrimage of godly men and women under
       both covenants (11:10, 13–16; 13:14). The choice of this designation for those righteous persons

        Precisely! The spirits of these godly, righteous believers now inhabit the Heavenly City, which was the
(preliminary and primary) goal of their misthological pilgrimage. A major part of their realized misthology is
that they are now allowed to live in the Reward City as an inaugurated foretaste of the full misthology yet to
come. This part he got right.
        Lane allows two options for the perfect participle in Heb 12:23: “The participle can be understood
eschatologically, [1] in reference to those who have already passed through judgment (cf. 9:27) and have
obtained the verdict that they are righteous, or [2] soteriologically, in reference to those who have been
decisively purged and consecrated to God by the sacrificial death of Jesus.” In other words, it can be used
misthologically or soteriologically.
        With his death-then-judgment affirmation, the writer of Hebrews already has hinted in Heb 9:27
that a preliminary judgment occurs immediately after death, not having to await the resurrection. He
does not postpone judgment by saying resurrection then judgment. Rather, he acknowledges death then
judgment. Logistically, a soteriological sorting between unbelievers and believers must occur immediately after
death. The writer of Hebrews is laying the foundation for concluding that a preliminary sorting occurs
regarding the spirits of believers at the point of death. At the point of death, the spirits of righteous believers
are perfected in the intermediate state (so Heb 12:23; cp. 9:27), now that the church age has come (so
Heb 11:40), by a maturation that allows them to enter the Heavenly City and advance to the upper levels (so
Heb 12:23).226 To be consistent with the biblical context and his own summation of that context, the first option
that Lane posed for the participle, the misthological option, is the one he should have chosen: They now inhabit
this city because of their successful pilgrimage through a context discussing rewards.
        Not terribly surprisingly, though, Lane choses the other option, the second one, and thinks that the perfect
participle in Heb 12:23 “decisively favors the soteriological interpretation of the expression” and applies to all
believers on the basis of Heb 10:14. Not so! The perfection of ch. 12 is separated from the soteriological
perfection of ch. 10 by the misthological perfection of ch. 11. After laying the soteriological foundation of
perfection in Heb 10:14, the context advances to a higher level of perfection in ch. 11—misthological

unfulfilled burning passions and desires (pp. 115-116). He knew that he would have life forever (cp. Jn 5:24).
Based on his experience, he says, “In heaven there exists nothing but purity. No remembrance of any
wrongdoing, no regrets....Shame, guilt, remorse, all wiped out....This is why we can understand ‘God will wipe
away every tear’ (Revelation 21:4)” (pp. 120-121). I challenge this no-regret misthology in Part 1 of this series.
Reconciling his statements with my counterclaims is not difficult. His assessment is based on his experience
during the intermediate state. My intermediate model poses that regret and shame are not experienced during
the intermediate state but await the Bema. He will later affirm the doctrine of rewards and laying up treasure in
Heaven (p. 235). Further, he acknowledges: “I learned later that if we want God to forgive our offenses, we
must be willing to forgive others” and that the merciful will receive mercy (Mt 5:7; 6:14-15). Certainly, if God
does not forgive us at the Bema, then we will be painfully aware of the offenses concerning which He has not
forgiven us. Lack of misthological forgiveness necessarily implies that we will remember our wrongdoings if
they are unforgiven misthologically. Misthological shame and regret will then ensue if we have been
unforgiving and, therefore, are unforgiven misthologically (1Jn 2:28). After all, after his NDE regeneration,
Robinson acknowledges that Jesus was sadden by the way Robinson was subsequently living (p. 188). Later,
because of his serving the Lord faithfully in following years, Jesus was proud of him (p. 237). Biblically, one
can anticipate similar results at the Bema.

perfection—from which the writer of Hebrews derives his misthological conclusion in ch. 12.
       Lane correctly states that these spirits in Heb 12:23 are “‘righteous,’ because their lives reflected the faith
of which God approves.” Duh! In this statement Lane acknowledges that the righteousness in question is ethical,
not imputational. Their persevering faith expresses itself in their lives by the way they live and thus qualifies
for reward. Misthological righteousness, not a soteriological righteousness, is clearly entailed. Unfortunately,
Lane fuses soteriological perfection with misthological righteousness and thus confuses his soteriology and
misthology. He correctly observes, “It was necessary, however, for the people under the old covenant to wait
until their transfer to the heavenly city,” but he wrongly adds, “which is the direct result of the accomplished
sacrifice of Jesus in his office as high priest.”227 What? Has he forgotten what he himself has admitted, that they
are righteous because of the way they lived? The sacrifice of Jesus laid the foundation for these believers to
obtain the Heavenly City, no doubt, but they did so by their own faithful sacrifice. They build upon this
soteriological foundation with misthological works and won (earned) the prize. How quickly Lane has forgotten
ch. 11, which expounds upon the reward nature of the Reward City! Yes, under the old covenant they had to
wait for their transfer to the Heavenly City (Heb 11:40). Lane is correct in that part of his assessment. Yet what
the writer of Hebrews is strongly asserting is that the wait is over! With the dawn of the new covenant, these
faithful believers are even now, already during the intermediate state, in the Heavenly City.
       Granted, they still await the better resurrection of Heb 11:35, when the physical bodies of misthological
perfect spirits will be raised and transformed into co-gloried bodies to rule physically over the physical Earth
and universe. Apart from us, those OT believers would still be in subterranean Paradise. Yet, as attested by both
Scripture and NDE data, the spirits of these faithful believers are now in the Heavenly City, appropriately
clothed, as overcomers, in the white garments of victory (cp. Rev 6:11). Lane is correct that they already have
been judged, but he is blind to the misthological implications of such judgment: “Those to whom reference is
made in v 23b are the aggregate of faithful men and women who have already died and faced their judgment
(9:27), having been ‘perfected’ on the ground of Jesus’ high priestly offering (10:14).”228 Impossible! Lane is
proposing that as a result of their misthological judgment they get the soteriological perfection which was
granted (1) as a free gift (2) before they were judged! No way! The purpose of judgment is not to give free gifts
or something you already have! Judgment is always based on works and thus awards rewards, not gifts! Their
postmortem inhabitation of this city proves realized misthology.
Pink
       Referencing Owen, Pink is on the right track to affirm the misthological nature of present happiness in
the presence of God:

       As Owen defined it: First, they had reached the end of the race wherein they had been engaged,
       with all the duties and difficulties, temptations and tribulations connected therewith. Second, they
       were completely delivered from sin and sorrow, labor and trouble, which in this life they had been
       exposed to. Third, they had now entered their rest and reward and were, according to their
       present capacity, in the immediate presence of God and perfectly happy.229 (Bold his.)

       Notwithstanding his acknowledgment their entrance into this happy rest is a reward, Pink is prevented,
by his own prejudices, from following these comments through to the obvious conclusion. On the one hand, he
acknowledges that they now have been perfected because they have received their reward; on the other hand,
he thinks that this fulfillment in Heb 11:39-40 is merely the coming of the Savior. The promised Savior had
come, without doubt, but it apparently escapes his notice that the coming of the Savior was not a reward.
       Pink rejects, as “crude and arbitrary,” the attempts by dispensationalists “to rightly divide the word of
truth” on this matter, and he launches an extended discussion against dispensationalism, asserting that even in
the past OT “saints enjoyed all the essential spiritual blessings of which Christians now partake.” After all,
according to Pink, OT believers “went to Heaven at death,” just like NT believers.230 So he rejects the
dispensational alternate:

        This anti-dispensational answer by Pink is that all believers, both OT and NT believers alike, go to

to affirm a realized misthology. In some way, these faithful OT believers have now entered their rest and reward
in an inaugurated misthological manner consistent with their present capacity, in the immediate presence of
God, in a manner that they did not before that advent of the NT era.
        Dispensationalism makes a consistent answer possible. The OT believers were in a subterranean
Paradise, in a parallel dimension, overlapping the heart of the Earth during the OT era. At the time of Christ’s
resurrection, however, they and Paradise were moved to the immediate presence of God in Heaven. Thus,
faithful OT believers, having undergone the preliminary judgment, are today, after Christ’s resurrection, in the
Heavenly City, known also in my research and in accord with the context as the City of Rest and Reward City.
They have now, after Christ’s resurrection, come to “the city which is to come” (Heb 13:14). This city has not
yet come to Earth, but the faithful dead already have come to the city, now that the NT era has commenced.
The physical aspect of their holistic misthological perfection awaits the future, admittedly, but their spirits now
enjoy the Heavenly City. Pink does not merit any further refutation, as he refutes himself and is refuted by the
context.
                                      Misthological Salvation of the Spirit
        As explained more fully in Darkness, the misthological salvation of one’s spirit finds potential
collaboration in other biblical texts. Dwight Hunt (GNTC) has provided an attractive misthological
interpretation for 1Cor 5:5. The wayward believer is delivered over to Satan for (eis) the temporal destruction
of his flesh for the temporal goal of the person repenting in order that (hina) he may attain spiritual wellness at
the Bema.232
        Indeed, 1Thess 5:23 provides a collaborating conceptual parallel for Hunt’s misthological understanding
of such salvation. Paul prays that God may sanctify the believers wholly (spirit, soul, and body) in order that
they may be holistically blameless at the Bema. Specifically, he desires that their spirit will be misthologically
blameless. To have one’s spirit saved from misthological blame would be a misthological salvation of one’s
spirit. Conceptually at least, one may acknowledge the misthological salvation of one’s spirit. Perhaps one
might combine my preference for the spirit denoting a soteriologically secure ontological core with this
misthological view by suggesting that Paul desires the misthological salvation of the soteriological core. A
believer’s regenerate spirit will be soteriologically blameless and ontologically sinless, to be sure, but the
misthological blamelessness of the believer’s spirit will be contingent upon the purity of the believer’s walk.233
