    Wilkin well summarizes the misthological, holistic interplay between the spirit and body in 1Thess 5:23,
rightly asserting, at the misthological level, “One cannot be blameless in his spirit if this body is not blameless”
(GNTC, 949). Robert N. Wilkin, I Thessalonians, GNTC, 949. The misthological blamelessness of our spirit is
conditioned on what we do with our bodies. Or as explained more technically in my book, ELT, Paul prays that
their ontologically sinless spirits be found misthological blameless in 1Thess 5:23 because of his holistic
Chapter 2. Biblical Analysis of Heaven                                                                    Page 107
       Even those believers who do not walk in the light will find that they themselves are saved soteriologically
(1Cor 3:15) because of their regenerate spirit, but they will not find that their regenerate spirit is saved
misthologically. In less technical jargon, Paul desires, in 1Cor 5:5, that this born-again person repent in the
present life and thus experience salvation at the Bema. This believer is already “one spirit” with the Lord
(1Cor 6:17). Spiritual birth had resulted in spiritual union. As a result of this spiritual union, believers already
are betrothed to the Lord. Yet to attain the intended goal of this spiritual union and thus enjoy misthological
consummation, believers must be pure (2Cor 11:2). Just as Paul desires for the betrothed to be wed, so he desires
for those who are secure soteriologically to be saved misthologically.234 These spirits of faithful OT believers
now join faithful NT believers in the Heavenly City. They have been perfected in the sense of having reached
their appointed goal, the Reward City. The OT believers had to await the NT era to reach this goal. But now,
with the advent of the NT era, the OT faithful reside with the NT faithful in the Heavenly City.
       What about the unfaithful during the intermediate state? Lindsay did not really say. He skipped ahead to
the eternal state to indicate that only the faithful would qualify to dwell in this Bridal City. Notwithstanding, he
did supply us with the framework to make a straightforward affirmation from Hebrews of such misthopology
even during the intermediate state. The implication of Heb 12:23 is that ethically righteous believers, who were
trying to qualify for living in the Reward City, already have obtained their goal in relation to that city, insofar
as their spirits are able to realize that misthological teleiology—subsequent to Christ’s resurrection, per
Heb 11:40—so that they, and they alone, now inhabit that Reward City. In accord with the generic nature of
rewards and the specific misthological promises and warnings in the book of Hebrews, unfaithful believers
would be excluded from living in this Heavenly City. In fact, the writer of Hebrews practically says as much.
This Reward City can be appropriately called the City of Rest. The writer of Hebrews repeatedly warns believers
that they will not enter this rest if they give up the race (Heb 3:11-4:11). Dillow translates Heb 3:11 as saying
that they will never enter My Rest.235 Does never not mean forever? BDAG (ei, 4) likewise calls this
grammatical construction a “marker of strong or solemn assertion,” in this case, a negation that should be
translated strongly as “they shall certainly not enter.” This is an emphatic negation in the Greek text. The
unfaithful elect will never ever enter the rest.
       Given that the writer of Hebrews affirms that (1) faithful believers already have entered into the initial
phase of this rest, by entering into the City of Rest, and (2) that unfaithful believers never will enter this rest,
we are left with the straightforward deduction that (3) unfaithful believers are not now living in the City of Rest,
nor will they ever in the future inhabit this city. The never includes now. The Caulian-Crawfordian model is the
most plausible model: Unfaithful believers reside outside the city; faithful believers reside inside the city.
                                            Misthological Objections
Chitwood
       Some of my fellow misthologists will disagree with my conclusion for various reasons. Chitwood, for
example, in his book Salvation of the Soul, limits the salvation of the spirit to the soteriological realm and the
salvation of the soul to the misthological realm.

      Scripture carefully distinguishes between the soul and the spirit, never using the words
      interchangeably in this respect (cf. I Thess. 5:23; Heb. 4:12). And Scripture also carefully
      distinguishes between salvation in relation to the spirit and salvation in relation to the soul.
      Salvation in relation to the spirit is always dealt with in a past sense, but not so with the salvation
      of the soul. Rather, the salvation of the soul is always dealt with in a future sense.236 (Emphasis
      his.)

emphasis that envisions functional cleanliness rather than mere ontological purity.
234
    In any event, Moses and Elijah appearing on the Mount of Transfiguration with Jesus suggests that they
already may have been clothed in white garments, even during the intermediate state. The NDE literature
certainly affirms this to be the case. And if those standing in white robes in Rev 7:9-17 are martyrs who died
during the tribulation period, then we have strong evidence that, insofar as their spirits, they were perfect in the
sense of having white robes and living in the Heavenly City.
235
    Joseph Dillow, Final Destiny: The Future Reign of the Servant Kings, 20th edition (Monument, CO: Paniym
Group, 2014), 138, 638.
236
    Arlen L. Chitwood, Salvation of the Soul, revised ed. (Norman, OK: The Lamp Broadcast, Inc., 2011), 7.
Page 108                                                                                Misthological Models Part 4

        The most obvious problem with such a simple proposal is that it simply is not true. The singular passage
of Scripture dealing expressly with the salvation (sozo) of the spirit is 1Cor 5:5, and it places this salvation of
the believer’s spirit in the future: “I have decided to deliver such a one to Satan for the destruction of his flesh,
that his spirit may be saved in the day of the Lord Jesus” (1Cor 5:5). Admittedly, the interpretation of the verse
is highly problematic. But the best two options are to conclude that it is either affirming the unconditional
soteriological salvation of this believer’s spirit or the conditional misthological salvation of this believer’s spirit.
In either case, the salvation of this believer’s spirit is future. Moreover, the conceptual parallel that Chitwood
cites in 1Thess 5:23 is certainly dealing with the potential misthological salvation of the believer’s spirit. Paul’s
prayer, not guarantee, is: “Now may the God of peace Himself sanctify you entirely; and may your spirit and
soul and body be preserved complete, without blame at the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ.” Conceptually,
Chitwood’s book can be read profitably, but exegetically it suffers from oversimplification. His emphases are
not in accord with the exegetical facts:

              But once an individual has believed on the Lord Jesus Christ and has been dealt with on the
       basis of Christ’s finished work, realizing the birth from above — the salvation of his spirit — the
       salvation issue then shifts from the salvation of his spirit, to the salvation of his soul. The salvation
       of the spirit becomes a past, completed work and is never dealt with as an issue beyond this point.
       The Spirit of God, from this point forward, deals with the individual solely on the basis of present
       and future aspects of salvation. The individual, from this point forward, is dealt with in relation to
       the salvation of his soul.
              Thus, all Scriptures dealing with carnality or unfaithfulness of Christians, resulting in
       forfeiture or loss, MUST pertain to issues surrounding the salvation of the soul, NEVER to issues
       surrounding the salvation of the spirit.237 (Emphasis his.)

       While it is true that in terms of soteriological security the believer’s spirit is unconditionally secure and
saved the moment the believer becomes soteriologically regenerate, the Bible progresses beyond this
soteriological salvation of the regenerate spirit to allow misthological perfection, not only in 1Thess 5:23 but
in Heb 12:23 as well. A mature discussion of the salvation of the regenerate spirit will not only distinguish the
soteriological salvation of the spirit from the misthological salvation of the soul but also progress to a discussion
of the misthological salvation of the spirit. While the salvation of the soul is never entertained soteriologically
(at least not exegetically), the salvation of the spirit can progress to misthological salvation after the
soteriological salvation has been secured. Those who can handle a meaty discussion may proceed; those who
cannot should be satisfied by the conceptual milk offered by Chitwood and stop reading here.
Anonymous Writer
       As it synchronistically turns out, while I was trying to wrap up the discussion in this book, a pastor gave
me a copy of a book that his congregation had found on the internet and asked for my evaluation. Unfortunately,
the book is anonymous and lacks a Scripture index, thus not the type of book to which I normally would pay
much attention. Nevertheless, the timing of this pastor’s request perked my interest since chapter 16 of this
book deals exactly with this course of study: “Spirit, Soul, and Body—After Death, Where Does Each Go?”238
I will refer to this anonymous writer as AW and assume that this writer is a male for the sake of personal
pronouns. Just glancing at some of the material in his book gives me the impression that AW is an ultraist, and
I already have responded to a number of ultraists in my 1220 page book, The Outer Darkness, and found
ultraism wonting. Thus, I will not take time to digest or interact with AW’s 647 pages in the present writing.
For present purposes, I will content myself with chapter 16 of his book.
       AW rejects the model employed herein concerning the removal of Paradise from Hades during Christ’s
ascension. Not all ultraists would object, however. Whipple is an ultraist, and he and I are in general agreement
concerning the broad strokes of that paradise-removed model. Moreover, this model is certainly a popular

                                                Spirit-Soul Locality
        AW opens his chapter by quoting 1Thess 5:23 and then proceeds to give the standard trichotomous
explanation: “In man’s spirit he is God-conscious; in his soul he is self-conscious; in his body he is sense-
conscious” (p. 377).239 He then repeatedly appeals to Ecc 12:7 to prove that the human spirit returns unto God
at death. He argues, though, that the spirit cannot be the conscious ego of the person. Otherwise, you would
have unregenerate spirits consciously in the presence of God. Therefore, the conscious ego is limited to the
soul. AW, however, seems to be unaware of several problems with his argument pertaining to Ecc 12:7. Is he
saying that the spirits of the unregenerate are saved because their spirits return to God as well? Does salvation
of the spirit apply equally to the regenerate and unregenerate alike? How could the righteous believers (whose
souls are within Hades) be conscious of God (if their spirits were in Heaven)? How could their conscious ego
have consciousness of God if their conscious ego was not connected to their spirit?
        AW holds the opinion, shared by others such as Chitwood, that when Jesus died, His spirit went to the
Father in Heaven (Ecc 12:7; Lk 23:46), His soul to subterranean Paradise in Hades (Acts 2:27), and His body
to the tomb.240 Frankly, I find this to be an over refinement. Peter quite possibly specifies that it was “in the
spirit” that Christ went and made proclamation to the spirits now in prison” (1Pet 3:18-19). Granted, this passage
is not decisive because some translations take the reference in v. 18 as referring to the Holy Spirit, so as to read,
for example, “by the Spirit” (NKJ). In any case, when Jesus commends His spirit to the Father, He may simply
be using a synecdoche of the part for the whole.241 The same is true in Acts 2:27, regarding Christ’s soul not
being abandoned to Hades. He committed His spirit (inclusive of His soul) to His Father, but this does not mean
that He immediately went to His Father. Rather, His spirit-soul metaphysical conscious ego was not abandoned
in Hades by His Father. In His metaphysical person Jesus went to Paradise before He went in His spirit-soul to
the Father. He went to Paradise before He went home to His Father. Soul and spirit are not being juxtaposed
with one another in these passages. Rather they are being used to refer to the entire immaterial part of His being.
        As to AW’s insistence that Ecc 12:7 proves that the human spirit returns to God, if this verse must be
pressed to have metaphysical specificity and applicability to all humanity at the point of death, as AW seems
to think, then this statement need not mean anything more than at death the metaphysical component returns to
God in the sense of being metaphysically accountable to God and going to the metaphysical location assigned
by God. The writer of Hebrews suggests something similar with his death-then-judgment metaphysical
affirmation (Heb 9:27).
        Paul’s exuberance at the prospect of being with the Lord at the point of death is not explainable by AW’s
hypothesis that Paul would be sent to a subterranean Paradise. Whereas Paul, as a NT believer, counted it gain
to die and be at home with Christ, OT believers did not rejoice at the prospect of death. Consider Paul’s
eagerness to die and be with Christ: “For to me, to live is Christ, and to die is gain. But if I am to live on in the
flesh, this will mean fruitful labor for me; and I do not know which to choose. But I am hard-pressed from both
directions, having the desire to depart and be with Christ, for that is very much better” (Phil 1:21-23). “We are
of good courage, I say, and prefer rather to be absent from the body and to be at home with the Lord” (2Cor 5:8).
Contrast the bleak statements made by the psalmist at the prospects of death: “For there is no mention of Thee

239

conscious, although that consciousness is mediated through the spirit. I offer a more sophisticated trichotomy

treatment. Suffice it to say here that the soul needs the spirit to be conscious of God. For this reason, among
others, AW’s placing the soul in Hades, separated from the spirit in Heaven, is rejected herein.

in death; in Sheol who will give Thee thanks?” (Ps 6:5) “The dead do not praise the Lord, nor do any who go

I found distress and sorrow” (Ps 116:3). Righteous Hezekiah did not want to go to Sheol, expressing the same

                                            David’s Spiritual Ascension
        Moving on to another of his proof texts, AW asserts that Acts 2:34 proves that David was still in Hades
after Christ ascended to Heaven. Now perhaps if the present tense had been used in this verse, as the KJV
translates it, then this might have been a little more challenging argument: “For David is not ascended into the
heavens” (KJV). AW cites some commentators holding that perspective, but I am totally unimpressed since the
aorist tense is used: “For it was not David who ascended into heaven, but he himself says: ‘The Lord said to
my Lord, “Sit at My right hand.’” The thousand years that David had been dead was more than long enough for
it to be apparent to all Peter’s listeners that this passage from Ps 110:1 was not fulfilled by David. AW seems
to have forgotten that in this context Peter is stressing the fact of the physical resurrection, that God raised Jesus,
not David, physically from the dead to fulfill this prophecy.
       29
         “Brethren, I may confidently say to you regarding the patriarch David that he both died and
       was buried, and his tomb is with us to this day. 30 “And so, because he was a prophet, and knew
       that God had sworn to him with an oath to seat one of his descendants upon his throne, 31 he
       looked ahead and spoke of the resurrection of the Christ, that He was neither abandoned to
       Hades, nor did His flesh suffer decay. 32 “This Jesus God raised up again, to which we are all
       witnesses. (Acts 2:29-32, cp. 2:24)

        Peter stresses that David’s body was still in his tomb; Jesus’ body was not. This passage was not fulfilled
by Jesus’ spirit allegedly ascending to the Father without His soul and body. This fulfillment requires a physical
resurrection. The only thing that I see that AW might have proven is that David was not one of those resurrected
when Christ was raised from the death (Mt 27:51-53). AW certainly has failed to prove that Christ could not
have taken David up to Heaven with Him when He ascended. For this reason, even if Lenski were correct
(which he is not) to assert that David ascended spiritually to Heaven when he died, David would not have
fulfilled this prophecy because, as Lenski notes, a physical resurrection was necessary. This prophecy
presupposes a physical resurrection so as to qualify to sit in this manner. One cannot sit as conqueror over death
until one has conquered death personally, for example.242

                                                 Captivity Captive
        As to leading captivity captive in Eph 4:8, AW argues that this cannot mean to led the OT believers from
Hades because the OT background in Ps 68:18 is that of taking the opposing forces captive, leading them “forth
in a victory parade in which he would go in front of his chained ENEMY CAPTIVES” (emphasis his). So AW
asks, “Did Paul, when he quoted this verse from Psalms 68, mean to reverse the interpretation from the
original?” (p. 384) Even accepting AW’s analysis at face value, I might ask, “Did AW not notice that when
Paul quoted the verse he reversed the word receive to make it give?” In the OT verse, it says that He received
gifts. In the NT adaptation is that He gave gifts. Is receiving gifts the same as giving gifts? Now, I do not see
any real conflict with either. Receiving gifts for men and giving gifts to men expresses the same basic idea. You
have to receive the gifts before you can give them. So too, even though Blaikie believes that the enemy forces
were “led captive by Christ,” it was an “occasion of a triumph of spoils of the enemy” so “we must not press
the analogy too far.”243 Taking captivity captive shows taking the triumphant spoils of the enemy, in this case,

242
    Even if David had been raised from the dead and passively taken up to Heaven, this would not necessarily

    W. G. Blaikie, Ephesians, PC, s.v., Eph 4:8.

those OT believers who had been held captive in Hades by death and leading them forth out of enemy
territory.244 After all, Jesus did not lead the demons forth out of the torment section of Hades in chains. They
are still there. Personally, I am inclined to see Abraham’s rescue of Lot and his family and possessions in
Gen 14:16 as a typological picture of this event: “And he brought back all the goods, and also brought back his
relative Lot with his possessions, and also the women, and the people.” Abraham defeated a band of kings and
led the captives to freedom, to be sure, but to the victor belongs the spoils (Heb 7:4), and they (i.e., his family
and friends) were part of the spoils of his victory.
        On the other hand, taking AW’s argument at face value is open to serious question. He appeals to the use
of this expression in the OT for support. I will provide the fuller quote used above:

      The expression “led captivity captive” is used twice in the Old Testament. The first occurs in
      Judges 5:12, and is the very cry of Deborah to Barak who had returned victorious from battle with
      Sisera. She was instructing him as the victorious commander to lead forth in a victory parade in
      which he would go in front of his chained ENEMY CAPTIVES. Deborah certainly did not mean
      that he was to gather his own soldiers who may have been prisoners of Sisera and whom had been
      released at victory. (Emphasis his, 384.)

       E. R. Craven, the American editor for Lange’s commentary on Revelation has an extended discussion
therein, entitled Excursus on Hades, which defends the descent-into-Hades model admirably, wherein he comes
to the exact opposite conclusion:

             It also seems clear to the writer that, in accordance with Scripture usage, the phrase “led
      captivity captive” must have reference to the deliverance of captured friends. This
      phrase, unqualified, occurs but twice in the Old Testament—once in the Psalm from which the
      Apostle quotes it, Ps. 68:18; and again in the Song of Deborah and Barak, Judges 5:12: “Arise,
      Barak, and lead thy captivity captive, thou son of Ahinoam.” Regarded merely as a phrase, it may
      mean either of two things: (1) to lead as prisoners a number of enemies, or (2) to lead as re-captured
      a number of friends previously captured by an enemy. The latter seems to be its most natural
      interpretation;* and this manifestly is its meaning in Judges 5:12, the only passage in which the
      context determines the meaning. It is clearly implied, Judg. 4:16, that Barak took no prisoners, in
      the words: “All the host of Sisera fell upon the edge of the sword, and there was not a man left.”
      The captivity that Barak led captive must have been captured Israel. As this interpretation is
      manifestly the meaning of the phrase in one of the two instances of its occurrence in the Old
      Testament, it is but logical to conclude that it is its meaning in the other also. This conclusion is
      strengthened by the considerations, first, that there is nothing in Ps. 68 to forbid our putting this
      interpretation upon it; and, secondly, that the Song of Deborah and Barak was manifestly in the
      mind of the inspired writer when he penned the Psalm. This is evident from a comparison of the
      two passages of Scripture.
             This, then, is not only the natural, but the scripturally suggested interpretation
      of Eph. 4:8, 9,—that Christ descended into Hades, and then ascended into Heaven (above all
      Heavens), leading a multitude whom He had delivered (captured) from captivity.245 (Emphasis
      his.)

      Evidently, AW failed to check the broader context. He certainly failed to mention the reference in
Jdg 4:16, which appears to undercut his whole argument. Craven’s assessment is superior, leading him correctly
to deduce that in Heb 12:22-24 “the teaching seems to be that not only are “‘the spirits of just men’ now
‘made perfect’ (comp. 11:30); but that all such are with angels, and with God the Judge of all, and with
Jesus, in the heavenly Jerusalem.”246
244
    For a scholastic example of the difficulties one encounters in explaining how the NT writers use the OT, see
Walter C. Kaiser, The Uses of the Old Testament in the New.
245
    John Peter Lange, Revelation vol. 24, Commentary on the Holy Scriptures, ed. Philip Schaff (Grand Rapids:
Zondervan Publishing House, 1960), 374. This is from Craven’s entire discussion therein: Excursus on Hades.

                                          Paradise and Third Heaven
       In order to maintain his assertion that OT believers were not led forth from Paradise into Heaven, AW
strains to make a distinction between Paradise and the third heaven by posing that Paul had two separate visions
in the following passage:
       2
        I know a man in Christ who fourteen years ago—whether in the body I do not know, or out of
      the body I do not know, God knows—such a man was caught up [harpazo] to the third heaven.
      3
        And I know how such a man—whether in the body or apart from the body I do not know, God
      knows—4 was caught up [harpazo] into Paradise, and heard inexpressible words, which a man is
      not permitted to speak. (2Cor 12:2-4)

       The reason AW insists that Paul is talking about two different visions is so that he can maintain his thesis
that OT and NT believers are still in subterranean Paradise. The multiple “visions and revelations,” however,
to which Paul referred in 1Cor 12:1, should be understood as taking place in Paradise in the third heaven.
Admittedly, AW correctly points out that harpazo can either mean caught up or caught away. The direction of
the movement is determined by the context and subject matter. Naturally, AW acknowledges that the translators
are correct in rendering harpazo as caught up regarding Paul being taken to the third heaven. Yet he insists that
harpazo be translated as caught away when used of Paradise in the same context because AW believes that
Paradise is still in Hades. However, if Paul’s intent is to say that he went down to Paradise then he certainly has
done so in a very strange manner. First, he uses the same word which he has just used to describe being caught
up to Heaven to describe going down to Paradise in Hades. Second, he uses a word that does not denote going
down. Harpazo may denote being caught up or away, but it does not denote being caught down. AW is fostering
an unnatural understanding upon the word to make being caught away to mean being caught down. Third, it is
bazar that the inexpressible words that Paul describes were spoken, in AW’s opinion, down in Hades rather
than up in Heaven. To say that his theory is strained is an understatement. It sounds as if Heaven was a downer
compared to Hades in AW’s model. Paul went up to Heaven, but the exciting, inexpressible “visions and
revelations” were down in Hades. Was Heaven a letdown?

                                      The Reception of Stephen’s Spirit
      Many believe that Paul’s trip to Paradise occurred as a NDE when he was stoned (Acts 14:19). Stephen
apparently had a similar experience when he was stoned:
      55
        But being full of the Holy Spirit, he gazed intently into heaven and saw the glory of God, and
      Jesus standing at the right hand of God; 56 and he said, “Behold, I see the heavens opened up and
      the Son of Man standing at the right hand of God.” 57 But they cried out with a loud voice, and
      covered their ears, and they rushed upon him with one impulse. 58 And when they had driven him
      out of the city, they began stoning him, and the witnesses laid aside their robes at the feet of a
      young man named Saul. 59 And they went on stoning Stephen as he called upon the Lord and said,
      “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit!” (Acts 7:55-59)

Jesus stood! From both the OT and NT, we would have anticipated Jesus to be sitting (Ps 110:1; Acts 2:33-34;
Eph 1:20; Col 3:1; Heb 1:3; 8:1; 10:12). An impression shared by many is that Jesus stood to give Stephen a
standing reception into Heaven as the first Christian martyr. AW would have us skip over the context (which
strongly conveys the impression that Stephen’s spirit was received up into Heaven) and run all the way back to
Ecc 7:7 (p. 383), so as to conclude that Jesus sent Stephen down to Hades rather than receive him into Heaven!

                                               Heavenly Paradise of God
       As if that argument was not forced enough, AW then acknowledges that the Tree of Life which is in “the
paradise of God” in Rev 2:7 “is heavenly in location,” but he tries to reduce the impact of this observation by
pointing out that it is “future, not present, as to our enjoyment of it” (p. 387, emphasis his). Certainly, Revelation
does promise the Tree of Life as a future reward in the eternal state (Rev 22:14,19). Nevertheless, this does not
prove that it cannot be experienced right now. After all, overcomers are not only promised that they will be able
to eat of the Tree of Life in the future, but they are also promised white garments (Rev 3:5). Yet it appears that
white robes might be given to them even in the intermediate state (Rev 7:9,13). Perhaps some rewards, such as
Chapter 2. Biblical Analysis of Heaven                                                                 Page 113
living in the Reward City, wearing white robes, and eating of the Tree of Life are being experienced already by
the faithful. If the NDEs have any credibility, then this is indeed the case. In any event, according to Rev 2:7,
the Paradise of God is (presently, not merely futuristically) in Heaven, not Hades, and Heaven has the Tree of
Life, which in the future, even if not presently, will be limited to overcomers. The most natural interpretation,
however, would be to pose that only overcomers inhabit this heavenly Paradise presently in white garments and
partake of the Tree of Life, in accord with Hebrews stressing that subcomers will never enter this spatial
experience of rest.

                                              Souls under the Alter
       As to the souls under the alter (Rev 6:9) that John saw when he was caught up to Heaven (Rev 4:1),
AW’s assessment is that the alter represents the Earth and these souls are thus under the Earth in subterranean
Paradise.247 Although I disagree, I am very open to part of his hypothesis: “At the time here in view the
resurrection of these godly martyrs has not yet come, for the role of the martyrs is not complete. These
brethren therefore are still without their resurrection bodies” (p. 388, emphasis his). This proposition is
reasonable, perhaps even probable. In any case, it is very popular among the commentators, and I will adopt
AW’s disembodied state of these souls as my working hypothesis as well. AW and I also concur that these
garments are misthological. Believers must be faithful in order to wear such garments (p. 390). That being the
case, my thesis that faithful believers already could be rewarded to a preliminary extent, and thus dwelling in
the Heavenly City and eating from the Tree of Life currently, is completely reasonable. As we both would
agree, then, a preliminary misthological judgment must occur at the point of death that allows limited
misthological benefits to be conferred on faithful disembodied souls. I pose that these benefits are experienced
in heavenly Paradise rather than subterranean Paradise. They are given as a misthological pledge of the fuller
misthological benefits yet to come when they stand physically before the Bema in resurrected bodies.248 As to
AW’s speculation that the alter represents Earth and the souls are under the Earth, I am more intrigued by the
NDEr who was caught up to Heaven and saw the souls standing under the alter—the alter was a raised structure,
so a multitude of disembodied souls were standing under it in Heaven. These souls already have been perfected
misthologically to the extent possible in their disembodied state as they wait in Heaven for their physical
resurrection and the corresponding rulership to be awarded them at that time.

                                               Perfect Participle
       Appealing to Heb 11:40 and 12:23, AW argues counter wise: “It was not possible that ‘they apart from
us’ should be made perfect” (p. 392, emphasis his). Agreed! That part of his argument is clear from Heb 11:40.
But his argument has a fatal flaw when he adds his interpretation, “The Old Testament saints also are waiting
to ‘be made perfect’ at the same general time as the overcoming Christians” (p. 392, emphasis his). Using the
present tense he claims that they “are waiting.” Supposedly, “therefore the godly dead must yet await for their
perfecting” (p. 393). Not so! The writer of Hebrews asserts otherwise in 12:23: These spirits already have been
made perfect. The biblical writer uses the perfect participle and AW completely ignores this fact, thereby
distorting the facts. These NT believers have come (perfect tense)—in terms of misthological potentiality and
new dispensational reality—“to the spirits of the righteous having been made perfect” (TM, perfect participle).
Checkmate! They have come “unto a point of privilege” that is now being experienced already in the new
era by the spirits of the disembodied righteous.249 Because AW misses the significance of the perfect
participle in 12:23, he completely misconstrues the meaning of Heb 11:40, standing it on its head to make it
mean that they “were still not perfect” (p. 394). The biblical text is asserting just the opposite of what AW

      Craven, in beautiful contrast, not only gets the perfect aspect correct but also opens the misthological
nature of the present perfection for further reflection:

                 A second Scripture is Heb. 11:40, compared with Heb. 12:23. These passages occur in the
         same section of the Epistle—that which exhorts believers to patience that they may obtain the

        My optimistic assessment of Craven’s position is based not only on his comment above, which conditions
their obtaining this present spiritual perfection by means of their patient perseverance, but also on my other
summations regarding Craven as expressed in Darkness. Namely, as explained more fully therein, as early as
1874, Craven had concluded that the citizens of the city were risen glorified believers who composed the Bride
of Christ, that the nations probably were composed of men in flesh and blood bodies who reproduced throughout
eternity, and that the Bride of Christ likely was composed of only overcomers who are the governors (rulers)
of the New Creation.
        Craven believes the Bride is composed of a select portion of the redeemed rather than all the redeemed.
Therefore, his earlier comment that the Bride refers to “the whole body of the saints (the quick and the dead),
at the Second Advent of the Lord” (p. 337) should not be understood as indicating that the Bride refers to all
the redeemed but that the Bride is composed of both the living and the dead. In short, Craven believes that the
Bride is not composed of all believers but only those believers who overcome (regardless of the time period in
which they live). One need not necessarily agree with his early observations on all points in order to accept his
conclusion. It is not necessary to identify the Bride with the 144,000 or with the overcomers of all ages in order
to accept the fact that the Bride is only composed of overcomers. That all overcomers will rule does not, in and
of itself, prove that all overcomers are called the Bride.
Misthological Death
       In misthological circles, affirmations of misthological death are normally limited to the salvation of the
soul. The possibility that misthological might apply to the salvation of the spirit would be foreign to their
mindset. But if misthology is not limited to the soul but also includes the spirit, as has been argued above, then
misthological death must have applicability to the spirit as well. This assessment is intuitive in that in
1Thess 5:23 Paul prays for a misthological blamelessness that would apply holistically to a believer’s spirit,
soul, and body. Those believers who fail to obtain this misthological blamelessness, on the other hand, would
be misthologically blameworthy. Because being misthologically blameless is a form of misthological life, being
misthologically blameworthy would be a form of misthological death—both apply equally to the spirit, soul,
and body. As discussed more thoroughly in Darkness, Paul teaches that God

         will reward every man according to his works. 7 He will reward eternal life to those who seek for
         glory and honor and immortality by perseverance in good work. (Rom 2:6-7; TM).

        Of course, as Paul goes on to demonstrate, it is impossible for unjustified sinners to please God by their
works. However, believers have been justified and regenerated and, consequently, can live lives that are
pleasing to God. They can seek for immortal glory and honor by doing good works, and as the text goes on to
state, “Glory and honor and peace will be rewarded to everyone who works what is good” (Rom 2:10; TM).
Believers can qualify for eternal life as a future reward in the form of eternal glory and honor, if they do the
good works that are necessary. Conversely, Christ will be ashamed of some believers (Mk 8:38) and put them
to shame (1Jn 2:28). Instead of honor, they will reap dishonor (2Tim 2:20). Physically, they will walk around
in naked shame (Rev 3:18).
        From such texts, a misthological thanatology is easily formulated. Misthological death will affect the
subcoming believers holistically: affecting their spirit, soul, and body. Their bodies will not be: (1) clothed with
white garments, (2) able to eat of the Tree of Life, (3) wear the crown of life, or (4) allowed to enter the Reward

250
      Craven, 377.
Chapter 2. Biblical Analysis of Heaven                                                                        Page 115
City. They will be physically separated from life in such misthological regards. In regard to their physical
senses, they will be very much aware of their misthological death. In terms of their sense-conscious bodies,
they will be misthological dead. Likewise, in terms of their souls, they will be self-conscious about their
misthological shame, weeping and gnashing their teeth in soulish regret. Similarly, their God-conscious spirits
will be aware that God is ashamed of them and that they are not able to be partners with God in His misthological
enterprises. They are separated from God in terms of sharing His throne or living with Him in His capital city.
       Granted, we are able to deduce that at the soteriological level the spirit is regenerate and thus eternally
secure. The salvation of a believer’s spirit is unconditionally assured—at the soteriological level. But for that
matter, the salvation of a believer’s body is unconditionally guaranteed as well. All believers will have
redeemed, immortal, glorified bodies as a free gift. Nevertheless, this affirmation of physical salvation for all
believers does not impede misthologists from readily affirming that having immortal co-glorified bodies is a
reward limited to faithful believers. Consequently, misthologists should be able to deduce that the salvation of
the believer’s spirit may likewise be experienced at two different levels: freely at the soteriological level; costly
at the misthological level.
       At the same time, conceptually, we could affirm the soteriological salvation of the soul, with a very
important caveat: The salvation of the soul is never used in this capacity in Scripture. This caveat should not be
used as an unassailable deterrent, however. The term soteriological salvation of the soul, at least for the
misthological mature, is a conceptually useful term.251 Exegetically, salvation of the soul is never used
soteriologically, though. Conceptually, we must acknowledge that salvation is ultimately holistic, both
soteriologically and misthologically. Soteriologically, all believers will be saved in relation to their spirit, soul,
and body.252 Misthologically, only faithful believers will be saved in relation to their spirit, soul, and body.
251
    For example, I find the term glorification salvation very useful theologically and thus do not object to those
who use the term. Yet, as I point out in my exegetical analysis elsewhere, the actual words for salvation (sozo,
soteria) are never used in that capacity, being used instead to affirm co-glorification salvation in that futuristic
sense. For such reasons, James Hollandsworth can argue, plausibly, the carnal believers would be better
described as having redeemed bodies rather than glorified bodies. For my interaction with his preference, see
my book, Advanced Exchanged Life Trichotomy (AELT).
252
    The “total redemption of man,” as Whipple would put it, necessitates that all believers are saved physically,
soulically, and spiritually at the soteriological level, but Whipple fails to reach this conclusion (Whipple,
Shock, 23). He acknowledges that all church-age believers will be raptured or translated at the point of the
rapture. Good, no partial rapture. But he delays the translation of the body into glorified bodies until long after
(i.e., at the end of the millennium) in the case of unfaithful believers. Thus, he winds up putting the out-
resurrection before the resurrection (pp. 42-45)! A more logical approach would be to put the resurrection before
the out-resurrection. The out-resurrection is a misthological out-gathering at the Bema, a subset from the larger
group of those who already have been resurrected or translated at the rapture. The out-resurrection is a higher
order of resurrection. Logically, the out-resurrection must be preceded by the lower order of resurrection.
Whipple has it backwards.
          The mechanics of his ultraistic model requires that he deny that all believers have immortal bodies at
the time of rapture, resulting in a counterintuitive sequence regarding the out-resurrection. My model, in
contrast, affirms the standard dispensational understanding that all church-age believers receive glorified bodies
at the time of rapture. Contrary to Whipple, redemption does not simply put us back to where Adam was—in
sinless Adamic bodies. No! We have something Adam did not have at the time of his pre-fallen state, namely,
regenerate spirits. Therefore, the redemption of our bodies cannot possibility put us back to having no more
than what Adam lost.
          Some may mistakenly think that when the sin nature is removed from the soul, the soul will no longer
be misthologically dead. This mistake would be tantamount, to some degree, to confusing the cause of death
with the state of death. Sin causes death (Rom 6:23; Jam 1:15). But the removal of sin does not in and of itself
restore life. God must bestow life. If a corpse is taken to the morgue with a fatal gunshot in the head, the removal
of the bullet from the brain does not restore life. The fact that God removes our sin nature at the point of death
or at the rapture’s translation does not mean that He has bestowed misthological life. Having our sin nature
removed is a soteriological gift. This gift does not grant misthological life. Likewise, when God implanted
eternal life in our spirits at the point of regeneration, His doing so removed sin from our spirits. Still, holistically,
our spirits may be dead misthologically.
Page 116                                                                            Misthological Models Part 4
                                                   Conclusion
        Exegetical analyses of Heb 11:40 and 12:23 necessitate that we concur with those commentators who
understand these verses as teaching that at the commencement of the NT era the metaphysical, spirit-soul,
postmortem makeup of believers was caught up from the subterranean Paradise to heavenly Paradise to dwell
in the Heavenly City as their preliminary reward. The grammatical impact of the verbal aspect of the perfect
participle in Heb 12:23 makes it perfectly clear that these spirits of the OT faithful have been perfected. Yet we
know from Heb 11:40 that this perfection did not occur until the new era. From the immediate context, we can
deduce that this perfection is associated with entrance into this Reward City and the misthological status of
being the firstborn. From the broader context, we can perceive that it is associated with misthological rest. Since
this city is a reward and unfaithful believers are not allowed to enter this City of Rest, we may infer that they
reside outside of the city in the surrounding territories. As faithful believers in the present era die, they are
currently entering this promised City of Rest, with their works following them because of a preliminary
judgement inferred in Heb 9:27.
                                       Chapter 3.
                             Biblical Experiences of Heaven
         Introduction
       The following material in this misthological model was originally included as an appendix in my book, The
Outer Darkness (TOD). At that time, I had not seriously considered the possibility that Heaven might be bigger
than the Heavenly City. So, basically, I presented the classical descent-into-Hades theory as my working model. In
view of the current series, though, this classical model needs refinement to be true to the biblical data, particularly
Heb 12:23. These modifications will also take the better NDE conclusions into consideration. Most of the new
material will be marked in red for the sake of easy comparison.
       A basic understanding of the sequence of events regarding the intermediate state is helpful in developing
one’s misthology. Nevertheless, it must not be thought that the basic outline of events described below are limited
to misthologists or even to one particular form of misthology. The position summarized below is a popular
understanding of the sequence of events known as the Descent into Hades. Lange’s commentary on Revelation has
an extended Excursus on Hades by the American editor, Craven, inserted at Rev 20:8, that gives a far more detailed
defense of this position.253 Archer (a non-misthologist) and Whipple (a Gehenna misthologist), as well as I,
subscribe to the basic components of this popular view.

         On Earth
      The Hebrew word for garden is gan; the Greek word is paradise (paradeisos). Christians are familiar, of
course, with the Garden of Eden in Gen 2:8-16. It also may be translated as Paradise of Eden in the Greek OT (i.e.,
LXX). Alternatively, it also is referred to as the Paradise of God (Eze 28:13; 31:8-9; LXX). Paradise, otherwise
known as God’s garden, originally was located on Planet Earth. After man sinned, man was removed from Paradise.
Subsequently, Paradise was removed from Earth, at least from the surface of Earth.

         Below Earth
       Jesus said that the people of Capernaum would descend to Hades when they died: “And you, Capernaum,
will not be exalted to heaven, will you? You will descend to Hades; for if the miracles had occurred in Sodom which
occurred in you, it would have remained to this day” (Mt 11:23). In the time of the OT, the people of Sodom went
to Hades. Thus, it may be concluded that lost people went to Hades in the past. Looking to the future, Jesus still
affirms that people of Capernaum will go to Hades. Therefore, it may be deduced that lost people in the present and
future still go to Hades. Thus, Hades is the abode of the lost dead.
       The KJV unfortunately translates this reference as saying they would be in Hell, thus translating both
Gehenna and Hades as Hell. But Gehenna and Hades do not refer to the same eschatological sphere of existence.
They are not the same thing. Both the lost and saved went to Hades in OT times. Hades could be understood simply
to mean the abode of the dead. Concerning the account of a certain rich man, Jesus relates, “In Hades he lifted up
his eyes, being in torment, and saw Abraham far away and Lazarus in his bosom” (Lk 16:23). To be in his bosom
would denote an intimate dining experience. This Semitism denotes table fellowship. Because of the use of cushions
rather than chairs around the table, they could recline in proximity to each other’s chest around the table. A great
impassable chasm existed between the rich man and Lazarus (Lk 16:26).
       What were Abraham and Lazarus eating around the table? They were eating fruit from the Garden of Paradise.
Paradise had been moved to this location, as we learn a few chapters later in the Gospel of Luke, when Jesus
promises the dying thief that both He and the believing thief would be in Paradise (the Garden) when they died:
“And He said to him, ‘Truly I say to you, today you shall be with Me in Paradise’” (Lk 23:43). Accordingly, when
Jesus went to Hades, it was to Paradise. In that day Paradise was in subterranean Hades.
       Since we know that lost people descend to Hades when they die, we may conclude that the chamber of
torment in which the rich man was imprisoned was a compartment within Hades. Since Lazarus and Abraham were
in a neighboring compartment, having what appears to be a dining experience, the most natural deduction is that

        This impression is reinforced by several passages that indicate that Christ indeed did descend into Hades
when He died on the cross. Christ was not abandoned to Hades when He died (Acts 2:30-31), meaning He was not
left there. He went there and then left. Yet He did not leave alone, as we learn from Paul:
      8
       When He ascended on high, He led captive a host of captives, and He gave gifts to men. 9 (Now this
      expression, “He ascended,” what does it mean except that He also had descended into the lower parts
      of the earth? 10 He who descended is Himself also He who ascended far above all the heavens, that He
      might fill all things.)” (Eph 4:8-10)

       It is quite possible that Peter also describes Christ’s descent in 1Pet 3:18-19. If so, then Christ gave
proclamation to the lost and liberation to the saved.255 He did not suffer there. When Jesus died on the cross, He
declared, “‘It is finished!’ And He bowed His head, and gave up His spirit” (Jn 19:30). We are redeemed by His
blood (His suffering on the cross), not by any suffering on His part in Hell. Our redemption was paid in full by His
sacrifice on the cross. But where did His spirit go? “And Jesus, crying out with a loud voice, said, ‘Father, into Thy
hands I commit My spirit.’ And having said this, He breathed His last” (Lk 23:46). He committed His spirit to His
Father, but this does not mean that He immediately went to His Father. Rather, His spirit was not abandoned in
Hades by His Father. In His spirit Jesus went to Paradise before He went in His spirit to the Father. According to
Paul, Jesus descended before He ascended. He went to Paradise before He went home to His Father.
       David’s prophecy about not being left in Hades reached out beyond himself to include the Messiah: “Thou
wilt not abandon my soul to Sheol; neither wilt Thou allow Thy Holy One to undergo decay” (Ps 16:10).
Prophetically, David referred to Jesus’ soul inclusively: his/His soul/spirit was not abandoned to Sheol/Hades.256 In
the second half of the verse, David refers exclusively to Jesus’ body.

      Above the Earth
Phase One
       Jesus did not go straight home to the Father when He ascended in spirit from Hades and lead the captives
from the subterranean Paradise. He stopped to pick up His body on the way—via His resurrection. Evidently, He
shared this experience with some of the captives whom He had just liberated as well. “And the tombs were opened;
and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised; and coming out of the tombs after His resurrection
they entered the holy city and appeared to many” (Mt 27:52-53). They were resurrected also. Typically, three
questions are asked about this event. (1) When were they raised—when Jesus died or when He was raised? Since
Jesus was the first fruit (1Cor 15:20, cp. Rev 1:5), He probably was raised first and others were raised subsequently.
(2) Who was raised—was it OT heroes or believers who had died recently? Since it was evidently a resurrection of
those who had been buried around Jerusalem (who entered Jerusalem) and who were recognized when they entered
the city, most likely they were recent inhabitants of Jerusalem: Believers who had died recently could appear in the
city as witnesses to their friends of Jesus’ liberating power.257 It is not beyond the range of possibility that the
believing thief who died on the cross with Jesus could have been in that number and went and witnessed to his

Phase Two
       After greeting them, Jesus ascended, taking with Him to Heaven all those who had been in Paradise (Eph 4:8-
10). He not only moved the inhabitants of Paradise, He moved Paradise itself. According to Rev 2:7, the Tree of
Life is now in the Paradise of God. Note the present tense. The Tree of Life is in the Holy City (Rev 22:14). A
simple deduction is that the Paradise of God is in the Holy City, both now and in the future. Speaking of the present
time period, Paul says that when he was caught up to the third heaven, it was to Paradise (2Cor 12:2,4). Where is
the third heaven? The same place you will find Paradise—the Heavenly Jerusalem. Paul was caught up to Paradise;
he did not descend down to Paradise. We may deduce that Paradise had been transferred to the Heavenly City. This
deduction is confirmed by Heb 12:22-23, where the text explicitly confirms that the departed spirits of the righteous
currently inhabit the Heavenly Jerusalem.
       This standard descent-into-Hades model as presented in TOD is now amended as follows with
modifications pictured in Illustration 10. Subterranean Paradise moved to Planet Paradise. The writer of
Hebrews is affirming that, now that the transition to the NT era has occurred (Heb 11:40), these righteous
spirits already are living in the Reward City (Heb 12:23), thereby implicitly affirming the moving of
subterranean Paradise to Heaven. We are further able to deduce from his epistle that this Reward City may
also be appropriately termed the City of Rest. Moreover, this biblical writer insists that the unfaithful will
never inter this rest. Therefore, the most reasonable conclusion is that, when the captive spirits of the
redeemed saints were led forth from subterranean Paradise to heavenly Paradise, a preliminary
misthological sorting had to take place between the righteous versus unrighteous spirits of the redeemed
saints. The spirits of misthologically unrighteous believers were not allowed into the capital city—New
Jerusalem—when the subterranean Paradise was moved to its heavenly location.
       My working hypothesis is that Planet Paradise is the place where the departed spirits of the redeemed
were first taken when this transition between the OT and NT era occurred as Christ led captivity captive.
The NDE statement by Marietta Davis to this effect is very reasonable. After first being taken to the
paradisiacal plains of Planet Paradise, those spirits found to be misthologically worthy of living in the Reward
City will be taken to the city. Once in the city, they will quickly adapt to their new environment and be taken
to their heavenly mansions within the city. This level of realized misthopological perfection is envisioned by
the biblical writer in Heb 12:23. Thus, NDErs, such as Davis and many others, visiting the Heavenly City
during the church-age are finding it populated with the spirits of the righteous having been made perfect,
perfectly in accord with the biblical data, particularly the perfect participle in Heb 12:23.
       Conversely, those redeemed spirits that are not misthologically worthy of living in the city are most
likely taken off planet to inhabit the other nearby heavenly planets in the third heaven. These outlying
heavenly planets may very well be the location of the outer darkness, at least presently and perhaps
eternally.259 Therefore, in accord with the biblical data in Hebrews and the NDE data supplied by Davis, who
said that these outlying planets in the heavenly realm (i.e., the third heaven) were inhabited by holy immortal
beings in varied degrees of spirituality, I have labeled these outlying planets as the outer darkness in this

      Round Trip
       Returning now to the standard descent model, after seeing His Father and transferring Paradise and its
inhabitants to the Heavenly Jerusalem, Jesus made a return trip to earth. He wanted to see select individuals and
provide some hands-on experience. “Then He said to Thomas, ‘Reach here with your finger, and see My hands; and
reach here your hand and put it into My side; and do not be unbelieving, but believing’” (Jn 20:27). He demanded
that Thomas touch Him. Before, when Jesus had talked with the ladies, He commanded them to stop touching Him.
Chapter 3. Biblical Experiences of Heaven                                                                        Page 121
Now, He already has ascended to His Father and returns and demands that this doubting disciple touch Him.

       Guaranteed Trip
       In the OT, when believers died they went to Hades because the price for their redemption had not yet been
paid. They were put on layaway, so to speak. Once Jesus paid for their redemption with His blood, His first order
of business was to liberate these believers from their subterranean department. In the present time period, when a
believer dies, he or she still goes to be with the Lord in the third heaven (cp. Acts 7:55-60; 2Cor 5:8; Phil 1:23).
Believers are no longer put on layaway because Jesus already has paid the full price for their pardon. This guarantee
of being with the Lord applies to all believers for all time (1Thess 4:13-18). Believers will always be with the
Lord, although not necessarily in His capital city, but at least with Him in His heavenly kingdom. Gehenna is
an impossibility. Paradise has relocated from the realm of the dead to the realm of Heaven, the abode of God.
Paradise in now located within the third heaven (1Cor 12:2-4). When Paul was caught up to the third heaven,
he went to that specific part of the third heaven called Paradise, presumably to the Heavenly City on Planet
Paradise.

       With the Lord
       As a Gehenna misthologist, Faust challenges my original summation. At a kingdom conference at which
Faust and I were both teaching, while we were answering questions from the audience in a symposium at the
conclusion of the first day of the conference, I responded to a question regarding the intermediate state by surmising
that to be absent from the body is to be at home with the Lord. Faust challenged this statement by reading the text
in 2Cor 5:8 and noting that the exact wording does not make this explicit confirmation and by further pointing out
that he already had expressed his counter in his book.260 In my session the next morning, I outlined my reasons for
coming to the summation I had given. At the same time, with my paradise illustration, I also answered a question
that had been raised regarding the Heavenly Jerusalem.
       According to Faust’s assessment of the intermediate state, Stephen’s invocation suggests a condition when
he prays: “Lord Jesus, receive my spirit!” (Acts 7:59). Stephen was a white sheep, accordingly white sheep can
expect the Lord to receive their spirits. I conceded that Stephen was a white sheep, so I could not use this passage
to prove that gray sheep or black sheep would be with the Lord in the intermediate state. This text, in and of itself,
does not refute the contention made by Gehenna misthologists that the receiving of one’s spirit by the Lord at the
point of death is conditioned on being a white sheep. However, my assessment was not based on a simplistic
assumption regarding this text. Turning to the principle text in question, I made an exegetical observation:
      8
        We are of good courage, I say, and prefer rather to be absent from the body and to be at home with
      the Lord. 9 Therefore also (kai) we have as our ambition, whether at home or absent, to be pleasing to
      Him. 10 For we must all appear before the judgment seat of Christ, that each one may be recompensed
      for his deeds in the body, according to what he has done, whether good or bad. (2Cor 5:8-10)

        Even if Paul is using an exclusive we, so as to refer to the apostolic circle rather than to the Corinthian readers
in vv. 8-9, the point is still valid that his ambition is to be pleasing to the Lord, not to be present with the Lord. The
latter is presumed rather than pursued. Being with the Lord is an unqualified anticipation. Being pleasing to the
Lord, in contrast, is an ambition. The also (kai) that introduces this ambition signifies addition. That is, in addition
to the unqualified (and apparently unconditional) anticipation of being with the Lord, Paul also has the ambition of
being pleasing to the Lord. In fact, the expression of good courage that prefaces the anticipation of being with the
Lord is frequently translated as confidence: “We are confident, yes, well pleased rather to be absent from the body
and to be present with the Lord” (NKJ). Paul expresses complete confidence that if he is absent from the body, he
will be at home with the Lord. Moreover, this confidence is unconditional. The conditional component is reserved
for the additional constituent found in the next verse and amplified in the verse following it. The ambition of being
pleasing to the Lord is conditioned on a positive result at the Bema judgment.261 Together these two components

260
   Faust, 273-276.
261
   My argument in this section—for the unconditional anticipation of being home with the Lord—remains
intact, even in the new model. However, I was wrong to think that the ambition of being found pleasing to
Him is exclusively post-Bema in scope. Whether we are at home with the Lord in a disembodied state or
Page 122                                                                             Misthological Models Part 4

absent from the Lord while still in our physical bodies, we want to be found pleasing to Him—now, not just
later, that is, at the Bema. If absent in 2Cor 5:9 means to be absent from the body, as it did in 2Cor 5:8, then
the new model has explicit confirmation in this passage. Paul’s ambition is to be pleasing to God even as a
disembodied spirit in the intermediate state. If, on the other hand, absent in 2Cor 5:9 means absent from the
Lord, as it did in 2Cor 5:6, then at home in v. 9 means at home with the Lord. Once again, the new model is
confirmed; Paul’s ambition is to be pleasing to God even in a disembodied state. Regardless of which way
absent is interpreted in v. 9, Paul’s ambition is to be pleasing to God even as a disembodied spirit in the
intermediate state.
          Nonetheless, commentators frequently deny that 2Cor 5:8 has applicability to the intermediate state
because they wrongly think that such an interpretation would necessitate believers striving/working during
the intermediate state to please God. Not so! Our works done while we are in the body are the works in
question (2Cor 5:10). These works follow with us: “And I heard a voice from heaven, saying, “Write, ‘Blessed
are the dead who die in the Lord from now on!’” “Yes,” says the Spirit, “that they may rest from their labors,
for their deeds are following with them” (Rev 14:13; TM). Although commentators offer various possibilities
as to what this verse could mean, a realized postmortem misthology is certainly a viable option.
          Walter Scott, Revelation, thinks that the verse means that it would be more blessed to die during the
tribulation than live to the end of it because if you live to the end of tribulation you will enter the millennial
kingdom as a ruler rather than a subject. This typical dispensational answer suffers from shallow
understanding of the type of salvation alluded to in a passage like Mk 13:13. Enduring until the end of the
tribulation is rewarded with more than mere survival. Ruling in the kingdom, not mere physical salvation,
is at stake. Furthermore, what about the souls of those believers slain before this point in time during the
tribulation but nevertheless are given white robes (Rev 6:9-11)? Are they not blessed? As a result, Boxall
rightly insists, “‘From now on’ must refer to the eschatological ‘now’, that is, from the time of the death and
resurrection of the Lamb. This Lamb is now identified as the Lord (11:8; 17:14; 19:16; 22:20, 21), who offers
rest to all his faithful dead” (emphasis his). Ian Boxall, Revelation, BNTC, s.v., Rev 14:13. In similar fashion,
Easley believes that from now on is better taken as referring to the point of time John is writing to his readers
(i.e., the NT era) rather than some future point in time during the tribulation. Kendell H. Easley, Revelation,
HNTC. Beale allows this as one possibility but adds another plausible alternative, which could be
supplementary: From now on “could merely express that it is at the moment of death when blessed rest begins
for believers. This idea is attested by 4 Ezra 7:92–99, which describes the reward of the righteous at death:
‘they will rest … they will understand the rest … from now on.’” G. K. Beale, Revelation, NIGTC, s.v.,
Rev 14:13. Apparently, John thought that these misthological blessings are happening even now, as a reward,
in the postmortem state, even before the righteous spirits in question reach their appointed eschatological
Bema! We must work now if we are to be found individually pleasing to God in the intermediate state, as
well as at the eschatological judgment at the Bema. A postmortem blessing, and therefore interim judgment,
seems to be implied. Greene is on the right track: “All believers who have died since the day of Pentecost
have gone to Paradise.” Oliver B. Greene, Revelation (Greenville, SC: Gospel Hour, 1963), 361. The only
thing that needs to be added to this general affirmation is the reward aspect. The faithful dead now, in the
NT era, go to the Heavenly City in heavenly Paradise. Now that the NT era has come, believers go to their
heavenly reward at the point of death. An exclusively eschatological Bema that must wait until the
eschatological judgment to see if we have been found misthologically pleasing to God is certainly called into
question by several passages (2Cor 5:9; Heb 12:23; Rev 6:11; 7:9-17; 14:13).
          Even 2Cor 5:10 might encourage an inaugurated death-then-judgment mentality. Postulating a
preliminary postmortem Bema is certainly more reasonable than the assumption by those commentators
who think that it is impossible to be found displeasing to God in the intermediate state. Paul’s affirmation of
judgment pertaining to believers in 2Cor 5:10 is derived from his argument in Rom 14:10-12, according to
which believers certainly will be judged by God because unbelievers and believers alike are going to be
judged by God. We know that unbelievers are subject to a preliminary postmortem judgment; nonetheless,
they will stand before the Great White Throne Judgment. An eschatological group judgment does not
preclude an intermediate judgment in their case. Yet if unbelievers are undergoing a preliminary judgment,
then we would expect that believers are also.
          Some will object because Paul does not elsewhere deal with intermediate misthology. Granted, that
may be the case, unless the Pauline authorship of Hebrews is entertained. Nonetheless, given the positive
Chapter 3. Biblical Experiences of Heaven                                                                   Page 123

                 Unconditional Anticipation (v. 8) + Conditional Ambition (v. 9)
       The logical implication is that Paul anticipates the pleasure of being with the Lord even if he is not pleasing

indications of preliminary postmortem judgment by the other biblical texts, I do not find this objection,
derived from Pauline silence, to be particularly convincing. Such commentators are reading into the text
when they say that Paul’s ambition in 2Cor 5:9 is simply to be pleasing at the Bema, that is, not until the
Parousia. Originally, I made that same mistake, but in light of Heb 12:23 and related passages, one must
question whether Paul really intended to limit the Bema in 2Cor 5:10 to an eschatological, post-resurrection
event in light of his home-absent context (2Cor 5:1-9). Could it be that 2Cor 5:10 allows the possibility of a
death-then-judgment misthology that is inaugurated at the point of death? Is not the focus of the context on
the believer being absent from the body but at home with the Lord during the interim period? This
proposition is certainly more reasonable than commentators who insist that it is impossible to be found
displeasing to God in the intermediate state. Admittedly, the Pauline focus regarding the salvation of a
believer’s spirit is principally eschatological, to be experienced at the future Bema (1Cor 5:5). Still, could not
the apostle, who already had been to Paradise, not anticipate a foretaste of misthological rest for righteous
spirits in Paradise during the intermediate state? Moreover, it must be remembered that Paul had a very
strong sense of imminence, affirming in this very epistle, no less, that “the time is short” (1Cor 7:29; KJV).
Compare 1Thess 4:15,17 where he uses we to refer to those believers who would be alive when Jesus returned,
though, by the same token, he uses us in 2Cor 4:14 and we in 2Cor 5:1, where he at least allows the possibility
that he might die before the rapture. At the time of such writings, Paul expected that the Lord most likely
would return within the lifetimes of those to whom he was writing. Given the OT emphasis of the kingdom
being set up on Earth and experienced by those in physical bodies and Jesus’ emphasis on imminence (which
would include the resurrection of physical bodies), it is little wonder that, by and large, the NT writers
focused on being ready for the Bema to be experienced by NT believers at the time of Jesus’ return rather
than on the possibility of postmortem reward dispensed during the intermediate state.
         Various interpretations for 2Cor 5:1-8 are posed by the commentators: (1) intermediate body during
the intermediate state, (2) New Jerusalem, and (3) resurrected body during the eternal state. I propose that
Paul purposefully is employing ambiguity to allow multiple viewpoints (in 2Cor 4:16-2Cor 5:10). The inner
man is being renewed during our temporal time in our earthly body and will not be unclothed during the
intermediate state. Rather, our inner man will be clothed with an eternal body (that is heavenly in origin and
does not die) during the intermediate state that will become a glorified body when enjoined with the physical
body at the resurrection. This soteriological glorification is unconditionally guaranteed (2Cor 4:14). At the
same time, the passage is concerned with an eternal weight of misthological glory (2Cor 4:17; 2Cor 5:10).
Soteriology and misthology are enjoined in the passage, as well as the intermediate and eternal state.
Additionally, even if Paul was not the author of Hebrews, he surely would have been familiar with the thought
behind Hebrews, particularly Heb 12:22-23, especially if Hebrews was written by either Barnabas or Apollos.
The Corinthians quite possibly would have had some familiarity with this perspective, given their fascination
with Apollos, for example. Likewise, Paul was probably familiar with the teaching behind Jn 14:1ff, a
teaching that was spoken to all the apostles and that certainly have been made known to Paul. Consequently,
postulating that the heavenly tabernacle, that is, New Jerusalem, whose builder is God (Heb 11:10), may be
part of the intended allusion to our heavenly dwelling is not out of the question: “For we know that if the
earthly tent which is our house is torn down, we have a building from God, a house not made with hands,
eternal in the heavens.” (2Cor 5:1). Christ “entered through the greater and more perfect tabernacle, not
made with hands, that is to say, not of this creation....For Christ did not enter a holy place made with hands,
a mere copy of the true one, but into heaven itself” (Heb 9:11,24). Indeed, given Paul’s possible dual, soteric-
mistholic desire to be clothed rather than naked, one might wonder if misthopological nakedness might be a
possibility, especially considering the possibility of misthological nakedness in Rev 16:15. Having an
intermediate body that is only clothed in soteriological glory (that is naked in terms of misthological glory)
would result in not being allowed to dwell in the Heavenly City and thus being unclothed misthopologically.
Page 124                                                                                  Misthological Models Part 4
A number of corollaries are naturally implied: (1) Even if they are not pleasing to the Lord, all the believers referred
to in v. 10 will be with the Lord at the time they become absent from their bodies. (2) The judgment of all these
believers apparently will take place at the Lord’s home. And (3) the outcome of the judgment determines whether
they are pleasing to the Lord, not whether they are present with the Lord—not even during the intermediate state.
Implicitly, their presence with the Lord during the intermediate state is affirmed to be unconditional.
       Indeed, Paul explicitly affirms that all believers will be raptured to be with the Lord: “For God has not destined
us for [tribulational] wrath, but for earning [millennial] salvation through our Lord Jesus Christ, who died for us,
that whether we are [morally] awake or asleep, we may live together with Him” (1Thess 5:9-10). Being with the
Lord via the rapture is not conditioned on earthly performance. This is a word of comfort and applies to all raptured
believers from the point of the rapture forward (1Thess 4:17-18). Even the judgment of believers by the Lord does
not dampen this promise. All believers, even those not found pleasing to the Lord, will be with the Lord after the
rapture, despite its attendant judgment. Taken together, these Thessalonian and Corinthian passages affirm that all
believers (good and bad) will be with the Lord before and after the rapture. To be absent from the body is to be at
home with the Lord. Also, to have a glorified body is to be at home with the Lord as well.
       Although the above argument has not been based on the passage in Acts regarding Stephen, his prayer does
exemplify the above interpretation derived from key Pauline passages. As specified in 1Thess 5:10, redemption is
the Pauline basis for this unconditional union with the Lord in the intermediate state. We will be with the Lord
because He died for us, not because we lived for Him. Stephen may very well link his being with the Lord to
redemption as well. Luke is the only one of the gospel writers who records Jesus’ appeal to the Father for the
forgiveness of those who were crucifying Him: “Father, forgive them; for they do not know what they are doing”
(Lk 23:34). Luke also uniquely records these closing words: “Jesus, crying out with a loud voice, said, “Father, into
Thy hands I commit My spirit.” And having said this, He breathed His last. (Lk 23:46). Surely in his Luke-Acts
composition, Luke intends for us to see the connection between Jesus’ dying statements and those of Stephen: “And
they went on stoning Stephen as he called upon the Lord and said, ‘Lord Jesus, receive my spirit!’ And falling on
his knees, he cried out with a loud voice, ‘Lord, do not hold this sin against them!’ And having said this, he fell
asleep” (Acts 7:59-60). Whereas Jesus committed His spirit into the Father’s care, Stephen (in a conceptually
parallel fashion) committed his spirit into Jesus’ care. Before the stoning started, Stephen saw Jesus standing at the
Father’s right hand (Acts 7:55-56). I dare suggest that Stephen had his eyes fixed on Jesus rather than on his
performance as his hope of being with Jesus. Like David, he had his eyes on his Redeemer: “Into Thy hand I commit
my spirit; Thou hast ransomed me, O Lord, God of truth” (Ps 31:5). Jesus quoted the first part of this verse as He
was providing the ransom price on the cross. Jesus committed His spirit into the Father’s care as He completed
redemption. David and Stephen were able to commit their spirits into the Lord’s care because of this redemption.262
       Although the conclusion that to be absent from the body is to be at home with the Lord is based primarily on
the evidence from the key passages such as 2Cor 5:8-9 and 1Thess 5:10, circumstantial evidence is collaborative.
Stephen is currently with the Lord, even before the rapture. As to the rapture, “God will bring with Him those who
have fallen asleep in Jesus” (1Thess 4:14). They will be brought with Him at the rapture because they are with Him
before the rapture. Those who have fallen asleep in the Lord already have preceded those who are yet to be raptured.
In other words, those who have fallen asleep are already with the Lord (1Thess 4:15). As to after the rapture, those
who will be waiting in their intermediate state for the results of the Bema are seen waiting in Heaven (Rev 6:9-11).
Granted, those who will be waiting with the Lord in that context are faithful believers who died during the
tribulation. Still, the reasonable presumption is that believers are not presumed guilty until proven innocent. Faust’s
assumption that unfaithful believers are kept in Hades as a holding cell (as a result of some preliminary judgment
awaiting their judgment at the Bema) is refuted by the evidence.
       Such was my argument in Darkness, but I now amend that argument with the following observation.
The Caulian-Crawfordian model being adopted in the present work allows a mediation between my earlier
treatment and that of Faust. My new model postulates that an intermediate form of the outer darkness is
now in effect as a result of a limited preliminary judgment. This intermediate outer darkness is probably
located on other planets in the outlying regions of the outer realm of the third heaven. Even Paul’s statement
in 2Cor 5:8-10 seems to lead to that anticipation, since Paul says that we currently “have as our ambition,

262
   As even acknowledged in my original model, my argument regarding Stephen was indecisive. He was,
