was, then he might have anticipated that Jesus was standing to honor him misthologically. In that case,
Stephen was anticipating a misthological welcome.
Chapter 3. Biblical Experiences of Heaven                                                                      Page 125
whether at home or absent, to be pleasing to Him.” To be pleasing to God right now, during the church age,
before the Bema takes place, even while we are absent from the body in a disembodied state, is Paul’s
misthological ambition. Why is it so important to be found pleasing to God even during this intermediate
period? Is it because we spend this intermediate period in Gehenna as Faust insists? No, I still maintain that
all believers will unconditionally be at home with the Lord as Paul affirms. (See my book, Destined for
Salvation, for further defense of this thesis.) Nevertheless, as Paul immediately explains, the reason we want
to be found pleasing to God even as disembodied spirits in the interim (v. 9) is because the Bema is coming
(v. 10). The preliminary misthological results being experienced in part now by the departed spirits of
believers are only anticipatory of the more intense results to be eternalized at the Bema.
       Returning now to my discussion in Darkness, I still affirm that none of those who have fallen asleep in
the Lord are in Hades waiting for the rapture. But my following statements are now open to objection: For
that matter, unfaithful believers are not cast into the outer darkness until after the wedding feast starts. Not even the
results of the Bema immediately go into effect. Unfaithful believers remain with the Lord in His city until such time
as His kingdom expands to encompass the earth. [I now hold this earlier assessment to be in error.] Then they
can be cast into the outer darkness. One reason the effects of the judgment are not carried out until this time is
because their presence with the Lord in His kingdom is guaranteed unconditionally. Until that kingdom expands
beyond the walls of the city, they are with Him in the city. [I erroneously limited the kingdom to the walls of this
city during the intermediate state.] After the kingdom expands beyond the walls of the city, it is no longer
necessary to keep unfaithful believers in the city in order to keep them within the kingdom. Instead, it is necessary
to expel them from the Reward City once kingdom rewards are realized because they have no part in the realization
of that reward. Nevertheless, they remain in the kingdom because merely being present in the kingdom is not a
reward.
       My earlier assessment was in error because I wrongly assumed that the third heaven would be limited
to the Heavenly City during the intermediate state. Further biblical analysis has demonstrated that my
original assumption was in grievous error. So I am taking out the red ink pin and correcting my error in the
present book. Nevertheless, my logic in TOD was correct: The expansion of the kingdom beyond the walls of
the city necessarily leads to the inference that unfaithful believers are outside of the city. The error I made
was in timing. I had not seriously entertained the possibility that the kingdom of Heaven was already larger
than the Heavenly City. Consequently, having now deduced that the heavenly realm presently encompasses
more territory than the confines of the city, consistency dictates that unfaithful believers be located outside
of the city even during the intermediate state.
       The corrections I am now making have secondary collaboration by the NDE data as well. While it is
true that the post-Bema outer darkness parabolically does not occur until after the wedding feast starts, it is
open to conjecture as to what was the state of the wedding participants before the feast started. Probably,
the guests who were appropriately clothed washed their garments and got their garments ready before the
feast started. The guest who was not ready when the feast started was not ready before the feast started.
Although it would be pressing the details of the parable too much to say that the parable proves that the
guests were standing in the outer courtyard in a misthologically clothed or unclothed disembodied state
before the feast started, such a possibility is certainly allowed by the parabolic data, indeed even encouraged
by it, and therefore may be postulated as part of the anticipated background imagery.
       In any event, the kingdom already has expanded beyond the walls of the city. In fact, it never was
confined to those walls. Surely, the kingdom of Heaven encompasses the entire outer realm of the third
heaven. Keeping unfaithful believers inside the Heavenly City never has been necessary to keep them in the
heavenly kingdom. The kingdom is much, much bigger than its capital city. Excluding the spirits of
unrighteous believers from the Reward City is already necessary, having become a necessity once the
realization of that misthopological reward was inaugurated at the beginning of the NT era (Heb 12:23).

      Tabernacle
       The writer of Hebrews has much to say about the heavenly tabernacle. He commences his discussion
of this tabernacle, in fact, by making his main point: “Now the main point in what has been said is this: we
have such a high priest, who has taken His seat at the right hand of the throne of the Majesty in the heavens,
a minister in the sanctuary, and in the true tabernacle, which the Lord pitched, not man” (Heb 8:1-2). Such
language is anticipatory of the Heavenly City: “For he was looking for the city which has foundations, whose
Page 126                                                                            Misthological Models Part 4
architect and builder is God” (Heb 11:10). “The greater and more perfect tabernacle, not made with hands,
that is to say, not of this creation” is the heavenly “holy place” (Heb 9:11-12). The most reasonable deduction
is that the heavenly tabernacle, at least the part where Jesus took His seat, was the Heavenly City.
Confirmation comes from Revelation: “And I saw the holy city, new Jerusalem, coming down out of heaven
from God, made ready as a bride adorned for her husband. And I heard a loud voice from the throne, saying,
‘Behold, the tabernacle of God is among men, and He shall dwell among them, and they shall be His people,
and God Himself shall be among them” (Rev 21:2-3). The OT tabernacle was a migratory place of worship.
Even in this aspect it severed as a picture of the heavenly tabernacle. The city moves from one location to
another. Thus, the earthly tabernacle was truly a “copy and shadow of the heavenly” one (Heb 8:5).
       The earthly tabernacle consisted of two parts: an inner tabernacle versus an outer tabernacle: “For
there was a tabernacle prepared, the outer one, in which were the lampstand and the table and the sacred
bread; this is called the holy place. And behind the second veil, there was a [inner] tabernacle which is called
the Holy of Holies” (Heb 9:2-3). I will postulate that the outer tabernacle represents the outer darkness (thus
Paradise in the broader sense); whereas, the inner tabernacle represents the specific part of Paradise known
as the Holy City. This theory would allow the migration of both the outer tabernacle and inner tabernacle.
The distinction between the two tabernacles, nevertheless, is the point of emphasis: “Now when these things
have been thus prepared, the priests are continually entering the outer tabernacle, performing the divine
worship, but into the second only the high priest enters, once a year, not without taking blood, which he
offers for himself and for the sins of the people committed in ignorance” (Heb 9:6-7). But what does this
distinction between the copies mean in terms of the corresponding metaphysical realities. The writer provides
this tantalizing clue: “The Holy Spirit is signifying this, that the way into the holy place has not yet been
disclosed, while the outer tabernacle is still standing” (Heb 9:8). My hypothesis is that access into the holy
place, that is, the Holy City, was not possible until the veil of the temple was torn when Jesus died: “And
behold, the veil of the temple was torn in two from top to bottom, and the earth shook; and the rocks were
split, and the tombs were opened; and many bodies of the saints who had fallen asleep were raised; and
coming out of the tombs after His resurrection they entered the holy city and appeared to many” (Mt 27:51-
53). Their entrance into the holy city after the veil was torn typologically pointed to the entrance of the
faithful into the Heavenly City to testify to the faithfulness of God regarding His promise regarding the
Reward City. As long as the separation between the outer and inner tabernacle was functionally intact, access
was limited to one person, the high priest. Jesus obliterated this limitation with His death. The separation
between the outer and inner tabernacles was functionally and dimensionally broken in that subterranean
Paradise was moved to its heavenly location. Yet that was not the ultimate objective; rather, the higher goal
was to move those in Paradise who qualified from the outer court to the inner court misthologically. Just as
these resurrected righteous saints entered the earthly holy city following the split, so Jesus took captivity
captive in order to take the disembodied spirits of the righteous into the heavenly Holy City.
       Presently, all believers living on Earth have remarkable access to the inner tabernacle via prayer:
“Since therefore, brethren, we have confidence to enter the holy place by the blood of Jesus, by a new and
living way which He inaugurated for us through the veil, that is, His flesh and since we have a great priest
over the house of God, let us draw near with a sincere heart in full assurance of faith, having our hearts
sprinkled clean from an evil conscience and our bodies washed with pure water” (Heb 10:19-22). However,
we must avail ourselves of this access during our earthly lives if we wish to continue to have access to this
inner tabernacle in the hereafter. Otherwise, we only will have access to the outer tabernacle—the outer
darkness—albeit now in the heavenly realm. God’s spreading “His tabernacle over them” is promised to
righteous believers who wash their robes and make them white. They are the ones who have access to the
“throne of God” in the afterlife (Rev 7:14-15). “His tabernacle” is “the tabernacle of God,” the Heavenly
City (Rev 21:2-3). Residency in this city, therefore, is limited to those believers who are clothed appropriately
in righteous works (Rev 19:7). The city is spread out like a bridal canopy over the bridal saints.
Chapter 3. Biblical Experiences of Heaven                                                             Page 127
        Illustration 11. City Migration from Intermediate State to Millennial Location to Eternal State
Page 128                                                                               Misthological Models Part 4

       The sequence of events, then, are amended as follows from what I had in TOD. All believers in the
intermediate state are currently with the Lord in His kingdom: OT as well as NT believers, good believers as
well as bad believers. Presently, the spirits of righteous believers are in the Heavenly City located on Planet
Paradise, presumably to the far north of Planet Earth, but the spirits of unfaithful believers are on
neighboring planets in the outer darkness of the heavenly realm, which is the outer realm of the multiverse.
At the rapture the Lord will bring all these believers with Him—both unfaithful and faithful believers—by bringing
the city to an orbit around Earth. (The city will be cloaked from view until the end of the tribulation.) During the
ten years of Earth time before the millennium starts (the latter seven of those ten years comprise tribulation), the
Bema judgment (of at least all church-age believers) will take place atop the Lord’s capital city. Those church-
age believers who are judged to be well pleasing to the Lord will hear the words, “Well done,” and enter into
permanent marital union with the Lord. Although all faithful believers will have the proper attire at this time, they
do not consummate the physical benefits of their rewards with the Lord until the marriage supper starts on Earth
during the millennial reign.
                         Illustration 12. Post-Bema Return Trip to the Outer Darkness




       Unfaithful and faithful believers alike will be summoned to the Bema atop the Heavenly City. During
the Bema proceedings, those believers who are disqualified from experiencing marital bliss with the Lord
will be cast out of the bridal city, probably to dwell in the outer realm of third heaven. If so, they will make
a return trip to the outer darkness in the outer rim of the heavenly realm, at least until the millennium starts.
       For hypothetical considerations, one may entertain the speculative possibility that they might be
brought from the heavenly outer realm to our physical dimension at the beginning of the millennial kingdom
and experience their exclusion within the confines of the physically expanding kingdom at that time. At least
Chapter 3. Biblical Experiences of Heaven                                                              Page 129
that is a possibility entertained in TOD. Otherwise, they simply would be left in the outer heavenly realm.263
Yet, if the postulation in TOD is correct and they are brought back to the physical realm to be cast into the
outer darkness in the physical realm after the millennial kingdom starts, they will perform menial service
for millennial inhabitants instead of ruling with Christ. At any rate, unfaithful believers will be excluded
from the city throughout eternity.

      Inaugurated Misthology
       Evidence of inaugurated misthology is evident in a variety of places: Jesus’ parables picturing
judgment going into effect at the time of the rapture before He sets up His kingdom on Earth (as Dillow
argues regarding Mt 25:14-30, for example), John’s description of disembodied tribulational believers
experiencing a degree of reward, Paul’s desire to be pleasing to the Lord even while in a disembodied state,
and the explicit and typological misthopology of Hebrews. Given the rather widespread affirmation of this
limited misthology being experienced in the intermediate state, suggesting that Peter is open to such a
possibility in his writings is not out of the question.
       To be sure, Peter has a strong apocalyptic flavor to his misthology (1Pet 1:7,13; 4:7,13; 5:1,4,6;
2Pet 1:11; 3:11-13). Notwithstanding, in a few places he might be understood as allowing a foretaste in the
intermediate state. For instance, when he says, “It is time for judgment to begin for the household of God”
(1Pet 4:17), it is tempting, in light of the above discussion, to think that he might be allowing the possibility
of a realized misthology in which faithful believers are already, at the point of death, experiencing a
preliminary judgment. Additionally, when he immediately follows up by using the present tense to assert, “It
is with difficulty that the righteous are being saved” (1Pet 4:18, not will be saved; TM), one might suppose a
realized misthological salvation. After all, he commenced his epistle by reminding his readers that they have
an inheritance currently “reserved in heaven” (1Pet 1:4). Would it not be natural to suppose that when they
get to Heaven, they get to experience some benefit from following Jesus’ injunction to lay up treasures for
themselves in Heaven? Why suppose that heavenly treasure cannot be experienced in Heaven before the full
realization of that treasure expands to include the Earth? Likewise, when Peter uses the present participle
to say that they are presently obtaining the salvation of their souls as the outcome of their misthological faith
(1Pet 1:9), why not allow an inaugurated enjoyment on the part of those believers who have departed? His
enigmatic context certainly makes one wonder if glories following suffering must await the far future for
believers when this was not the case for Christ (1Pet 1:10-12). Would not Christ’s leading captivity captive
be part of His glory? If the judgment of the physically dead is intended in 1Pet 4:5, then would not the gospel
preached to the dead in the next verse be a descent-into-Hades affirmation, as is commonly asserted (cp. 1Pet
3:19)? Consequently, would not living in the spirit (1Pet 4:6) refer to living in the Heavenly City in the
intermediate state?264 Would the injunction to “regard the patience of our Lord to be salvation; just as also

263
    Some kingdom teachers teach that entrance into the millennial kingdom is a reward. As a corollary, such
teachers necessarily teach some form of kingdom exclusion. Various possibilities for the latter are suggested:
They are excluded from (1) kingdom rulership, (2) New Jerusalem, or (3) the millennial kingdom itself. In
my book, The Outer Darkness (TOD), I argued for the first two options and rejected the third option.
However, in this Misthological Series, I pose a mediating position. If the millennial kingdom is defined
narrowly as being limited spatially to New Jerusalem and planet Earth, which is certainly the focal point of
the millennial perspective, then unfaithful believers could be regarded as excluded from the millennial
kingdom. The model favored in this series is to propose that they are confined to the outer realm of the
heavenly domain and not allowed into New Jerusalem or on Earth. If this model is adopted, one could argue
that they would live in the heavenly kingdom but do not enter the millennial kingdom. In that case, entrance
into the heavenly kingdom is a gift; entrance into the millennial kingdom is a reward. Since rewards are
eternal, unfaithful believers would be eternally confined to the outer realm (aka the outer darkness), never
being allowed to enter New Jerusalem or set foot on planet Earth after being excluded from these realms at
the Bema.

       Indeed, one is left to wonder if Paul’s use of the present tense in 1Cor 15:2 does not allow an
inaugurated realization: “You are being saved, if you hold fast” (ESV). That is, you are qualifying for a
reward that is being experienced even now by faithful believers who are dying and going on to their heavenly
reward. For such believers, dying is misthological gain even now during the intermediate state (cp. Phil 1:21).
Notwithstanding, Paul reveres the full misthological realization for the Bema. Even in the face of imminent
death, he looks beyond any reward experienced in the intermediate state to the eschatological reward
bestowed at the Bema: “Henceforth there is laid up for me the crown of righteousness, which the Lord, the
righteous judge, will award to me on that Day, and not only to me but also to all who have loved his
appearing” (ESV). Apparently, he will not receive this crown during the intermediate state, though it is
presently laid up for him in Heaven, but have to await until Judgment Day to be awarded this crown.
       Adopting this perspective allows us to put the pieces together in such a way so as to make sense out of
Lk 16:9: “And I say to you, make friends for yourselves by means of the wealth of unrighteousness, so that
when it fails, they will receive you into the eternal dwellings.” Money fails as soon as you die. For these reason,
commentators frequently see this as a postmortem experience (e.g., Constable, EGT, PC, and WBC). On the
other hand, other commentators, such as NIGTC, think that the reference to eternal (aionios) makes it
eschatological. Why not make it both by considering it an example of inaugurated misthology? Another
interesting detail that stumps commentators is that the reference to dwellings is skene, which actually means
tents? But the concept of eternal tents is paradoxical. Jesus purposely uses this odd expression to alert us to a
cryptic message. From Scripture, we do know of an eternal tent. The same Greek word is used in Rev 21:3
for God’s eternal tent: “Behold, the tent of God is among men” (TM). This passage describes the eternal state
in which New Jerusalem comes down out of Heaven. NIGTC was correct to suggest that the eternal dwellings
in Lk 16:9 refers to where God dwells. Another translation for skene is tabernacle. The OT tabernacle was a
place where the presence of God dealt and represented New Jerusalem. Various commentators suggest a
connection with the many mansions of Jn 14:3, naturally. Being given a warm welcome into Heaven by your
converts is also a common suggestion. I would only add that, although the text indicates that those giving the
warm welcome are those believers to whom you have ministered, the text does not specify that the eternal
dwellings into which you plural (ye in KJV) are welcomed are necessarily the dwellings of others. Your own
mansion might also be a possibility. NDErs report that loved ones who have gone on before are able to have
a part in preparing the heavenly mansions of their loved ones who have not yet reached Heaven. Therefore,
the loved ones involved in the preparation are able to welcome these new arrivals into both their own
mansions and the mansions they have prepared. All in all, Jesus’ statement is supportive of the hypothesis
herein that those to whom you show temporal mercy will be able to show you misthological mercy (Mt 5:7;
Jam 2:13) at your point of death by welcoming you into your own heavenly mansions as well as their own
heavenly mansions in the Heavenly City, assuming of course that they died before you and that you, as well
as they, are qualified for heavenly mansions.
       Contextually, Jesus proceeds to discuss poor Lazarus receiving a warm post-mortem welcome, being
transported by the angels to Abraham (Lk 16:19-31). This post-mortem location in a subterranean
compartment in Paradise was to be temporary, to be replaced shortly by an ascent into Heaven, when Jesus
would move captivity captive, which might be likened to folding up one’s tent and moving elsewhere. If Jesus
is anticipating this moving of the faithful from their temporary subterranean residence to their eternal
heavenly residence, then the imagery of eternal tents is well explained. The composite explanation for this
term eternal tents would seem to encompass all these considerations. Just as God’s tent was moved in the OT
and just as it typologically and mathematically pointed to the eternal dwelling located in the Eternal City, so
the temporary post-mortem location of the faithful was soon to move to this new location. Abraham did not
receive Lazarus into an eternal tent. Rather, the faithful residing within this temporary tent were taken to
their eternal location in the Heavenly Tent when Jesus led captivity captive.

saints. However, that objection is not valid. The word for preach in 4:5 is euaggelizo and refers to preaching
good news! The OT saints were given good news—they were being taken from Hades to Heaven! The verb
for proclamation in 1Pet 3:18 is kerusso. One should not confuse a negative proclamation with positive gospel
preaching.
Chapter 3. Biblical Experiences of Heaven                                                                   Page 131
      Conclusion
       After the layaway transaction was completed in the act of redemption, the Lord’s first order of business was
to take His ransomed people home. Thereafter, they always will be with Him at home in His kingdom. However,
His first order of business, after He physically expands His kingdom to include the millennial Earth, will be to cast
unfaithful believers into the outer expanse of His kingdom, whether it be in the physical realm or heavenly realm.
One can only wonder as to what His first order of business will be after His kingdom rule expands to other planets.
Will the exile of unfaithful believers become the outer expanse of His inhabited kingdom if they were allowed in
this physical universe?265 As the kingdom expands, will the distance they are exiled from the capital city increase
so that they inhabit the remotest parts of the physical universe? One can only wonder if they will wander from one
star system to the next in the eternally expanding outer fringes of the physical kingdom. Although I will not appeal
to Jude 1:13 to support this conclusion, what evidence we do have is suggestive that this indeed may be the case. In
that case, Jude 1:13 would apply correlatively to those wandering from star to star in the outer darkness. As Earth
becomes increasingly prime real estate in eternity future, why think that those cast into the outer darkness will have
their homes on this planet? In eternity future, their recollections of Earth may become increasingly distant yet
haunting memories.




265
   Alternatively, the anticipation of this new model is that unfaithful believers might be sent immediately
from the Bema to the outer realm of the heavenly realm to live on the planets of the outer darkness, which
would be the current abode of unfaithful believers during the intermediate state. The closest they ever get to
the Heavenly City is to appear before the Bema atop the city before being summarily dismissed, never to
return to this Reward City.

                                                  Introduction
      Those who discount the possibility of female angels either assert that (1) angels are genderless and simply
appear in the disguise of male and females for the sake of the mission at hand266 or (2) angels are all male, so any
alleged female angel is a phony.267
      I have counterposed with many reasons for believing that angels are genuinely male and female in my book,
Monogamous Sex in Heaven! Collaborating testimonies from NDErs have also been included in the present book.
The personal testimonies herein affirming winged angels or female angels have primarily been from NDErs. Such
testimonies of heavenly encounters with angels would be more valuable than personal encounters on Earth because
encounters of angels in Heaven would be more readily expected to perceive angels in their true state. Nevertheless,
if NDE testimonies of female angels in Heaven are valid, then one would expect that testimonies of those seeing
guardian angels on Earth would confirm this to be the case, and such is the case. This excursus will add further
collaborating testimony from those experiencing interactions with angels on Earth.
                                                   Billy Graham
        I thumbed back through a book on my bookshelves by Billy Graham, Angels: God’s Secret Agents. In the
opening pages, he posed that an angel may have appeared as a woman’s recently deceased daughter in order to
bring medical aid to the desperately ill mother (p. 14). This postulation is not enough to affirm the possibility of
genuinely female angels, however. If it was an angel, it may have assumed the guise of the deceased daughter.
Perhaps, the gender was merely part of the disguise for the mission at hand. Even if the child’s guardian angel had
assumed her identity to bring relief to her mother, this would not insure that the guardian angel was a female.268
Guardian angels do not necessarily have to be of the same gender as the one they are guarding. In any event, Graham
will go on to assert, on the supposed basis of Mt 22:30, that “angels are sexless” (p. 46). Thus, Graham would take
the first option above and assume that the female angel was not truly female in its true state. In terms of gender, an
angel is an it, per those taking this approach.

       As to Bob Jones, he rightly reasons that a counterfeit necessarily implies the reality of what is being

must be their true state. Accordingly, the same must be true of us (at least in our resurrected state) since in Heaven
we will be like angels.
                                                James Pruitt
      In his book on angels, Pruitt documents angels who appeared in times of war. He relates the well-known
account of the Angel at Mons:

             At that moment another guardsman looked up from his digging and noticed a warm glow just
      beyond their position. For a second he thought someone was wandering about with a lantern. He
      quickly alerted the others. Everyone stopped digging and watched the light. Someone said it could be
      a farmer searching for his lost barnyard stock. Another joked that it was possibly a ghost. “No matter
      what it is,” said the color sergeant, “wandering about a battlefield with a lantern is bloody suicide.”
             As the light drew closer, the guardsmen began to see the dim outline of a female figure. As it
      came closer, it became more distinct. Every last man of the guard stood stock-still and stared in awe
      at the sight. “My word!” gasped the veteran color sergeant, rubbing his eyes, then staring again at the
      approaching light.
             The figure looked remarkably like one of the many representations of angels they had seen
      numerous times in the regimental chapel: tall, slim, and wearing a flowing white gown. She had a gold
      band around her hair and sandals on her feet. A pair of white wings were folded against her slim back.
             “She’s beckoning to us,” muttered one of the guardsmen. There was no doubt about it, the angel
      was holding out her arm and with a motion of her hand was beckoning them to follow her. Not one
      member of the guard moved. She drew closer and her signal became more insistent. Anxious looks
      were exchanged among the Coldstreamers. What were they going to do?
             No one remembers who crawled out of their shallow battle position first, but one by one the
      Coldstreamers hauled out their weapons and equipment, lined up, and followed the glowing figure
      across an open field. Not a word was spoken by anyone. The angel moved on, her right hand still
      inviting them to follow until she came to a halt on the upper rim of a sunken road. The guardsmen
      were astonished. Earlier they had sent out patrols in all directions to locate a road or path exactly like
      the one on which they were now standing, but the patrols had reported finding nothing, not even a cow
      path.
             The color sergeant registered a blistering stare at a young guardsman whose patrol had been
      assigned to cover this very area earlier. The man was quick to defend himself, stating flatly that no
      such road had existed in the area only a few hours ago. True, one man could have possibly missed
      finding the road, but not all ten men of the patrol. The others agreed.
             Raising her hand again, the vision led the way until all the soldiers had reached the end of the
      sunken road, then she floated up the bank and pointed to a thicket of small trees only a short distance
Page 136                                                                                 Misthological Models Part 4
        away. She turned, faced the men of the Coldstream Guard, smiled a warm, pleasant smile at the amazed
        men—then vanished before their very eyes.
               Not questioning this strange visitation, the soldiers made their way to the thicket. Once there,
        they encountered two British sentries of a regimental forward observation post. They had found their
        main force. The sentries were equally excited to see the Coldstreamers. Headquarters had already
        written them off as destroyed in action, or, at the very least, as prisoners of the Germans.
               When the story of the angel of Mons reached the high command, they pored over every available
        map and questioned numerous local residents in an attempt to locate the sunken road identified in the
        Coldstreamers’ highly unusual report, but no such road could be found on any map, nor had any
        resident ever seen or heard of such a road in that area.
               The Coldstreamers, realizing that their honor was now in question, returned to the same area a
        few days later. In an effort to prove the existence of the road, they scrupulously searched the entire
        area. Starting at the site of the positions they had dug only a few nights before, the guardsmen fanned
        out in a search that covered nearly a mile in all directions. No road was ever found.
               Today, as then, no one can explain how the Coldstream Guard escaped certain annihilation that
        night at Mons, but they did. Some members of the present-day regiment often scoff at the legend of
        the Angel of Mons and argue that these were tired, battle-weary men whose minds were easily fooled
        by hallucinations. But yet these same guardsmen, only a few days later, went from Mons to an exposed
        position in another battle area and held their ground, unrelieved, against a vastly superior number of
        Germans for three weeks—hardly the actions of men suffering from hallucinations.
               To this day, no one can positively explain what happened that night to the Coldstream Guard.
        Nor has anyone ever found the sunken road that provided a path for an angel, and gave life to those
        whom she protected that night.272

      Pruitt treats this account as factual. Perhaps he is correct. You can easily find opinions to the otherwise if you
search on the internet. The legendary nature of this account prevents me from necessarily accepting its historical
credibility. Notwithstanding, given the logic of the proceeding argument, if the historical credibility of this story is
granted, then the genuineness of the gender of the female angel should be presumed.
                                                   Judith MacNutt
       Scripture teaches that angels guard those who trust in the Lord (Ps 34:7; 91:11). In her book documenting
accounts of guardian angels, MacNutt provides the testimonies of various people who claimed to have seen guardian
angels.273 Contrary to those who say that angels do not have wings, there are numerous accounts of angels with
wings in her accounts—some male, some female. Angels do not always have wings, but frequently they do. If the
testimonies of those who see angels with two wings are valid, then the objection by those who say that angels do
not have wings must be rejected. Some naysayers insist that since the male angels described in Scripture do not
have wings, angels do not have wings. Limiting one’s perspective to such artificial restrictions makes one very
shortsighted. The angelology of the Scripture is by no means exhaustive. Everything affirmed in the Scripture is
true. But not all truth is limited to the Scripture. The Bible does not state that male angels do not have wings. It
merely gives examples of cases where male angels do not necessarily have wings. If the testimonies of those seeing
guardian angels are to be believed, then we must conclude that some male angels, in their heavenly state, have
wings. But if we are to accept such testimonies regarding wings, then we should accept their testimonies regarding
gender. For present purposes, the testimonies that MacNutt provides regarding female angels are the ones cited in
the present excurses:

•     Jessica McClellan: “Out of nowhere, a girl my age swam up behind....I truly believe this was my guardian
      angel” (p. 44).

                                                     Conclusion
        The testimonies of those who have seen guardian angels confirm that the Lord’s angels appear in feminine
form: sometimes in an earthly form and thus obviously in disguise, sometimes in their heavenly form and thus
presumably without any guise. The conclusion that angels are sexless is groundless, strained beyond credibility by
the fact that these angels are assuming feminine form even in their heavenly form which would be presumably
guileless. That angels can shapeshift and assume different forms is readily apparent. But the postulation that they
shift their gender from neutral to masculine or feminine, depending on the circumstances of their assignment, sounds
more like a transgender agenda being foisted onto the data rather than a natural conclusion being read from the data.
The genuine femininity of female angels is herein accepted as the most straightforward analysis of the data and the
preferred conclusion via Occam’s Razor.

                                                     Introduction
       After I had finished the initial rough draft of this book, I went to a large book store in Tennessee with some
friends of mine during a Bible conference. I recently had shared a preliminary rough draft of this book with one of
these friends—Keith Call—and asked him if he knew of any other books that might advance my research. So, while
at the bookstore, he suggested that we look for some additional books on NDEs. He loaded me up with another
stack of books. I was still working on various other writing projects, so I would have time to read this stack while
working on those projects. I have added my interaction with some of those books here.
                                                   Eben Alexander
        Eben Alexander’s book relates his NDE. The nature of his experience and his neurological background and
analyses make it exceedingly difficult for skeptics to deny the metaphysical nature of his experience. The last words
he shouted before slipping into his comma and NDE were: “God, help me!”274 His neighbor and rector from the
Episcopal church had arrived quickly on the scene (p. 26). Alexander went to this church on Christmas and Easter
(p. 34). So one might assume that Alexander had a Christian experience. However, the theological nature of his
experience, or at least his assessment thereof, leads me to believe that he was misled by a metaphysical experience.
        Alexander initially finds himself in a primordial land of darkness in his metaphysical state. He was taken
from this land of darkness by a BOL in the form of a beautiful girl sitting on the wing of a butterfly who assured
him that he was loved and that there was nothing he could do wrong (pp. 40-41). This girl was an Orb of light who
helped him communicate with Om, which is his name for God because that was the sound he remembered
associating with the unconditionally loving creator God he experienced during his NDE (p. 47). This God had an
“inky-black core” but was also “brimming with light” (p. 48). Biblically, we can stop right here and conclude that
this is not the God of Christianity: “This is the message we have heard from Him and announce to you, that God is
light, and in Him there is no darkness at all” (1Jn 1:5). Rather, this Om god is better associated with Hinduism and
Buddhism.275 Alexander comes to a pantheism conclusion: “The universe has no beginning or end, and God is
entirely present in every particle of it’ (p. 156; cp. 160-161). I believe Alexander’s experience was in the astral
realm, and he mistakenly took it for Heaven because of the fallen angels of light who were masquerading as this
Orb and giving him false visions (pp. 102-104). He mistakenly thought this “holy darkness of the Core” was part
of heaven and the supposed divine Om (p. 71). The message of this BOL was:

      You are loved and cherished.
      You have nothing to fear.
      There is nothing you can do wrong (P. 71; emphasis his.)

        This anything-goes morality is false and asserts that we are part of the Divine and that nothing can separate
us from God (p. 76). Alexander should have been alert to the falsifiable nature of his experience since he
acknowledged that his NDE experience lacked the life review found in the NDE of many others (p. 77). But he
assumes, wrongly, that his experience falsifies their experience because he thinks that he died harder and traveled
deeper than they did (p. 78). Nonsense. First, his body was still functional on life support. Many NDErs do not have
an even partially functional body. Some NDErs die and are raised form the dead. Second, a friend of Alexander,
who was a channeler who “had written a book called Third Eye Open” (p. 87) claimed to communicate with him
psychically while he was in his comma state. This would mean he was in the astral plan, the second heaven, not the
third heaven. Third, after he came out of his comma he engaged in OBE techniques which he says, “Enabled me to
return to a realm similar to that which I visited deep in coma, but without having to be deathly ill” (p. 159). OBE
experiences, such as astral projection, only allows one to enter the astral plan, the second heaven, not the third
Heaven.
        Even though my assessment is that Alexander only made it into the astral plan and was deceived by the fallen
spirits he encountered therein, I am open to the possibility that the information related to him was not entirely false.

More likely, it was truth mixed with error:

              Through the Orb, Om told me that there is not one universe but many—in fact, more than I
       could conceive—but that love lay at the center of them all. Evil was present in all the other universes
       as well, but only in the tiniest trace amounts. Evil was necessary because without it free will was
       impossible, and without free will there could be no growth—no forward movement, no chance for us
       to become what God longed for us to be. Horrible and all-powerful as evil sometimes seemed to be in
       a world like ours, in the larger picture love was overwhelmingly dominant, and it would ultimately be
       triumphant.
              I saw the abundance of life throughout the countless universes; including some whose
       intelligence was advanced far beyond that of humanity. I saw that there are countless higher
       dimensions, but that the only way to know these dimensions is to enter and experience them directly.
       They cannot be known, or understood, from lower dimensional space. (P. 48; cp. 83.)

        On any other occasion I simply would have ignored this statement because of my initial inclinations to:
(1) distrust Alexander’s experience; (2) reject the notion that free will necessitates the ability to sin; (3) disbelieve
that trace evil is found in the other universes of the multiverse, and (4) doubt that life in some of these other universes
is more advanced than that of humanity. However, at about the same time I read this claim, I read (1) a defense of
God’s existence by MacGregor which postulates that creation necessitates evil and (2) some material by Heiser
arguing that extraterrestrial life need not be incompatible with Christianity. Even though I was skeptical of such
arguments when I first read them, the serendipitous timing of their convergence gave me pause to at least think
through the issues a little more deeply.
MacGregor
       As to MacGregor’s book, I reject the simplistic freewill defense (FWD) of the necessity of evil, which
postulates that God had to allow moral evil in order “to create creatures with libertarian freedom” (p. 260).
Libertarian freedom will still exist in the eternal state when moral evil is no longer possible. Therefore, I would
postulate that God naturally could have created a world which allowed libertarian freedom but made sin impossible.
However, I would also insist that such a world is not the type of world He morally should have created—initially.
Rather, God created the type of world He did, with an optimal balance of good and evil (OBGE), because for the
purposes He had in mind for humanity such a world in this universe is better than a world without any moral evil.276
For starters, creating a world in which moral evil eventually would occur and be allowed for a short duration allows
those who trust God to love Him more and understand Him better, thereby enriching their souls (cp. Jam 1:2-4;
1Pet 1:4-9). This soul-making-theodicy (SMT) argument might be called a qualified-end-justifies-the-means
(QEJTM). It is an argument for the greater good (GG), which is my explanation for the problem of evil at the macro
and micro level. See my book MSIH for further discussion. Opting, then, for an OBGE and QEJTM/GG, I can
concur with MacGregor that “a world with less gratuitous evil than the actual world is not feasible for God to create”
(p. 260). And I agree completely when he concludes that the reason “God responds to evil when he does” is “in
order to bring about the greatest good of maximal human salvation” (p. 265). MacGregor too uses a GG model.
Maximal salvation entails much more than just being sinless and spared from any moral evil.
       But the part of MacGregor’s thesis that pertains more directly to the present study is his postulation that
creation necessitates natural evil. He defines “perfection as completeness or wholeness in each and every respect”
(p. 261). He then postulates that only God is perfect in this sense. Such “perfection is an essential attribute of God”
(p. 261). “It is intrinsically impossible for God to crate anything that is intrinsically perfect” (p. 261). “As we saw
in our discussion of natural evil, we may hold that various defects are ontologically necessary to the creation, as
perfection is an incommunicable attribute of God” (p. 266). MacGregor’s definition and argumentation might be
acceptable. But an alternate definition of perfection might accomplish the same objective more definitively. If we
simply define perfection as the lack of unwitting error, then I would more readily agree with MacGregor’s
apologetic. Even in Heaven we can make mistakes because we are not God. Making a mistake need not be equated

altogether.

with sin (i.e., moral evil). God does not make accidental mistakes, but we do because we are finite creatures.277
        Now to integrate MacGregor’s discussion with that of Alexander, we may further deduce that natural evil
will exist even in the eternal state. God cannot create or cause moral evil, but He can create natural evil (Is 45:7)
and misthological evil (Zech 8:14). Surely, if He can create evil, He can allow it. Could Adam trip, fall, and stump
his toe physically before he fell morally? Of course. This natural fall, resulting in the natural evil of a hurt toe,
would be possible before his moral fall, resulting in spiritual death. Adam could accidently do evil to his toe even
in his sinless state before he did evil to his spirit. Likewise, even in the eternal state, the leaves of the Tree of Life
will be used for the physical healing of the nations (Rev 22:2), thereby indicating the continued but limited existence
of natural evil. Misthological and natural evil will still exist in the heavenly kingdom. Therefore, we may deduce
that trace levels of natural evil are found in the other universes of the multiverse. If this is what the entities meant
to communicate to Alexander, then their communication is truthful to that extent.
Heiser
       Among other things, in his fictional series, Heiser entertains the possibility of intelligent extraterrestrial
(ETI) life on other planets.278 I was not impressed by many of Heiser’s arguments in this second volume, such as
his freewill argument against eternal security (p. 282). I have refuted such arguments against eternal security
repeatedly in my writings. (See MCMC.) I reject his rejection of the rapture (pp. 383-384). (See DFS.) Nevertheless,
some of his arguments for ETs from the first volume of this fictional series were of particular interest:

              “There are three more substantive obstacles to getting those who share this worldview on board
      with an ET reality. The first is the idea that if ET is real, and he is a sentient being capable of religious
      interests, then Jesus would have to go to his planet, die, and rise again so ET could be redeemed.”
              ....This view forgets that, in Christian theology, the only reason humans need atonement for
      their sins is because they are morally guilty before God as a result of Adam’s fall. The New Testament
      teaches that Adam’s guilt was transferred to all humans, and therein lies the loophole. ET, as a
      nonhuman, isn’t in need of forgiveness since he wasn’t the species punished by the fall. He’d suffer
      the effects of the fall, like the rest of creation according to the New Testament, but he wouldn’t need
      personal forgiveness.
              “ET would benefit from the atonement in a general way. That is, he’d either be part of the new
      heaven and new earth that Christianity teaches will appear some day when Christ returns, or he’d be
      completely peripheral. And ET having religious interests doesn’t undermine my argument, since the
      Bible teaches angels have that and are not included in the atonement. The objection is completely
      baseless, but it’s very common.”
              ....“What’s number two?” “I’ll call it the ‘image of God objection.’ In a nutshell, the book of
      Genesis teaches that when God created humans, He created them ‘in His image.’ According to biblical
      theology, the image is that which makes humanity unique among all created things. It’s clear that this
      can’t be physical appearance because the Bible elsewhere teaches that God is spirit and genderless.”
               “So what does the Church teach on this?”
              “Theologians of Judaism and Christianity have taught for centuries that the image of God refers
      to things like intelligence, consciousness, communication capability, morals, the ability to commune
      with God, and the like. If any of those or some combination are correct, then an ET that had the same
      abilities would prove the Bible is wrong on this point and that humans aren’t the apple of God’s eye,
      so to speak. You only need to remember how the Church reacted to Galileo when he proved the earth
      wasn’t the center of the solar system—that it wasn’t anything special. This objection fears the same
      thing would happen with humanity—we’d be nothing unique.”

    God can make purposeful mistakes, not accidental mistakes. See MMP2. For Jesus to experience surprise during

expected for people to react one way when they reacted contrary to His expectations. Thus, He could marvel at
great faith (Mt 8:10; Lk 7:9). But in His preincarnate state He purposefully chose to submit Himself to making such
mistakes in His incarnate state. See POV for limited acceptance of the open view perspective.

      life. The two are mutually exclusive concepts. The result is that Jews and Christians alike who take
      their faith seriously have no reason to be alarmed should intelligent extraterrestrial life ever become
      part of our worldview.”279

       The argument is not as simple as Heiser surmises in this fictional account. For starters, the problem of sin is
not only imputational but ontological. As a result of Adam’s fall, the rest of creation was affected. Thorns would
grow; death would ensue. Animals would not only kill one another but also eventually kill humans. Even worse,
humans would kill humans. Animals could not be held morally accountable, of course. But because humans are
moral creatures created in the image of God, they are morally accountable. To kill a fellow human is to kill God in
effigy because humans are created in the image of God. Therefore, if Adam’s fall had an impact on the rest of this
universe so that ETs in this universe underwent an ontological change so that they sinned morally as a result, killing
one another for example, then these ETs would also need an atonement, contrary to Heiser. (For one ETs to murder
another ET would be to kill God in effigy because ETs are created in the image of God also.) Nevertheless, if
Adam’s fall only affected our universe, then ETs in other universes would not have been affected. Therefore, the
atonement objection need not apply to ETs in other universes. Allowing the possibilities of ETs in other universes
is thus not difficult.280
279
    Michael S. Heiser, The Facade Saga: The Facade, vol. 1, Kindle Edition (Bellingham, WA: Kirkdale Press,
2014), 123-126. For his scholastic chapter devoted to this topic see, Michael Heiser, “Chapter 10: Panspermia: What
It Is and Why It Matter,” in How to Overcome the Most Frightening Issues You Will Face This Century, Kindle
Edition (Defender Publishing), KL 3707. Even though he accommodates the possibility of directed panspermia
through theistic evolution, while my support for creationism disinclines me to do so, I would acknowledge that I do
not find the anthropic principle used to defend creationism to be particularly persuasive against all forms of
intelligent design. Heiser would say that if panspermia turns out to be true, then it “indicates more design to the
universe” (KL3968). What he allows as a theoretical possibility, however, I would find to be a theological
probability. God created the universe to be inhabited by humanity, so, in fact, He designed it to be even more
anthropically friendly than typically posed by creationists. Expanding the anthropic principle does not require that
one abandon a creationist position. Still, the directed panspermia postulation does require that one suppose that God
created ETs elsewhere or used ETs or angels to spread life to Earth. Alternately, I hold that our universe and the
multiverse is more anthropic than thought by many creationists because I believe God created our universe and the
multiverse to be inhabited by man—eventually. The mathematical improbability of the chance occurrence of
another planet in our universe that would support life is readily affirmed but is offset in my model by the fact that
God, not chance, created such planets in our universe for man to eventually inhabit and rule. The presence of such
planets, mathematically, rules out the possibility that they are explainable by chance but rather point to a Creator.

    Gilbert and Peck follow Heiser in asserting that since Adam’s moral guilt is not imputed to ETs, they do not
need atonement (pp. 179-186). Gilbert and Peck’s premise is true; their conclusion does not follow, however. They
fail to consider the possibility that ETs could be moral creatures and therefore be morally susceptible to sin and
thereby potentially in need of atonement. Also, Gilbert and Peck fail to address the possibility that Adams’s sin
could have had a negative moral impact on ETs in our universe. Granted, “the Earth and animals are not guilty in
the moral sense” (p. 183). Yet this is because animals are not moral creature, not merely because animals are not
created in the image of God. Gilbert and Peck correctly follow Heiser in asserting that the divine council and humans
are both created in the image of God. This acknowledgement practically destroys their argument that ETs could not
be created in the image of God also. Since the image-of-God status is, per their own acknowledgment, not limited
to humans, their assumption that ETs cannot be God’s image bearers on their own respective planets is suspect.
More consistently, we may pose that the special status conferred upon humans is not simply that they are created in
Excursus on Miscellaneous Books About Heaven                                                                   Page 143
       As to the image-of-God objection, I have expressed reservations regarding Heiser’s limiting the image of
God to function and concluded: “The status of being created in the image of God presupposes the ability to function
in a manner compatible with that status—as a species” (MSIH, 48). Corresponding abilities are necessary. Even so,
this poses no problem to my ET hypothesis in that ETs may be assumed to have similar abilities as God’s image
bearers on their respective planets, thereby allowing them to function in the same capacities in their worlds. Angels
are created in the image of God. Humans are created in the image of God. ETs may be created in the image of God
also. Moreover, like angels, these ETs may be more advanced than we are. If these ETs are unfallen, then surely

the image of God or even that they were put in charge of part of God’s creation (angels are also); rather, what make
humans unique among God’s image bearers is that: (1) Christ became human and made atonement directly
applicable to humans, and (2) humans have been given the unique royal potential of co-glorification with Christ
and thus the possibility of rulership over all of God’s creation. Further, we may postulate that if ETs are moral
creatures (thus having an eternal soul and spirit, as accountable beings before God) and if they have fallen morally,
they would need redemption through Christ’s blood also. If this is the case, then either Christ’s death for humans
would have to avail for fallen ETs indirectly (which seems unlikely) or Christ would have to die for these fallen
ETs directly (which seems highly unlikely). “Christ died for sins once for all” (1Pet 3:18). “One sacrifice for sins
for all time” (Heb 10:12). But these statements are contextually meant to apply to humans. Therefore, the most
reasonable deduction is that if genuine God-created physical ETs exist on other terrestrial planets in other universes,
they are unfallen and thus not native to Earth’s universe. They are not native to our cosmos. If these ETs from
another cosmos visit our cosmos, then they do so as ECs (extracosmologicals). If these unfallen ECs visit Earth’s
universe, then I would pose that they do so without becoming contaminated by sin, much like holy angels are able
to minister in our universe without subcoming to sin. Such ETs would not be native to our universe, and they would
not mate with us, for to do so would be sin. (Note, EDs are not terrestrial or physical and thus not to be confused
with ECs.)
       Granted, my restricting the direct benefits of the atonement to humans is due in part to my preference for
monogenism. In my view, the atonement of Christ only applies directly to the original Adam and Eve and their
descendants. Christ died for them, not for other image-of-God beings, such as angels (Heb 2:14-18). Gilbert and
Peck evidence a bias in in favor of polygenesis by linking monogenesis with Serpent Seed Theory, hyperliteralism,
and geocentricism (pp. 201-204). Such associations are unnecessary and reflect Gilbert and Peck’s theological
prejudice. The atonement is most readily understood as being for Adam and Eve and their descendants (Rom 5:12-
21). The polygenistic postulation that humanity came from multiple sources poses problems for the most
straightforward understanding of the atonement. For Christian polygenists, however, who imagine that the
atonement could apply directly to humans who are not descendants of an original Adam and Eve, one can anticipate
that such polygenists would have little difficulty posing that the atonement could apply to ETs who are not
descendants of Adam and Eve. Derek P. Gilbert and Josh Peck, The Day the Earth Stands Still: Unmasking the Old
Gods behind ETs, UFOs, & the Official Disclosure Movement (Crane, MO: Defender, 2017).
       When convenient, Peck writes as a literalist, that is, as a monogenist: “Entropy entered the world when Adam
fell from grace. The fall of mankind brought something into the world that didn’t exist before: death and decay.”
Josh Peck, Unraveling the Multiverse: The Christian’s Guide to Quantum Physics, Entities from Higher Realities,
Strange Technologies, and Ancient Prophecies Being Fulfilled Today (USA: Defender Publishing, 2017), 42. If
there was more than one original pair of humans (so polygenism), then what happened when the first pair of humans
sinned. Did death, decay, and entropy spread to the other pairs of humans who had not sinned? Apparently so, since
the world was affected. Did these humans become subject to death, decay, and entropy even though they had not
yet sinned? Again, it would seem so, if polygenism is correct. These humans became subject to death even though
they had not sinned! The doctrine of original sin poses well-known problems for polygenism. Monogenism is
superior in posing that there was an original pair of humans who sinned, thereby plunging the entire human race,
via their descendants, into sin and the need for redemption. Moreover, this death, decay, and entropy would probably
not be limited to this world. Would it not also spread like shockwaves throughout this whole universe? Thus, if you
had sinless ETs on another world in Earth’s universe, would they not become subject to death even though they had
not sinned? Again, apparently so, just like supposed polygenistic humans on Earth. These morally sinless ETs in
our universe would be become subject to death just like allegedly sinless humans elsewhere on Earth would have
become subject to death when the first pair of earthlings to sin became subject to death, which clashes with biblical
teaching that death is the result of sin (Rom 5:12; 6:23). Biblical Christianity is at odds with the notion of either (1)
polygenism or (2) native ETs in the present universe.

    Gary Bates challenges Heiser’s assessment that God could have created ETs. Among Bates various objections
his most substantial one is derived from the atonement: “Christ’s atoning death at Calvary cannot save these
hypothetical ETs, because one needs to be a physical descendant of Adam for Christ to be our ‘kinsman-redeemer’
(Isaiah 59:20).” See Gary Bates, “Did God create life on other planets?” Available at https://creation.com/did-god-
create-life-on-other-planets. Accessed 1/14/2018. Bates also has a very good book dealing with UFOs and
abductions, which refutes Heiser in its appendix. Gary Bates, Alien Intrusion, Kindle Edition (Powder Springs, GA:
Creation Book Publishers, 2004). My assessment is somewhat of a mediation between Bates and Heiser. Unlike
Bates who rejects the multiverse cosmology, my mediation poses that the universal curse following Adam’s fall
was limited to the universe in which Adam’s fall occurred. Thus, the groaning of the “whole creation” is only
referring to the creation pertaining to this universe (Rom 8:18-22). The whole multiverse would not be subject to
corruption or to angels, but the whole multiverse would be subject to the subjugation of Christ and His glorified
human co-heirs (Heb 2:5-8). To answer Bates’ bridal objection, I pose that Christ’s Bride will be selected from
God’s human image bearers on Earth who have overcome in the face of their conflict with sin and Satan. ECs from
other universes would be ruled over by these bridal saints. ECs would not be part of the bride. As pointed out by
Peck and Woodward, “The inner connection between humanity and the LORD above is something special that
people possess. It is quite possible that this is another factor that distinguishes human beings from the angels”
(Reality, KL 1365-1367). In other words, even if ECs have spirits, the Holy Spirit may not join Himself to their
spirits as He does to the human spirit (1Cor 6:17). After all, angels are spirits (Heb 1:14), but He does not join
Excursus on Miscellaneous Books About Heaven                                                                 Page 145

over the multiverse and any ECs therein.

Himself to them (Heb 2:16). Nevertheless, even if other ECs can have a soteriological union with Christ at the
spiritual level, this would not be sufficient for them to have misthological union with Him. The Bride of Christ is
composed of those who overcome evil. Only by overcoming evil can redeemed humanity undergo the character
transformation and maturation necessary to become Christ’s Bride and misthological partakers of the divine nature
(2Pet 1:4-8). See MMP2 and MMP3.
        Although I am in substantial agreement with Bates regarding ETs, I disagree regarding ECs. I am much more
open to the multiverse theory than Bates. See Gary Bates, “Multiverse theory—unknown science or illogical raison
d’être?” Available at https://creation.com/multiverse-theory. Accessed 1/14/2017. For reasons explained in TOD, I
deduce that humanity will spread throughout the galaxies. Moreover, as deduced in the present series, this infinite
growth of the human population cannot be limited to our finite universe but must extend into other universes.
Therefore, intergalactical and interdimensional space travel and communication must be possible. Indeed,
theologically, we may deduce that they already are occurring. Paul was caught up to the third Heaven, thereby
experiencing interdimensional travel at faster-than-light (FTL) speeds. Philip found himself transported, evidently
interdimensionally, from one spot to another in our physical reality, even while he was in his physical body (Acts
8:39-40). Such supernatural means of travel might just be a technologically advanced means of travel. We are likely
on the cusp of FTL communication with quantum entanglement, scalar waves, and torsion fields. Zero-point energy
(i.e., Vacuum Energy) is probably already being used secretly. See Revising Reality. Joseph P. Farrell, Covert Wars
and Breakaway Civilizations: The Secret Space Program, Celestial Psyops and Hidden Conflicts (Kempton, IL:
Adventures Unlimited Press, 2012).
        Indeed, some believe that the forbidden technology shared with humanity by fallen angels before the flood
vastly surpasses our current technology. (Noah, of course, would not have used these forbidden technologies to
create the ark.) If so, it may be that some of the genetically modified humans escaped the destruction of the flood
by fleeing to other planets outside our solar system. (Any habitations they had in our solar system, such as on Mars
or Astra/Krypton/Rahab, would have been destroyed or exploded respectively (Flynn, 446). I am modifying Flynn’s
timeline. See The David Flynn Collection. The arguments are basically the same for post-Adam Noahic ET diaspora
and pre-Adamic race destruction-dispersion.) If that is the case, panspermia may have worked in the reverse as to
what is typically thought to have happened. Instead of ETs from other planets bringing life to this planet, Nephilim
from this planet may have been the ETs spreading humanoid life to other planets. As Nephilim, they would not be
fully human and not redeemable. The destruction associated with the flood may not have been limited to this planet
but wiped out their colonies on other planets in this solar system. A slight modification of Farrell’s thesis in War
would easily allow for such a possibility. The destruction of now missing watery fourth planet could have been part
of the means resulting in our flood. The only Nephilim who would have escaped would be those who fled beyond
the realm of our solar system. To avoid God completing their destruction through angelic warships, they may not
be too eager to return or communicate with us. Joseph P Farrell, The Cosmic War: Interplanetary Warfare, Modern
Physics, and Ancient Texts. Adventures Unlimited Press (Kempton, IL: Adventures Unlimited Press, 2007).
283
    For the sake of Christian science fiction, I will pose a completely theoretical option. When God broke up
humanity at the Tower of Babel, He could have had His angels take couples from this planet to galaxies throughout
our universe to act as derivative Adam-and-Eve propagators in a panspermia dispersion of humanity. Their human
dependents would be more scientifically advanced than we are on Earth because humanity on each of those planets
would be unified through a common language. Through prophets that God would rise up on their planets, they could
have been kept apprised of what happened here on the Eden Planet and of the atonement made available for them
here. The death of Christ on the Eden Planet, namely Earth, would thus avail for them also, and they would hear of
it through their prophets. Christ need not die on their planets because His death on our planet was for the whole
human race (for all the descendants of the original Adam and Eve) and thus would apply to them also. Thus, the
whole of creation groans from the fallen humanity dispersed throughout our universe.
        Do I believe God did this? No! But I pose it because it opens discussion for an alternate nefarious possibility
which is more realistic. One might pose that the fallen angels took Nephilim from Earth before the flood to populate
other planets. Some pose something similar for underground bunkers. After all, one of the popular explanations for
the post-flood Nephilim among various Christian writers is that some of Nephilim survived the flood. Whereas
some Christian writers typically pose that some Nephilim survived on a remote part of Earth or in subterranean
parts of Earth, I am allowing the possibility that some of them might have survived off planet. Similarly, speaking
of Greys, Peck states, “I believe there are beings composed of three spatial dimensions that are truly alien; for

Paradise. However, since he says it is like another planet rather than is another planet, it would seem to be more

value of his testimony is limited because his view of Paradise was blocked until he landed there.

may have transported human couples off-planet to populate other worlds. But if fallen EDs are manufacturing
biological robots off-planet, as Peck believers, what is to prevent us from thinking that fallen EDs may have
abducted humans and taken them off-planet to reproduce and thus produce a ET slave force on other planets or to
interbreed with Nordics (first-generational blonds, KL 1729)? After all, concerning UFO abductions Schnoebelen
says, “Far too many reports were coming back of people NOT being returned” (KL 1249-1250; emphasis his). And
as for slave labor force, “Many of them claim to have been used (against their will) as slave labor in these
extraterrestrial labor camps” (KL 1338-1339). The smart thing for fallen EDs to do would be to use the slave labors
to breed slave labors off-world. Better yet, for their purposes, change the human DNA of these human breeders so
that their offspring would not be redeemable. As to the atonement, I would modify Schnoebelen belief that Jesus’
death can be applied to anyone (ETs included) as long as they believe (KL 1505) by pointing out that the infinite
value of Jesus’ blood is given limited application, namely, it only washes away the moral guilt of Adam and Eve
and their human descendants. One has to be human enough to believe in Jesus for eternal life for His blood to be
applicable. William J. Schnoebelen, Space Invaders, Kindle Edition, (USA: Xlibris Corporation, 2003). If fallen
EDs and their manufactured ETs are taking human abductees off-planet now for interbreeding and slave labor,
which is reported to be the case, then we would conclude, per Jesus, that the EDs were doing the same thing in the
days of Noah (Mt 24:37). Because of interbreeding, the offspring of abductees may not be sufficiently human to be
redeemable.

        Trenholm is a missionary who relates an experience he had of Heaven, but he is not sure if it was real or just
a dream.287 The publisher added a forward in which a reviewer claimed: “Many folks, as far as I can tell, didn’t
fully appreciate that this was an actual experience the author had, not an inspired fictitious story” (KL 10-11).
However, the page after the forward classifies it as “FICTION/Christian/Fantasy” (emphasis theirs). Yet, in the
author’s preface to the book, he explains at length that it is an “account of what actually happened,” though at the
end of the book he is not entirely sure but what it might have been a dream. He attests, “This reality was beyond
anything I could ever have dreamed! Or was this a dream? I didn’t know” (KL 218-219). Some people might call
this a night vision. At any rate, the missionary is relating his experience as conveying plausible information about
Heaven; therefore, at the very least, his book provides his opinion of Heaven. Whether the data provided is in a
factual or fictional format is open to discussion. I will tend to take is as factual unless the evidence requires me to
take it as fictional.
Flat Planet
       Trenholm arrives at a great city named Tricon, in a great plain in a land named Ekron. He meets a boy named
Jamal, who appears to be about 12 years old. Tricon is an outpost city on a planet in the third heaven. Jamal is really
very old but has retained this youthful appearance, even though he died thousands of years earlier. Trenholm
himself, though an old man, takes the form of a boy the same age as Jamal in Heaven. Other NDErs have confirmed
that people in Heaven can vary their apparent age to whatever they desire for the occasion, so these age-related
matters are within the realm of possibility. The presence of many cities in the third heaven is confirmed by other
NDErs. The proposition that these cities are dispersed on planets throughout Paradise has been postulated in the
present study. Additionally, Trenholm’s description of the planet as flat is affirmed by others. Illustration 13 is an
extraction of the land of Paradise Planet previously provided, in Illustration 7, which was drawn to scale with the
estimations given by Gaulden. Such details may be taken as factual.
